IncidentDescription: Bear broke wall at Housekeeping and knocked over 1 trash can. The hole in the wall was about 3 ft. by 2ft.

Resident Katie Hopkins was taking a shower when she heard loud noises coming from outside. When she exited the shower she heard ripping of canvas and shined her small light at it. A very large dark colored bear snapped its jaws and did a short bluff charge towards her. She ran back into the bathroom and the bear left. The bear ripped into two unoccupied tent cabins. House #12 had food trash strewn about inside and out with minor damage to the door. #14 had the lower wooden portion totally ripped out and the canvas ripped with recycling and bird seed inside the cabin. The bear also obtained a significant amount of food trash from an unsecured trash can left outside that had been used primarily for construction trash. I was unable to locate the bear on telemetry.
Bear broke into unoccupied tent cabin #503 in Curry Village. Damage to front door and canvas on right front corner. Mike Siler took original report.
Bear was seen attempting to enter two bear boxes, one used as linen storage and the other as food storage. No food was obtained but the bear box was tampered with and damaged.
Second hand report from Facebook post that climbers were on route and saw a bear take their backpack so they climbed down and chased the bear away. The bear got some food.

Valentine heard a bear knocking over a trash can near the Curry pavilion. As he approached the trash can he heard more crashing near cabin 18A. Valentine saw the bear standing over two large bear proof lockers that it had knocked off of their 4x4 pedestals. The bear tore the bottom off of one of the lockers accessing the trash inside. It knocked a glass fire extinguisher holder off of the building and broke it. Valentine chased the bear away. Photo available - call V31.
Small window in left rear cab of truck broken and a medical backpack was removed. Food wrappers were carried away. Unable to find victim.
Car seats in vehicle. Trim over the windows on both sides of the vehicle was damaged.

Food was in a bear box that was left open. People were in campsite within 4 ft. of bear box. When the bear came into the site the people ran away in fear. Bear box was closed but not locked and the bear obtained food.

Bear entered Ranger Club through side door near kitchen. Bear ate 2 chocolate cakes, 1 box chocolate, 1 pint blueberries, 1 bag chips, 1 bag onion, 1 pack spinach, and 1 dozen eggs. Bear opened refrigerator. Resident came downstairs, saw bear and ran upstairs to call 911. Another resident came through kitchen, saw bear, yelled and scared it back outside. Door was not latched.
Bear tore screen on door. Was unable to get access to building. DNC Security had followed bear from the Lost Arrow Dorms where it had gotten into some trash.
Attempted entry at residence - rear screen damage with small puncture tear.
Convertible top ripped open and interior damage.
Attempted entry at garage door. Bent door but did not enter. No food present.

Residents Paul Doherty and Stephanie Hance awoke to the sound of a bear climbing through their laundry room door. They yelled at the bear but were afraid to open the door. The bear ran back out the way it came in before they got a look at it. I responded and upon spotlighting the house across the street found a large dark brown bear with a green tag in its left ear on the side of the house peering through a window. Once spotlighted, the bear ran around the west side of the apartments and across the road towards the cemetery. The bear was not collared and I was picking up bear #3001 a long distance off. The bear entered the house by pulling the upper window off the door and peeling back the lower window to get in. No food was present or obtained, just laundry odors.

Bear entered through flimsy wooden front doors, became trapped in the office and exited by breaking a window. While inside, it got into the refrigerator and obtained creamer, crystal light, probiotics, and horse de-wormer. There were also Schedule 1 drugs in the refrigerator (Lydocaine).

Bear entered through flimsy wooden front doors, became trapped in the office and exited by breaking a window. While inside, it got into the refrigerator and obtained creamer, crystal light, probiotics, and horse de-wormer. There were also Schedule 1 drugs in the refrigerator (Lydocaine).

Nurse Scott Barlow reported a disturbance at the back of the clinic. He saw a bear attempting to gain entry to the rear doors and called dispatch. We responded from lower housing to find a large brown bear with green tag in left ear exiting the rear clinic doors with food in its mouth. I chased the bear towards Church Bowl and the bear dropped the ice packs and food. It then paused on a rock uphill and broadside to me giving me a clear view of its profile (left side). The bear is the same one we have seen around breaking into houses and in the housing area.

Nurse Scott Barlow reported a disturbance at the back of the clinic. He saw a bear attempting to gain entry to the rear doors and called dispatch. We responded from lower housing to find a large brown bear with green tag in left ear exiting the rear clinic doors with food in its mouth. I chased the bear towards Church Bowl and the bear dropped the ice packs and food. It then paused on a rock uphill and broadside to me giving me a clear view of its profile (left side). The bear is the same one we have seen around breaking into houses and in the housing area.
Bear box was left open and all the contents were removed by a bear.

During patrol through the NPS maintenance lot I noticed that the stables office door was ripped open again for the second night in a row. The bear pushed the weakened door open and went for the fridge. The bear bit into a bottle of water and that was it.

Kelly's neighbor reported a damaged rear door on the house to dispatch who notified us. The residents were out of town. We found the rear door had been broken through most likely by the same bear that ripped into two adjacent houses less than 100 yards away.

3rd hand report of bear entering the dorm room through the window. Bear opened the window and tore out the blinds then it was chased back out the same window. Details are pending - very vague 3rd hand report. Residents who were involved were asked to call us with further details.
Bear ripped off the screen front door. Dogs went crazy scaring the bear off. The Mates did not hear the door being damaged. Did not gain entry.
Bear ripped out the lower window of the back door and damaged the screen. Jim yelled and the bear did not leave. He then wielded his light sabers which was effective in scaring the bear away.
Victim Phone #: 248-259-2395 DNC at break-in site with car and victim when we arrived. After looking around parking lot I spotted a bear running toward Curry Village.

Huff House 215: Bear opened the camper shell door of an S-10 full of food. The bear obtained a box of oatmeal and a jar of peanut butter. Bear returned and was positively identified. The vehicle was towed and the owner will be cited by Jared Mitrea.

Huff House 215: Bear opened the camper shell door of an S-10 full of food. The bear obtained a box of oatmeal and a jar of peanut butter. Bear returned and was positively identified. The vehicle was towed and the owner will be cited by Jared Mitrea.

A visitor heard lots of banging in a neighboring site and when she got up to use the bathroom she saw a bear eating an entire campsite of Chinese takeout. The woman became frightened and hurried back to tell her husband. He got up about 10 minutes later. When he shone the flashlight at the bear if went around the corner. When the man came out of the bathroom, the bear finished eating all the contents of the site and slowly walked off. The visitors whose food was eaten left without reporting the incident and the front desk had no contact information. Visitors in the neighboring site showed Resources 90 pictures of the destroyed site.

The bear broke down the back door, entered laundry room, tore 2 sets of blinds off of the windows, pushed the top sash of one window down (storm window intact), and started trying to open the kitchen door by pounding on it. Fortunately the kitchen door opens out rather than in so it stood up to the bear pounding on it till the resident woke up and came down with his wife. No food was taken or present in the laundry room. Three days later Jack Hoeflich observes a bear with an orange tag going up to the now boarded up door and chased it off.

A bear described as large (about the same size as a bear locker) got into a bear locker. The visitors heard the latch lift and opened the door. They threw a broom out and the bear didn't turn around. They threw a boot and hit the bear and it still didn't leave. The visitor went to get dressed and the bear left before he cam out again. The bear ate lays, chocolate, and marshmallows and left the other food. The visitors heard a noise at the next site over but no more yelling. They insist the locker was closed properly.

Bear 3562 was in Huff House. Resource units were looking for her, and when they found her, she tried to grab a stick of butter that was laying on the ground. The bear missed it, tried to do a second run-by, and missed it again. She was then chased off. It looked like someone had dropped food on their porch, but resources were unable to locate the residents.

Vehicle had severe damage to the left rear door and window, the back interior, and left outside mirror. No food was claimed to be present in the vehicle. Vehicle was not drivable. Hotel 21 was called to the scene and impounded the car. Photos were taken by campgrounds ranger. The plastic from the inside panel of vehicle was chewed. Bear prints were all over the vehicle and the hind paw print was roughly 6 inches long.

The victim's dog barked and the owner looked out the window of his house and saw a bear near his car. The resident chased the bear away from the car and noticed a green tag in the left ear of the bear (he felt pretty confident with the identification). The rear left window of the minivan had been broken out. Sandy bear paw prints were on the side of the vehicle and the other windows. Resident said the bear was a very cinnamon color and very large. When the resident chased the bear it ran away. While taking the incident report Green 75 (3001) was heard on telemetry at moderate strength, however Green 75 has a right ear tag and the reported bear's tag was in the left ear (with moderate certainty).
The bear ripped through a metal screen to obtain recycling that was temporarily being stored in the screened off area of the back dock.
The food was in an ice chest in the locker, which was probably not fully closed. Food eaten by bear includes chicken, cheese, sausage, and peppers.

The bear got into a bear locker and ate for thirty minutes. Cereal, ginger snaps, oranges, mayonnaise, and apples were among the items eaten (A whole bear box of food). The visitors heard a large bang and then could hear the bear opening packages. They claim that the locker was properly latched.

The report was taken from a third party observer of the incident. The visitor was climbing below a party whose packs were on the ground. The visitor witnessed bear 3062 grab 2 packs and drag them off into the woods. The party above admitted to having food in their packs, but the quantity was unknown. The visitor saw the party collecting their damaged packs on his descent.

The report was taken from a third party observer of the incident. The visitor was climbing below a party whose packs were on the ground. The visitor witnessed bear 3062 grab 2 packs and drag them off into the woods. The party above admitted to having food in their packs, but the quantity was unknown. The visitor saw the party collecting their damaged packs on his descent.

The food in the packs included a peanut butter sandwich, goo, sunscreen, an orange that wasn’t eaten, and a bag of nuts. The reporting party was a guide who was up on a ledge with clients. Their backpacks were below them about 20 feet away on a second ledge of 3rd class terrain. Another party was on or close to the ledge with their packs. The RP said she turned to look for the packs to check on them and they were gone. A second party told her that they saw a bear so the RP went down and found all packs but one of her clients. RP's pack was ripped and wouldn’t zip, clients pack remains unrecovered. The unrecovered pack contained the clients wallet, Leatherman and cell phone. The guide said that there was no room in the locker at the base which was surrounded by 20 kids and their stuff. She said she didn’t think of a bear and thought they were close enough to their stuff.

The food in the packs included a peanut butter sandwich, goo, sunscreen, an orange that wasn’t eaten, and a bag of nuts. The reporting party was a guide who was up on a ledge with clients. Their backpacks were below them about 20 feet away on a second ledge of 3rd class terrain. Another party was on or close to the ledge with their packs. The RP said she turned to look for the packs to check on them and they were gone. A second party told her that they saw a bear so the RP went down and found all packs but one of her clients. RP's pack was ripped and wouldn’t zip, clients pack remains unrecovered. The unrecovered pack contained the clients wallet, Leatherman and cell phone. The guide said that there was no room in the locker at the base which was surrounded by 20 kids and their stuff. She said she didn’t think of a bear and thought they were close enough to their stuff.

The food in the packs included a peanut butter sandwich, goo, sunscreen, an orange that wasn’t eaten, and a bag of nuts. The reporting party was a guide who was up on a ledge with clients. Their backpacks were below them about 20 feet away on a second ledge of 3rd class terrain. Another party was on or close to the ledge with their packs. The RP said she turned to look for the packs to check on them and they were gone. A second party told her that they saw a bear so the RP went down and found all packs but one of her clients. RP's pack was ripped and wouldn’t zip, clients pack remains unrecovered. The unrecovered pack contained the clients wallet, Leatherman and cell phone. The guide said that there was no room in the locker at the base which was surrounded by 20 kids and their stuff. She said she didn’t think of a bear and thought they were close enough to their stuff.
A bear obtained food by banging on the locker. The latch opened and the bear got food from a cooler.

The bear obtained sausages, peanut butter, cheese, ham, fruit, etc. (about 2 grocery bags of food). People heard the bear in a locker and yelled at it for about fifteen minutes before the bear finally left. When asked how big the bear was the visitors indicated that it was about 4 feet high. They weren't sure the locker was properly latched.

Resource 90 was hiking up to the base of El Capitan to climb on days off. Bear 3062 was seen in the clearing on the approach trail ripping into a pink bag. Resource 90 chased bear off of stuff and up into the woods, but the bear continued to chew the bag it had drug off. Resource 90 backed off so that the bear would drop the bag, which it did. She then attempted to scare the bear away from the bag to retrieve it, and 3062 bluff charged. After giving the bear some space, she chased it and treed it. The bear huffed and only went 15 feet up. A visitor reported to Resource 90 that she and her children were watching climbers sitting down when a bear approached them from the woods. The woman was scared for her children so she gathered them and their packs, but hers was left. No food was in the pack, but a fragrant container of Burt's Bees hand salve was at the bottom. The bear chewed and ruined the bag.
The visitors heard a bear hitting the food locker, and observed it eating. They saw a yellow ear tag. The food eaten included snacks, candy bars, and Motrin (drug for baby).
Visitors heard the bear hitting the food locker and observed a bear with a yellow tag eating from it. The bear bluff charged them twice and ate pasta salad, 32 oz. of hummus, and flavored water.
A bear re-opened a flimsy screen that has been broken into for several consecutive nights by bears to obtain trash and recycling.

The bear obtained a hand full of peanuts by tearing a hole in a small camelback. The visitor said that their child forgot to store the food properly. The visitors heard the bear and chased it off. It was reported as being a small, light golden brown bear, unknown if the bear was tagged (reported by Security 74-Ian).

The bear obtained a hand full of peanuts by tearing a hole in a small camelback. The visitor said that their child forgot to store the food properly. The visitors heard the bear and chased it off. It was reported as being a small, light golden brown bear, unknown if the bear was tagged (reported by Security 74-Ian).

Granola bars were obtained by the bear. The visitors left the food out unintentionally. Resource units watched the bear pull it out of the hanging bag and lay down to eat the bar. Resource units snuck up to 25 yards, yelled, and fired 3 slugs as the bear ran towards the beach.
Some food was left out in the outside space of the tent cabins. The bear returned at 0600 and was chased away by occupants. It was the same bear as several earlier incidents. A bagel was obtained.

Resource units spotted a bear on food next to an open locker. Resource 90 chased the bear out of the campground and got a partial ID. The bear was cinnamon colored and looked like a small adult. The visitors enthusiastically claimed that thy closed their locker and checked that it was latched. They didn't hear anything from their tent until resource units arrived.

Bear obtained orange juice, butter, oatmeal, and pizza sauce. The visitors were in their tent when they heard a noise. They looked out and saw a bear messing with their locker. They said they watched it open their latched locker and get food. The man got out of the tent and the bear stepped towards him and then returned to the locker. Their neighbors then scared the bear away. The description sounded like bear 1278 and the telemetry box picked up 1278 at the time of the reported incident.

The vehicle was packed up with suitcases, food, and miscellaneous other items. The damage was to the passenger side rear window. The latch was broken and the window popped all the way off. There were deep scratches on the roof as well. The rear drivers side window was also popped out and locked. The back windshield wiper was also bent. There were bear paw prints all over the van, including the roof. Sun Chips, coffee, and drink cups were visible from the windows.

The vehicle was packed up with suitcases, food, and miscellaneous other items. The damage was to the passenger side rear window. The latch was broken and the window popped all the way off. There were deep scratches on the roof as well. The rear drivers side window was also popped out and locked. The back windshield wiper was also bent. There were bear paw prints all over the van, including the roof. Sun Chips, coffee, and drink cups were visible from the windows.
Resident purposely left windows of vehicle down. In the morning, the car was dirty with slobber all over, and a water bottle had bite marks on it.
Food locker was left open. Bear obtained marshmallows and food bars.
The bear ripped the screen off of the back door of a secured building and a wood panel off of the door frame to the garage, but did not gain entry in either case.
Bear broke front driver's side window. No damage was done to the interior or frame of the car. Baby seats were present, but undamaged.

Bear entered a car through the sun roof, popped off glass, and broke the panel. Damage was done to both leather seats in front. There was also damage to the passenger's side rear window and a panel in the trunk of the car panel which was popped off and cracked. Also a puncture to one of the rear seats and the rear wiper was bent. No food present, but baby seats were in the vehicle. Some scratches were on the pain as well.

A backpack was found across the road in North Pines from site #111. It is unknown where the pack came from. A bear ate a handful of small hard candies and two energy goo packets. The bear bit into Vaseline and bug repellent, as well as an unmarked bottle of capsules full of white powder. The bear also bit into a couple of the capsules. The bear also tore the bottom of a backpack with a camera inside which was turned over to law enforcement.

A backpack was found across the road in North Pines from site #111. It is unknown where the pack came from. A bear ate a handful of small hard candies and two energy goo packets. The bear bit into Vaseline and bug repellent, as well as an unmarked bottle of capsules full of white powder. The bear also bit into a couple of the capsules. The bear also tore the bottom of a backpack with a camera inside which was turned over to law enforcement.

Bear 3562 got into an unlatched bear locker and took a loaf of bread. She probably ate a third of the loaf before we caught up with her. The bear treed with the bread, then ran with it a ways before she finally dropped it.

Visitors stored food in a backpack within a locked tool box in the bed of their truck. Damage was done to the lock lugs (repairable). Scat was present beside the vehicle. Bear obtained a bag of food including oranges and canned goods.

Visitors stored food in a backpack within a locked tool box in the bed of their truck. Damage was done to the lock lugs (repairable). Scat was present beside the vehicle. Bear obtained a bag of food including oranges and canned goods.

A bear obtained two types of pasta, popcorn, and packaged meat from an improperly latched locker at the Ahwahnee Parking Lot. The bear had a very shiny reddish coat and there was a pile of scat very near the locker.
Latches to rear window of camper shell were damaged and condiments were taken from a plastic storage container within the camper shell.
Latches to rear window of camper shell were damaged and condiments were taken from a plastic storage container within the camper shell.

A red North Face backpack was found near the Camp 4 parking lot next to a small scat. Suntan lotion, snacks, 2 pairs of sunglasses, 3 walkie-talkies, and a "Hothands" cap in neon. Items stored in ranger briefing office at the lost and found locker.
A bear got a cup of dog food that was left out in an unknown site. Resource rangers were following her at the rime and chased her away from it.
A bear broke out the left rear door window, entered the vehicle and did some damage to a seat. The bear ate four apples and steaks were also reportedly in the back.
Driver's side door of a vehicle was slightly bent. Paw prints were all over the car. The bear did not get in the vehicle. It's possible that the damage could be a day old.

Bear locker open and a couple of Cliff bars, pita chips, carrots, and peas were eaten. Visitors didn't hear anything. Resource rangers found it open when they were spotlighting. There is a possibility that the incident was caused by two nearby raccoons. The food was scattered unlike most bear incidents and a surprisingly small amount of food was consumed.
A cooler was left out overnight. Some students saw the bear. Bear obtained cheese and candy from the cooler.

The back window on the passenger's side of the van was slid open by the bear. No damage was done to the window, but the screen was ripped. Food was present in the vehicle as well as incense sticks and strong odors. Resident reported not knowing food was in the vehicle.

Visitor's first time in Yosemite. They arrived late (02:30) and told by a ranger to park in the overflow parking and stay in Camp 4. Bear obtained food from the camper shell including eggs and milk in an ice chest.

Visitor's first time in Yosemite. They arrived late (02:30) and told by a ranger to park in the overflow parking and stay in Camp 4. Bear obtained food from the camper shell including eggs and milk in an ice chest.

The bear ate 3 lbs. of bacon and turkey. The visitors were asleep and heard an ice chest drop and then heard licking. They came out and the bear kept eating. The visitor hit the locker and the bear didn’t move. The visitor hit the bear on the head a couple of times with a walking stick and the bear ran away about ten feet and stopped. The bear then took a couple of steps towards the food before leaving. The bear walked (not ran) away. The people think they may have seen a collar but were very unsure. Orange 59 had just set off the alarm and was chased out of Housekeeping about 15 minutes later, but the visitors said they saw a white tag.
The bear tore the back of the pickup bed cover. No food was present in the cab or bed of the truck. The bear did not gain entry into the bed of the truck.

Resource units tracked Green 75 to the Curry West Lot and found a Dodge Van that the bear popped out the right rear window of. Green 75 ran away from the vehicle towards the ice rink. The vehicle was filthy and disgusting. Soda and doughnuts as well as trash was present. Bear obtained some food but unaware what food or how much (looks like candy and a few doughnuts). The baby seat that was present was very dirty and coated with unknown substances that smelled rancid.

Visitor had been in backcountry, returned to vehicle and stored a "cleaned" BBQ grill inside several black trash bags. Camped in Backpackers and returned this morning to a peeled passengers side door. The BBQ appeared to have been the target and no other food, trash or toiletries were involved.
Two granola bars and pack of gum were eaten. Sun block, and Advil were not eaten but the bottles were punctured. Visitors forgot that they left food in the backpack.

LocationDetail: Housekeeping Camp site D100. Bear Box 111
IncidentDescription: The food was left out until 1:30 am. The visitor was warned by resources. The bear returned at 1:30 am and opened the locker. Food for twenty visitors was consumed. 2 lbs of bacon, watermelon, humus, bread, 2 lbs. of sausage, alcoholic beverages, and soda was taken. The bear returned to Housekeeping while the report was being taken. The bear bluff charged the reporting desk officer. The bear is the same as case numbers 10-0819 and 10-0820 taken on 4/30/10.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: "Bounce" sheets were on the dash of the car. No food was known to be taken.
The bear entered through the skylight. There was food still in the vehicle when reporting party arrived on the scene.
I found a small cooler in the woods between Lower Pines and Stoneman Meadow. Something had opened it and got a couple of candy bars, some M&Ms, eggs, coffee creamer, and string cheese.

The bear obtained 2 tootsie pops. The visitor was asleep and heard a noise just outside the fence and saw and animal that left immediately. Wildlife staff located bear on telemetry and chased out of area.

The bear obtained 2 tootsie pops. The visitor was asleep and heard a noise just outside the fence and saw and animal that left immediately. Wildlife staff located bear on telemetry and chased out of area.

The visitors were asleep and heard a noise at the bear locker. They woke up and saw the bear. Resource 90 was just around the corner and saw the bear in the locker eating food. The bear pulled the cooler out and ate multiple items including bread, and 2 packages of deli meat, cheese and another package of buns. Visitors reported earnestly that they latched their locker, and demonstrated it.

The bear was on top of a backpack when the reporting party drove by. It got two partial boxes of crackers and multiple (~5) sodas. The visitors left out a backpack and a cooler the previous night because it started raining and they missed it. The backpack was ripped.

The bear was on top of a backpack when the reporting party drove by. It got two partial boxes of crackers and multiple (~5) sodas. The visitors left out a backpack and a cooler the previous night because it started raining and they missed it. The backpack was ripped.

Victor 33 found three bears eating two granola bars in woods by the parking lot. The sow left quickly but the yearlings needed some more convincing. It is unknown where the food came from. Victor 33 said they were making a lot of noise when he arrived like they were fighting.

The bear got into the locker and ate about 21 Hershey's bars, 2 Reese's bars, and half of a bag of marshmallows. The bear ate for about 15 minutes. The visitors heard a loud bang and when they saw it was a bear, they ran to the front office and called dispatch.
The drivers window was broken. No food was observed.

The employee's car had a pass #2586. A bear broke out of the front driver side window of an older model thunderbird in the orchard lot. The owner patched up the window with trash bags. The bear returned later and tore a new hole into the plastic.

The reporting party arrived and saw Yellow 31 and her 2 yearlings walking away from the motorcycle. There were 6 beer cans broken into from inside. The cooler strapped to the back of the motorcycle. The reporting party chased the three bears away. The reporting party then contracted the owner in Camp 4 and cited him for failure to store his beer.

A bottle of vodka, empty coke bottle, deodorant, chap stick, and gum were all stored in the passenger compartment of the vehicle. An entire bin of toiletries was in the trunk. The bear broke the driver's side back window. It poked a hole in the vodka, and the full bottle was almost emptied. That was the only internal damage to the vehicle. Bears Green 75 and Yellow 31 and her two yearlings were all within one hundred yards of the lot.

A bottle of vodka, empty coke bottle, deodorant, chap stick, and gum were all stored in the passenger compartment of the vehicle. An entire bin of toiletries was in the trunk. The bear broke the driver's side back window. It poked a hole in the vodka, and the full bottle was almost emptied. That was the only internal damage to the vehicle. Bears Green 75 and Yellow 31 and her two yearlings were all within one hundred yards of the lot.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear broke out the rear window. Zicam pills were present and according to Christenson were the only food or smelly item in the truck. Green 75 and Yellow 31 with her 2 yearlings were both seen in the area but not seen on or in the vehicle.
A backpack with food in it was left out on the picnic table. A bag of chips, Cheese Nips, 3 Cliff Bars, and one 20 oz. Mountain Dew was obtained. Orange 66 was seen in the area.
Sometime between 0700 and 1715 a bear damaged the tent of an NPS trails employee. The tent was unattended between those times. The fly and some tent poles were damaged. No food was present.
The bear obtained marshmallows, coffee, olives, tortilla chips, and marinade.

Between 0720 and 1730 the owner of the tent was not there. During the time the owner was away a bear ripped the tent in multiple places. The tent was totally destroyed, and there is positive evidence that it was damaged by a bear. There was no food present.

The bear dragged two bags out of the locker, which was found by resource units wide open. One bag was ripped up and a bag of rolls were taken and eaten out of the bag. The other bag contained no food and was not damaged. The visitors thought that they latched the locker but said that they must not have pushed the latch all the way down.

The bear dragged two bags out of the locker, which was found by resource units wide open. One bag was ripped up and a bag of rolls were taken and eaten out of the bag. The other bag contained no food and was not damaged. The visitors thought that they latched the locker but said that they must not have pushed the latch all the way down.

Nate from DNC Security witnessed the bear Orange 59 rip the passenger door down and pull garbage out of the vehicle. He yelled at her and she walked off slowly. The damage to the vehicle was pretty severe.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The reporting party chased 2394 out of the Camp 4 parking lot and checked vehicles for damage. Upon finishing the reporting party tracked 2394 into the middle of the campground where she was found eating from a pack. 2394 was then chased by the reporting party up the hill and was scared off by a banger. The bear continued to get farther away. The reporting party followed the train of food to a bivy sack at site #36 where the victim was found. He was extremely apologetic and was given a very stern warning. The reporting party would have called LE but none were available. The bear obtained 9 days worth of food including beef jerky, dried foods, and many bars etc.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The reporting party chased 2394 out of the Camp 4 parking lot and checked vehicles for damage. Upon finishing the reporting party tracked 2394 into the middle of the campground where she was found eating from a pack. 2394 was then chased by the reporting party up the hill and was scared off by a banger. The bear continued to get farther away. The reporting party followed the train of food to a bivy sack at site #36 where the victim was found. He was extremely apologetic and was given a very stern warning. The reporting party would have called LE but none were available. The bear obtained 9 days worth of food including beef jerky, dried foods, and many bars etc.
The bear entered the camp, the campers left, the bear then obtained some food. The campers and the reporting party then scared the bear away but the bear wouldn’t leave the area.
The bear broke into the driver's side rear window. The visitors had thoroughly cleaned the vehicle and vacuumed the vehicle and were very distressed because of their efforts.

The frame of the driver's side front door was bent down and the glass was broken. There was a bag of food garbage on the driver's seat. Green 75 was close to the parking lot when the reporting party arrived.
There was a box of trash left out with tuna fish and oranges. Although it was trash there was significant left overs and the bear obtained food.
The campers heard a noise and exited their tent and saw a bear taking food out of their locker. The bear made off with a large basket of blueberries.

The visitors heard their locker get hit by something at 03:00. The next morning, they realized something had gotten into their locker and eaten two partial bags of cereal. They said their locker wasn't latched completely.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The right front window was broken out. The bear entered the vehicle and opened a water bottle and went back in where the grocery bags were which did not contain any food items. There was a bottle of sunscreen in the back of the car. The victim was present when the desk officer arrived. DNC security officer, Nathan Perryman, observed a bear in the parking lot and chased it away at about 05:25.

The vehicles back passenger side door was damaged and the window was broken. Glass was covering the back seat. Several scented items were in the vehicle including scope mouthwash, hot sauce packets, and empty sunflower seed packets. The visitors reported that they had no other food in the vehicle. The visitors stated they forgot about the scented items in the vehicle.

The van had many items in it. The driver's side window was busted out. There were paw prints on the side and front of the van. Also the visor on the front window was broken so that a bear could gain access to the window. The visitor originally claimed that no food was in the vehicle However, after inspecting the damage, the visitor showed me a bag full of damaged half eaten vitamins that he didn’t know had to be stored.

The van had many items in it. The driver's side window was busted out. There were paw prints on the side and front of the van. Also the visor on the front window was broken so that a bear could gain access to the window. The visitor originally claimed that no food was in the vehicle However, after inspecting the damage, the visitor showed me a bag full of damaged half eaten vitamins that he didn’t know had to be stored.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The vehicle's rear drivers side window was broken into by a bear. Two packs were drug out of the vehicle and away from the car. One duffel bag was severely damaged and chewed on. The other pack was a backpack and it was opened at the zipper. No food items were found, but the vehicle smelt strongly and there were food wrappers in the side door. The windshield also had extensive damage and on close inspection was likely due to a bear.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The vehicle's rear drivers side window was broken into by a bear. Two packs were drug out of the vehicle and away from the car. One duffel bag was severely damaged and chewed on. The other pack was a backpack and it was opened at the zipper. No food items were found, but the vehicle smelt strongly and there were food wrappers in the side door. The windshield also had extensive damage and on close inspection was likely due to a bear.

There was granola, pound cake, HoHos, four packs of Top Ramen, and Gatorade taken from the locker. The visitors heard a bear hitting the locker and then the bear was in the locker. The visitors flashed a light at the bear and yelled but the bear did not leave. The bear was in the locker for more than ten minutes before security saw the bear and chased it away. The bear scared easily away when security arrived. Upon arrival about 20 minutes later. Yellow 31 was near by the area in Curry ( gain 145).
The bear snuck up and grabbed a bag of food. The visitors forgot that the food was left out. Campers were in the site setting up the tent. The visitors threw rocks and yelled to no avail.
The bear broke out the rear passenger window. There was no food present.
The backpack was left on the table while the campers were in the vicinity but not at the campsite. The bear drug a large pack away from camp. No food was present in the pack.

The vehicle was broken into by a bear. Many food items were in the car including a grocery bag of food. The bag was drug out and the items eaten include chocolate, a bag a barbecue chips, and carrot sticks. Another cooler was in the back of the vehicle with toiletries inside. Both of the passenger side windows were broken, the back door was bent and dented, and the leather front seats and back panel was ripped.
The bear entered the vehicle through the drivers side door. There was lots of "junk" in the vehicle.

The vehicle smelled strongly of cigarettes. There was an old coffee cup in the front seat. The front passenger window was broken out. A moldy orange was laying on the ground nearby with some glass. The owner of the vehicle could not be identified based on their employee sticker.
The bear gained entry into the camper shell of the truck. Unknown if food present.

There was lots of food in the vehicle. The bear ate Cliff Bars. The vehicle was towed at Camp 4 two nights earlier by J. Hoeflich for improper food storage. The visitor complained about being towed and then proceeded to leave food in their vehicle for the second time. The visitor was written a mandatory cite by J. Hoeflich.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear broke the driver's side window out, obtained and broke a Tupperware that contained various toiletries. The toiletries included toothpaste, cough drops, pills, and soap. Paw prints covered the car with the back paw being approximately six inches long. The vehicle had a warning put on it the day before for the toiletries in the vehicle. The bear also chewed a mesh screen for their tent and pulled out a down jacket that had no damage.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear broke the driver's side window out, obtained and broke a Tupperware that contained various toiletries. The toiletries included toothpaste, cough drops, pills, and soap. Paw prints covered the car with the back paw being approximately six inches long. The vehicle had a warning put on it the day before for the toiletries in the vehicle. The bear also chewed a mesh screen for their tent and pulled out a down jacket that had no damage.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear broke the driver's side window out, obtained and broke a Tupperware that contained various toiletries. The toiletries included toothpaste, cough drops, pills, and soap. Paw prints covered the car with the back paw being approximately six inches long. The vehicle had a warning put on it the day before for the toiletries in the vehicle. The bear also chewed a mesh screen for their tent and pulled out a down jacket that had no damage.

There was food garbage in the back of the vehicle. A reusable grocery bag was torn into. The vehicle's drivers side rear window was broken out and the frame was bent down, causing damage to the rear passenger door.
The rear passenger's side back window on the van was broken out. There were many items in the van including cookware. It is unknown what attractants were in the vehicle.

There were bear paw prints all over the vehicle. The front paw was approximately four to five inches across. The vehicle had many items inside and was very messy, but the bear tipped and opened up a Tupperware with Dr. Brommer's soap and other toiletries inside. The passenger side front window was ripped down, the front door was dented, the windshield wiper was broken, and some weather stripping on the back window on the passenger's side was ripped off and chewed and slobbered on. There was a toilet paper roll that was chewed and some vitamins were also visible.

The bear popped molding and lock on the rear window of a camper shell. The molding was chewed and ripped. No food items were present in the vehicle. The bear crawled inside to investigate things and bit a box to a water filter, but nothing was pulled out or chewed on.

Jeffrey Trust saw a bear running the opposite direction of the car. There were paw prints all over the vehicle. The back side window was broken. A backpack was on the ground next to the vehicle with food trash beside the pack. J. Trust yelled at the bear and it ran away. Bear 2394 was in the immediate vicinity with another dark colored, larger, untagged bear. Resource units had to chase both of them out of Yosemite Lodge Parking about 20 minutes after this incident occurred.

Jeffrey Trust saw a bear running the opposite direction of the car. There were paw prints all over the vehicle. The back side window was broken. A backpack was on the ground next to the vehicle with food trash beside the pack. J. Trust yelled at the bear and it ran away. Bear 2394 was in the immediate vicinity with another dark colored, larger, untagged bear. Resource units had to chase both of them out of Yosemite Lodge Parking about 20 minutes after this incident occurred.

358 Warren chased Orange 59 away from Sentinel Beach Picnic Area where she was eating someone's unattended picnic. By the time Resource 89 arrived, the party had cleaned up and left, so it is unknown how much food was obtained, but apparently it "looked like the whole picnic lunch." A large bear was in the woods by the road and followed her across the road while she was being chased.
4 cans of beer were left outside the camper in a cooler.

The door frame of the car was bent back about 1 inch with window glass intact. There was no visible food in car but many other items present: climbing gear, bicycle, and water bottles. Yellow 31 was very close on telemetry and is the likely culprit. The bear did not gain entry into vehicle.
The right passenger door of the car was pulled down. There were a lot of items inside.

On 06-01-2010 at 10:00, visitors were returning from a day canoe trip to find bear chewing on a backpack. Once they arrived at their site and saw the bear, they scared the it away and found their tent was ruined. The tent and one air mattress was ripped apart by the bear. The on 06-01-2010 at 11:00, same visitors returned to their site to find 2 more air mattresses ripped apart and all of their belongings strewn about. The 2 visitors decided to leave after the 2nd incident.

On 06-01-2010 at 10:00, visitors were returning from a day canoe trip to find bear chewing on a backpack. Once they arrived at their site and saw the bear, they scared the it away and found their tent was ruined. The tent and one air mattress was ripped apart by the bear. The on 06-01-2010 at 11:00, same visitors returned to their site to find 2 more air mattresses ripped apart and all of their belongings strewn about. The 2 visitors decided to leave after the 2nd incident.
Visitor's vehicle was damaged but no food was present inside. There was a box inside car that may have looked like a cooler. There was also climbing equipment, skis, and clothes present in car.
The visitor left food in a cooler within their camper shell. Ranger L. Schwille issued a citation under the same case number.
The visitor left food in a cooler within their camper shell. Ranger L. Schwille issued a citation under the same case number.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The driver's side window was peeled back and the window was broken. The vehicle possibly had toiletries in their trunk. The back seat was pulled at by the bear, and foam was pulled out of the seat. A nearby camper heard the window break but did not see the bear.

A message was left on the bear hotline of a bear grabbing a loaf of bread from a picnic table. The bear approached the picnickers. The visitor's dog chased the bears across the road. There was no further information from the hotline report.

The right rear window molding was torn, and the tool box (diamond plate) mounted on the bed of the pickup was torn open. There was food in the tool box and paper wrappers (two candy wrappers) were in the bed of the pickup.

The right rear window molding was torn, and the tool box (diamond plate) mounted on the bed of the pickup was torn open. There was food in the tool box and paper wrappers (two candy wrappers) were in the bed of the pickup.

The bear was laying down in the second loop of Upper Pines. When resource units spotlighted him, he got up and had a large can of gourmet hot chocolate in his mouth. The bear was chased through the campground and he dropped the hot chocolate before resource units lost him. No nearby lockers were open and no nearby visitors claimed the chocolate.

LocationDetail: Mirror Lake Road by the bathrooms and bike trail
IncidentDescription: Bear 3565 destroyed a daypack and obtained : almonds, granola bars, and a sandwich. Orange 66 and Orange 59 were tearing into logs just off the Mirror Lake road and a crowd of visitors came within 20 feet to watch the feeding. The visitors half circled the bears and were getting closer. One visitor left his pack on the road to get a closer look. Orange 66 saw the pack and charged toward the crowd to get it. Once on the pack some visitors yelled at the bear and charged it, but the bear charged back at them, keeping the pack for himself. Once Resource 88 arrived, the bear was leaving because all of the food had been eaten.

LocationDetail: Mirror Lake Road by the bathrooms and bike trail
IncidentDescription: Bear 3565 destroyed a daypack and obtained : almonds, granola bars, and a sandwich. Orange 66 and Orange 59 were tearing into logs just off the Mirror Lake road and a crowd of visitors came within 20 feet to watch the feeding. The visitors half circled the bears and were getting closer. One visitor left his pack on the road to get a closer look. Orange 66 saw the pack and charged toward the crowd to get it. Once on the pack some visitors yelled at the bear and charged it, but the bear charged back at them, keeping the pack for himself. Once Resource 88 arrived, the bear was leaving because all of the food had been eaten.
The bear was observed running from the vehicle and was identified by telemetry as 3001. The damage was to the camper shell and some plywood inside. One candy bar was consumed.
The bear was observed running from the vehicle and was identified by telemetry as 3001. The damage was to the camper shell and some plywood inside. One candy bar was consumed.

A climber said that his wife was watching him climb from the meadow during the day and a bear snuck up behind her and grabbed her purse. She chased the bear and yelled at it and the bear dropped the purse and left. There was minimal damage to the purse. She was sitting in the meadow at the time of the incident.

The incident was reported to the Wildlife Office by Noreen from YA. A group was moving from site C to site D in Yellow Pines. They left a box of crackers on top of a bear box. A collared bear began to eat the crackers. Noreen yelled and slammed a bear locker to scare it away. The bear left the food and bluff charged her from 15 yards away. The bear only got some of the crackers. Bears 3001 and 2394 were heard on telemetry, weak, at 0900 hours.
The visitors were sitting at their picnic table with their backs to the table. The bear came from behind and took a black plastic bag from the top of the table and ran away towards Happy Isles.

Resource units saw bear 2394 running from Lower Pines into Boystown. Upon returning they found that she had ran from a vehicle that she had broken into. The drivers side rear window was broken with some damage to the moldings as well. The vehicle was filthy and filled with trash and other items. The bear obtained some raisins.

The bear came into the visitors campsite four to five times on 6/1/2010. It chewed and sniffed a backpack, tried to get into a bear locker, and then sat down about twenty feet from the visitors and just stared at them. On 6/2/2010 the bear ripped and broke into the visitors tent. Each time the bear entered the campsite the visitors yelled and threw sticks, but it kept coming back. Never once did it obtain any food.

Two bears approached the Snack Stand and tried to reach for the condiments. An employee scared the bears away but a visitor nearby became frightened and threw her hotdog on the ground and ran away. The bears ate the hotdog.
The pickup cover was ripped and a cooler was in the bed of the truck. No food was observed.
A camelback with the bladder and many bars was ravaged by a bear. It was found near Camp 4.
A camelback with the bladder and many bars was ravaged by a bear. It was found near Camp 4.

Victor 43 was informed of a bear on top of a car at Sentinel Beach. The bear was on top of a black Honda Element with a Thule cargo container attached to the roof. The bear had already torn the middle section of the container open and was trying to pull a black bag out of the container. He drove up to the bear, approximately ten feet away, and activated his lights and sirens and got out to yell at the bear. The bear casually got off the roof and it ran about ten feet into the bushes and just looked at Victor 43. It eventually walked off towards Yellow Pines. He called for Resource units to bring hazing guns, and the bear was walking back towards him. He chased it off a third time and proceeded to follow it around the entire picnic area. The bear walked from the Yellow Pines/ Sentinel intersection all the way over to the stream, crossing it and eventually walking back to the beach. He yelled at the bear approximately ten times and the bear seemed unaffected. He noticed that it was Green 75. The resource units came and Victor 43 went back to look at the vehicle but it had left and he had no information by which to identify it. He found the vehicle about 20 minutes later. The visitor stated that no food was currently in the cargo container but a few days ago it had held some freshly baked goods.

The visitor was standing in front of their locker getting food out of it and a bear came up behind him and grabbed a bag of marshmallows from the top of the box. The camp host chased it out of camp and about 5 minutes later the bear was back in the next site over. It did not obtain food the second time, but came within 5 feet of visitors both times. The bear did not move quickly when being chased.

As resource units were driving past Wahoga they spotted eye shine. They investigated and found a cooler that had been left out with food strewn about. A cooler full of drinks was also left out nearby. They woke up a man sleeping in an adjacent truck and explained the issue. The man was cooperative and he found room in a nearby locker for his food. There were also several trash bags and other small violations scattered around as well as what appeared to be a home made electric fence running off of a car battery surrounding a trailer containing food.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: A backpack and cooler were visible in the vehicle but it is unknown if there was food in either. A very small window at the rear of the drivers sided was broken into.
No food was found in the vehicle, visitors had their backpacks with them. The vehicle was a rental car from National Rental Car.

The visitors removed an ice chest from their locker and left it cracked open while standing ten feet away. They saw a bear investigating their stuff and yelled. The bear grabbed an empty pack off of the top of the locker and ran off. The pack was not retrieved.

This is a secondhand report taken on the cables of Half Dome, so there is limited information. Some visitors reported that the campsite next to them at the Sunrise Junction had a stuff sack chewed on by a bear. No food was present, but the bear also entered their campsite shortly after. They yelled and scared it away. The visitors saw no ear tags on the bear. The incident happened at dusk.
A carrier box attached to the receiver hitch of the vehicle was broken into. The bear ripped the box off of the carrier. DNC reports that food was in the carrier.
The bear entered through the right rear camper window.
The bear entered the right front passenger window and then tried to enter the trunk through the back seat.
The bear entered the car through the right side front door.

The bear broke in through the rear passenger side window. The car contained toiletries, beer, assorted food items (candy, applesauce, etc.), and trash. The paw prints on the vehicle looked pretty small.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The door and window were destroyed on the left rear side. No food was observed but there was a large amount of cosmetics and medicine. There was also lots of climbing equipment in the vehicle.
The bear broke in through the rear passenger side window. There was lots of food in the vehicle and the Desk Officer recommended an impound.

The visitors claim that no food was left in the vehicle, but there was possibly trash in there. The visitors were staying in site 33 in Camp 4 and were woken up in order to remove their expensive camera from their vehicle.
The bear broke in to the RV portion of the cab over the truck. The bear pulled a stove off of the canister and caused a propane leak. The RP witnessed a fireball come out of the vehicle.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: There were paw prints on the front, side, and rear windows, as well as on the hood, all over the doors, roof, and trunk. The molding on the driver's side and passenger side windows were ripped off. There was a lot of trash in the rear of the car, including empty plastic cups and glass bottles. The license plate was bent back by the bear as well.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The back cover of the truck was ripped off, which ruined the snaps on the tarp cover. The bear also scratched the paint on the top of the vehicle, hood, side window, and back window of the truck. The bear ripped the molding off of the driver's side window. No food was present, but hand sanitizer and a sprite can were in the cab. The bear did not gain entry into the cab, and did not remove any items from the bed of the truck.

LocationDetail: Parking area at the Wood Lot
IncidentDescription: The vehicle was left for an hour while the resident was hiking. The rear driver's side window was broken out. The back passengers side floor mat was also chewed on and pulled out. A bear jam occurred at the same time as the incident. The bear observed at the jam was chestnut brown and had a "goldenrod" tag in the right ear. The bear was foraging in the woods nearby.

The visitor was approximately 20 feet from an open bear locker with food on top of it. The bear grabbed potatoes while the visitor was putting away food. The bear continued to approach camp. The bear ate spaghetti sauce while a visitor was yelling from less than 20 feet away and banging the picnic table. The bear left again. The bear also obtained 2 packages of bacon. The visitor reported that the bear came back many times (around 20). A visitor from a neighboring camp came over to help and saw the bear from around 11:30 to 12:30. Resource units and LE Rangers all chased the bear into the meadow.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The window of the vehicle was broken overnight. The passenger window was left open approximately one inch. A puncture to a camera bag was the only sign of a bear inside the vehicle. An empty coffee cup was in the vehicle.

The bear climbed on top of a hard sided trailer and broke into the window/vent on the top. There were paw prints and hair left on the trailer. The visitors woke up to a banging noise and when they got up the bear ran away with a bag of chips. Resource units arrived about 5 minutes later. About 15 minutes after the incident resource units chased a small, untagged bear away from the area. The visitors moved their vehicle to the impound lot for the night and planned on getting the roof reinforced.

The bear climbed on top of a hard sided trailer and broke into the window/vent on the top. There were paw prints and hair left on the trailer. The visitors woke up to a banging noise and when they got up the bear ran away with a bag of chips. Resource units arrived about 5 minutes later. About 15 minutes after the incident resource units chased a small, untagged bear away from the area. The visitors moved their vehicle to the impound lot for the night and planned on getting the roof reinforced.

Ranger Scott Jacobs was on patrol when he saw a bear break in at El Cap Cross. The vehicle had been damaged in the back. The truck's topper window was torn off in the back. The truck bed was lined with wood for compartments and that was torn in multiple places. A skateboard and a tennis racquet were broken as well. There was food present in the vehicle. The vehicle was impounded for food storage as well as cited.

Ranger Scott Jacobs was on patrol when he saw a bear break in at El Cap Cross. The vehicle had been damaged in the back. The truck's topper window was torn off in the back. The truck bed was lined with wood for compartments and that was torn in multiple places. A skateboard and a tennis racquet were broken as well. There was food present in the vehicle. The vehicle was impounded for food storage as well as cited.

Victor 42 was on patrol in the Wilderness Lot when she observed a motorcycle that had been knocked over with food scattered on the ground. The food was stored in the motorcycle's soft pack. She spoke to a witness who saw the bear and scared it off. About 5 minutes later she saw Yellow 31 at the edge of the parking lot and hazed the bear with one rubber slug. The motorcycle was impounded and a citation was left for when the owner picked it up. This was the first motorcycle towed for food storage ever.

Victor 42 was on patrol in the Wilderness Lot when she observed a motorcycle that had been knocked over with food scattered on the ground. The food was stored in the motorcycle's soft pack. She spoke to a witness who saw the bear and scared it off. About 5 minutes later she saw Yellow 31 at the edge of the parking lot and hazed the bear with one rubber slug. The motorcycle was impounded and a citation was left for when the owner picked it up. This was the first motorcycle towed for food storage ever.

The visitors reported that no food or anything scented was in their vehicle at the time of the break in. There was no food or garbage when the vehicle was inspected by the reporting party. No one reported to see or hear a bear.

Some campers were sitting in the campsite. Other campers were moving food around in the locker and then left the locker open and went to the restroom. A bear came into the site and went right up the open locker and grabbed a box of granola bars and ran off.
The bear entered the car through the right rear window of the car. The bear obtained a bottle of ketchup according to DNC security.
The bear entered the car through the right rear window of the car. The bear obtained a bottle of ketchup according to DNC security.
This was the second break in of this particular vehicle. The bear ripped open the plastic covering over the window. There was odors and packs with climbing gear present.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Left front window broken, rear seat destroyed. Back pack, clothing bags, paper, empty paper food wrapper and misc. trash was inside the vehicle. Unknown if food was stored in vehicle.
The bear entered the car through the rear door. The bear of unknown description was chased away from the scene by security. There was slight dents on the roof as well.
The bear entered through the drivers side door. The back seat was torn up, it was suspected that there was food in the trunk.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear entered through the drivers side window. There were coffee cups in the vehicle.

The food was left in the bed of a truck. There were several beers and some salsa and olives outside of the cooler. The cooler was in the truck bed, open. Resource units saw Orange 66 across the meadow on River Straight just before seeing the vehicle.
The bear entered the car through the right rear corner canvas top.

Bear 3001 attempted to rip into the back door of the Carroll's house. They were home and attempted to scare the bear off. It casually walked about 25 feet and stared at them. Resource 85 arrived on scene and fired 4 hazing rounds (slugs) on target. The bear continued to lurk behind the housing area, went through Churchbowl and then on to the Ahwahnee. The damage to the house was a ripped screen.

The visitors left their locker open with food on top while they were sitting with their backs to it. The heard the bear and yelled at it. It ran away but obtained a small pack of graham crackers. Ranger Bissmeyer had spoken to this campsite earlier in the night about having food out and their locker open.

A sow with two cubs approached four hikers who were resting with their packs off, but within arms reach of them. The sow did not stop when the hikers made noise. When the sow did not stop, the hikers backed away and the sow approached their packs. The hikers threw a rock and the bear took one pack and ran up the hill and tore it open. The bear tore up the pack and sleeping bag. The visitors were not able to see what else was destroyed. The hikers were headed to LYV and so were not carrying bear canisters.

A sow with two cubs approached four hikers who were resting with their packs off, but within arms reach of them. The sow did not stop when the hikers made noise. When the sow did not stop, the hikers backed away and the sow approached their packs. The hikers threw a rock and the bear took one pack and ran up the hill and tore it open. The bear tore up the pack and sleeping bag. The visitors were not able to see what else was destroyed. The hikers were headed to LYV and so were not carrying bear canisters.

A sow with two cubs approached four hikers who were resting with their packs off, but within arms reach of them. The sow did not stop when the hikers made noise. When the sow did not stop, the hikers backed away and the sow approached their packs. The hikers threw a rock and the bear took one pack and ran up the hill and tore it open. The bear tore up the pack and sleeping bag. The visitors were not able to see what else was destroyed. The hikers were headed to LYV and so were not carrying bear canisters.

A sow with two cubs approached four hikers who were resting with their packs off, but within arms reach of them. The sow did not stop when the hikers made noise. When the sow did not stop, the hikers backed away and the sow approached their packs. The hikers threw a rock and the bear took one pack and ran up the hill and tore it open. The bear tore up the pack and sleeping bag. The visitors were not able to see what else was destroyed. The hikers were headed to LYV and so were not carrying bear canisters.

Security 83 observed the bear breaking into the truck, and it is unknown if food was obtained. Gum and condiments were present in the vehicle. The bear dragged a laptop off but it was recovered. The bear entered the vehicle by breaking out the passenger side window.

The camper had walked to their locker that was locked and closed. He opened the locker to get food out and a bear walked up to him. The visitor stepped away from the locker and the bear. The bear pulled the cooler out of the locker and took veggie burgers out. When the visitor first saw the bear it was about twenty feet away. The bear returned a few minutes later to the site next to them. The campers yelled at the bear and it left.
An ice chest with a large amount of food was taken. The food items that were taken include fish, cheese, chicken, turkey, cream cheese, and power bars.
Resources 89 and 91 were tracking Green 75 in the Wilderness Lot and found him in an open locker. The bear obtained food and was chased away by yelling and chasing and the use of a paintball gun.

Resource units came into Wilderness Lot and saw Green 75 inside the passenger side window. They yelled and chased the bear up the hill into the rocks. The car contained Top Ramen, Slim Jims, and other food items. The bear was initially on the drivers side of the vehicle and once the resource units approached the bear went to the passenger side to exit through the window. The bear ran when yelled at but did not go far or run fast. The bear hung out very close to the car for at least another half of an hour.
The passenger side window was shattered by a bear. It is unknown if food was present or obtained. This incident was reported by DNC security.
The bear obtained a food container from the locker. The bear ate a box of raisin bran, a bag of marshmallows, and cookies.

The visitors were at their picnic table approximately twenty feet from their locker, which was not completely latched. The visitors looked up and saw a bear at their locker. They yelled and the bear did not leave. They watched it pull up on the top of the latch and get food out. The bear ran off with a bag of food containing at least marshmallows and Bisquick. While the bear was at the locker visitors threw objects at the bear while yelling. The bear did not appear to care.

An ice chest was left out. The bear ate cheese, candy bars, and a couple other bags of food. The bear also bit the ice chest. Resource units saw a bear across the campground road shortly after they discovered the ice chest, but could not ID the bear.

The owner came upon the bear after it had ripped a horizontal gash in the tent (about 1 ft. opening) and dragged the victims camera about ten feet from the tent. The owner yelled at the bear and chased the bear. The bear ran away but not very quickly. There was no food found inside the tent.

2 visitors went to pump water when a bears approached. The visitors backed off and the bears took their food (tortellini and parmesan). The visitors were not afraid of yelling at the bears but bears stayed around camp for a while and eventually left. The 2 bears were light brown and cinnamon in color and one had a yellow tag in its right ear. Blame: visitors afraid of bears.
There were odors in the vehicle from cake that was transported in the vehicle. The bear attempted to enter the vehicle from the right rear door.
Bear was seen trying to get into a tent by cutting tent material with claws. Inside the tent was toilet paper and a sunglasses kit. The bear bit into the sunglasses kit.

The bear was attempting to get into a small plywood trailer. It was unknown if there was food inside but reporting party could see what appeared to be a case of water. The bear destroyed a tarp that was bungeed around the trailer. The bear would not leave when the visitors started yelling and honking their horns. There were paw prints all over the trailer. Orange 66 was in the area.
Bear broke into vehicle by breaking right rear window. There was no evidence of food in the vehicle and no damage inside the vehicle.

The superintendent called in a bear attempting to get trash out of a can but the resource units were tied up with a bear jam. The reporting party was then recon acted by dispatch to inform me that the bear was now breaking into vehicles. I responded and found that 358 Warren had chased the bear off. The superintendent and I spoke briefly about the nature of our bear program and the owner of the vehicle showed up. He was verbally warned. The bear obtained crackers, cheese and several other small items. There was also a missing party located at the same time at Camp 6 which made for an intense couple of minutes. Food was left uncovered in plain sight within the passenger seat. Damage was to the passenger side window.

Visitor had beef jerky in the top part of a pack during the day and at night emptied the pack and left it outside. The bear took the pack into the woods and damaged the top compartment of the pack which was later retrieved by owner. Report obtained by third party not pack owner.

R92 and R94 pulled into Sentinel Beach parking while tracking bear 3001 and found a vehicle that had just been broken into. They chased the bear off and the vehicle sped away before they were able to obtain a report. M. Stark was able to locate the individual to gain some detail of the incident. I was informed later by a Housekeeping camp host that apples were left in the vehicle and the bear broke in to obtain them.
There was cat food believed to be in the latched locker. The bear was able to open the locked locker and get the cat food.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The right front window to the vehicle was broken out. There was a water bottle, papers, bags and cups in the vehicle.

LocationDetail: Housekeeping camp parking lot near southside dr.
IncidentDescription: The passenger window was broken. The windshield was cracked. There was bear paw print found on the right door. The vehicle was towed.

A bear tore apart the visitor's tent and chewed a foam sleeping pad due to food wrappers left inside the tent. The bear chewed/tore up a backpack and possibly ate sunflower seeds. The visitors did not think dry foods such as sunflower seeds needed to be stored in the bear canister. The visitors were not present when the bear was in their camp. The visitors were hiking from Tuolumne meadows to Yosemite Valley.

A bear tore apart the visitor's tent and chewed a foam sleeping pad due to food wrappers left inside the tent. The bear chewed/tore up a backpack and possibly ate sunflower seeds. The visitors did not think dry foods such as sunflower seeds needed to be stored in the bear canister. The visitors were not present when the bear was in their camp. The visitors were hiking from Tuolumne meadows to Yosemite Valley.

A bear tore apart the visitor's tent and chewed a foam sleeping pad due to food wrappers left inside the tent. The bear chewed/tore up a backpack and possibly ate sunflower seeds. The visitors did not think dry foods such as sunflower seeds needed to be stored in the bear canister. The visitors were not present when the bear was in their camp. The visitors were hiking from Tuolumne meadows to Yosemite Valley.

Resource units received a report of a bear with a radio collar ripping into the A-Frame in Happy Isles Fen. The resource units arrived at the building but there was no bear present but bear 3565 nearby on telemetry. The reporting party spoke to Paula with Yosemite Conservancy who reported the incident. The bear ripped shingles and 1 by 4 panels off the building. It was unknown if the bear obtained food, but interpretation rangers were called to come out and remove any scented items. The BF6 key did not work on the door.
The residents heard a noise in the backyard. The bear broke into the storage shed. No food was present.
The bear broke the right rear window of the vehicle. There were food containers on the back seat but they were empty.

Bear entered left rear panel/window and pulled it out. Food present and obtained as reported by DNC security. Bear reported as tagged orange 66 and found with telemetry and observed by Curry campground host leaving the scene. Sun-chips present in vehicle.

Received call from Yosemite dispatch about an incident in Curry tent #3. Upon arrival to the scene, observed scratch marks at the bottom latch. The visitor informed LE that locker was closed but was unaware about the possibility that bottom latch may not close. The bear probably opened the locker by pulling the door since the bottom latch was not secure.
Vehicle right front window was broken by an unknown bear. No sign of food being present in the vehicle.
The bear entered the vehicle through the left front window. There was a protein drink found on the ground outside of the window.

The bear scared the visitors from their picnic and ate their food. The bear also got into a vehicle with its windows down. This is a third hand report from Arch Rock to dispatch to resource units. The bear had a tag but that’s the only description of the bear.

The bear was reluctant to run. It took many people shouting and someone threw a rock. People were sure they latched the locker properly. It was easy to latch and would have been difficult to have not latched it properly. The bear ate chicken stir fry, chips, and cheese.

The bear got into the vehicle through the passenger window. No food was in the vehicle but damage was done to the seats inside the vehicle. The owner of the vehicle said that he made sure there was no food in the vehicle when he parked it. Bear 3001 was observed by the vehicle earlier and was chased out of the area but did not see him breaking into this vehicle.

LE was driving on Northside Dr. when she observed a white Toyota Tacoma with the passenger side window broken. There were bear paws on the trucks' passenger side door and inside the car was candy, 5 containers of vitamins, 3 empty drink containers, empty tortilla bag, chap stick, and 3 emergency drink packs. LE towed the vehicle to the LEO impound lot.
According to person taking the report the bear box is difficult to latch.

The bear pulled the driver's side door back about one inch with the window kept intact (bear did not gain entry.) There were scratches and paw prints on the doors (driver side and rear) caused by the bear. The car contained a baby seat only.
Bear broke into left side of car (the driver side) window. The bear tore out the driver seat and there was no sign of food present in the vehicle.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The damage was to the drivers side front window. Trash, food wrappers, and a drink bottle were present.
The damage to the vehicle was on the left side rear window. There was food present and possible crumbs on the back seat.

The bear was found in vehicle eating granola. Bear exited vehicle and Resource 85 shot 5 rounds from shotgun at bear. The vehicle's right front window was broken. This incident occurred before dark and in a gap of less than 2 minutes that resource units were not in visual contact with this bear. The bear's actions are becoming increasingly bolder.

The bear was found in vehicle eating granola. Bear exited vehicle and Resource 85 shot 5 rounds from shotgun at bear. The vehicle's right front window was broken. This incident occurred before dark and in a gap of less than 2 minutes that resource units were not in visual contact with this bear. The bear's actions are becoming increasingly bolder.

The bear did not enter the car. The damage was to the drivers side vinyl convertible top. A warning was left on the vehicle from 7/13/2010 from 328. There was a paper bag on the seat in the vehicle with no signs of food in it.
Visitor heard noises for approximately 20 minutes and went outside of tent to find food out of locker. The bear obtained a wide variety of food.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear broke the driver's window. The bear was not seen. Paw prints and hair were on the vehicle, no interior damage. No food inside vehicle, just a small container of lotion in the back of one of the seats.
DNC Security reported that a resident's vehicle was damaged by a bear. It ripped the canvas off of a Jeep Wrangler. No food was present in the vehicle.

Steve was making coffee when he observed a bear attempting to get into the same dining room window that all of the other bears have entered. He chased the bear off as it was looking into his van. There was minor damage to the screen on the window.

Bear 3062 came into the visitors campsite near the intersection of Lake Eleanor Rd and the Frog Creek trail junction. The visitors had just finished eating when the bear came into their site and took food and damaged a backpack. The bear then bit into a can of aerosol insect repellant and left, salivating heavily. At approximately 1530, volunteer Ryan Vogel chased the same bear off of a tent outside the Ranger Office. The tent was torn open and the bear was carrying a pack away, but she dropped it as she ran. The tent and its contents were moved into the shed, and there was no food or any scented items in the tent or pack. The bear returned shortly and was scared off again. On June 1st, another visitor reported that his tent was torn into and a backpack containing one empty jerky wrapper was pulled out. The next day there was no food in the visitor's tent, but the bear entered again and popped both air mattresses inside. On June 2nd, a backpacker heard a scream and found two day hikers who had stopped at the campground to take a break. One of the hikers had been leaning against a tree eating trail mix when bear 3062 approached him and swatted him on the back, leaving a large scratch. The bear obtained the trail mix and left. No contact was made with the injured hiker, the report came from the backpacker who came upon the scene.

Bear 3062 came into the visitors campsite near the intersection of Lake Eleanor Rd and the Frog Creek trail junction.
