The visitors had just finished eating when the bear came into their site and took food and damaged a backpack. The bear then bit into a can of aerosol insect repellant and left, salivating heavily. The tent and its contents were moved into the shed, and there was no food or any scented items in the tent or pack. The bear returned shortly and was scared off again. On June 1st, another visitor reported that his tent was torn into and a backpack containing one empty jerky wrapper was pulled out. The next day there was no food in the visitor's tent, but the bear entered again and popped both air mattresses inside. On June 2nd, a backpacker heard a scream and found two day hikers who had stopped at the campground to take a break. One of the hikers had been leaning against a tree eating trail mix when bear 3062 approached him and swatted him on the back, leaving a large scratch. The bear obtained the trail mix and left. No contact was made with the injured hiker, the report came from the backpacker who came upon the scene.
The bear broke in through the drivers side window. Food and clothing were present inside. DNC Security saw the bear breaking in.
The bear broke in through the passenger side front window. There was a pillow in the backseat, and other miscellaneous items visible inside.
The bear broke in through the drivers window. There was climbing gear and some clothes and odors in the vehicle.

Victor 42 observed a vehicle with a piece of cardboard hanging from an open window. Next to the vehicle was a bag of spiced mango that was torn open by a bear. V42 was not completely sure that the wrapper came from inside the vehicle, but there was evidence that the bear was in the vehicle with no other food present. She left a warning on the vehicle and threw away the torn bag because some of the mangoes were still present. There was no new damage to the vehicle.

The person reporting was on foot in backpackers camp when she observed a locker wide open with food pulled out of the locker. She walked 20 yards away and found more food that had evidence that it was eaten by a bear. She woke up the people in the site and the visitors admitted it was possible that they may not have closed the locker properly. There was evidence that a bear may have put its mouth on the locker to pull it up. The reporting party thinks the locker was improperly locked so the bear was able to open it and eat a container of yogurt, a box of crackers and an unknown amount of food trash. The bear also damaged two Nalgene bottles.

The person reporting was on foot in backpackers camp when she observed a locker wide open with food pulled out of the locker. She walked 20 yards away and found more food that had evidence that it was eaten by a bear. She woke up the people in the site and the visitors admitted it was possible that they may not have closed the locker properly. There was evidence that a bear may have put its mouth on the locker to pull it up. The reporting party thinks the locker was improperly locked so the bear was able to open it and eat a container of yogurt, a box of crackers and an unknown amount of food trash. The bear also damaged two Nalgene bottles.
The bear attempted entry of the vehicle on the left side. The molding on the door was torn. There was only clothes and water bottles inside.
The bear entered the vehicle through the right front door. The window was broken and the frame was bent. There was a cooler type box in the back. There were clothes and odors in the vehicle.
A sow and a cub were seen rummaging through a guests bear locker that had been left open. The Duo was scared off by approaching guests.
Bear obtained popcorn from a bag of white cheddar. The resident yelled at the bear which scared easily. The locker was unlatched.

The visitor said that he walked up to his vehicle and saw resource units nearby tracking a bear. The visitor talked to the resource units but didn’t notice at the time that his vehicle was damaged. After the resource units left the visitor noticed that the recycling (beer bottles) was missing from the truck bed and that the side view mirror was broken off. There were bear paw prints all over the car.
Resource units were less than a minute behind bear 3001 when he broke into this vehicle for food trash. They found him still inside the vehicle and hit him with several hazing rounds.
Resource units were less than a minute behind bear 3001 when he broke into this vehicle for food trash. They found him still inside the vehicle and hit him with several hazing rounds.

During an inspection of North Pines, Campground ranger 327 came across bear 1278 with his head in a food locker. The bear initially ignored him when yelled at, and then he ran/walked towards Tenaya Creek. The bear crossed the creek west of the backpackers camp.

During an inspection of North Pines, Campground ranger 327 came across bear 1278 with his head in a food locker. The bear initially ignored him when yelled at, and then he ran/walked towards Tenaya Creek. The bear crossed the creek west of the backpackers camp.

A visitor heard a bear opening their locker and identified it as White 88 as the bear was fleeing the scene. A bag of marshmallows was taken by the bear. Victor 42 hazed the bear with 3 shotgun rounds.

Food was left in plain sight in the front and back of the car, on the seats and on the floor. A baby seat was also present. Chips, jerky, protein powder, and soft drinks were in the vehicle. The car was alone in the A lot of Camp 6. The drivers side glass was broken, and paw prints were seen on the passenger door.

Food was left in plain sight in the front and back of the car, on the seats and on the floor. A baby seat was also present. Chips, jerky, protein powder, and soft drinks were in the vehicle. The car was alone in the A lot of Camp 6. The drivers side glass was broken, and paw prints were seen on the passenger door.

Security was called about a bear breaking into the back of a pick-up truck with a camper shell in Tecoya. Security chased the bear out of the truck towards the clinic. Rangers Kulp and Hance arrived and chased the bear up Indian Canyon. Two cases of Ramen noodles were left in the bed of the pickup truck along with sunflower seeds and fishing supplies (unknown type of bait). The bear entered through the camper shell and obtained two Ramen noodle cups.

The visitors had been woken up at 5am by DNC Security. The bear broke into the passenger's side rear window. The dashboard was also torn into. The visitors had canola oil, baby powder, chap stick and wet wipes in the car. A backpack was found ripped open outside the car also. The bear obtained a Cliff Bar from the pack.

The visitors had been woken up at 5am by DNC Security. The bear broke into the passenger's side rear window. The dashboard was also torn into. The visitors had canola oil, baby powder, chap stick and wet wipes in the car. A backpack was found ripped open outside the car also. The bear obtained a Cliff Bar from the pack.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The visitors had left the driver's window down and the bear entered the car through the window. Sunscreen was left in the vehicle, but otherwise it looked clean. The driver's seat was torn and no other damage was observed.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The vehicle was found with the passenger's side front door frame pulled down and the window shattered. There were scratches and paw prints on the vehicle in and outside of the vehicle. DNC personnel informed Resource 91 about the vehicle. Inside the car was a baby seat with a wrapper in it, and a Trader Joe's Crunch Bar wrapper was in the passengers side front door. The owners of the vehicle were not located.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Resources 91 and 93 found the vehicle with bear prints all over the windows. The drivers side window was broken. No glass was around or in the car, as if it had been moved. There was an air freshener inside the vehicle. No other food or scented items were found in the car, but the car wasn't particularly clean. There may have been trash inside.

Resource units tracked Orange 66 into Curry New Housing. Upon arriving at the back loop, he saw the bear jump out of the back passenger's side window of the vehicle. 3 soda bottles were on the ground and a lot of food was present in the front and back of the car. One banger round was fired and the bear ran up into he talus.

Resource units tracked Orange 66 into Curry New Housing. Upon arriving at the back loop, he saw the bear jump out of the back passenger's side window of the vehicle. 3 soda bottles were on the ground and a lot of food was present in the front and back of the car. One banger round was fired and the bear ran up into he talus.

The vehicle owner reported that the only damage that he noticed was that the passenger's side front window was shattered. There was an orange drink, and old coffee cup with sunflower seeds in it, and an empty tea bottle present in the vehicle, as well as an empty can of tea in the bed of the truck.

Driver's side window was broken out but there was no damage to the car's door frame. The car contained a package of smoked turkey and all of the visitor's toiletries. The visitors said that no food was taken from the car because their friends in site 31 had scared the bear away before it could take anything from the car. There were paw prints on the door and the center console of the car.

The camper shell back window was busted out and the frame was broken. A screen on a sliding side window of the camper shell was ripped. There were paw prints all over the camper shell and inside the truck bed. No food was present, only tool boxes and oil were in the truck bed.

Visitors stated that they probably didn't latch their locker correctly. A very large bear with a white tag opened the locker and obtained marshmallows, beef jerky, and a few other small items. Security 84 was on scene very quickly and walked the bear across the river.
Bear broke passenger side window. No food was obtained by the bear, and no food was present in vehicle.

Many people on the beach attending to their food. The bear approached and the visitor's (a couple from Austria) were alarmed and left their food and belongings unattended. The bear took their 2 backpacks and opened them, damaging their belongings and obtaining some food (bread, cookies, and dried fruit.) No tags were observed.

Many people on the beach attending to their food. The bear approached and the visitor's (a couple from Austria) were alarmed and left their food and belongings unattended. The bear took their 2 backpacks and opened them, damaging their belongings and obtaining some food (bread, cookies, and dried fruit.) No tags were observed.
Rear passenger side window was broken, no damage done to door frame. No food was visible in vehicle, only sleeping rolls and some clothes.

The latches on the bear locker were hard to jam closed and the visitors must have not slammed it hard enough to latch properly. The items of food eaten were: parmesan cheese, loaf of bread, left over pizza, graham crackers, etc. The bear was scared away by rangers, but they didn't notice the food damage.

LocationDetail: Near Happy Isles Rd., north of 4th loop
IncidentDescription: 328 and R. Leahy were tracking bear #2394 after an alarm and were able to locate her on a pack that contained several bags of fruit snacks and an apple. Leahy and 328 chased bear towards Wilderness Lot.

LocationDetail: Near Happy Isles Rd., north of 4th loop
IncidentDescription: 328 and R. Leahy were tracking bear #2394 after an alarm and were able to locate her on a pack that contained several bags of fruit snacks and an apple. Leahy and 328 chased bear towards Wilderness Lot.
Bear lockers at Soda Springs trailhead were found with items removed. Items include: a candy bar wrapper, shampoo and conditioner. Trash was thrown away and items were put back into locker.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained a bag of dirty clothes from a vehicle by breaking the rear left window. No food was obtained. Rangers chased the bear out of the camp and across the small creek, eastward toward the Merced River.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained a bag of dirty clothes from a vehicle by breaking the rear left window. No food was obtained. Rangers chased the bear out of the camp and across the small creek, eastward toward the Merced River.
Sunflower seeds were left out in the middle console of vehicle. Window stripping was torn away from the upper portion of the driver's side window and paw prints were visible on the car.
The bear entered through the rear right passenger door window. There were miscellaneous items inside the vehicle. No other details provided by desk officer.
Bear was observed to be quick and smooth when opening a locker. Visitors chased the bear after a couple quick pictures of the bear eating. The locker was claimed to be latched by the visitors.
Bear entered right front passenger window. There were lots of miscellaneous clothes and heavy odors.

Driver front window was destroyed, there was some trash present and scattered inside the car. No food was apparent, but the car was messy. There may be a duplicate report taken by a desk officer, but this report is associated with bear property damage and contains a case number.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear entered through front passenger door window. There was a water bottle on the floor and a jacket in the back seat. Lotion was reportedly present as well as per security.

Bear was observed and locker was claimed to be latched properly. Bear slobber was observed on latch and a variety of food was obtained: fruit, donuts, and candy. The family had just arrived for a multiple night stay so they had lots of food.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear entered vehicle through left rear window. There was a baby seat in view as well as a Red Bull can.

LocationDetail: Across from Shuttle stop #10, Lower Falls
IncidentDescription: Visitor was hiking the upper falls trail and when he returned to vehicle after dark, he noticed scratches and drool on all 4 of the car's doors. No windows were broken, but the doors were damaged enough to need repair. The visitor claimed no food or scented items were in the car.

Visitors were woken by the noise of the bear searching for food. Visitors then watched the bear and recorded video. They grabbed some cow bells and scared the bear away into the woods. A bag of chips was noticed in the bear's mouth as it ran away.

V-42 arrived on the scene and the food was stored in the bear locker, but travel size container of face wash and empty diet coke bottle was inside canvas tent. Jen was told by bystanders that a visitor who witnessed the bear trying to break into the tent, had got the food out of the tent and placed it inside the food locker. The responsible party denied having left any food in the tent. Jen issued a verbal warning and had them put all scented items in the bear locker. The bear damaged the front door of the canvas sided tent.
Bear obtained a bag of granola bars.
The bear was seen in the early morning near site 31. The bear ate some cheerios that had been left out.

A bag of food was left out on the site and Green 75 ate most of the items. He was chased into the woods and he brought the bag with him and continued to eat. He was extremely difficult to chase off on food, even when hit with paintballs. Items eaten include fruit snacks, rice, wheat thins, cookies, and granola bars.

The locker was not all the way closed. The bear obtained tortillas and some bread. 3001 was extremely close on telemetry. The visitors never heard anything but their neighbors saw a bear in their locker.

Picnic table was covered with a tent-screen. There were board games sitting on the table and the bear ripped through the mesh screen, knocking over some of the board games. The bear then left due to there being no food present.

Following Green 75 on telemetry, bear was very close but out of direct sight. Could hear bear getting into locker and came around corner to see multiple items pulled out of locker: cooking oil, Luna bars, chips, etc. Bear ran away with some food items. Informed visitor at site that locker was not properly closed and continued to follow bear on telemetry.

We were tracking green 75 on telemetry behind Camp 4 and he had dragged a backpack up the hill and ripped it up. There were orange peels and zip lock bags that were ripped and scattered about. No nearby visitors claimed the pack. We paintballed the bear and he ran away.

We tracked 3001 from Curry Village to Upper Pines where we found him on a bag of flour that was dragged from site #24. We found a large amount of food left out in the campsite. Kulp responded and cited the visitor.
We tracked 2394 into NP and located her near the volunteer sites eating a bag of food that had been dragged from site #308. We fired hazing rounds at her and she released the pack.
Camp host saw bear eating and tearing into cooler, he then chased the bear off into the woods.
Camp host saw bear eating and tearing into cooler, he then chased the bear off into the woods.

Eggs, cheese, milk, half and half, cottage cheeses, sour cream, and watermelon were eaten by bear. The visitors saw the bear at about 3:30am in the morning in their bear locker. Several people were outside yelling and honking car horns at the bear. After the bear obtained food he left and came back once more to lick around the locker. The visitors yelled again and chased him off again. A cooler was damaged in the process. The visitors reported their bear locker was completely closed and claim that it is due to a dysfunctional locker. Resource 91 tried to open the locker and it was relatively easy.

Eggs, cheese, milk, half and half, cottage cheeses, sour cream, and watermelon were eaten by bear. The visitors saw the bear at about 3:30am in the morning in their bear locker. Several people were outside yelling and honking car horns at the bear. After the bear obtained food he left and came back once more to lick around the locker. The visitors yelled again and chased him off again. A cooler was damaged in the process. The visitors reported their bear locker was completely closed and claim that it is due to a dysfunctional locker. Resource 91 tried to open the locker and it was relatively easy.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear broke into vehicle through passenger window. Only item in car was a kitty litter deodorizer. Not much info, a hotline report.
While spotlighting we found 1278 eating out of a bear box. We chased him across the river and then through Lower Pines towards Stoneman Meadow.

Bear damaged shed causing $500 damage on July 12th (report taken). The bear returned on July 19th and pulled down side of shed again and bit into a box containing an air conditioner. No additional damage- already reported in previous incident. No food or attractants were stored inside the shed.
Food was stored in a cooler with visitors in the campsite. Bear walked into site and got into cooler.
Bear ripped off boards on building trying to gain entry into YI storage room that had food. Bear did not gain entry.
Bear got into watermelon, meat, and most of their locker. Visitors thought locker had been latched. Bear was at locker for 5 minutes and came back later. 2nd hand report from HK hosts.
Bear got food from an unclipped locker. The visitors "dinked a can" and bear left. Bear ran off with a bag of hamburger buns and a beer.

The visitors left their food unattended for approximately 3 minutes to brush their teeth. They came back and a bear was in their locker. It obtained a package of bagels and a box of Triscuits. The bear came back shortly after they scared it off but didn't obtain more food.

Bear entered residence through screen window and obtained food from refrigerator. Resident thought he closed window, but didn't latch it- although admits he could have forgotten to close it. Bear also ripped screen off door, but main door was closed. Several of the windows in that house don't latch. Bear obtained 1 lbs. butter, cherries, and tortillas.

Bear entered residence through screen window and obtained food from refrigerator. Resident thought he closed window, but didn't latch it- although admits he could have forgotten to close it. Bear also ripped screen off door, but main door was closed. Several of the windows in that house don't latch. Bear obtained 1 lbs. butter, cherries, and tortillas.

Individual had his back pack sitting approximately 10 feet from his location. The pack contained a camera, food, and other paperwork or documents. The bear grabbed the pack and ran away. The visitor tried to follow bear but couldn't keep up. Pack has not yet been located as of 11pm on 7-31-2010.

Individual had his back pack sitting approximately 10 feet from his location. The pack contained a camera, food, and other paperwork or documents. The bear grabbed the pack and ran away. The visitor tried to follow bear but couldn't keep up. Pack has not yet been located as of 11pm on 7-31-2010.

Individual had his back pack sitting approximately 10 feet from his location. The pack contained a camera, food, and other paperwork or documents. The bear grabbed the pack and ran away. The visitor tried to follow bear but couldn't keep up. Pack has not yet been located as of 11pm on 7-31-2010.
Visitor heard noise at 7am. Observed bear leaving camp with a day pack into the woods. She had pulled a bag of clothes from the tent. Pack contained 1 granola bar.
Visitor heard noise at 7am. Observed bear leaving camp with a day pack into the woods. She had pulled a bag of clothes from the tent. Pack contained 1 granola bar.

Responded to alarm in HK camp, used telemetry to ID and follow bear. Heard visitors yelling and ran toward site. Chased bear out of site and across road. Came back to log behind site and found sautéed onions, BBQ sauce, partial hamburger patty, and chili beans spread along log. LE V-42 responded also to inspect. Cleaned up and disposed of food/trash. Unknown who left food out.
No food obtained by bear. Bear paw prints evident on car. Molding around driver's side front and rear windows was damaged.

We responded to the North Pines alarm and found 2394 moving to the stables with a pack in her mouth. She dropped it when we chased her. We were unable to locate it's owner. Bear treed the next time we saw her.

We responded to the North Pines alarm and found 2394 moving to the stables with a pack in her mouth. She dropped it when we chased her. We were unable to locate it's owner. Bear treed the next time we saw her.
Duffle bag was found outside of vehicle containing cosmetics. Pills, cough drops, etc. Damage was done to right front passenger window and mirror.
Victim said locker was locked properly. The bear broke into locker and would not leave for 1/2 hour.

V 42 was called by Resource 92 to Curry Village for a bear incident. When V 42 arrived Resource 89 and 92 had already cleaned up the $5 worth of food that 3001 had obtained from #742. From the information V 42 received from the visitors, V 42 could conclude that the visitors did not properly lock their locker. The visitors received a verbal warning.

Blue 53 was found on food by a volunteer at the back of North Pines. It is unknown where the food came from. There was some zip lock bags that contained an unknown food and some maple syrup that was not consumed yet.
Between 15:00 and 17:00 a bear ripped into an un-occupied tent. There was no food or any other attractants in the tent. There was a large rip in the tent and a pole was broken in multiple places.

Bear bothering all campers along the trail at campsite. Bear was approaching people within arm's reach. People were cooking and had all food within arm's reach. The bear came up behind them and grabbed trail mix. Visitors chased bear away and bear came back multiple times during dinner and they kept chasing bear away. Bear was back in the morning being persistent until afternoon. People were yelling for 10 to 15 minutes straight.

Visitors heard a bear making noise at their locker and it got into it. Visitors were all yelling for a long time and were unable to scare it away. The pictures taken by visitor show a short, very large bear with a balding rear. The bear ate lots of food including lunchmeat.

Visitors heard a bear making noise at their locker and it got into it. Visitors were all yelling for a long time and were unable to scare it away. The pictures taken by visitor show a short, very large bear with a balding rear. The bear ate lots of food including lunchmeat.

Bear was not observed but claw and paw marks were present on the door and door handle. Door was either lightly closed, not latched, or bear opened the door. Dog food was scattered about and a Rubbermaid container that the dog food was in was moved. Bear obtained only dog food and no damage to the door or any other items was observed. Dog food was in 1-2 lbs. bag.

Large group of Boy Scouts (~18 people) left packs and bear canisters at LYV and hiked to Half Dome. One bear canister was left open but no food was obtained from it. Several packs had food trash and/ or smelly things within. 2 packs were damaged and food trash was strewn about. Doubtful that food was obtained. 2 LYV units saw bear after it left campsite and chased it away. Bear was blonde with a brown belly (possibly molting) and looked like a yearling or a 2 year old.

Bear ate a granola bar and some bread from a locker. Visitor thought they had closed the locker properly but they did not. The visitors did not hear anything and the locker had slobber on it. Bear #3520 was in the campground when we found the locker incident. No bear seen at locker.

While spotlighting through Lower Pines, we did telemetry and spotted 2394 eating food in site #22. The bear was eating from a jar containing noodles. We attempted to get hazing equipment but the bear vacated the premises with a quickness.
Bear damaged soft top of convertible. Prints and claw marks observed.
Food left in rear seat of car and window was broken out.

Unknown if locker was properly closed. Bear was in a group of 3. A large bear with a yellow tag opened the locker at site #207 and ate all the oranges inside (approx. 10) and left the skins. There were also Hershey chocolate bars (unknown #). 3 campers observed the incident in sites #207 and 208.

Unpacking from a day hike when a bear took pack from picnic table. Did not observe this but later found pack. About ten minutes later bear approached visitors as they were placing food in bear locker. Visitors were about 10 to 15 feet away as bear approached them. Visitors yelled and directed their flashlights to scare bear away. Bear stayed in place for about 30 seconds before slowly moving away.

Unpacking from a day hike when a bear took pack from picnic table. Did not observe this but later found pack. About ten minutes later bear approached visitors as they were placing food in bear locker. Visitors were about 10 to 15 feet away as bear approached them. Visitors yelled and directed their flashlights to scare bear away. Bear stayed in place for about 30 seconds before slowly moving away.
Bear got a bunch of food: 2 loaves of bread, graham crackers, marshmallows, Dorito's, and hot dog buns. Mike 11 heard yelling and responded and chased the bear off using one rubber slug.
Flats of peaches were left underneath the seats in vehicle along with granola bras, mints, and baby wipes.

Visitors in campsite and bear was in the next campsite and approached site with visitors. Visitors banged wood on the table to make noise. Bear locker was unlatched so as the bear still approached visitors retreated to their car. Bear went straight for the locker and grabbed 1 bag of chips, drug it off and cub began to eat the chips too. Bear left only after a log was thrown at it.

At 6:00 AM a bear (Blue 55) confronted an off duty LAPD officer. The visitor reported that the bear was aggressive and charged him. The officer fired his pistol into the ground to scare the bear. It ran to the neighboring campsite, and those campers chased it away holding a machete. The bear ran back toward the officer who discharged his gun into the air, which finally scared the bear away. Yosemite Law Enforcement later visited his site and impounded a cooler that was left out. Law Enforcement said that they would cite him for illegal discharge of his weapon.

A bear walked into campsite 119 as 5 people were present eating and cooking. The bear grabbed a plastic bin of food and ran across the road and ate it. The bear got two loaves of bread, hot dog buns, 2 boxes of graham crackers, marshmallows, and a bag of chips.

The bear was eating food from a cooler. The bear ate tortillas, shredded cheese, and four sticks of butter. The visitors yelled and chased the bear out of camp. The responding resources units saw the bear and continued to chase it.
The bear opened the locker and ate the food for ten minutes. The visitors were unable to chase the bear way as it at buns, candy, and chorizo.

The visitors reserved two sites for there visit. They just arrived and were setting up in one site when the bear obtained a loaf of bread from the open locker in their next site over. The bear was described as an adult and medium brown. The bear was not observed by NPS.
The bear dragged a bag of food trash into another site and at it while the visitors watched. The visitors did not attempt to chase the bear away.

The bear entered the house by ripping through a window screen because the window was left open by the residents. Resident said that she forgot to close that one window in the dining room. Once the bear entered the house it went to the pantry though the dining room. The bear got into garbage and various items. The bear left the house when residents turned the lights on. The bear took a large bag of pretzels and a Costco sized box of nutri-grain bars and ate every one in the woods. The resources unit recorded that 20 minutes after the incident, telemetry showed bear 3251 in the meadow just across from the house by Ranger Y. The resources unit could hear the bear walking, but could not make a visual. After yelling the bear would still not leave.

The bear entered the house by ripping through a window screen because the window was left open by the residents. Resident said that she forgot to close that one window in the dining room. Once the bear entered the house it went to the pantry though the dining room. The bear got into garbage and various items. The bear left the house when residents turned the lights on. The bear took a large bag of pretzels and a Costco sized box of nutri-grain bars and ate every one in the woods. The resources unit recorded that 20 minutes after the incident, telemetry showed bear 3251 in the meadow just across from the house by Ranger Y. The resources unit could hear the bear walking, but could not make a visual. After yelling the bear would still not leave.
The food was put in a pickup truck bed covered with a canvas camper shell. The bear was scared away after the camper shell was damaged by the bears attempt to get the food. No food was obtained.

Campers were in their site when a bear approached. The people were scared and hid in their car without closing their food locker. The bear ate food out of their locker which included sugar, nutella spread, uncooked sausage, marshmallows, and bread.

The neighbors in site 14 reported seeing the bear eating out of the locker in site 12. Visitors in site 12 fled that evening from fear of the bear according to the neighbors. Food was obtained which included a large bag of tortilla chips and other unknown items.

Visitor's food was stored in their locker, but it was improperly latched. The Ranger showed the visitors how to properly lock it. Visitors said that the bear was able to open the locker when it was locked, but they had done it wrong. Neighbors in site 14 also reported 2 sandwiches were eaten at site 12.
A bear got into the visitors tent while they were sleeping in the car. No food was in the tent. The tent poles were snapped and the tent had tears in it.

A family was sitting at a picnic table in site 424 when an untagged bear began to eat the food that was left on the picnic table. As the bear was eating the food, a male visitor tried to get the bear out of the campsite by hitting it with a roll of aluminum foil.

Food obtained by bear includes peanut butter, trail mix bars, pretzels, Asian crackers, and cheerios. The visitors claimed that they locked their locker properly. Resource 91 and resource 93 scared the bear across the river, but only after firing a screamer he slowly meandered across the river with a tub of peanut butter.

Visitors were inside their tent in campsite 41. Blue 55 entered campsite and took a cooler while visitors were nearby. The bear came back to the site and showed his teeth and charged the visitors. The bear left after all of the food was gone.
Campers left their bear locker open while sitting around their camp fire. The bear took their food and the visitors yelled at the bear. The bear obtained a bag of peanuts and shells.
Food was stored properly but a small amount of brownies were on table in site. Bear jumped on table with 1 camper present and took food.

Visitor was standing next to the food locker and heard foraging in the locker. Visitor looked thinking it was the neighbor and the bear took off with a nag of groceries. The visitors made noise and threw rocks at the bear while it was eating just outside of the campsite. At this time Resource 92 arrived at the campsite tracking the bear with telemetry and noticed the excitement. Res. 92 walked onto the scene and hazed the bear off the food and across the road using the paintball gun and yelling. The bear then showed up within 5 minutes after taking the report. The bear was hazed again using the paintball gun and yelling.

Hotdogs, chips, dried fruit, etc. were taken by a big bear. The locker was not closed properly. The visitor threw her shoe at the bear while he was in her locker and the bear charged the woman and took her other shoe out of her hand and took it back to the locker and continued eating. Many visitors were on scene yelling, dogs barking and one man used bear spray. The third time spraying the bear, it slowly wandered off. White 88 matched the behavioral characteristics of the report/ description.

Visitor left food sitting on front seat from day hike. The bear broke into the passenger side window and took 3 granola bars and trail mix. Person in next site over heard noise at approximately 04:30 and saw a sow with 2 cubs.

Visitor left food sitting on front seat from day hike. The bear broke into the passenger side window and took 3 granola bars and trail mix. Person in next site over heard noise at approximately 04:30 and saw a sow with 2 cubs.
Bear damaged left side passenger window (broken out). No signs of food taken.
People were eating breakfast and had oatmeal packets sitting next to them and slightly behind them. Bear snatched oatmeal and ran off.

Visitors were sitting around their campfire with their locker cracked open approximately 8-10 feet away. They heard a noise and a bear was in their locker. It grabbed a large bag of trail mix and ran across the creek and ate it all. The bear came back but they had closed their locker.
RP witnessed bears coming over to 3 people having lunch and tearing into the backpack of one of them.
Visitors sitting at picnic table with their locker open. Bear came into campsite and took a loaf of bread.
Blue 55 approached site at 18:00 while the visitors were at their picnic table. The visitors backed off their food and yelled but the bear snatched a loaf of bread and ran off.

Visitors were unable to fit all their food in their locker, so they left a cooler of food out while they went to the valley. The next site over observed the bear entering the site around 18:30 and consuming the contents of the cooler (fruits and fish.) The bear was positively identified as Blue 55 and was unresponsive to efforts to get him to leave the site.
A small dark bear with black legs was seen snatching a bag of trail mix from an occupied campsite.
Sow and cub ate apples from bear locker the 2 days later were seen at bathrooms at A73.

The visitors in site 48 heard their car window being broken into at 6:00 am. They positively identified Blue 55 as attempting to enter their car. They began yelling and the bear retreated into the woods. Apparently toiletries were stored in the vehicle and beef jerky and a can of coke were also observed.

The visitors in site 56 were sleeping in their tent when they heard a bear in their site. They heard the bear manipulating a secured bear canister that was on the ground next to their bear locker. They didn’t react because they assumed the bear couldn't get in. However, in the morning they realized the canister had been strategically penetrated at the locking mechanism and the content of ground coffee and Gatorade powder had been consumed.

The visitors in site 56 were sleeping in their tent when they heard a bear in their site. They heard the bear manipulating a secured bear canister that was on the ground next to their bear locker. They didn’t react because they assumed the bear couldn't get in. However, in the morning they realized the canister had been strategically penetrated at the locking mechanism and the content of ground coffee and Gatorade powder had been consumed.
Food in locker, stored improperly (unlatched.) Visitor chased bear and the sow challenged the visitor.

When I arrived at Upper Pines site #90, after getting a call from dispatch about a bear in the site, I observed white 88 in the locker. I hazed white 88 with 2 rubber slugs. He obtained 15 Nature Valley granola bars.

The residents were at home and had their kitchen door open with the screen closed. They heard a noise and ran over to see that the bear had popped the screen off. They chased it off. The bear did not gain entry or obtain food.
Bear entered vehicle through right front door window. There were miscellaneous items behind the seat.
Bear entered vehicle on driver's door. There were miscellaneous items in the vehicle and a small back pack was found on the ground outside the vehicle.

Bag of Lucky Charms, tangerines, bread crust and Capri Sun drinks were eaten by the bear. The bear was spotted in the pack full of food by R91 and R93. The bear was chased off by paintball gun and yelling and chasing. Telemetry was used to identify the bear as Blue 53.

At approximately 00:45 while on patrol in Upper Pines V42 got a report from a visitor who saw a green tagged bear eating out of locker #184. V42 contacted the visitors in site #184 who said they made sure the locker was closed. V42 checked the locker and found out it was broken. The top latch sticks so the visitors used a locker nearby that was empty. Informed Res. 85 about the broken locker.
The visitors were unloading food from their vehicle to their locker when Green 60 approached. They backed off their food and she grabbed a bag of hamburger buns.
Visitors were eating dinner and a bear snuck up behind them and grabbed the cooler off of the food storage locker. Bear took bread and a sandwich.
There was no food present in the car. The car was very clean. The damage was to the back window only.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The visitor says they put all food away but forgot a tube of "Fire Paste," a flammable fire starter.

The rear drivers side window was bent back about 8 inches, with the window glass intact. The bear did not gain entry into the vehicle. There were minimal scratches on the paint of the rear passenger's door. The car contained no food. There were utensils, an air freshener, and STP fuel additive in the vehicle, and nothing in the trunk.

The bear, White 88, ate one package of steaks, chorizo, one dozen eggs, and possibly two more steaks. The family was able to film the bear eating steaks out of the locker. The bear had first attempted to get into a nearby locker before successfully getting into the locker at site 166.

The visitor heard a clanking noise and came out of the screen section of their tent. They saw a bear in their locker. They yelled and the bear did not leave. Other campers yelled at the bear and it ran off with bread and donuts.

The campers were eating dinner when a bear came up and physically moved a camper with his head and ate his food (a bowl of noodles) out of the bowl with campers present at the table. They were actively eating when the bear took the food.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: A bear came through the campground and got a citronella candle (bucket candle). The bear was working its way through the campground.
The group was unpacking the van. About 20-30 yards from where the people were unpacking the van the bear took a pack and tore chocolate out of the pack.
The group was unpacking the van. About 20-30 yards from where the people were unpacking the van the bear took a pack and tore chocolate out of the pack.

Jewel, the Housekeeping camp host, heard scratching, and subsequently witnessed White 88 eating out of a locker. The visitor had triggered their car alarm to scare the bear, but to no avail. The bear, after eating, sauntered away towards the river. Jewel's negative conditioning efforts were in vain.

The bear pushed in the window on the laundry room door to enter the house. The glass did not break, but the window popped out. The bear got bread and tortillas from the counter in the kitchen. Resident came down and yelled at the bear and the bear left. However, the bear returned to the back porch within 10 minutes. Wildlife units arrived at that time and chased the bear across the school field.

The bear pushed in the window on the laundry room door to enter the house. The glass did not break, but the window popped out. The bear got bread and tortillas from the counter in the kitchen. Resident came down and yelled at the bear and the bear left. However, the bear returned to the back porch within 10 minutes. Wildlife units arrived at that time and chased the bear across the school field.

The wildlife unite never actually saw the bear, but chased his noise through the rocks. Yellow 92 had been in camp multiple times earlier though. The visitors reported seeing a small bear taking off with their pack, which was left out with food inside, when returning from the bathroom. They yelled and chased it into the rocks and found the bag later.

The wildlife unite never actually saw the bear, but chased his noise through the rocks. Yellow 92 had been in camp multiple times earlier though. The visitors reported seeing a small bear taking off with their pack, which was left out with food inside, when returning from the bathroom. They yelled and chased it into the rocks and found the bag later.

The wildlife unite never actually saw the bear, but chased his noise through the rocks. Yellow 92 had been in camp multiple times earlier though. The visitors reported seeing a small bear taking off with their pack, which was left out with food inside, when returning from the bathroom. They yelled and chased it into the rocks and found the bag later.

Nobody in camp would admit to leaving food out. There were multiple large parties still up, but the bear was seen near site five with a loaf of bread. The bear was difficult to scare and chase out of camp. It was back in camp after ten minutes.

Visitors reported to dispatch that there was a bear in their food locker. We saw the bear eating in the locker when we arrived. It was large with a bald spot on its butt. The bear ran off as soon as we arrived. The bear ate lots of food including chips, crackers, oatmeal, and Hershey's bars, etc. The bear ran off with something as well. A 184 unit thought he saw a white tag. Bear 3001 was strong on telemetry. The visitors believe that they did not operate the food locker properly.

The victim's food was stored in a bear box. Vehicle was broken into via the passenger window. I arrived on scene before the registered owner and found no food, no toiletries, and no garbage in the car. It appeared that the bear did not even enter the car.

A food locker was found open in the Wilderness Lot in the AM while on patrol. Various items had been taken out including jerky, juice, cookies, oatmeal, toiletries. The items were collected and thrown away in the dumpster.
The bear was found eating out of a food storage locker and was chased away. The visitors were in their tent during the event.

The bear entered the vehicle through the convertible top. Lots of items were in the vehicle such as suntan lotion, mints, clothes. This vehicle was entered by a bear on two occasions. The first bear damage was on 8/21/2010 and the second was on 8/23/2010. The vehicle was impounded by V-3. It is unknown if the bear got food.

There was no visible food in the vehicle. After chasing yellow 31 out of Upper Pines Campground, we followed her to the Wilderness Parking Lot and continued to chase her away. Checking the area of the lot she was in revealed a broken back left window of a vehicle. No food was obtained.

We were following bear 3251 with telemetry and she was in Camp 6 Parking. We found her next to a vehicle eating food that was dragged out of a vehicle she had broken into. She had eaten some Oreos and a bag of chips. The car also contained an ice chest, beef jerky, soda, and more chips. The drivers door frame was pulled down and the glass was broken. The door was bent apart where the window meets the door also.

We were following bear 3251 with telemetry and she was in Camp 6 Parking. We found her next to a vehicle eating food that was dragged out of a vehicle she had broken into. She had eaten some Oreos and a bag of chips. The car also contained an ice chest, beef jerky, soda, and more chips. The drivers door frame was pulled down and the glass was broken. The door was bent apart where the window meets the door also.
The bear obtained strawberries. The visitors admitted that they left food out.

Visitors heard a bear in their campsite and proceeded to bang pots and pans and yell, but the bear did not leave. The bear ate food and was in the site for approximately ten minutes. The bear ate fruit cups from a cooler and left claw marks on it.
An individuals backpack was reported stolen out of site E 18 TMCG. I found the pack 50 yards from the site. Food was left out in the pack. The pack was not stored properly.
An individuals backpack was reported stolen out of site E 18 TMCG. I found the pack 50 yards from the site. Food was left out in the pack. The pack was not stored properly.
We tracked bear 3001 with telemetry into the Wilderness Parking Lot. As we pulled into the parking lot we saw him and chased him off into the woods.

While the resource units were turning off the North Pines monitoring box they saw a mess of food in front of a locker that was open. A bear ate chicken, hotdogs, chips, dairy products, cliff bars, beer, juice, mayonnaise, salami, and rice.

The bear was observed eating in a food locker. The bear would not run as attempted to chase and paintballed him. We had to walk him out of the campground and his back legs seemed to have severe arthritis.
The visitors were in their campsite, about 50 feet from the locker which was open. The visitors saw the bear and scared it away, but the bear took food with it. The bear obtained pretzels.

While visitors were at the Devil's Elbow area near the beach, a bear stole their pack. The bear obtained chips from the pack. The visitors retrieved their pack, but it is unknown if it was damaged because this report is secondhand information.
The bear obtained a bag of chips.

A visitor told us he had just been in the wilderness lot and saw a locker that a bear had gotten into. He went over to put everything back in the locker. He was kneeling at the locker and looked up to see a bear a few feet from him at the other side of the locker. He quickly threw the doors closed . The bear stayed for a minute before moving away. The visitor said he then saw a second set of eye shine that he thought was a cub. The bear ate quite a bit of food-mostly dry backcountry meals.
People left their bowl of dog food out. The bear was laying down eating out of the bowl when we arrived. We chased the bear away.

A bear broke the window of a trailer that had no one inside of it. There was food inside, but it was stored properly with the windows up. The bear did not gain entry because the campers woke up and scared it.

We found a bear eating food in the parking lot. The bear ate 5 bananas, 2 oranges, and some past, along with some unidentifiable items. We chased the bear away. The food was on top of some fresh looking glass. Not sure if food was left out or if it was in a car that was broken into and the visitors left without reporting it.

A bear ripped into the grain bin at the stables. A couple of boards were broken off so that all of the grain could pour out. No bear was witnessed in the act, but when we arrived a sow and cub were nearby in the horse stables. The grain was cleaned up and taken out of the bin. Estimated $100 of grain was eaten.

A bear ripped into the grain bin at the stables. A couple of boards were broken off so that all of the grain could pour out. No bear was witnessed in the act, but when we arrived a sow and cub were nearby in the horse stables. The grain was cleaned up and taken out of the bin. Estimated $100 of grain was eaten.

A visitor had her locker open, went inside the tent for "just a second," and when she opened the door back up, Green 75 was in her locker. The bear ate a large bag of Cheetos and a couple of graham crackers.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The damage was to the left side drivers door and window.

I arrived at the site and a bear was eating a large zip lock bag of chili and food was strewn about everywhere. An open, overturned ice chest was nearly empty of food. I immediately chased the bear with the paintball gun to the west of the campground. I came back to the site and the man was packing food/trash back into the ice chest. The bear soon returned, I chased it again, this time with a banger round and paintballs. When I returned, the ice chest was still out, closed, and the man was gone. Law enforcement came out, and other family arrived. No citation was issued and communication was the main issue.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The damage was to the right side passengers window. There was an incense stick on the dash board.
The visitor did not realize that he had a few suckers under the seat of his car. The bear did not fully break into the car. The bear tore off the seal of the passenger window and scratched the door.

The visitor claimed that there was no food in the vehicle. The resource unit was unable to inspect the car because the visitor left a hotline message and was out of the park at the time it was reported. There was a bad cell connection when the resource unit phoned him. The visitor claimed that the drivers window was broken and that the drivers seat was damaged. The visitor seemed annoyed to answer questions (despite having reported the incident on the hotline and leaving his phone number).
Katie Wallace came out in the A.M. to find her car broken into by a bear. The back seats were torn apart.
A bear got into a food locker and ate bread, apples, and meat. The visitors claimed they closed the locker and the bear opened it. The bear left before we arrived.
DNC Security observed a bear outside the vehicle and saw hair and scratches on the door. No information about the owners of the vehicle could be obtained.
DNC Security observed a bear outside the vehicle and saw hair and scratches on the door. No information about the owners of the vehicle could be obtained.

I was responding to a Upper Pines east alarm when I observed 2 bears eating out of a cooler. The cooler was dragged from upper pines site 218. Green 75 and Green 81 were both eating out of the cooler. John got a hazing round on Green 81 shortly after. I got a banger round off and only Green 81 ran 20 yards and stopped.

Visitors said bear was eating their food for 20 minutes before we chased it away. Food obtained includes tortilla chips, marshmallows, chocolate chip cookies, cereal, trail mix, and more chocolate. I shot 3 rubber slugs at the bear. The visitors claimed that their locker was closed and latched properly.

The right front window was broken. The window was pulled out. The left front window was pulled out of track. There was a backpack left inside the vehicle, and possibly sodas in the front of the backpack. The owner of the vehicle said that there was sodas but he took them inside.

The food stored in the locker included 2 steaks, cheese, 4 eggs, milk, juice, etc. A ranger checked their locker at about 8:30PM the night before and it was secure. The bear was heard rapping on the locker, not very loud, at about 5:00AM. The visitors looked out and saw a large bear. The bear got into the locker. A large crowd of campers were yelling and banging on metal objects. When the desk officers arrived, the locker and bear were surrounded by campers. They were told to step back and the desk officers blew whistles. The bear ambled off slowly across Tenaya Creek.

As we chased blue 53 (3520) through upper pines we saw green 75 (3001) running with a soft black cooler. I chased the bear above the curry tent cabins and retrieved the cooler for impound. I hazed green 75 away from the cooler with the shotgun. We were unable to find the victims of the black cooler.

As we chased blue 53 (3520) through upper pines we saw green 75 (3001) running with a soft black cooler. I chased the bear above the curry tent cabins and retrieved the cooler for impound. I hazed green 75 away from the cooler with the shotgun. We were unable to find the victims of the black cooler.

Resource 85 tracked 3001 into Housekeeping Camp, where he grabbed a bag of food out of an open locker. The bear obtained cookies and nutella and two bags of chips. Resource units chased him across the road and fired 2 bangers. Stern verbal warnings were issued by Victor 42.
The bear pulled off the seals for both of the front doors. We did not see the bear actually on the car, but we chased Orange 73 out of the parking lot around that time.
Visitors were in the site eating and cooking. The bear entered the site and grabbed a bag of marshmallows out of a open food locker. The bear was described as dark brown.

Visitors got into camp and were unloading the car and had the box open when a bear came into their site. The bear only took a loaf of bread and the visitors scared it off. The alarm box did not go off, however Yellow 31 was picked up in the area. The visitors did not know if the bear had tags or a collar.
Resource 85 found the left rear window of the vehicle pushed in after chasing Orange 73 through the Camp 4 parking lot. The car smelled very strongly and was full of climbing equipment.
The bear got a loaf of bread while the visitors were in the site.

The bear entered the visitor's camp despite their yelling and banging. The bear circled camp and repeatedly tried to enter camp. The bear also went to other camps in the area. The visitors were "forced" out of their camp by the bear. They brought their food and canister with them, but they forgot about some Emergen-C in their first aid kit and some gum that was left out.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: A bear obtained a citronella candle. The visitor saw it walking off with the candle. The bear stopped and ate the candle and then walked off.
The visitor was at the water when the bear approached. He collected the items that were near him but the bear was already at his pack. The bear opened the pack and got out a bag of sunflower seeds.

The bear shredded a tent and kept coming into campsites. The bear did not respond to yelling or banging, it only went away when people threw things at it. This happened periodically throughout the night.
No description of the vehicle break in.
There was no food left in the car. The details of the damage were not included in the report.
On the left side above the rear tire about 6 inches there were scratches from a bear. The visitors were parked near the tent cabins. The bear did not enter the vehicle.

The passenger's side front window was broken, the back seat was torn up, and the driver's window frame was pulled out from the frame. The bear entered the vehicle to obtain some bird seed that was in a cage. It is unknown if other food was present, but numerous items were scattered in the front and back seats.

Resource units arrived at the tent to an open locker and a soft ice chest on the ground with slobber on it. There was some trash scattered about. We chased Green 75 from behind the tent where he was eating out of some wrappers.
Resource units arrived at the tent to find a locker open, a destroyed soft cooler, and food scattered about. They subsequently chased Green 75 from behind an adjacent tent, where he was eating.
Resource units arrived at the tent to find a locker open, a destroyed soft cooler, and food scattered about. They subsequently chased Green 75 from behind an adjacent tent, where he was eating.

Victor 34 called to relay the message that a bear had gotten into a cooler in the Wilderness Lot. When the resource unit arrived he observed the bear next to the cooler. The bear was a yearling. He paintballed the bear and it treed.

The campers in a nearby site saw the bear and began to yell at it. As the bear walked away it obtained food out of the locker in site 118 because they left their locker open. The party was about 10 feet away at their campfire. When they noticed the bear they scared it off.

The resident heard a noise in the early morning but didn’t see the bear. Upon waking later in the morning he saw that his storage tent had muddy paw prints and two large holes clawed in the sides. He alleges that there was no food or scented items inside.

The visitors were preparing dinner at their picnic tables and had food on top of the locker, about ten feet away. A bear came up and grabbed some food from behind the locker. The man decided to push a milk crate full of food onto the bear to scare him off. The bear grabbed a bag of marshmallows. They finally started yelling and it took off.
The visitor claimed that the locker was properly latched and that the bear opened it.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: There was a milk box and trash present in the car. The report does not have any information about the damage to the vehicle.
There were lots of miscellaneous items in the vehicle.
Resource units found damage to the camper shell and trailer of a motorcycle. No food was visible. The bear tore into a sleeping bag, tarp, and a foam pad. There were no bears on telemetry.
The bear grabbed an unattended bag of food and ran into the meadow to eat it.
The bear grabbed an unattended bag of food and ran into the meadow to eat it.
The right passenger window and door were damaged. There was one box of food in the vehicle that contained fruit. The bear ate several nectarines and one banana.
The visitors left a bag of food out in the campsite unattended for "just a minute." The bear ate cracker jacks. The bear was treed by rangers after it ate.
While visitors were unpacking their vehicle a bear entered their open vehicle and grabbed an entire calzone and ran off with it. Bear 2394 was strong on telemetry.

The visitors had food at two picnic tables in two different sites. The bear approached site G8, so the visitors immediately began yelling and banging pots. The bear moved off a little. The visitors began putting stuff in the bear lockers and while they were going back and forth from the tables, the bear grabbed a bag of brown sugar and walked off.

Resource units observed the bear with food in his mouth and they chased him out using a paintball gun and a banger. The visitors were next to their open locker and the bear was observed taking food out of it.
Resource units tracked 3001 into North Pines campground, where he was observed within 5 feet of people grabbing a sandwich. The bear was chased out of camp with 3 slugs.

The bear obtained a loaf of bread, hamburger buns, and other items. The visitors in the next campsite saw the bear walking through camp and going to the locker in the neighboring site. The visitor was packing his backpack with headphones on, about 5-10 feet from his bear locker. The bear began to eat food from the locker and the visitors started to yell and make noise. The bear left after a little bit. The cub was in a tree the whole time and never ate human food.

Resource units found a vehicle broken into in the Wilderness Lot. The passenger window was broken, as well as the passenger side mirror. The external cab brake light was also torn off. There were full bottles of sports drinks in the vehicle as well as trash. An unknown amount of food was obtained. No collared bears were in the immediate area when the resource units discovered the break in.

Resource units found a vehicle broken into in the Wilderness Lot. The passenger window was broken, as well as the passenger side mirror. The external cab brake light was also torn off. There were full bottles of sports drinks in the vehicle as well as trash. An unknown amount of food was obtained. No collared bears were in the immediate area when the resource units discovered the break in.
Visitors were cooking in their campsite when a bear entered. The bear took a container from their open locker, removed two loaves of bread and ran away.
No food, trash, or odors were observed in the car. Right passenger window was broken out.

Food was in the visitor's open locker when the bear got into the food. The bear walked away with a bag of food to a tree and ate it. Visitors closed the locker. The bear came back to sniff the closed locker. Campers banged pots and pans, but the bear continued to come close to the campers (within about 25 feet) which called out to the bear, and the bear moved out of the site.

Climbers left their haul bag at the base of the wall with food in it after discussing with other climbers nearby about proper food storage. They were assured by their neighbors that it was OK to leave food at the base. Climbers were fixing an upper pitch and saw a large, dark brown bear getting into their haul bag and their neighbors haul bag. The bear obtained some energy bars from the haul bag, bagels, cliff bars, and a tin of fruit and granola. Haul bag had a small tear in it. The climbers yelled, the bear looked up at them, ate some more, and then wandered off with a water bottle in it's mouth.
A phone message was left at the Wildlife Office that reported a bear that got food. The campsite and amount of food were unknown and the observer was from the Yosemite Conservancy.

Resources were spotlighting and found an open locker. Upon further inspection, they found a bag taken out of the locker, presumably by a bear because it was ripped open. A large tub of yogurt was empty laying on the ground. The visitors said that was all the bear got, and the rest of the locker was untouched. Resources saw Orange 85 approximately 5 minutes earlier about 100 yards away from this same site.

Sometime around three in the morning visitors heard a bear banging on their locker. When they looked they saw the bear eating food out of the locker. They yelled and blew an air horn, but the bear did not leave. The bear stopped eating and snarled at them as the visitors approached for a closer look and the bear. The bear ate for approximately 20 minutes until it had eaten everything. Finally the bear walked away.

Sometime between 1700 on 9/24/2010 and 0800 on 9/27/2010, a bear entered the Yosemite Day Care through and open rear window of a bathroom. The screen of the window was ripped. The bear obtained food from an upstairs and downstairs refrigerator. Cottage cheese, string cheese, and cream cheese was the only food taken according to Jen, a Day Care employee.

Sometime between 1700 on 9/24/2010 and 0800 on 9/27/2010, a bear entered the Yosemite Day Care through and open rear window of a bathroom. The screen of the window was ripped. The bear obtained food from an upstairs and downstairs refrigerator. Cottage cheese, string cheese, and cream cheese was the only food taken according to Jen, a Day Care employee.

The visitor was laying down next to his tent with his head against a rope bag. He is positive that he bag contained no food, and had not contained any food all week. He opened his eyes and saw a bear head in his face. He tried to stay still while it sniffed him, then it swatted him in the face. He rolled over and started yelling and the bear went away. He had a scratch to the bridge of his nose and his lower right eyelid was bleeding. He was taken to the clinic by a friend. Nobody got a very good look at the bear, but he said it wasn't very tall. The scratches were not very long, but they were pretty substantial and were bleeding quite a bit.

A visitor returned to their tent cabin and said that they must not have shut the locker correctly before she went inside. The visitors heard rustling and a bear was in their locker. It pulled out the ice chest and ate blueberries, strawberries, and some beef jerky. They scared the bear away by yelling and banging things.
Cookies were left in a child's backpack overnight. The bear tore the pack open and ate the cookies.
Cookies were left in a child's backpack overnight. The bear tore the pack open and ate the cookies.

Visitors left their locker improperly latched and the bear ate orange juice, bread, milk, and a small amount of peanut butter and trail mix. The bear was on food when we came up to the site. The bear treed when we shot paintballs at it.

Locker was improperly locked by an unknown person. M. Smith (a neighbor SAR member) woke to a rustling around 0700, but went back to sleep. He again woke up at 0745, looked out, and saw bear 3098 in E. Aardal's food locker. M. Smith went out and tried to chase the bear away with rocks thrown from about 35 feet and hit her multiple times. The bear did not mover. M. Smith then used a slingshot to scare her away from the open locker. She eventually left after many rocks hit her. She allowed M. Smith to get within 15 feet while he was trying to haze her. The bear obtained oats, pasta, buckwheat flower, and oatmeal from the locker. The bear returned within 20 minutes; M. Smith then hit her again with the slingshot. Later that morning, at an unknown time, the bear returned and obtained a forgotten chocolate bar from a tent. She also ripped into a pack which had nothing in it.

Locker was improperly locked by an unknown person. M. Smith (a neighbor SAR member) woke to a rustling around 0700, but went back to sleep. He again woke up at 0745, looked out, and saw bear 3098 in E. Aardal's food locker. M. Smith went out and tried to chase the bear away with rocks thrown from about 35 feet and hit her multiple times. The bear did not mover. M. Smith then used a slingshot to scare her away from the open locker. She eventually left after many rocks hit her. She allowed M. Smith to get within 15 feet while he was trying to haze her. The bear obtained oats, pasta, buckwheat flower, and oatmeal from the locker. The bear returned within 20 minutes; M. Smith then hit her again with the slingshot. Later that morning, at an unknown time, the bear returned and obtained a forgotten chocolate bar from a tent. She also ripped into a pack which had nothing in it.

Locker was improperly locked by an unknown person. M. Smith (a neighbor SAR member) woke to a rustling around 0700, but went back to sleep. He again woke up at 0745, looked out, and saw bear 3098 in E. Aardal's food locker. M. Smith went out and tried to chase the bear away with rocks thrown from about 35 feet and hit her multiple times. The bear did not mover. M. Smith then used a slingshot to scare her away from the open locker. She eventually left after many rocks hit her. She allowed M. Smith to get within 15 feet while he was trying to haze her. The bear obtained oats, pasta, buckwheat flower, and oatmeal from the locker. The bear returned within 20 minutes; M. Smith then hit her again with the slingshot. Later that morning, at an unknown time, the bear returned and obtained a forgotten chocolate bar from a tent. She also ripped into a pack which had nothing in it.

Climbers put food in a tree while they climbed on Central Pillar of Frenzy. A bear climbed the tree to get their pack when they were a couple of pitches up. No damage was done to the pack. The bear obtained a bagel, trail mix, and an apple. Climbers yelled, but the bear did not care. The bear ate everything and left.
Victim opened the food locker, but did not close it properly.

The window to the kitchen was left open and the bear pushed the screen out. The only food obtained was about 15 pounds of chocolate chips. There were various foods stored in this room, but only the chocolate chips were obtained. Paw prints were present on the wall next to and under the window. Front paws were three and a half to four inches in width and the same in length. The workers forgot to shut the window after using the building or kitchen.

The window to the kitchen was left open and the bear pushed the screen out. The only food obtained was about 15 pounds of chocolate chips. There were various foods stored in this room, but only the chocolate chips were obtained. Paw prints were present on the wall next to and under the window. Front paws were three and a half to four inches in width and the same in length. The workers forgot to shut the window after using the building or kitchen.
The visitor was sitting within arms reach of their food when a bear came up behind them. The bear came within two feet of the visitors and took a bag of chips.
The bear was at the base of Central Pillar of Frenzy where some climbers left their packs with food. Climbers were about 300 feet off the ground climbing when the incident occurred.
The bear was at the base of Central Pillar of Frenzy where some climbers left their packs with food. Climbers were about 300 feet off the ground climbing when the incident occurred.

This record was taken through second-hand reports. The visitors had left by the time the incident was reported. However, their neighbors reported waking up at night to see a bear in their locker eating everything. The bear finished eating all the food in approximately 10 minutes. They described it as big and difficult to scare off.

Resources saw bear 3524 up the hill from site #23 in Camp 4 with a plastic jug in it's mouth. The jug looked like protein powder. The bear did not move until they sprinted toward it and fired paintballs. The bear returned to site 35 less than 10 minutes later.
Visitors were about 10 feet from the bear locker when the bear got into the locker. The visitor clapped at the bear which did not move. The bear obtained two V8 juices and cocoa powder.

Wildlife units arrived at campsite to find a black North Face back pack emptied of its contents including peanut butter, jelly, and Doritos potato chips. The bear ate the peanut butter and chips. The bear was spotted and hazed minutes before the pack was found.

Followed bear 3001 on telemetry, and found him behind a site on food. Spotlighted the bear and chased him across the road to Yosemite Lodge Annex. Resources continued to follow the bear with telemetry which did not re-enter the campground. Unknown site or reason for food being left out. Food included: oatmeal packets, multivitamins, candy, tea bags, sweetened drink mix, etc.
Wildlife units entered Wilderness Parking Lot and found trucks back door to flat bed shell pulled down in half. No food was present, but there were paw prints all over the back end of the vehicle.
Visitor believes locker closed correctly and checked again before incident. Bear obtained half a loaf of bread, 1 jar of mixed nuts, half a stick of butter, and some berries.
Bear pulled vent cover off of the camper trailer, exposing refrigerator and water heater vents.

A light colored bear tore a corner at a window on a canvas tent and disturbed items within reach of the window opening. No damage was done to guest property, and there was only minor damage to the tent. The bear possibly obtained a small amount of food. A torn zip lock baggie was found next to the tent containing cookie crumbs.

The bear obtained bagel bites, black bean burgers, cinnamon of a cabinet, and berries out of the freezer. The bear entered through the back door. It ripped off the screen, popped off the bottom of a sliding window and broke the top part of the window. The door window was not left open or unlatched. The bear got into the freezer only, not the refrigerator.

The bear obtained bagel bites, black bean burgers, cinnamon of a cabinet, and berries out of the freezer. The bear entered through the back door. It ripped off the screen, popped off the bottom of a sliding window and broke the top part of the window. The door window was not left open or unlatched. The bear got into the freezer only, not the refrigerator.

Visitors were in their campsite making dinner when they saw the bear walking around and immediately started putting food away into their storage locker. The bear started coming towards their site so the visitors started making noise by banging pots and pans together. The individual in the site said the bear did not react to him making noise and continued walking directly towards the open bear locker. The bear could not be chased off the food and took an entire grocery bag out of the locker to eat.
Individuals went to bed and did not latch their locker properly. They also left drinks and trash out in their site. Citation was issued to individuals.

Visitors were just sitting down to eat and had left their locker open. Shortly after they heard a rustling and a bear was in their locker. It ran off with a large nylon bag containing food. The bear first went up a tree with the food before running into the woods with it. This information is second-hand from a nearby site. They were unsure of exactly which site the food came from and I was unable to contact the responsible party.

There was no food left in the visitor's tent. In the middle of the night the visitor woke up because on of his tent poles was inverted. He says a bear jumped on his tent. There were two holes indented on either side of the pole. A bear did not obtain food, however, the previous night a bear did obtain food from the tent without damaging it.

Resources were doing a walk through of Camp 4 and spotlighted a bear on food behind campsites. The bear ran off after chasing and yelling, but took a sack with food items with it. Food included: mini Snicker bars, a Cliff bar, an Odwalla bar, etc. Visitors could not positively identify a bear which had an orange tag. Bear did not have a collar. Unknown site where the food was from. Bear did not run far and was seen 5 minutes later at the edge of the road and was chased off again.
The bear attempted to enter through the convertible top of a vehicle. The vehicle received a food warning at 10:45 PM by John.

The visitors left a backpack with food inside of it out in their campsite. The bear tore into the bag and ate the food. It then came back to their site two more times. Resources chased it off and the bear disappeared.

The visitors left a backpack with food inside of it out in their campsite. The bear tore into the bag and ate the food. It then came back to their site two more times. Resources chased it off and the bear disappeared.

Visitor slept in an open bivy sack with his backpack next to him. He emptied the pack of food except for several small candies and a wrapper that he forgot in a small pocket. At about 0005 hours, he awoke to a noise nearby. He yelled at the bear and then saw the bear right next to him with the backpack. The bear took a step back, paused, and then swatted the visitor in the head with its claw, causing a laceration. The bear then ran off with the pack. The visitor found the pack in the morning. The victim was unable to identify any details of the animal's appearance. Pictures were taken of the victim's wounds which consisted of one 2.5 inch long laceration in the middle of his forehead that appeared to be about 0.25 inches deep at the hairline.
The bear entered through the utility shell and ripped the door from lock hasp and hinge.
Bear damaged right side passenger window and door. Food observed in vehicle included: shaving cream, kettle corn, dried apricots, and a soft-shell cooler.

Resource 92 was doing telemetry for Orange 85 on Happy Isles Road just past the Wilderness Parking Lot when he noticed frantic flashlights and yelling. Orange 85 took off into the campground and treed. The bear obtained popcorn that the visitors had put in their open trash can and stated they didn't realize food trash also needed to be stored.

Bear 3524 had been chased out ten minutes prior to the incident. The bear circled right back into the campground and took a backpack that was left out. The pack had food in it and the bear was reluctant to run. It finally took off into the brush West of the Yosemite Lodge Annex. No one was around to claim the pack.

Bear 3524 had been chased out ten minutes prior to the incident. The bear circled right back into the campground and took a backpack that was left out. The pack had food in it and the bear was reluctant to run. It finally took off into the brush West of the Yosemite Lodge Annex. No one was around to claim the pack.

The visitors were at their picnic table with their locker open about ten feet away. The bear snuck up and took a bag of hot dog buns from the top of the locker. The visitors did not have a very good description but said it may have had a blue tag. They yelled and the bear ran away.

Campground host Ruth stumbled upon an open food locker and found pretzel wrappers and gum. When wildlife units arrived on scene, bear 3001 was moderate on telemetry and was subsequently chased out of Upper Pines East shortly after the incident.

The visitors didn't understand how to operate their locker. They thought it automatically locked when it was shut. The bear pulled out an ice chest and dragged off a few items. The bear ran away when wildlife units commenced chase.

Wildlife units witnessed the bear crossing Happy Isles road from Upper Pines to the wilderness lot. The bear had something in his mouth. Wildlife units chased the bear into the brush and did not locate the food.
Visitor was at his campfire and heard a bear at his locker. The visitor saw the bear and ran to his car, leaving behind half a sandwich, which the bear obtained.

Visitor believed he closed the locker properly but the bear got in somehow. The bear had pulled everything out of the locker and was just starting to eat. He ran away as soon as wildlife units arrived, but didn't go far. The bear ate a bunch of grapes, milk, bananas, and some dry food.
