Multiple visitors heard a commotion but didn’t think to do anything about it.
The bear obtained dried eggs, protein bars, and oatmeal from a locker thought to have been properly locked.
3001 walked within 5 feet of visitors and snatched their food before running down the road to get into 3 more sites. The food obtained was beef jerky.

The visitors claimed they were grilling within 3-5 feet of their bear box when 3001 entered their site and went straight for the bear locker. The visitors screamed and hit their car alarm but the bear continued to the box and began eating from it. They said the bear was looking up at them but was unwilling to leave for about 5 minutes. The bear obtained stove top stuffing, several granola bars, and chips. The bear ran across the road where wildlife units chased him off of the food.

Visitors left sandwich and a couple other attractants in their vehicle. Bear ripped up the passenger seat, and caused damage to the driver's seat as well. No damage to the outside or body of the vehicle. Did not get vehicle license plate.

The resident had forgotten a bag of fruits in the vehicle. She had looked for the bag previously and had missed the bag in the car. Both the driver's and passenger's door were bent and pulled back about 8-10 inches, but both windows were intact. There were scratches to the paint of both doors, and the weather stripping on both doors, inside and out, were pulled off. The bear gained entry by using the door handle on the driver's door. Food obtained included a butternut squash, some apples, and a pomegranate.

The resident had forgotten a bag of fruits in the vehicle. She had looked for the bag previously and had missed the bag in the car. Both the driver's and passenger's door were bent and pulled back about 8-10 inches, but both windows were intact. There were scratches to the paint of both doors, and the weather stripping on both doors, inside and out, were pulled off. The bear gained entry by using the door handle on the driver's door. Food obtained included a butternut squash, some apples, and a pomegranate.

Mr. Deputy said he had no food in his vehicle. The bear broke in through the passenger door, which has happened before in Yosemite with the same vehicle. He said he had no food in his vehicle either time and the bear did not obtain food. He did not report it for two weeks because he was afraid he would get a ticket.

A large party at site 12 awoke at 3:00 AM to a bear pulling an ice chest out of their locker. The bear ate 1 1/2 pounds of cheese, 1 pound of sausage, 3 pounds of lunchmeat, and 1 pound of pot roast. The visitors shined their flashlights at the bear, which did not move. They left the campsite, notified the camp host of the incident, and returned 1/2 hour later to find the bear still eating food. They shone their car headlights at the bear and it left. The bear returned to immediate area around 4:30 to 5:30 AM. The camp host reported to have found the bear eating some of the food it had gotten from site 12 later in the night at site 47. The host then shined a mag light at the bear and scared it into the forest.

A large party at site 12 awoke at 3:00 AM to a bear pulling an ice chest out of their locker. The bear ate 1 1/2 pounds of cheese, 1 pound of sausage, 3 pounds of lunchmeat, and 1 pound of pot roast. The visitors shined their flashlights at the bear, which did not move. They left the campsite, notified the camp host of the incident, and returned 1/2 hour later to find the bear still eating food. They shone their car headlights at the bear and it left. The bear returned to immediate area around 4:30 to 5:30 AM. The camp host reported to have found the bear eating some of the food it had gotten from site 12 later in the night at site 47. The host then shined a mag light at the bear and scared it into the forest.

Camp 4 host 330 was making the first round through camp when some campers said that their friend who had already left Camp 4 chased a bear across the road that had a backpack in tow. The same person went across the street the next day and retrieved the bag. They reporting party had no further bear details and no further contact with the person who had chased the bear. The retrieved bag was damaged by a few holes ripped in the bottom of the bag, but no food or remnants were found in the bag.

Car was void of food or scented items according to camper. The vehicle looked clean upon discovery, and no trash was found in the immediate vicinity of the car. The visitor requested a copy of this report.

Bear tore off a piece of trim on trunk of vehicle, gnawed the weather stripping around the window frame, and left scratches on the hood of the vehicle. Visitors claimed nothing was scented in the car, but admitted to possibly having drinks (beer or Gatorade) in the trunk of the vehicle. The car was not present for Bissmeyer to look at.

The visitor was sitting 3 feet from his open locker with his back turned to it. The bear approached and snatched his tote containing food and ran as soon as the visitor noticed and yelled. Resources quickly found a pile of food in the woods across the Happy Isles road after firing a banger round. Resources hear the bear running away through the woods. Bear 3001 was very loud on telemetry.

The visitor was sitting 3 feet from his open locker with his back turned to it. The bear approached and snatched his tote containing food and ran as soon as the visitor noticed and yelled. Resources quickly found a pile of food in the woods across the Happy Isles road after firing a banger round. Resources hear the bear running away through the woods. Bear 3001 was very loud on telemetry.

LE ranger, Hotel 22, relayed a second-hand report of a car break-in early in the morning on 10/27/2010 at the Camp 4 parking lot. She subsequently saw the vehicle with broken glass at El Cap Picnic Area parking. At 2200 hours, on the same day, while walking through Camp 4, a gentleman contacted a Camp 4 host about having witnessed the break-in and described how he chased the bear off food and away from the car. The bear was eating blueberries. The vehicle was a small pick-up of unknown make or model.

LE ranger, Hotel 22, relayed a second-hand report of a car break-in early in the morning on 10/27/2010 at the Camp 4 parking lot. She subsequently saw the vehicle with broken glass at El Cap Picnic Area parking. At 2200 hours, on the same day, while walking through Camp 4, a gentleman contacted a Camp 4 host about having witnessed the break-in and described how he chased the bear off food and away from the car. The bear was eating blueberries. The vehicle was a small pick-up of unknown make or model.

The rear driver's side window was broken out. The resident (of DNC Boystown housing) claimed that no food was in the car and that they had cleaned it out well. This information was secondhand and the resident did not want to be contacted for the report.

Car was void of food according to campers. The vehicle looked clean upon discovery. However, there was lots of gear and backpacks with possible residual scents. Campers requested a copy of this report.

LocationDetail: Behind Lewis residence or Fazio's garage
IncidentDescription: Resources tracked bear 3565 into lower NPS housing where they found the bear on a bucket of food that had been pulled out of an unsecured garage unit. The bear obtained brownie mix, syrup, and backpacking food. The bear returned within minutes and was hazed with 3 rubber slugs. R. Lewis informed them that the garage is used by the Fazio's who confirmed the origin of the food that was obtained from the bucket labeled "Fazio".
There was no food inside the vehicle. Vehicle was cleaned when owner arrived.
The vehicle's door was opened by a bear. No food was present, but there was a child's car seat.
Driver park vehicle in Camp 4 parking lot after dark and forgot to take out some items. He returned to the vehicle the next morning to find it had been broken into. No food was obtained by the bear.
A bear was ripping boards off a garage in Lower Housing and was chased off by resource 84. No food was stored in the garage.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: This car was broken into two days in a row. The owners got the door replaced after the first incident, parked the car in the same lot, and their car was broken into again. No food or trash was present either time but there was an empty cooler in the trunk and they had spilled soup in the back seat at some point. In the first incident the bear bent the drivers' door down and scratched at the back seat, and just bent the replaced door down in the second incident.
Bear ripped down door frame and ripped seats. Unable to see any food inside vehicle. Owner claims no food was stored inside.

All of the visitor's food was in the locker. The bear was seen on the box and the bear opened it and began eating the food. The visitors did not see how the bear opened the locker. However the top latch on the locker was sticky and did not go all the way up to make contact with the hole in the frame on the top. The bear most likely pulled and was able to force it open because of the top latch.

the bear obtained ham, bacon, hamburger patties and pork chops. The visitors were approximately 3 feet from their locker and the bear approached them. When the bear was close the visitor ran away and the bear took a cooler of meat and ate it.

The bear entered the car through the unlocked door with the door handle. There was no damage to the car. Car contained two baby seats . The were child's cups pulled out of the car and chewed on. Damage was to cups only. Bear did not damage seats/ interior of the car.

The locker was too frozen to shut properly so the visitors just left it swung shut. The bear came and got a full bag of groceries. They shone their lights on it and it ran away. They rigged up the locker with webbing and a small carabiner to close it. The bear returned about thirty minutes later and pried the box open again. He obtained only a bag of trash and we chased him away. Leahy found his stash and chased him up a tree.
The bear pushed a hole through the top of a storage container mounted to a trailer, possibly checking for food. It didn't find any and left.

One window in the front of the house was left open and a bear got in. Multiple screens were ripped on the outside of the house. The bear ate dog food, apples etc. The residents did not hear the bear at all, so it ate a lot of food.
There was trash and baby seats inside the vehicle. The bear did very minor damage to a door frame. It just bent the hinge.
Visitors were climbing on El Cap and left snacks in a backpack hanging from a tree. The bear destroyed the backpack.
Visitors were climbing on El Cap and left snacks in a backpack hanging from a tree. The bear destroyed the backpack.

Visitors were in the site with food on their table as they were packing up to leave. Bear did not respond to their yelling and car alarm. The bear took a small bag of groceries off the table and ran off. I chased the bear off while she had a box of graham crackers and ginger snaps in her mouth.
Locker was left open with people in the site. People were approximately 10 feet from locker. Green 60 ran in and grabbed a jar of peanuts and ran off.
Bear pulled driver door frame down and broke window. Owners claim no food was stored inside.
Empty coffee cup left inside vehicle. Bear broke left rear passenger window and door frame pulled down.
Bear bent rear hatch on the camper shell and caused minor scratches to the tailgate. Food was observed outside the vehicle on the ground and in the interior of the vehicle.
A bear was trying to break into a bear locker.
A bear was trying to break into a bear locker.
The bear broke the drivers side window.

Visitor was sleeping on the ground and woke up to an animal swatting his face. The visitor had three distinct claw marks on his face but refused medical treatment. There is limited information on this incident but the visitor claimed not to see the animal and said all of his food was stored in the bear locker.
Vehicle was found with the passenger's window broken. Unable to see food in vehicle and unable to locate the owners of the vehicle.
Bear broke into storage closet located on the south side of Ma' Curry Bungalow 2. No food was obtained only damage to visitor's padlock.
Bear pulled out driver door frame and ripped off molding around door and windshield. Bear did not gain access to the vehicle.

The vehicle involved had all the items stored properly in the food storage box. The adjacent site (#38) had improperly stored items, which were most likely the cause of the attractant to the area. Site #38 had left out a backpack with a food reward for the bear (peanuts). The vehicle in site #39 had damage to the soft top door and rear window. The convertible Jeep Wrangler Passenger side mirror also was damaged. The estimated damage to the Jeep Wrangler was approximately $1000. The party in site #39 heard the bear in their site at 2:30 am.

This report is second-hand from the visitors in an adjacent site because no one in site #38 spoke English. They had apparently left food out and a bear obtained at least peanuts from a pack, but probably more. They cleaned it up before anyone could see what food was obtained.
Will from security saw a Toyota rocking, he went knocking and bear came out. Visitors had improperly stored their food because, "Bears hibernate, right?"

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: A bear attempted to fain entry to Dave's Subaru Forrester. It pulled all of the molding off of the outside windows, but failed to get in. There were mint toothpicks inside the car.

Bear broke passenger side rear window and then pulled out the bottom of the door/window frame. Bear tore into climbing backpack and pulled out toiletries. The molding on the driver's side door was also damaged.

Bear broke passenger side rear window and then pulled out the bottom of the door/window frame. Bear tore into climbing backpack and pulled out toiletries. The molding on the driver's side door was also damaged.
Bear broke out passenger side rear window. Lots of luggage and gear inside the car.

Tarbutton and Yerman forgot to remove tea and lotions from car. Bear broke in between 1930 and 0800 through the back driver side door. Scented items were under many other things. Visitors thought they had removed all food and scented items to their bear box.

Bear obtained a bag of oranges, toothpaste, and donuts from a locker visitors left open. Visitors left locker in front of their cabin open and briefly went inside. They heard a noise outside, opened the door, and a bear was eating food. The girls closed the door, and the bear eventually left after eating. Visitors were a group of teenage girls and were very scared, consequently their story was slightly incoherent.

Bear obtained bagels, hamburger meat, chips, deli meat, bread, and candy. Visitor was going out in the early morning to use the bathroom. Visitor saw a bear on food at his locker. Visitor yelled, and the bear immediately ran away and didn’t come back. Visitors cleaned up the food. Visitors swore the locker was latched properly, three people checked it. Visitors heard some noise at the locker, but weren't sure if it was a bear. This was a boy scout group.

The visitor had thought they properly locked the bear locker. They walked 15 ft. away, turned around, and saw the bear in the locker. The bear grabbed a bag of food and ran off with it. There was approximately $30 worth of food inside. The visitor did not see if the bear had a tag or radio collar.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: No food in vehicle, air freshener near storing wheel.

The bear obtained M&M's, chocolate bars, butter, jerky, and edamame. The visitors were sleeping in their tent and heard a loud noise and heard a bear in their locker. They shined a light on the bear and saw it take a pack that was in the locker. The visitor got out and found the pack away from the site. The bear had pulled items out of the pack. The visitor put the items away and reinforced the locker by putting a hanger through the rings, and went back to sleep. The bear came back and got back into the locker and took garbage. The visitor then moved their food to a new locker because they claim the latches on their locker were broken. The bear came back once more but did not obtain any food.

The bear obtained M&M's, chocolate bars, butter, jerky, and edamame. The visitors were sleeping in their tent and heard a loud noise and heard a bear in their locker. They shined a light on the bear and saw it take a pack that was in the locker. The visitor got out and found the pack away from the site. The bear had pulled items out of the pack. The visitor put the items away and reinforced the locker by putting a hanger through the rings, and went back to sleep. The bear came back and got back into the locker and took garbage. The visitor then moved their food to a new locker because they claim the latches on their locker were broken. The bear came back once more but did not obtain any food.

A partial case of water and Gatorade was left in the vehicle. The bear did not obtain any of the drinks. The bear pried open the back passenger door frame, no bear was seen. There were also paw prints on nearby cars.
There was no damage to the vehicle. The bear had opened the unlocked door using the handle and pulled out an empty re-usable grocery sack from behind the seat.

The resident spilled stew outside the cabin after dinner on 3/22. The bear rooted around in the snow for the stew, and then tried to get into the cabin. The bear broke the screen and the lower portion of the door. The bear did not gain entry into the cabin. The bear returned to the spot in the early morning hours but did not cause any further damage.
A visitor was getting something from their locker and a bear charged their locker and grabbed a loaf of bread as the visitor backed away. This is a secondhand report.

The bear approached the campsite while the visitors were in it. The food locker was open, but the visitors were less than ten feet away from it. Both men in the site became afraid of the bear and backed away from the site. The bear went to the locker and grabbed and sandwich and ran away.

LocationDetail: Near the 2nd loop of Upper Pines
IncidentDescription: A ripped pack was found along the side of the Happy Isles road between the second loop of Upper Pines and the road in some bushes. There was lots of food garbage in the immediate area that had been ripped into. The pack was destroyed. The origin of the pack is unknown. Based on the damage to the pack it is assumed a bear had gotten it.

LocationDetail: Near the 2nd loop of Upper Pines
IncidentDescription: A ripped pack was found along the side of the Happy Isles road between the second loop of Upper Pines and the road in some bushes. There was lots of food garbage in the immediate area that had been ripped into. The pack was destroyed. The origin of the pack is unknown. Based on the damage to the pack it is assumed a bear had gotten it.

The bear obtained peanut butter, lunch meat, and cheese, among other items. The visitors saw a bear at their locker and scared it away. They re-latched the locker and cleaned up. This is a secondhand report from the camp host.

Resources 876 and 877 were following 3081 on telemetry. They heard yelling near the back loop of Curry Tent Cabins. The visitor witnessed a bear (unknown tags) pull out their cooler and packer from their locker and run off with the pack. 876 pursued the bear into the talus behind Curry Village and hazed it with paintballs. The bear took off with the packs. No bears were detected on telemetry in the immediate area. The bear got a pack with a sandwich, apple, orange, and chips. The cooler items that were taken included lunch meat, cheese, and mayonnaise. The visitors yelled at the bear but could not identify if it had tags or a collar. Visitors were staying in Curry with their class. The students "swore" the locker was closed, but could not be sure who was last in the locker, and if it was completely closed.

Resources 876 and 877 were following 3081 on telemetry. They heard yelling near the back loop of Curry Tent Cabins. The visitor witnessed a bear (unknown tags) pull out their cooler and packer from their locker and run off with the pack. 876 pursued the bear into the talus behind Curry Village and hazed it with paintballs. The bear took off with the packs. No bears were detected on telemetry in the immediate area. The bear got a pack with a sandwich, apple, orange, and chips. The cooler items that were taken included lunch meat, cheese, and mayonnaise. The visitors yelled at the bear but could not identify if it had tags or a collar. Visitors were staying in Curry with their class. The students "swore" the locker was closed, but could not be sure who was last in the locker, and if it was completely closed.

Visitors remember latching their locker before going to bed. Visitors heard a bear and were afraid to get out of their tent. They heard it eating chips and thought their neighbors had left chips out. Visitors also smelled the bear outside their tent because it was eating close to the visitor's head. Bear obtained a box of cereal and 3-5 granola bars. The locker was possibly improperly latched, but the visitors could not be sure.

Campers were in their tent. They heard a bear at the locker. They did not come out of the tent, but hear the bear bang on the door of the locker. There were chairs inside the locker. The bear pulled the chairs out of the locker and damaged them. The bear also damaged Upper Pines #27 locker as well. Campers said the locker was locked, and that they had put a "lock" on it. The bear got into the locker. Opened the doors, and bit with lock still on the door.

Campers were in their tent. They heard a bear at the locker. They did not come out of the tent, but hear the bear bang on the door of the locker. There were chairs inside the locker. The bear pulled the chairs out of the locker and damaged them. The bear also damaged Upper Pines #27 locker as well. Campers said the locker was locked, and that they had put a "lock" on it. The bear got into the locker. Opened the doors, and bit with lock still on the door.

Visitors thought they had closed the locker properly, but admitted to assuming they had not secured it. The bear got into an ice chest that was stored in the locker. He ate apple pie, bread, and bacon. The bear set off a car alarm and then left. Visitors re-secured the locker and the bear did not come back.

Report is second-hand. The bear box was being loaded while the car was being unloaded. A bear ran off with a significant amount of food. The bear reportedly got into a cooler from the food locker. The bear was reportedly never actually seen. Much of their food was gone.
A small amount of food was obtained from a food locker. Visitors claim that the locker was properly latched. No apparent damage to food locker.
A bear got a large amount of food from a locker. Unknown details to incident.
A bear charged a backpacker's tent at night 3 times. The next day the bear started to "track us" for 2 miles between Laurel Lake and Miguel Meadows.

LocationDetail: JMT 1/2 mile from the LYV junction
IncidentDescription: 881 responded to a call from dispatch about a bear not leaving camper's site. They were just off the JMT about a half mile from LYV junction. When rangers got there, the bear was at the campsite on the camper's pack with food in it. 881 chased the bear off the food, it's cub treed approximately feet from food while the sow ran away and came back to a tree 40 feet from the cub. Everyone was moved back to a tree 25 ft. from the cub. Everyone turned off their headlamps and remained silent to try to get the cub to come down. V-52 walked above to get possible hazing rounds. When the cub came down, V-52 fired 2 hazing rounds above the bears and 881 chased them off. The sow was extremely stressed. The campers called 911 prior to our arrival, and said the bear wouldn't leave their camp. Dispatch told them to leave their food, so the campers threw their Cliff Bars and a pack of gum away from them. The bear ate them and then rummaged through their packs when the campers abandoned their site. Campers were cited for out-of-bounds camping. Bear also got into a toiletry bag and damaged the tent and pack while obtaining food.

IncidentDescription: 881 responded to a call from dispatch about a bear not leaving camper's site. They were just off the JMT about a half mile from LYV junction. The bear ate them and then rummaged through their packs when the campers abandoned their site. Campers were cited for out-of-bounds camping. Second-hand report of Yellow 48 scaring picnickers off food near Yosemite Village.

Visitors left a backpack out containing food and a bear ripped into it. The bear obtained 2 oranges and possibly some jerky. There were other food items left out in the site that were not obtained including a bucket full of food and a cooler of drinks. The visitors watched the bear get the pack.

Visitors left a backpack out containing food and a bear ripped into it. The bear obtained 2 oranges and possibly some jerky. There were other food items left out in the site that were not obtained including a bucket full of food and a cooler of drinks. The visitors watched the bear get the pack.
Bear broke into residence, opened refrigerator, and ate all the food. No building damage occurred, and the door was unlocked.

At approximately 0200 hours, Talbott awoke to the site and sounds of Green 60 ripping through his bug tent which is connected to his main tent. Talbott confirmed the bear to be Green 60 as he hazed her away. Approximately 30 minutes later, Talbott awoke again and observed Green 60 again inside the bug tent licking the ground. Talbott again hazed her away.
Green 60 approached a group and took food off the picnic table and was chased off. People in the area were about 10 feet away from the food when it happened.

A visitor in campsite 238 found a backpack that was ripped into that had a plastic bag with crumbs in it about 15 yards into the forest from his campsite. The visitor explained that the backpack was not there when he left for a walk around 5:00am, and appeared when he returned around 7:00 am. Later that morning the owner of the backpack claimed to have forgotten about Powerbar in the ripped pocket of the pack. The bear obtained a Powerbar and trash.

A visitor in campsite 238 found a backpack that was ripped into that had a plastic bag with crumbs in it about 15 yards into the forest from his campsite. The visitor explained that the backpack was not there when he left for a walk around 5:00am, and appeared when he returned around 7:00 am. Later that morning the owner of the backpack claimed to have forgotten about Powerbar in the ripped pocket of the pack. The bear obtained a Powerbar and trash.
Green 60 approached the SAR site and grabbed a bag of food briefly with her mouth. People scared her off who were right there.

Visitor was sitting in a chair in the dark when he noticed a bear about 5-10 ft. away. He had spilled fajitas on the ground there and not picked them up yet. The bear ate it all. The visitor yelled and the bear came closer to him, he picked up a shovel and eventually the bear left, but it was hard for him to scare it away.
Victim related he had opened the bear box for breakfast. The bear approached him. The victim yelled and walked away from the bear box. Bear went into the bear box.

LocationDetail: bike path across from Housekeeping Camp crosswalk
IncidentDescription: A family was eating lunch on the roadside/bike path across the road from Housekeeping Camp. A man was reported to be feeding Yellow 15. Unknown how much food was obtained by the bear. LE wrote a citation. The LE said he chased Y15 into the woods, but she came right back. We chased her with paintballs and she treed immediately. The bear treed a total of 3 times, and finally wildlife rangers succeeded in chasing her into the woods. The bear was hit several times with paintballs.

Canister was 5 feet from camp site and fully closed. The visitor checked the canister multiple times before going to sleep. Bear came at midnight to the site and knocked canister down hill. The bear proceeded to bash the container loudly for 3 hours. All noise subsided. Visitor found the container in the morning 150 yards from the campsite. All consumables had been eaten. The medical kit, sunblock, and chapstick had been damaged.

Canister was 5 feet from camp site and fully closed. The visitor checked the canister multiple times before going to sleep. Bear came at midnight to the site and knocked canister down hill. The bear proceeded to bash the container loudly for 3 hours. All noise subsided. Visitor found the container in the morning 150 yards from the campsite. All consumables had been eaten. The medical kit, sunblock, and chapstick had been damaged.

LocationDetail: Top of Snow Creek switchbacks on the peninsula.
IncidentDescription: I camped on the West side of Snow Creek. I cooked food near the end of the peninsula and set up my bivy and tarp tent about 100 meters from where I was cooking. I set up in a meadow with a good view of Half Dome and then went back to cooking. I cooked food and locked down my bear canister. I put it next to a large rock near the campfire. I am 100% sure if it was locked and all scented items were within. I walked the short distance to my bivy and found my bivy had been ripped out from under my tarp and was lying in the meadow. I had a thermarest, a foam pad, and my sleeping bag in the bivy. The bottom of the bivy had been torn open and the thermarest had been torn out and a large hole bitten into it. I had no food near the bivy. In the morning I woke up and my bear canister was gone. I looked for 5 hours trying to find it. My only theory is that the bear rolled it off the cliff. This would be pretty impressive as there were all kinds of bushes, shrubs, and logs in the way.

During an evening star gazing event at the Glacier Point amphitheater, the visitor was sitting next to her pack with taffy and other food in it. The bear approached the woman and huffed, then took the pack. Other visitors yelled at the bear once they saw what happened and the bear dropped the pack but took the package of taffy with it. The woman recovered the pack not damaged. Woman did not get a positive ID on the bear but 3037 was active and strong on telemetry. The bear was hazed with a shotgun while yelling and chasing.
Food was left in the car.
Food was left in the car.
The left side passenger window was broken and there were paw prints on both sides of vehicle.

The Big Time gathering were utilizing an old coffin style bear locker at the Valley maintenance lot. The locker was left open overnight and an animal dragged food out of the locker and scattered it around the immediate area. Incident was likely not caused by a bear due to the amount of food not eaten. The two Native Americans I spoke to insinuated the incident was likely caused by some kids who didn’t latch the locker. The three of us cleaned up the mess and threw it away.

LocationDetail: Between the fire building and community hall.
IncidentDescription: We found bear 2255 on food via telemetry. He made haste into the thicket when we approached. He obtained several MRE meals. We discovered that a box of MRE's had been left out beside the fire trucks. A cooler of Gatorade was also out, but nothing was taken. Blue 1 ate two MRE meals which we were able to calculate the calories from. We got a couple fire boys to put the cooler away. They thought the MRE's were left out by forestry.

The visitor had rented a "Bear Keg" model bear canister from REI. The visitor claimed he was 100% sure it was locked properly. The bear ignored the two other models, the "bear vault" and the "bear cache" and went straight for the REI model. The bear reportedly picked it up and threw it.

LocationDetail: Granite Ct. in old El Portal
IncidentDescription: Resident brought in all but one bag of groceries from their vehicle. The bear broke in to the passenger window. The bear ate 3/4 of a bag of flour and syrup. There were some scratches on the outside paint and poop in the car.

LocationDetail: Granite Ct. in old El Portal
IncidentDescription: Resident brought in all but one bag of groceries from their vehicle. The bear broke in to the passenger window. The bear ate 3/4 of a bag of flour and syrup. There were some scratches on the outside paint and poop in the car.
The right front window and door were damaged to the point of allowing entry. Lots of miscellaneous items inside the car.

Bear got into a large tub with a lid on it and obtained 2 granola bars before being chased off by Tango 31 and 874. There were other food items in the tub and other small food trash and scented items around the site.
Jeff Redding - 619-306-1039 (RP) reported a soft-sided cooler in woods near campsite. The cooler was ripped open, food was on the ground near the cooler.
Jeff Redding - 619-306-1039 (RP) reported a soft-sided cooler in woods near campsite. The cooler was ripped open, food was on the ground near the cooler.

A bear approached the visitor's tent at night and grabbed a backpack out of the tent's vestibule (enclosed portion of the tent's porch). The visitor yelled and screamed at the bear. They went out of the tent and told the bear to go away. The backpack was not damaged, however, the tent had been ripped from the bears mouth. There was no food present in their tent or backpack. All of the visitor's food was in their bear canister.

LocationDetail: at junction of Clouds Rest and Sunrise
IncidentDescription: There were several second hand reports that a bear had ripped into three separate backpacks and got at least one can of tuna. The packs all belonged to a boy scout group. By the time the ranger got to the scene the group had left. The description of food storage on the report is a canister, however, due to the written description I labeled it as "backpack" for food storage method.

LocationDetail: at junction of Clouds Rest and Sunrise
IncidentDescription: There were several second hand reports that a bear had ripped into three separate backpacks and got at least one can of tuna. The packs all belonged to a boy scout group. By the time the ranger got to the scene the group had left. The description of food storage on the report is a canister, however, due to the written description I labeled it as "backpack" for food storage method.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: A bear came into camp late at night and smashed the visitor's BBQ grill.

At 04:00, resident heard noise in kitchen of house. Found food opened and strewn all across floor and outside of front porch. Bear was never observed by resident. Bear apparently entered house by turning door knob of his front door. I observed a paw mark on the floor and it doesn't look like a large bear. Bear also did the same thing at 01:40 at 2612 West Bruce (about one block away).

Pike, Alpha 50, ate dinner and left window open in house and went back out on patrol. He noticed his window was open and screen and blinds were damaged when he came home around 4-5AM. Definite signs of a bear: paw prints, scat, around house. Screen and blinds were torn by a bear. Pike stated that he forgot to close the window and that food, trash, and odors were present in the house. Unknown which bear attempted to break in, but 3565 was at the softball field earlier in the evening on 8/4/11. We will be trapping near his home.

Pike, Alpha 50, ate dinner and left window open in house and went back out on patrol. He noticed his window was open and screen and blinds were damaged when he came home around 4-5AM. Definite signs of a bear: paw prints, scat, around house. Screen and blinds were torn by a bear. Pike stated that he forgot to close the window and that food, trash, and odors were present in the house. Unknown which bear attempted to break in, but 3565 was at the softball field earlier in the evening on 8/4/11. We will be trapping near his home.
Bear took a pack with a wrapper and orange peel. The pack was recovered with a hole in it. The bear took the pack while the visitors were in their site.

We responded to an alarm in Upper Pines East and got 3081 on telemetry and followed bear into campsite. Observed bear on pack and hazed bear off pack. Pack contained a packet of string cheese and trash. The pack was damaged by the bear and we determined that the campsite it came from because additional baggies of food were found with trail mix in them in site. Contacted visitor and he confirmed that the pack belonged to his party. Took report and continued to track bear since it just crossed Happy Isles Rd.

We responded to an alarm in Upper Pines East and got 3081 on telemetry and followed bear into campsite. Observed bear on pack and hazed bear off pack. Pack contained a packet of string cheese and trash. The pack was damaged by the bear and we determined that the campsite it came from because additional baggies of food were found with trail mix in them in site. Contacted visitor and he confirmed that the pack belonged to his party. Took report and continued to track bear since it just crossed Happy Isles Rd.

About 5AM the visitors heard an animal on top of their RV. They heard the animal trying to open the vent on the top. They then saw the bear poke his nose through the vent and they scared it off the top of their RV. The visitors from the same site camping in a tent nearby, saw the bear run off into the woods. It appeared to have a yellow or orange tag. The bear bent the vent but the visitors said they bent it back with no permanent damage.

Some items were stored in food locker, others were in the hard sided camper that attaches to the bed of their pick-up truck. Visitor claims that the bear shook the camper between the hours of 23:00- 01:30 on the evening of the 22nd. The trailer shook twice. She was the only person of 3 individuals in the trailer that woke up. The next day the visitor found the bottom trim of the passenger side of the camper to be partially torn off. There were no other signs of a bear on the camper shell or the surrounding area at the time the report was taken.

Joe at Glacier Point called and left a message saying that a bear went through several food lockers in the parking lot during the night. One of the lockers was not properly locked. Another (GP5) he thought needed maintenance because it was difficult to operate. The bear obtained food- presumably from multiple lockers. It is unknown who Joe is and he did not leave a phone number.
Green 60 got a lunch from a worker but did not get to eat it. Worker retrieved lunch, unsure how it was gotten back.

Bear broke driver's window and pulled off the rubber around window. Small scratches on door. Baby car booster seat and water bottles inside. Lots of muddy prints all over door and interior of vehicle. There were cub prints at the bottom of the door and larger prints higher. Nose prints on rear window, driver's side.

873 + 876 were following bear 3081 through North Pines and into the stables housing area (DNC). Bear was observed briefly, then it ran off. Next we came upon a residence (#7) whose door was wide open with the light on and no one home. Food was spilled on the floor of the cabin. We followed O85 closely on telemetry but never saw him again. Behind another cabin (tent) we found crackers that were 1/2 eaten with saliva on them and another plastic bag of trash. The bear left the area and headed into the woods where we couldn't follow. The DNC area was littered with garbage and alcohol containers and recycling, many bear attractants.

A Big Oak Flat interpretation ranger called the bear hotline with a second hand report of visitors feeding a young bear beef jerky. The visitor was not contacted by NPS. The bear obtained food. The description of the bear was not given, besides it being a young bear.

While turning off boxes, we saw a pack lying in the middle of the road in the 2nd loop of Upper Pines. O85 was observed and strong on telemetry in camp at the time, but no one observed the bear that got into the pack. The pack contained a 1/2 of a turkey and tomato sandwich. 1/4 of the sandwich was eaten and the front of the pack was ripped into. The bear also got into vitamins, sunscreen, and "Off" wipes that were left out in the site. We verbally warned the visitor in the site. 874 and 878 were chasing and hazing O85 in Upper Pines as we recorded this incident.

While turning off boxes, we saw a pack lying in the middle of the road in the 2nd loop of Upper Pines. O85 was observed and strong on telemetry in camp at the time, but no one observed the bear that got into the pack. The pack contained a 1/2 of a turkey and tomato sandwich. 1/4 of the sandwich was eaten and the front of the pack was ripped into. The bear also got into vitamins, sunscreen, and "Off" wipes that were left out in the site. We verbally warned the visitor in the site. 874 and 878 were chasing and hazing O85 in Upper Pines as we recorded this incident.
An NPS employee witnessed the bear sitting by a tree at Manure Pile eating what looked like Capri Suns.

The bear got food from visitors while they were preparing for a hike. The visitors gave a report while in LYV about a bear getting a container of peanut butter while they were in the Valley. The visitors left their food unattended for a short time and a bear came into their camp and took a container of peanut butter. Neighboring visitors chased the bear and the bear dropped the container. The bear did not get any food, but damaged the food container and it was discarded.

A bear was chased out of Backpacker's Campground by wildlife technician, Jonathan Lewis, using two shotgun hazing rounds (one bean bag and one rubber slug). The bear ran out of the camp between large trees at the edge of camp. On its way out it ran over a camper sleeping on the ground behind the trees. His face was exposed, and was cut by the bear's claw. A single cut occurred between his eye and nose. The camper had been out of sight, slightly down hill and out of view when the bear was hazed. Despite the injury the camper was in good spirits. An ambulance responded and suggested that the camper went to Mariposa to see a doctor. The wound ended up being superficial and healed. Also see additional supplemental reports from Ryan Leahy and Jonathan Lewis for more detail.

Visitor was hiking in a group. The group had finished dinner and had put their bear cans in a small pile a good distance away from their site. They went back to put one more item in and saw the bear dragging off one of their cans that had a soft cover on it. They blew horns to scare the bear which ran off with 2 cubs. K. Ehler showed up on scene two minutes later. The bear was in the bushes when she racked the shotgun and the bear ran away and did not return that night. In the morning the bear can was found about 300 feet from the victims. The food was stored correctly.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Visitor's were warned by 873. They went to bed after double checking their bear cans and packs. At 23:45 they awoke to noise in their campsite. They jumped out of bed yelling and shining lights. Visitor reported seeing two sets of eyes in the woods. One set were very low to the ground. The bears left shortly after. In the morning they discovered they were missing a pack. They searched the area where the sow and cub were and found it lying there. The pack was unharmed but a small container of Deet was chewed through and the bag containing it was slobbery.

Bear entered vehicle from the left rear window. Food, candy, spam, chips, and purse were found outside of vehicle. An apple was not eaten. There was a noticeable odor of food. The purse was placed back into the vehicle.

Bear entered vehicle from the left rear window. Food, candy, spam, chips, and purse were found outside of vehicle. An apple was not eaten. There was a noticeable odor of food. The purse was placed back into the vehicle.

Two small bags of peanuts were stored in the center console, concealed by a hat. The window was cracked about 1/4'' on the driver and passenger side. The bear broke the passenger front window and entered the vehicle. Paw prints were found in the back of the vehicle as well, but there was no other evident damage besides the window glass.

Two small bags of peanuts were stored in the center console, concealed by a hat. The window was cracked about 1/4'' on the driver and passenger side. The bear broke the passenger front window and entered the vehicle. Paw prints were found in the back of the vehicle as well, but there was no other evident damage besides the window glass.
There was damage to the window molding on the right side, right side rearview mirror, and scratches on the body paint. No entry was made.
There was damage to the exterior rear window wiper, paw prints on top of vehicle and on hood. No entry was made. There were two baby seats and a stroller inside.

Owner of pickup left bags of household trash in bed of truck. Upon arrival, Orange 36 was pulling trash from truck. The owner was watching from 10-15 feet away. Leslie Davis scared the bear away and advised owner to back away. Owner didn't move and said that she knew about bears from living in Tahoe. Ranger R. Lewis issued owner a citation for improper food storage. Dwayne and Leslie Davis cleaned the area and followed the bear into the rocks. 873 was notified and requested law enforcement to handle the citation.
Pike arrived home at 0300 and observed that the kitchen window blinds and screen were torn open. The bear did not enter the residence. Food was stored properly.
Pike arrived home at 0300 and observed that the kitchen window blinds and screen were torn open. The bear did not enter the residence. Food was stored properly.
A bear ripped apart the hammock belonging to the bear host, Jose. There was no food present.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Visitors checking in to site B5 reported trash in the site from previous campers. The camp host saved the garbage which appears to have been damaged by a bear. A small soft sided cooler was ripped into. The contents included food trash, a lime, and two soda cans. Both soda cans had punctures and large tears. Method of food storage is unknown as is the time of the incident.

Visitor was at their picnic table getting ready to put food away when they noticed a bear at their locker. They yelled and ran to the car to find items to throw. The bear took a loaf of bread and ran up the hill. Some of the bread was recovered by the camp host.
Bear obtained Top Ramen noodles. Visitors watched bear eat food. Eventually the bear was chased off and visitors got some of their food back.

The visitor's locker was improperly latched. The bear got into 2 bags of Doritos, cashews, rice, food trash, peaches, etc. There was also a significant amount of food in their vehicle. E. Shiell and J. Bristol were tracking the bear with telemetry when they came across 3591 eating a bag of cashews. They chased her out of the campground and came back to find the bear locker open with a trail of food and trash that the bear had gotten. Law enforcement was contacted and a citation given.

Bear 3591 was observed between the camp and the road in C-loop eating a package of cookies. She had obtained 1-2 cookies before bear team members chased her out and cleaned up the other cookies. Crew was unable to locate the site that the food had come from. The crew had been chasing the bear from the store and the gas station when she grabbed the cookies.

The building had an open window and the screen was not attached. A resident opened the front door and the bear jumped out of the window. The bear obtained ramen noodles, flour, and possibly some noodles. She bit into a pack of rice but did not eat any, and dropped the pack of noodles on her way out of the window. We secured the window with a board and left a note for residents to close the window. The resident chased the bear up the hill. Probably Blue 51.

Incident happened early in the morning. Bear entered the cafeteria through the side door, but there were no signs of forced entry. Counselors admitted that door must've been left unsecured. The bear ate many items and spilled other things on the floor. This is a second hand report, the original witness was the camp cook. Bear ate: peanut butter tub, a banana, cereal, 3 loaves of cinnamon raisin bread. Counselors repeatedly stated that in past years they never had bear problems with any buildings.

Bear 3586 was exiting the Chowchilla room and eating a small white item when I appeared on scene. He ran away with the item when hazed. No signs of forced entry to the building which was occupied when the bear entered. Occupants of the room were questioned and admitted to leaving the door open to the room. Bear obtained a bag of trail mix.

2nd hand report: screen door bent, visitors were occupying the cabin at the time the damage occurred. Bear did not permanent damage to the screen door. The door was bent back into shape. No other information is known.

Bear bent aluminum screen door. No permanent damage done to door. Building was unoccupied- when visitors came back they realized the bear had tried to get in. Happened sometime before dark and visitors reported incident before 8:30PM. The bear did not gain access to the building.

Sliding glass door was left open on accident, and bear ripped through the screen door while they were sleeping (victim and her roommate). The roommate woke up and saw that less than a 1/4 of their food was eaten from fridge: chocolate chips, frosting, chips, fruit, and a protein shake. The roommate saw the bear exiting through the screen door, she got close enough to touch the bear. She yelled at the bear and it jumped the railing of the house. It then turned around and she yelled at it again and then it ran away. They took photos of the trash and food it left. RP's phone # is (805)720-8403. The RP did not think she saw a tag or collar on the bear. The bear came back again a second time and pushed in the kitchen screen as well as her bedroom screen. The bear was not observed the 2nd time and did not enter.

Sliding glass door was left open on accident, and bear ripped through the screen door while they were sleeping (victim and her roommate). The roommate woke up and saw that less than a 1/4 of their food was eaten from fridge: chocolate chips, frosting, chips, fruit, and a protein shake. The roommate saw the bear exiting through the screen door, she got close enough to touch the bear. She yelled at the bear and it jumped the railing of the house. It then turned around and she yelled at it again and then it ran away. They took photos of the trash and food it left. RP's phone # is (805)720-8403. The RP did not think she saw a tag or collar on the bear. The bear came back again a second time and pushed in the kitchen screen as well as her bedroom screen. The bear was not observed the 2nd time and did not enter.

The NPS packer stated that while unpacking mules at night, a bear grabbed a peanut butter jar from the front step of the tack room. The employees were approximately ten feet away inside unloading things. When they went back outside they saw Blue 51 eating peanut butter. They chased her up a tree and then called dispatch.

Trail crew and stables workers were outside near the stables, away from their food. The bear obtained chips and chocolate from a backpack, as well as tortillas and peanut butter from an unknown area. The residents later treed the bear.

Visitors were loading their food storage locker, moving food back and forth from their vehicle. They turned around from their vehicle and noticed a bear eating inside their locker. The visitors chased the bear out of the site. The visitors did not notice a tag, but the bear technicians arrived on the scene about ten minutes after the incident and saw Blue 51 walking back towards the site. When the bear noticed the technicians, she ran back towards the woods. Jono chased after the bear and shot paintballs at her.
Bear Orange 85 obtained trail mix and sandwich from a backpack that was left out.
Bear approached visitors at picnic table and took soy milk from the table. Visitors were 10 feet away and yelled at the bear.

Visitors came to the snack stand and reported to a concession employee that a bear was currently eating food on top of a van behind the Happy Isles Snack Shack. The employee called the bear hotline and reported the information she heard. She later told wildlife that there was a cooler and other food items on top of the van. She did not personally see the bear eating the food, but the visitor who did see it, claimed they watched the bear actively obtain food.

Visitors were preparing breakfast and reported to be a foot away from the locker when the bear came in and got a bag of chips. Multiple people confirmed that the food was stored and monitored properly. They had a report similar to many others: the bear waited until they turned their back and swept in for the kill.

Visitors were arriving and were actively loading their locker with food from their car when they noticed Blue 51 inside their car. The bear made off with a loaf of bread. It treed in the campsite and we hazed it intermittently in the tree to negatively condition it's behavior. The people were 5-10 feet from their open car when they saw the bear in the front seat.

LocationDetail: 2 miles East of Chinquapin on Glacier Point Road
IncidentDescription: Received a report of a cub hit by vehicle on Glacier Point Road. W-2 responded and was on scene after incident occurred. W2 reported that cub was hit in the West-bound lane and the sow and second cub were still in the area. While the Whiskey units controlled traffic, the sow came up the hill (North side of the road) and dragged the cub back downhill. The Whiskey unit was certain that the cub was dead. Upon inspection of the area, we noticed broken tail-light material and glass on the road where the cub was hit. W2 confirmed the wreckage was recent and from this accident.

Visitor was unloading vehicle, they left the door open while moving supplies into their camp. Visitors turned around and the bear was exiting their vehicle with a bag of food. Blue 51 climbed a tree and consumed the food in the tree.

LocationDetail: Trail crew parking lot in ranger camp
IncidentDescription: Food was stored in a backpack that was forgotten in a truck bed. Bear obtained a granola bar.
Bear came into campsite while visitors were close to the bear locker. Bear got half a loaf of bread. Visitors tossed rocks at the bear.

The visitors went to the bathroom and say they must not have properly latched their locker. Their neighbors heard the bear eating food sometime around midnight and tried unsuccessfully to scare the bear away. Unknown exactly what items were eaten but they included" red vines, other assorted candy bars, and some granola bars. Some food was recovered.

A stargazer and his family had a cooler near them. The bear came up and grabbed crackers out. The bear then left but shortly returned. The man attempted to scare the bear away with loud noises but the bear showed no fear.

The vehicle was parked multiple nights in the Glacier Point parking lot while the visitors were camping. While they were gone, they had left multiple food and trash items; sour patch candy, soda, beef jerky, Cheetos, chocolate wrappers, Fanta soda bottles, Jeremiah Weed spiked cola, McDonald's food wrappers, fries container, and a Starbuck's Mocha can. A bear found the car and broke in. There were bear prints found on the roof and hood, as well as scratches on the passenger side door. The rear passenger window was broken and the other three windows were cracked.

5 bear canisters for a group of 13. One bag of dried meals would not fit in canisters. At around 3:00 am, one party heard bear in camp, opened tent and saw bear running away with bag of dried meals. Estimated 13-15 dried meals at 800 calories per meal.
Camping at Donahue Pass- Stored packaged food in canister but left 'stinky' food out. Bear obtained food, knocked around canister, and proceeded to return to camp throughout the night.

Visitor left candy bar in his backpack and left pack in tent cabin. Bear entered his cabin and awoke the visitor. The visitor could hear the bear and only see its outline. The bear rummaged through the visitor's bag but did not damage any property. Bear obtained candy bar from open pack. Visitor had forgotten about the candy bar. The visitor was too afraid to make noise or otherwise disturb the bear in his tent cabin. The bear sniffed around for a few more moments and not discovering anything else appetizing, left. The visitor wanted his identify to not be disclosed, but I gave him a verbal warning about food storage violations. He was apologetic.
Visitor woke up to bears getting can. No food obtained.

LocationDetail: Section on JMT between Cloud's Rest and Half Dome
IncidentDescription: Bear appeared six feet away from us in the trees. We walked away and the bear took a cup of nuts from the open canister (we were cooking breakfast). We scared the bear away yelling and throwing items at it. It came back some minutes later and we scared it away again. It then went to another campsite. There was a cub we saw from afar.

LocationDetail: Parking near rockfall, large propane tanks
IncidentDescription: DNC worker left garbage bags in back of truck when at lunch. The bear climbed into the back of the pick up and went through the garbage bags eating food trash. Four off duty DNC employees were on scene upon our arrival and the bear was sitting 10 feet from the truck waiting for them to leave so that he could go back to the garbage. We hazed him with 1 bean bag and 3 rubber slugs, but he was still reluctant to leave. We warned the driver upon his return.

Truck trailer parked in the back of Camp 6 parking lot with a large hole ripped into the rear door panel. The lowest panel was damaged only and no food or odors were present. The truck trailer was not locked and had a furniture and plastic wrap inside. Unknown when incident occurred but it did not look recent. Will contact DNC security to inform them of vehicle's damage. There were bear scratch marks on the rear door- obvious damage done by a bear.

Bear pulled down window frame (rear driver side). There was dog food in the trunk and an open empty bag of chips, apple, and banana peel in passenger compartment. The bear did not get into trunk where dog food was stored, although it tried to. Incident occurred the night of 11/16 or early morning of 11/17.

LocationDetail: Bridalveil Creek/ Pohono Trail backcountry site
IncidentDescription: Internet report from victim- backpacking on the Bridalveil Creek/ Pohono trail and awoke to their bear canister being cracked. No bear was observed and no food was obtained by the bear. They also had clean cups and pans near the canister that were scattered about their campsite. 877 emailed the visitor to get more info on whether the canister is still usable and bear-proof. If not, it would have property damage value to add to this report. (emailed on 9/7/11)
A group camp of llama campers reported a bear bluff charging their campsite multiple times. No property damage caused by bear.

Breson Nathalie. 0800 hrs. The vehicle was parked at camp 4. Inside the vehicle were 4 cans, unopened, inside the trunk. The owner had checked into camp 4 after hours in the sign-up sheet. All 4 doors were pried back, the roof was dented and there was bear paw marks all over the vehicle. The bear was not successful at entering the vehicle.
Bear broke L/R window- no food present in car- car seat next to broken window.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear broke into vehicle in Camp 4 lot. Driver's window was cracked a couple inches and the owner of the vehicle stated that the only food item in the vehicle was a candy bar wrapper. The bear broke the window and entered the vehicle just to retrieve the wrapper. No other damage/items were disturbed. There were paw prints present on the driver's door. The bear did not receive a food reward since it was just a wrapper and the owner of the vehicle stated that he forgot the wrapper was in his vehicle.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear break in reported by interp ranger. Unaccompanied vehicle with broken L rear window, trash in rear vehicle, coat/personal items on ground. Initial report did not include damage amount. Added by K. Rodriguez after observing damage to vehicle in impound lot. Unknown if food present/damaged.

LocationDetail: 1.4 miles east of Glacier Point on the Panorama
IncidentDescription: Victim called wildlife office to report that a bear with a green tag in its left ear took his pack, along the panorama trail. Victim put pack down and walked away and bear took pack.

LocationDetail: 1.4 miles east of Glacier Point on the Panorama
IncidentDescription: Victim called wildlife office to report that a bear with a green tag in its left ear took his pack, along the panorama trail. Victim put pack down and walked away and bear took pack.

Occupant of tent went to the bathroom and upon returning, saw a bear trying to get into the tent. The visitor had a low lumen flashlight and was not able to see any specifics about the bear, but guessed all black in color. Visitor yelled at the bear and scared it away. It was later discovered that a pack within the tent contained an orange. The group was a large school class and stated that they had been strict on food storage throughout their stay. Only two visitors at the site during the incident. The rest of the group were on a night hike. Incident occurred after dark.

Bear broke into vehicle through the left, rear window. Damages to the vehicle include: Broken left, rear window; dents below the broken window;, scratches on the back of the car; broken left side mirror; weather strip on the roof top peeled back. The bear obtained the following: oranges; blackberries; apples; apple sauce; hena packets; marshmallows; chocolate cookies; a pie; protein powder; goo-energy packets; and skittles. The car is smeared with food items on the inside.

Bear broke into vehicle through the left, rear window. Damages to the vehicle include: Broken left, rear window; dents below the broken window;, scratches on the back of the car; broken left side mirror; weather strip on the roof top peeled back. The bear obtained the following: oranges; blackberries; apples; apple sauce; hena packets; marshmallows; chocolate cookies; a pie; protein powder; goo-energy packets; and skittles. The car is smeared with food items on the inside.

Back right window glass and seal broken. Crash pad chewed. Food remaining in the vehicle includes: small cooler full of beer; several Gatorade bottles; box of crackers, mostly empty that has been chewed open; a box of granola bars that has been chewed open; various food and trash items including a ripped open plastic wrapper from a loaf of bread.

Back right window glass and seal broken. Crash pad chewed. Food remaining in the vehicle includes: small cooler full of beer; several Gatorade bottles; box of crackers, mostly empty that has been chewed open; a box of granola bars that has been chewed open; various food and trash items including a ripped open plastic wrapper from a loaf of bread.

Back right window glass and seal broken. Crash pad chewed. Food remaining in the vehicle includes: small cooler full of beer; several Gatorade bottles; box of crackers, mostly empty that has been chewed open; a box of granola bars that has been chewed open; various food and trash items including a ripped open plastic wrapper from a loaf of bread.

Yellow 48 came up to the picnic table where the 2 visitors were eating and snatched a loaf of bread from the opposite side of the table from where they were sitting. They didn't notice her until she put her front paws up on the table. They yelled and she rand away. All of the food was close and within arms reach. Report was taken at 02:00 am.
Passenger door was pulled away from the jamb at the window surround and had scratches and small bear prints on it. There was no food in the vehicle, only a red water canteen.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Myself, Lauren, Louisa, and Mike were in Camp 4 discussing car break-ins when we heard a large crushing noise in the adjacent lot. I ran and saw the rear end of a small, light colored bear running into the forest. The vehicle had previously contained a large amount of food that Adrianne had dealt with the owners about. The car had odors of food, trash, and sunflower seeds left in the car.
Food was stored inside a locked cargo carrier, attached to the top of the vehicle. Bears broke an 8" X 6" hole in the rear of the plastic cargo carrier and removed food.
Food was stored inside a locked cargo carrier, attached to the top of the vehicle. Bears broke an 8" X 6" hole in the rear of the plastic cargo carrier and removed food.

Observed Toyota in camp 4 parking lot with damaged window. Plastic bag with food residue found outside car. Large amount of camping/climbing supplies in back seat of car. I found no food in back seat, only plastic bag outside. I located the owner of the vehicle, Mike Schmit, who told me he put all of his food in a bear box. Schmit was unaware that he left a plastic baggie containing garlic inside his car. The driver side rear window frame was bent and the glass shattered. The bear attempted to pull the rear passenger window frame, bending the frame slightly. Glass was not broken.

Visitors were cooking dinner and were within feet of their bear locker, when 2394 entered behind them and snatched a bag of lemons. Visitors described that the bear was silent and "very sneaky". She ran off when they yelled.
Bear's head was sticking out window as soon as I hazed (yelled) she ran away. About 20 min. later, she came back around, but behind us near Yosemite Lodge.

Hertz rental car broken in to. No visible attractants, only luggage present in the vehicle. Both of the door frames on the right side are bent. The left rear door frame is severely bent and the window is broken. The incident occurred between 00:00 and 01:45.

Hertz rental car broken in to. No visible attractants, only luggage present in the vehicle. Both of the door frames on the right side are bent. The left rear door frame is severely bent and the window is broken. The incident occurred between 00:00 and 01:45.

Alamo rental vehicle right rear passenger window frame ripped open, pulled off rubber stripping, glass inside and out. Doors locked. Car parked at 21:00. Middle seat had a gym bag, book bag, books, maps, clothing, and a towel. The head rest was torn out half way. Paw print on the back seat/ The back area had 2 empty bear canisters, water jugs, and empty plastic bags. Prints all over the car as well as the car next to it, and several others in the parking area. Pictures taken by J. Hoeflich and sent to desk office.
Visitors 20' away from open bear box.

LocationDetail: JMT Half Dome intersection. 100m up HIL.
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Left bear cans in pack on Half Dome Trail. Bear dug through 4 packs and took one pack. Bear seen with pack 0600. Group got back to packs at 0800. Bear damaged Ice Hot and sunscreen.

LocationDetail: JMT Half Dome intersection. 100m up HIL.
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Left bear cans in pack on Half Dome Trail. Bear dug through 4 packs and took one pack. Bear seen with pack 0600. Group got back to packs at 0800. Bear damaged Ice Hot and sunscreen.

Yellow warning left on vehicle at 12:30am 6/18/12. 12 backpacks (bags and packs) left in vehicle. Chevy suburban w/5 occupants arrived wilderness parking on 6/17/12. Received conflicting directions to north pines backpackers camp and wound up at mirror lake. Returned to their vehicle at 1900 hrs. and squatted w/3 tents behind space #106 in upper pines/ Left in their vehicle were 6 backpacks and 6 duffel bags stuffed full. Food left in plain sight including 2 liter bottles of soda. Warning was left at 0020hrs on 6/18/12. Desk officers discovered break-in at 0720 hrs. on 6/18/12. T-1 initially assisted, H22 arrived at 0940hrs to follow up and cite as determined.

Yellow warning left on vehicle at 12:30am 6/18/12. 12 backpacks (bags and packs) left in vehicle. Chevy suburban w/5 occupants arrived wilderness parking on 6/17/12. Received conflicting directions to north pines backpackers camp and wound up at mirror lake. Returned to their vehicle at 1900 hrs. and squatted w/3 tents behind space #106 in upper pines/ Left in their vehicle were 6 backpacks and 6 duffel bags stuffed full. Food left in plain sight including 2 liter bottles of soda. Warning was left at 0020hrs on 6/18/12. Desk officers discovered break-in at 0720 hrs. on 6/18/12. T-1 initially assisted, H22 arrived at 0940hrs to follow up and cite as determined.

While spotlighting upper pines, saw a left out bear (?) in site. Upon further inspection, found a camelback pack that had been torn into and damaged by a bear. Pack was found w/ trail mix and granola bar wrappers left out in truck bed. The visitor was up and stated that no other food was in the pack (that was damaged). There were also potatoes, sodas, beer, and a cooler with drinks left in the truck bed. There were 2 other packs in the truck bed that were not damaged and the visitor was unsure if they contained food. Visitor was unsure if any other food items were missing from the truck bed, so it is unknown if the bear acquired food (the wrappers were garbage items). No bear was observed, but 2394 was previously in camp and close by on telemetry.

Was tracking 2394 in boulder field behind camp 4 and found a grocery bag with 6-10 torn open cliff bar wrappers and soy sauce. There was bear scat next to the bag that seemed relatively fresh. I picked up the garbage and threw it out.

Group had parked their vehicle in the wilderness parking lot and were staying in backpackers camp. They said the car was completely clean with no food or scented items and I totally believe them. Bear broke front passenger window and ripped apart the back seat and ate half of a trail map. No food was obtained.

LocationDetail: 100 yards N. of kiosk in the second row.
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: At approx. 1715 hrs. on 6/26 I observed a broken out rear window in a sienna van parked in the curry orchard lot. Bear prints in the dust on the R. Middle window. Vehicle contained several child booster seats and unopened water bottles and a container of baby wipes. NFA

2 climbers hiking up the base came upon a medium sized bear with a white tag rummaging through property at the base of heart ledges at El Cap. They yelled and threw rocks at the bear and it ran away. Soon a cub returned to the scene and they scared it away. I arrived and noticed a few bits of trail mix, a fork with sardine remnants on it. Spilled salt, and odors. I searched the equipment and found lots of toiletries and 5 or 6 tea bags as well as a slobbery vitamin gel packet. Other supplements were found as well. I awaited the owners return and gave then a warning.

LocationDetail: 0.25 miles from the JMT and Half Dome junction.
IncidentDescription: Bear came within 60-70 ft. of tents and went through all of the bear canisters. The bear found 1 that was not closed completely even though the group said they checked them all and thought they were all good. The visitors only saw the bear's shadow.

LocationDetail: 0.25 miles from the JMT and Half Dome junction.
IncidentDescription: Bear came within 60-70 ft. of tents and went through all of the bear canisters. The bear found 1 that was not closed completely even though the group said they checked them all and thought they were all good. The visitors only saw the bear's shadow.

Visitor had an empty can of pringles and a bag of coffee inside the vehicle. The bear broke the front, left glass window and left a few scratch marks on the inside weather strip. Bear obtained garbage only according to the victims. However, a warning had been left on the car prior to the break-in by M. Brown and was marked for food, drinks, and trash.
Entry gained through right front passenger window. Damage to window and frame. Food present. Bear may have been scared away by traffic or persons present. Vehicle parked along side of traffic lane.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Camper was away from campsite. She thinks she spilled food on the pack that the bear chewed on and ripped into. Campers yelled at the bear and it ran away. The incident occurred between 1200 and 1600 hrs.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear peeled back molding on door. Campers in 92 yelled at the bear and it took off. Soda can present in vehicle.

Victim stated that there was no food stored in the vehicle. Desk officer did not observe any food or wrappers in vehicle. Driver window busted out and door frame separated. Victim sais he heard his alarm go off at 02:30 am. When he got to his car the bear had left.

While tracking 2394 in U. Pines found bear on food. Bear for into cooler that visitor claims was inside locker. Visitor stated that locker may have not been properly latched, Bear got 2 containers of yogurt and half of a bag of marshmallows. There was a lot of other food in the cooler but we scared her away before she could eat mote. We hazed her away from camp and warned visitor that she may return to their site. We showed the visitor how to properly latch their locker.

LocationDetail: Turnout west of El Cap Cross.
IncidentDescription: I received a call from dispatch regarding a bear inside a vehicle at the el cap cross. When I arrived, I saw a large medium to dark brown bear standing at the rear of the Toyota truck removing food from the camper. I honked the car's horn and the bear ran away. The bear forced open the rear glass lift door to the camper shell to open the door. The latches and weather stripping were damaged. A large amount of food was inside the camper including tortillas, avocados, onions, tomatoes, pasta, energy bars. The vehicle was impounded. Bear returned to area and waited on a log for us to leave. Food was also inside locked cab.

LocationDetail: Turnout west of El Cap Cross.
IncidentDescription: I received a call from dispatch regarding a bear inside a vehicle at the el cap cross. When I arrived, I saw a large medium to dark brown bear standing at the rear of the Toyota truck removing food from the camper. I honked the car's horn and the bear ran away. The bear forced open the rear glass lift door to the camper shell to open the door. The latches and weather stripping were damaged. A large amount of food was inside the camper including tortillas, avocados, onions, tomatoes, pasta, energy bars. The vehicle was impounded. Bear returned to area and waited on a log for us to leave. Food was also inside locked cab.

We tracked 2394 into North Pines and found her behind the campground and behind the stables eating blueberries. Next to the open container of blueberries was more food: energy bars, trail mix, and dried fruit. We chased the bear off the food. Multiple visitors reported seeing the bear run through their sites, but nobody would admit to their food being taken. We didn't actually see the food taken, only the bear eating it in the woods.
People preparing food and a bear went between two people and grabbed a bag of chips and ran away with it. Second hand report through Dennis of B&G, limited details.

We were tracking Y31 on the Happy Isles road and then on foot behind Curry. We arrived at the Wilderness lot to see Y31 running away from a yellow Toyota truck. The truck bed was full of empty beer cans and an ice chest of hot dogs, possibly missing food. The cab of the truck contained many food items including bread, onions, spices. There was a bag of dog food and ketchup and barbeque sauce in the truck bed as well. We scared Y31 out of the area.

Bear had broken out the left, rear window and entered through that window. An empty corn chip bag was located on the floor in the rear passenger area. The bear had torn the headrests off attempting to get to a blue Rubbermaid style storage container located in the rear storage area. Unknown contents of the storage container. The corner of the container torn out but full entry was not made. A full orange/ gray backpack, a mac laptop and notebook were removed for safekeeping.

Housekeeping hosts came up on bear getting into the back of a truck, upon which the bear ran away. Dave (326) responded first. The bear had dragged various items (avocado, garlic, wasabi, fruit salad, trail mix) into the forest. Many items had been thrown out of the camper shell outside the truck (crash pad, toiletries, papers, clothes, etc.) The bear gained entry through the camper shell door, which was unlocked. Y31 was strong on telemetry, we had just chased her from lower pines 5 minutes prior to getting called to the orchard lot.

LocationDetail: North shore of Lower Young Lakes.
IncidentDescription: Bear took backpack away from campsite and was getting into it. When confronted with flashlights and noises, bear dropped pack and left. There was no food in the backpack. All food and garbage was stored in bear cans. However, hiker had put away dishes, silverware, cup, and a napkin that served to wipe dishes (after washing with water and camp soap) in the backpack.

Hikers saw a dark bear in the night. The following morning, their plastic bag was found ripped open. The bag had chewing gum in it, which the hikers had forgotten to take out. The bear did not eat the gum.

Food was stored in residence. Resident heard screen on window on hard sided door get popped off. Resident turned on outside light and saw a large dark bear run away. Window on door was slightly cracked and adjacent room had a pantry and cat food inside. Door was secure. Resident stated she will ensure windows are all properly secured at night. Bear did not enter building and did not obtain any food/scented items. Resident could not determine if bear had any tags. Wildlife responded and checked telemetry but did not pick up/observe any bears.

LocationDetail: Between Middle and Lower Young Lakes.
IncidentDescription: Troop of boy scouts couldn't fit all their food into their 14 bear canisters, so they hung two stuff sacks with food from a tree. The bear climbed the tree and dragged the food down and ate it. There was approximately 5 to 10 pounds of food. Troop leader got a mandatory appearance citation.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Van passenger window and frame was destroyed. Possible bear entry through opening. Short brown hair on arm rest. No interior damage was observed. No food observed inside vehicle.
