Small plastic bag on passenger floorboard untouched - unknown contents. There was a child seat on second seat - driver side. Several large paw marks on that window.

Visitor heard bear eating food out of locker. They shone their light and saw a bear running off with an amount of Oreo cookies. There was bear slobber on the ground next to the locker. 2394 was strong on telemetry, we had been chasing her around the Pines for a while.

A visitor reported seeing a bear run north out of backpackers with a pack. Wildlife arrived and found a small pack about 50 feet from its owner, full of food but still zipped up and un-damaged. A second pack, nearby, was damaged and contained a bear canister. The bear only damaged the larger pack. Unknown if food was obtained as the pack owners couldn't remember if any loose items were with the larger pack.

Fire guys in El Portal reported a bear in a dumpster that was unclipped. V26 and H11 arrived first, but the bear had gotten itself out. H11 said the bear was tagged, unknown color/ear. He said it was a different bear than the larger, untagged bear he has seen in that area.

Visitors left out an empty pizza box. Bear took pizza box, but dropped it. Visitors shouted and scared bear away. Pizza box was approximately 6 feet away from where the group was sitting. They said they knew it had to be within arms reach, but probably misjudged what that meant.

Dispatch called in visitor reporting a bear in Upper Pines #177. 326 was in the area and responded and spotted yellow 31. He chased her and got food back but she did manage to eat half of it (bag of peanut butter cups minis).

Visitors were putting food into locker and bear snuck into and stole food from the locker. She took the food to the edge of the campground and began to eat. She was able to eat a full bag of cereal until 877 and 878 were able to haze her out. As she ran away she grabbed another bag but dropped it a little while after.

326 was talking to visitors from earlier case # 2931 and getting info when he heard pots and pans and yelling. 326 ran towards the sounds and yellow 31 was running from site 207 with a bag in her mouth. 326 chased her about 150yards into woods and she dropped the food and tried to pick it back up but only got a bag of trail mix. 326 grabbed the damaged bag of food while still chasing 2394 and she went up a tree, waited, she came down and ate her snack and as 326 ran at her, she did not move. 326 tried to throw some rocks at her and hit her with them but she did not move. When she finished eating the food she finally left.
Visitor was at open locker with food on top of locker. Bear approached locker from other side and grabbed buns. She was chased away.

Visitors opened locker and were pulling food out when the bear came up behind her and pulled a bag of groceries out of the visitors' hand. Within one foot of visitors. Bear ran towards Clark's bridge and ate the food.

Visitors noticed bear 2394 come into their site and started banging bottles together to scare the bear away. When the bear did not move, they sprayed bear mace first from 15 feet and then closer, hitting the bear. The bear did not react. The visitors started yelling at the bear. Finally 326 arrived and effectively chased the bear out of the site and campground.
Peaches and trail mix inside vehicle. Bear popped open camper shell and was sitting by truck eating. Trust chased her away.
Food was stored in bear locker but the locker was improperly latched. We saw the bear with a bag in it's mouth and chased it off. Bear obtained 1/2 a loaf of bread and 1/4 bag of marshmallows.

Visitors in site 34D were cooking when they noticed a bear a few feet away grabbing a small bag of tortillas that were within arm's reach. The visitors yelled at the bear and it ran away. They described the bear as having a yellow tag, left ear, being small and looking "mangy".

Visitors were sitting about 6-10 feet away from their vehicle on top of which two packs were sitting. A bear came up and grabbed 2 packs on the roof. The bear dropped one pack and took another containing multiple Cliff bars and sandwiches. Deanna and Sam tracked yellow 31 and scared her off the pack.

Visitors were sitting about 6-10 feet away from their vehicle on top of which two packs were sitting. A bear came up and grabbed 2 packs on the roof. The bear dropped one pack and took another containing multiple Cliff bars and sandwiches. Deanna and Sam tracked yellow 31 and scared her off the pack.

Visitor went to the bathroom and 2394 grabbed a soft-sided cooler containing one full beer and one empty beer. She dropped it before she got anything. Hotel 11 chased her out and retrieved the cooler. The people didn't realize anything was in the cooler when they left it out.

Visitor was standing next to the side of their open locker. He looked down and saw a bear in the locker. He instinctively grabbed for the bag the bear had in its mouth. The two played tug of war with it for a few seconds, then the visitor dropped it. The visitor said it was a bag that contained no food. The bag was retrieved from the woods.
Second hand report of a bear obtaining chips from Horse Camp.
Visitor accidentally left a Cliff Bar out of their bear canister, apparently in their backpack. The bear dragged the backpack uphill and ate the cliff bar.

A bear came into the campsite and broke into an improperly closed carbon fiber canister. The bear was able to eat a bag of trail mix before it was scared away. Initial verbal yells and rocks did not phase the bear. After screaming loudly the bear ran away. The visitor was contacted and disclosed that only one of three clasps on the canister were latched properly. The bear pried the top off and sheared the single closed clasp to obtain the food. The canister was not smashed.

A bear came into the campsite and broke into an improperly closed carbon fiber canister. The bear was able to eat a bag of trail mix before it was scared away. Initial verbal yells and rocks did not phase the bear. After screaming loudly the bear ran away. The visitor was contacted and disclosed that only one of three clasps on the canister were latched properly. The bear pried the top off and sheared the single closed clasp to obtain the food. The canister was not smashed.
Shingles were ripped off the right side of the Happy Isles A-frame.
Passenger rear door glass was broken out of the vehicle. There was no sign of complete entry. No food was observed inside the vehicle. The contents inside the vehicle appeared to be undisturbed.

A YTS bus driver called dispatch who dispatched Wildlife to Camp 6. We arrived to find the reporting party who told us she saw an orange tagged bear break in, rip apart, and jump out of the white sedan. The owners of the vehicle were OB camping nearby with food also hanging in a tree near where they were sleeping by the river. The bear apparently smelled food located in the trunk. The backseat was ripped apart to allow access to the trunk. Their were multiple boxes of food in the trunk. Pickles were strewn about outside the vehicle. The owners were clueless about all aspects of food storage and park regulations.

A YTS bus driver called dispatch who dispatched Wildlife to Camp 6. We arrived to find the reporting party who told us she saw an orange tagged bear break in, rip apart, and jump out of the white sedan. The owners of the vehicle were OB camping nearby with food also hanging in a tree near where they were sleeping by the river. The bear apparently smelled food located in the trunk. The backseat was ripped apart to allow access to the trunk. Their were multiple boxes of food in the trunk. Pickles were strewn about outside the vehicle. The owners were clueless about all aspects of food storage and park regulations.

A YTS bus driver called dispatch who dispatched Wildlife to Camp 6. We arrived to find the reporting party who told us she saw an orange tagged bear break in, rip apart, and jump out of the white sedan. The owners of the vehicle were OB camping nearby with food also hanging in a tree near where they were sleeping by the river. The bear apparently smelled food located in the trunk. The backseat was ripped apart to allow access to the trunk. Their were multiple boxes of food in the trunk. Pickles were strewn about outside the vehicle. The owners were clueless about all aspects of food storage and park regulations.

Food was stored in a box in the back of the visitor's SUV. The bear broke into the right passenger window and pulled some food out. Another visitor witnessed the bear exiting the vehicle around 07:30. The vehicle was from Camp Towanga. The bear obtained risotto and fruit. Two cubs were seen nearby but not in the vehicle.

Food was stored in a box in the back of the visitor's SUV. The bear broke into the right passenger window and pulled some food out. Another visitor witnessed the bear exiting the vehicle around 07:30. The vehicle was from Camp Towanga. The bear obtained risotto and fruit. Two cubs were seen nearby but not in the vehicle.
A "pound plus" chocolate bar from Trader Joes was left out on the table 6 feet from the visitors. About 1/4 of the bar was eaten.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Trash and odors were present in the campsite. The bear approached and when yelling didn’t work, the visitors backed off and the bear may have gotten some trash. D. Quinn and L. Fanucchi chased the bear away shortly thereafter.
The bear took a backpack from the SAR site while they were near the pack. The details of what was in the pack are unknown.

The bear came into the campsite and obtained an 8-pack of hot dogs and a pack of sandwich turkey. Visitors yelled but the bear did not move. Visitors threw rocks and the bear ran away. The bear returned at 03:00 the next morning and obtained half of a 16 ounce bottle of Pepsi.
A yellow tagged bear approached visitors as they were grabbing food from their locker. They were afraid and backed away. The bear then grabbed a bag of Lays potato chips and ran into the woods.

Visitors opened their locker to get something, left it open, and returned to their picnic table. Within seconds the bear was at their campsite eating out of their food locker. They yelled and the bear grabbed a bag of food and took off.

Campground Ranger D. Wright responded to an alarm in Lower Pines and tried to locate the bear but was unable to. Lower pines site 3 had not latched their locker correctly. The details of what the bear obtained are unclear.

Campground Ranger D. Wright obtained a second hand report of a bear obtaining food in an adjacent site to the reporting party. The visitors in site 503 chased a yellow tagged bear out of site 501 after they saw it getting food.

Found bear break-in while patrolling wilderness lot. Ice chest removed from back seat. Ice chest contained orange juice, Kool-Aid, cliff bars, candy bard, deli meat, dried fruit, cheese, and mustard, all eaten by the bear. Rear diver window frame pulled down by bear, which broke the window. Back-county permit# 17287 to Lewis Morgan. Ranger Price placed a warning on the window on 8/13 at 21:15 for ice chest. Ranger Drawert issued citation for improper food storage on 8/13 at 12:42 am. Impounded food and valuables.

Found bear break-in while patrolling wilderness lot. Ice chest removed from back seat. Ice chest contained orange juice, Kool-Aid, cliff bars, candy bard, deli meat, dried fruit, cheese, and mustard, all eaten by the bear. Rear diver window frame pulled down by bear, which broke the window. Back-county permit# 17287 to Lewis Morgan. Ranger Price placed a warning on the window on 8/13 at 21:15 for ice chest. Ranger Drawert issued citation for improper food storage on 8/13 at 12:42 am. Impounded food and valuables.

Resident informed our office that a bear attempted to gain entry into his residence. The bear pried the screen door off the wooden door- completely destroying it, bear did not gain entry or obtain food from residence. Resident was not home at the time of incident, but said it was between 3:30 and 17:30 on 8/18/2012. Informed resident that our office would follow up and alert his neighbors to the incident. Took pictures of door on 875's iPhone. Bear #3520 was active and moderate on telemetry, just east of Foresta Road.

I was on bear patrol- found Sedona with broken rear window. The window appeared to be closed instead of vented. Three zip-lock bags were lying outside of the van. The bags were ripped open and emptied. I don't know what kind of food was inside the bags. Wilderness permit in window #17360. Last name- Roupe.

I was on bear patrol- found Sedona with broken rear window. The window appeared to be closed instead of vented. Three zip-lock bags were lying outside of the van. The bags were ripped open and emptied. I don't know what kind of food was inside the bags. Wilderness permit in window #17360. Last name- Roupe.

Open locker containing ice chest, food, packs, and trash. Items were scattered throughout campsite and area. All food was consumed except for some sliced cheese in individual wrappers. I woke up tenants and had them clean mess and gave warning. They said a lot of fruit was eaten along with shredded cheese, jerky, and cookies. Thompson said he thinks he did not properly secure bear box.
Victim returned to her motorcycle and found the leather saddle bag torn open. Only food item (banana peel) had been removed. The peel was lying on the ground next to the motorcycle.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Front passenger window broken out- no interior damage. Empty Luna Bar wrapper and empty orange juice bottle on front passenger floor board.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Left rear window smashed out. Clear 1 gallon empty zip lock bag with what appears to be peanut butter smears was found on pavement outside of vehicle. Bag had been torn open, no other food present.

Visitor had unpacked his food and went back to the car for his tent and the bear was inside his open passenger door. The visitor came around the side of the car and then noticed the bear about 1-2 feet from him- he gave a startled yell and the bear ran, stepping on his foot. There was no food in the vehicle and there was no damage.
Horse grains were left out in 3 barrels as well as a large cooler filled with soda and a watermelon. The bear obtained food from one of the 3 barrels.
1. Bear teeth exactly ripped top latches, opened container (Bear Vault solo) pictures taken by ranger. 2. Failed to open BV 500.
1. Bear teeth exactly ripped top latches, opened container (Bear Vault solo) pictures taken by ranger. 2. Failed to open BV 500.
Visitors were about 20ft from improperly latched locker. Bear finished off half of a family size (large) bag of peanut butter m&m's.

Campers were sitting at the picnic table and saw the bear approaching. They stood up, backed away about 5 ft. and started yelling and banging pots etc. The bear approached, grabbed a bag of Funions and then ran away. The bear came back about 5mins later, but this time they scared her off before she got any nor food.

Bear entered house through glass window. Incident happened between 18:00 on 8/23/12 and 16:00 on 8/24/12. Bear got into freezer and took out salmon, but did not eat it. Bear got into cabinet and got chips and crackers and ate several peaches. Damage was done to glass window and bear broke glass to get into window. Blinds of window ere destroyed and another window frame was bent out of place. Inside the house the cabinet was splintered where the bear gained entry. Owners were not home at the time of the incident. This is the 3rd time the bear has visited this house, but this is the most escalated event. Owner will send pictures of house pre-clean-up to 875. Unknown which bear caused incident, but bear #3899 was seen several hours after the incident near the home.

Bear entered house through glass window. Incident happened between 18:00 on 8/23/12 and 16:00 on 8/24/12. Bear got into freezer and took out salmon, but did not eat it. Bear got into cabinet and got chips and crackers and ate several peaches. Damage was done to glass window and bear broke glass to get into window. Blinds of window ere destroyed and another window frame was bent out of place. Inside the house the cabinet was splintered where the bear gained entry. Owners were not home at the time of the incident. This is the 3rd time the bear has visited this house, but this is the most escalated event. Owner will send pictures of house pre-clean-up to 875. Unknown which bear caused incident, but bear #3899 was seen several hours after the incident near the home.

Second hand report. Visitors in site B32 chased the bear off a large bag of M&M's in a canvas bag. The food did not come from their site. The bear was difficult to chase off and came back multiple times.

Visitors were at picnic table 5-6 ft. from bear locker, on top of which some food had been left. Visitors saw bear as it grabbed a full bag of crackers from atop the locker; they started yelling just as L. Fannucchi and I arrived, yelled and chased the bear. The bear treed and dropped the bag of crackers, which was ripped open, but still full. We do not believe the bear got any food.

The visitor had some small food items in a pack left next to the tent and was 10-15ft away. The bear gabbed the pack and ran. The food contents spilled out of the open pack and the bear did not eat the food. The pack was recovered by 881 and 874 slightly damaged. There was also a pair of rain pants in the pack that were not recovered.

Arrived at Cathedral Beach to find 3516 standing about 30 yards from some picnickers. I yelled and he did not move. I shot him with a rubber slug and he ran away. The first party said the bear approached their picnic and ran away when yelled at. The bear then went down to the beach and the visitors abandoned their food. The bear ate at least 3 sandwiches and left teeth marks in a plastic container. According to others in the area. The "victims" had left by the time I responded.

While unloading food from car, the bear approached and took 2 packs of hot dog buns from the food locker while the visitor's back was turned. 1 bag was dropped. The visitor was approximately 3ft from the locker. Bear described as black and untagged.
Group was sitting around campfire with food left out. Y31 took 2 loaves of bread off the picnic table.

Obtained big Costco carton of goldfish. Was eating when visitor attempted to chase her off. She did not respond. LE was able to chase her off and she dropped the food. Visitors were about 20 feet from goldfish when the bear got to it. They got close to the bear to try to scare her off with no success.

1 of 3 break-ins that occurred at this residence on this date. Resident returned home to find that a bear had broken in through the screen of an open window. The bear had gotten out most of the food from the refrigerator and the freezer. Non-consumed food from the freezer was still frozen, indication to the resident that, although the break-in occurred some time before 09:30am, it probably occurred close to this time, due to the condition of the frozen food. The resident closed the window that had been the entry point for the bear, but did not secure the remaining windows. The resident left the house and later 2 more break-ins occurred.

1 of 3 break-ins that occurred at this residence on this date. Resident returned home to find that a bear had broken in through the screen of an open window. The bear had gotten out most of the food from the refrigerator and the freezer. Non-consumed food from the freezer was still frozen, indication to the resident that, although the break-in occurred some time before 09:30am, it probably occurred close to this time, due to the condition of the frozen food. The resident closed the window that had been the entry point for the bear, but did not secure the remaining windows. The resident left the house and later 2 more break-ins occurred.

1 of 3 break-ins that occurred at this residence on this date. Resident returned home to find that a bear had broken in through the screen of an open window. The bear had gotten out most of the food from the refrigerator and the freezer. Non-consumed food from the freezer was still frozen, indication to the resident that, although the break-in occurred some time before 09:30am, it probably occurred close to this time, due to the condition of the frozen food. The resident closed the window that had been the entry point for the bear, but did not secure the remaining windows. The resident left the house and later 2 more break-ins occurred.

Approx. 2 oz. package of crackers was accidently left in pack; crackers were hidden by clothes, and therefore were not found when loading the bear canister. All other food was in the canister; bear tore hole in pack and got the crackers. We scared off bear by yelling. Model of container: Garcia. No problems with the container.

Bear 3251 and her cub were observed by DNC employees attempting to gain entry to a Bear Vault 450 and a food locker that was properly locked. She was unsuccessful in opening either. According to the witness, she was causing the bear locker to shake. The DNC witness eventually got her to leave and she walked away and into the closed rock-slide area where later R. Leahy hazed her with several shotgun rounds.

Two separate camp raids occurred. One was at 21:30 during which the bear attacked our Kevlar bear bags. Loud noises and lights did not deter the bear. The second raid occurred at 02:00 at our new campsite with new people. Food was hung and the bears got it all. Noises and lights did nothing. The bears were very aggressive and unafraid of humans. (Victims were using Ursack).

Two separate camp raids occurred. One was at 21:30 during which the bear attacked our Kevlar bear bags. Loud noises and lights did not deter the bear. The second raid occurred at 02:00 at our new campsite with new people. Food was hung and the bears got it all. Noises and lights did nothing. The bears were very aggressive and unafraid of humans. (Victims were using Ursack).

Two separate camp raids occurred. One was at 21:30 during which the bear attacked our Kevlar bear bags. Loud noises and lights did not deter the bear. The second raid occurred at 02:00 at our new campsite with new people. Food was hung and the bears got it all. Noises and lights did nothing. The bears were very aggressive and unafraid of humans. (Victims were using Ursack).
Went through camp. 2x holes in screen tent. Bear entered screen tent covering picnic table. Exited and made second hole/ tear. Visitors claim there was no food in there.

Tango 31 and 874 located the bear in group camp site E, eating trail mix out of a backpack. The campers in that site claimed that it was not their pack. It is unknown where the pack came from. The only item eaten was a bag of trail mix, but the pack also contained a second bag of trail mix and sunscreen.

Tango 31 and 874 located the bear in group camp site E, eating trail mix out of a backpack. The campers in that site claimed that it was not their pack. It is unknown where the pack came from. The only item eaten was a bag of trail mix, but the pack also contained a second bag of trail mix and sunscreen.
Excess food was hung from a tree and the bear obtained fruit and freeze dried food.

Visitors were at their table about 8-10 feet from their locker with a box of food on top. The bear was eating food when they noticed it. They had difficulty scaring the bear away. Items eaten were hot dog buns, a loaf of bread, and marshmallows.

Heard noise, saw box open, then saw eyes of bear 20ft away. Chased bear away with noise. Bear obtained bag of granola from vest from improperly latched locker. Vest was found with minor damage and returned to owner.

Heard noise, saw box open, then saw eyes of bear 20ft away. Chased bear away with noise. Bear obtained bag of granola from vest from improperly latched locker. Vest was found with minor damage and returned to owner.

The visitors were less than 10 feet away from the locker and the bear grabbed a whole bag of groceries. We were right there and chased the bear. She dropped most of the food, but got some, including dry soup mix.
Bear grabbed package of apricots from on top of a locker as visitors were cleaning up. Bear ran away when bear team came running after her, then grabbed more food from the site next door.
Visitor had back turned to locker, fiddling in car less than 10 feet away. Bear grabbed cardboard box and ran. Food spilled out and box ripped, bit it is likely the bear got something.

The visitor was sitting at his fire with his back to the open locker about 10-15 feet away. He turned around and the bear was in the locker. It is unclear exactly what the bear ate as the man was French and there was a language barrier. The neighboring site said they thought the bear got " a lot " of food. The bear was chased off by 874 and 881 and Tango 31.

Visitors were eating at picnic table about 10 feet away from locker. Bear grabbed package of rice cakes from open locker. Ran away as we came running after her. Later I spoke to the visitors, I turned and saw the bear laying down eating about 15 ft. away from me and the bear locker from which she had obtained food.

LocationDetail: Above the junction of the JMT and Cloud's rest.
IncidentDescription: We were sleeping, the bear apparently rolled the can down a hill. We found it down below on the trail. The top came off the canister somehow (the bear got it off). The bear ate trail mix.

LocationDetail: Above the junction of the JMT and Cloud's rest.
IncidentDescription: We were sleeping, the bear apparently rolled the can down a hill. We found it down below on the trail. The top came off the canister somehow (the bear got it off). The bear ate trail mix.

LocationDetail: 8.5-9 miles in on the JMT/ Lyell Canyon
IncidentDescription: VIP Kevin (T-44) reported that the bears had obtained trash hung in tree. They did not report that they had hung trash in tree and that the bears obtained food from them when they filled out this report in the TMWC.

1st bear sighted moving from east to west towards the campground (from the direction of the ranger station) walking in deadfall forest. Scared the bear off by repeatedly throwing rocks in its direction. 2nd bear sighted as 1st was chased away. 2nd appeared to be eating something (from camp?) it was lying down while earing. Also scared 2nd bear off with rocks.
Broken left front driver's window. No signs of food present. Several clothing items in vehicle. No signs of entry to the vehicle.
Food in back of vehicle that had an unlocked tail gate. Rear camper shell door unlocked. Left rear slide sliding window and screen damaged.

Bear obtained a small bag of cookies (about 4), 6 marshmallows. Bear opened fruit, didn't eat much oats, quinoa, pasta, ate one GU. Dayton tradesman was left shut and latched, but not locked. Visitor heard bear, came out of tent and chased bear away.

LocationDetail: Cliff below point of Snow Creek footbridge.
IncidentDescription: Found ripped dry bag a little below cliff. Looked like bear had gotten in - some things punctured and such. Packed all items out.
Cub took package of crackers from around fire ring. Then black cub came by twice and we scared away.

Third-hand report from another backcountry report at the Sunrise Creek Junction. They added to their report that another came saw a bear that ate a bunch of their food that was not in a bear box, but was hung in a tree.

At approx. 16:00 an adolescent bear came through LYV ranger station. When it started through camp, no one was there. It found one Nalgene with Gatorade mix in it and an empty, washed chili can in the dish drying rack. It put its teeth into 1/2 gallon of Clorox bleach and empty container of orange pumice hand soap. It also explored the kitchen area. Tom Robinson hazed the bear with the paintball gun at approx.. 16:45. P.N. came back from the campground at approx.. 16:55. Robinson has good footage of the bear on his personal camera. P. N. never saw the bear.

While on campground patrol P. Nether and LYV 3 (Robinson) spotted a bear who was medium sized and black in color. The bear was on the Western edge of the campground. Hazed the bear with 2 rubber slugs from about 70ft. It ran into the trees and was followed to find an empty, torn up mountain house lasagna package. It looked uncooked. As LYV3 and P.N. left the campground they saw it cross the JMT trail and two more slugs were fired and it was followed for about 300yards. It then cut across and behind the ranger station and LYV3 was able to put 4-6 paintballs down range. Hitting more than missing,

Observed bear 2255 on trash outside residence in trailer park of El Portal. Trash was boiled, cut potatoes- almost looked like baiting since there was no other trash items around. Had bear 2255 strong on telemetry and observed bear on trash. Unsure if bear ate potatoes, but 877 and 875 hazed bear away from residential are and cleaned up trash.
No food visible from outside of vehicle. Bear prints on all sides of vehicle including roof. Sun roof visor was removed by bear- exterior only. Bear never gained access.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Visitor reports that another group buried lots of trash underneath a rock. Bear moved rock and tore and licked trash bags clean. Visitors did not see bear, but afterward picked up rock to get trash. Was clean area, but then trash everywhere.

LocationDetail: Approx. 5 mi. East of Sent. Dome
IncidentDescription: Approximately 10 plus people eating lunch with paper plates and food on picnic blankets. Yellow 48 approached from wood line within 50 feet. People packed up all food, but left plates and blankets.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Mother and two cubs were observed leaving the pickup truck and running down the hill. Entry was gained through the roof sky-light window which was torn off and laying on the hood. The middle, front seat was also popped out. Adult and cub prints on hood. Talked to victim on 9/5 and he reported that there was not any food in the vehicle, but that they were missing a duffel bag with clothes and cosmetics.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Mother and two cubs were observed leaving the pickup truck and running down the hill. Entry was gained through the roof sky-light window which was torn off and laying on the hood. The middle, front seat was also popped out. Adult and cub prints on hood. Talked to victim on 9/5 and he reported that there was not any food in the vehicle, but that they were missing a duffel bag with clothes and cosmetics.

Residents returned to their Dana Way home very late on 9/4/12. Their car was undamaged as of 22:30. They woke up sometime in the early morning 9/5/12 to find their car broken into. The only scented item in the car was incense. Their was a vegetable garden adjacent to the car that was undisturbed.

Resident comes into kitchen around 04:00 to find a cabinet with food tipped over. The refrigerator was wide open and trash was strewn about. The resident saw a bear about 40 feet from his house. The bear obtained a block of cheese, brownie mix, and various other food items. Bear 2255 was very close on telemetry upon NPS Wildlife's arrival.
Bear gained entry through right side front passenger's window. No food present - two water bottles on dash.
Box of pots and pans was left out when visitors went to bed. They didn't realize it also had a little food in it. Bear took box ~20 ft. into woods, obtained some smoked salmon, maybe more.
Visitor was ~ 15 ft. away, with back turned to car. Bear obtained a 1 gallon zip-lock bag of cereal, possibly more, from visitor's open trunk. Visitor yelled and bear ran off with the food.

LocationDetail: Trailer court dumpsters near entrance to Hwy 140.
IncidentDescription: Observed bear 2255 come out of an unclipped dumpster after 875 kicked the dumpster. There were several bags of food, dog food, and chicken packages in the dumpster. The bear ran away quickly after kicking the dumpster and the dumpster was fixed. Unknown if calories were obtained from the food and trash.
The left side driver's window was down and a backpack was on the ground outside of the vehicle. There was no damage to either the vehicle or the pack.
Food was in a bear canister. A bear came three times over night. A portable "Garcia "food canister was nowhere to be found the next day.

Visitor opened locker and then walked 15 feet away to his vehicle. When he turned around, bear 3591 was taking food from a cooler in his locker. Visitors saw the bear eating something up the hill but couldn't determine exactly what they had lost.

At 03:00 an unknown bear ripped off a screen door of a house that was broken into the previous night. No bears were observed but there were new paw prints and marks on the door. The bear did not gain entry and did not obtain any food.

LocationDetail: Cloud's Rest junction on John Muir Trail
IncidentDescription: The reporting party was neighboring the visitors whose food was taken by the bear. The bear visited the neighbor's site several times during the night. Food was not properly stored and bear obtained food. Bear was said to be aggressive. Bear had been in campsite the previous night as well and may have also obtained food by getting into a bear canister.

"I had a plastic cover around my two backpacks. I had electrical wire wrapped around the cover. The backpacks were tied to the tree. The packs were 5 feet off the ground. On top of the packs was a trash bag. The bear tore off the plastic cover and took the trash bag. He tore open the dehydrated food bags."

"I had a plastic cover around my two backpacks. I had electrical wire wrapped around the cover. The backpacks were tied to the tree. The packs were 5 feet off the ground. On top of the packs was a trash bag. The bear tore off the plastic cover and took the trash bag. He tore open the dehydrated food bags."

Kym came downstairs to find the door open and a small bear in the kitchen eating dog food. Kym yelled at the bear and it started to retreat. Kym tried to close the door against the bear which then pushed the door forward to grab a bag of dog food, overpowering Kym. Kym secured the house and in the morning found the dog food bag and scat on the lawn close to the house. They had just installed a push lever handle enabling easier opening of the door. She could not see a tag or collar on the bear. The bear was described as non-aggressive.

Kym came downstairs to find the door open and a small bear in the kitchen eating dog food. Kym yelled at the bear and it started to retreat. Kym tried to close the door against the bear which then pushed the door forward to grab a bag of dog food, overpowering Kym. Kym secured the house and in the morning found the dog food bag and scat on the lawn close to the house. They had just installed a push lever handle enabling easier opening of the door. She could not see a tag or collar on the bear. The bear was described as non-aggressive.

LocationDetail: 1/4 mile West of Big Meadow on Big Oak Flat Road
IncidentDescription: Bear hit by vehicle. The vehicle struck a mid-sized bear on the left shoulder. The bear limped and ran off downhill and out of sight. The bear was unable to be located.

Visitor set down pack and began to set up tent. Visitor was within 10 feet of pack when the bear came in and took the pack. Visitors threw rocks and scared the bear away and recovered some food but the bear obtained trail mix, bars, mango, and almond butter. Bear was unfazed by people in the site.
Bear moved backpack 10 feet away, ripped a hole in the lid and pulled a package of beef jerky out, opened it and ate the beef jerky.
Bear moved backpack 10 feet away, ripped a hole in the lid and pulled a package of beef jerky out, opened it and ate the beef jerky.

LocationDetail: In the woods on the south side of the campground
IncidentDescription: The lid to a nutella jar and a peanut jar were found with canine punctures. An empty bag of prunes was also found, as were several paper bowls that had been ripped and punctured by teeth.

Reporting party heard the campers up the hill attempting to scare a bear away on and off for a half an hour. The next morning the reporting party discovered that the campers had hung their food, some of which the bear had obtained. Campers reported the incident on their bear observation as well as to Roda Tran a backcountry ranger. The victims, apparently could not fit all of their food in the bear canister and hung the remaining food.

While following 3131 behind the Ahwahnee, we saw the bear go up to the base of Royal Arches climbing route. We saw the bear rummaging through some packs and obtaining a small bag of food trash: Orange peels, a tuna can, builder's bar wrappers, Starbucks cans, and likely the bear ate a few craisins. We gave the owner a stern warning when he returned 10 minutes later.

Campers were asleep. I walked into the site and found a food locker open and a mess of food thrown around the locker. I followed the food and trash trail after waking up the campers. I found a torn open, empty bag of trail mix 50 yards away from the site still covered in saliva.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Trash was left in the vehicle. Gatorade bottles mostly. Bear broke the window of the vehicle. No food was present in the vehicle. Incident happened sometime after 0700. Employee heard the bear, but, "didn't want to go out in the rain."

Bear bent driver's door frame out a few inches, and tore off some of the rubber from around the window. Bear fur was found on the edge of the door. Bear did not gain access to the vehicle. No food or attractants in vehicle, only a couple of empty reusable grocery bags. Unsure what attracted the bear to the vehicle.

LocationDetail: Indian Village Shed behind Visitor Center
IncidentDescription: Bear broke back into the Indian Village shed after roof was repaired by B+G. Bear ripped off roof patch and obtained more acorns and food that was missed from the day before.

LocationDetail: Indian Village Shed behind the Visitor's Center
IncidentDescription: Food was stored in the shed. Bear ripped off the sun roof and random patches along roof to get in. Bear obtained flour and sugar.

Bear tore one of the skylights off the roof of the shed in the Indian Village. Bear got into flour, but didn't seem to get into anything else. Lots of food in fridge and in second room in building. Bear apparently only ate flour. Bear was inside when we arrived. When we opened the door he treed after climbing out of the roof hole he had created.

Bear tore one of the skylights off the roof of the shed in the Indian Village. Bear got into flour, but didn't seem to get into anything else. Lots of food in fridge and in second room in building. Bear apparently only ate flour. Bear was inside when we arrived. When we opened the door he treed after climbing out of the roof hole he had created.
Per owner, no food in car. Old food stains on front passenger seat. Seat was chewed and destroyed.

Unknown bear attempted to or gained entry of building where toilet paper and other paper products are stored in the valley near the sign shop. Noticed damage on the way to the office. Couldn't locate valley custodial to let us know any more details, but reportedly there was no food or attractants stored in this building.

At approximately 0915 hours, I received a call from dispatch that the Yosemite Lodge Gift Shop had been damaged by a bear. I arrived on scene and met with DNC security officer Mike. He said that he had seen a bear, weighing approximately 150lbs, during the last few days roaming around the Lodge. I examined the damage done to the North side of the building. It is my belief that the damage was done by a bear. Several pieces of wood siding were ripped off the building, along with a large amount of insulation. It appears that the bear was trying to get into the gift shop in order to find food.

Visitors were sitting about 7 feet from their locker. There were marshmallows on top of it. The bear came up and grabbed the marshmallows. The visitors did not notice the bear until it grabbed the food.

LocationDetail: Half Dome Junction on the JMT
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear was observed in visitor's campsite. Bear damaged a backpack and obtained food from a canister that was unsure if it was secured. Bear also attempted to get food from another canister. Bear entered the camp multiple times. Bear was observed but the visitors could not identify tags or collars. Bear was described as large, and an adult. Unknown whether canisters were secure. Also unknown type of canister. Bear obtained multiple items from canister and ripped into a pack for lip-balm. No food was present in the pack. When visitors tried to scare the bear away, the bear squared off and semi-bluff charged him. Canister incident was a second hand report.

LocationDetail: Half Dome Junction on the JMT
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear was observed in visitor's campsite. Bear damaged a backpack and obtained food from a canister that was unsure if it was secured. Bear also attempted to get food from another canister. Bear entered the camp multiple times. Bear was observed but the visitors could not identify tags or collars. Bear was described as large, and an adult. Unknown whether canisters were secure. Also unknown type of canister. Bear obtained multiple items from canister and ripped into a pack for lip-balm. No food was present in the pack. When visitors tried to scare the bear away, the bear squared off and semi-bluff charged him. Canister incident was a second hand report.

Bear got food from IGBC approved "Lighter1.com" brand canister by breaking the hardware that keeps the lid on. The visitor reported the bear at 2300 and described it as being "black". The bear got the complete contents of the container including: 2.5 bags of mixed nuts, half a salami, 2 bags of triscuits, 6 "Zoneperfect" bars, half a bag of vita-light juice mix.

Bear got food from IGBC approved "Lighter1.com" brand canister by breaking the hardware that keeps the lid on. The visitor reported the bear at 2300 and described it as being "black". The bear got the complete contents of the container including: 2.5 bags of mixed nuts, half a salami, 2 bags of triscuits, 6 "Zoneperfect" bars, half a bag of vita-light juice mix.

A bear with a White 81 tag in it's left ear was seen approaching climbers at the western base of El Capitan. It was described as bold and was chased off several times. The bear was later seen with a small pack and was eating a bag of chips. No trash was found by wildlife management upon arrival. It is unknown how the food was obtained or stored. The victim was gone, only the reporting party was present.

LocationDetail: Base of Magic Mushroom Trip route on El Capitan
IncidentDescription: Reportedly a young bear with a white or yellow all flex tag in it's left ear with the number 81, approached the victim's haul bag at the base of the El Capitan route Magic Mushroom trip on the eastern side. There was no food except for some ibuprofen. The victim rappelled several times to chase the bear off but it stayed close. No food was obtained but there was damage to the haul bag and contents such as sleeping bags and dry sacs. The bear was later seen around the base of El Capitan by climbing parties.

LocationDetail: Picnic table near the river adjacent to Camp 6
IncidentDescription: Second hand report from YC volunteers in Camp 6. White 3 obtained an entire picnic near parking area A at Camp 6. Visitors were afraid of the bear. Visitors attempted to yell at bear but she was undeterred. Shotgun round fired near bear but did not hit bear. Ryan Leahy yelled and chased the bear to Ahwahnee meadow.
Found bear 3132 with telemetry in Upper Pines West. Bear was tearing into a duffel bag full of dog food. Visitor forgot.
Found bear 3132 with telemetry in Upper Pines West. Bear was tearing into a duffel bag full of dog food. Visitor forgot.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Adult sow, came near our camp. We observed and followed from a distance. She was non-aggressive and comfortable with us watching her. We also saw a yearling. It was far more skittish and ran away soon after we saw it on the trail from Vernon to Tilltill Valley. No food obtained. The bear did get a bag of garbage, wet wipes, sunblock, and toothpaste. We recovered all items. Bear did not return to camp.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Adult sow, came near our camp. We observed and followed from a distance. She was non-aggressive and comfortable with us watching her. We also saw a yearling. It was far more skittish and ran away soon after we saw it on the trail from Vernon to Tilltill Valley. No food obtained. The bear did get a bag of garbage, wet wipes, sunblock, and toothpaste. We recovered all items. Bear did not return to camp.

The visitor staying in site 42 explained that she heard chattering from the neighboring site ( G 507 ) about the bear making an appearance. She then came outside to see the trash laying around. She then made conversation with the neighbors about what happened. They explained that they were sarcastically joking about leaving a ham hawk out next time. She then noticed chicken and chocolate left overs laying neatly on the ground. The instigators of the G 507 camp left before we could speak to them. Camp host Greg gave us the name and number of the potential victims: Hidalgo 416-262-6115

People were crowding around bear that was eating food at a picnic site. Victims were not present. Bear was surrounded by about 30 people. The bear was not worried about the people and showed no sign of fear. Hazed with paintballs and crossed river.

Visitors observed a bear on food in Housekeeping. The bear was surrounded by people, and didn't care about them and was eating food. The bear was reported as medium sized, medium brown. It had a yellow tag in left ear with only one number on the tag. The visitor who reported the incident was only observing the incident. Unknown who the victim was.

Bear approached cabin and awoke Dick who woke up yelling to chase the bear away. Dick opened his front door and hit the bear in the head with his door. The bear then attempted to enter the cabin by sticking its head in. Dick then attempted to slam the door shut and the bear moved a bit away. Dick then yelled and the bear moved on.

Bear seen on car by visitor around 0530 and reported to dispatch around 0900. The car contained bags of food, but no entry was made into the car. The rear spoiler was ripped off and there are many scratch marks on the vehicle. Ford Edge CA plate # 7AFD334.

White 3 (3132) was picked up strong on telemetry following the Camp 4 monitoring box being triggered. She was located and spotlighted under a tree at the edge of camp. She was eating at the base of the tree and did not respond to the lights or being approached. She was paintballed and yelled at to which she did not leave immediately, but quickly ran away and was chased and further paintballed. A bag of peanuts was found at the base of the tree.

885, 884, and 879 were called to a bear jam outside Housekeeping Camp by Traffic 1. 885 arrived first and observed Blue 53 standing over a small pile of trash. Traffic 1 reported Blue 53 had bluff charged him on multiple occasions as he waited for Wildlife. 885 got into position and yelled and paintballed him multiple times in the rump. Blue 53 ran straight uphill and we were unable to pick him up on telemetry. Five minutes later, 885 called law enforcement to file a violation on nearby tour bus with banana peels scattered around it and found violations inside. Door was easily pulled open by hand. LE decided to try and revoke permit through Ruth Middlecamp.
Second-hand report from a visitor in Camp 4 that a pack with food got ripped into by a bear. Packs were supposed to be hung in a tree. No other details aside from food present in bags.
Second-hand report from a visitor in Camp 4 that a pack with food got ripped into by a bear. Packs were supposed to be hung in a tree. No other details aside from food present in bags.

LocationDetail: In forested area above Snow Creek Trail
IncidentDescription: Hikers/backpackers had food stored in approved bear canister. They heard a noise in the middle of the night and in the morning the canister was gone.

Roved Lower Yosemite Falls on the way to Yosemite Village. White 3 was browsing logs and stumps across the creek from the Falls View/ Muir Plaque. Bear was about 100 feet away from visitors, no incident. When I arrived at the Visitor Center about 25 minutes later, before I could notify Wildlife of White 3's presence, a visitor approached the counter telling me people were getting within 20 or 30 feet of the bear. She also said one person tossed food to the bear. They were certain of the feeding, but uncertain as to the type or amount of food. Another visitor approached about 5 minutes later to tell me people were getting too close to a bear at Lower Falls. After first visitor report, I called Wildlife and they dispatched a unit to respond.
Foreign visitors had food at base of El Cap at Freerider. Climbers were up on the first pitch and saw White 81 get into their pack and eat their food.

A guest staying at Camp 4 told the rangers at Arch Rock entrance station that at 0300 a bear took a pack that was in a neighboring camp site. There was no description of the bear or if there was food present. There was only small pieces of the pack left at the site upon Wildlife rangers arriving.

The truck was left at Glacier Point Parking lot for two days (May 28&29). When returned the front right passenger window was smashed and glass was everywhere as if popped in. The truck had an alarm so the bear may have ran off as it didn't look like it entered the car. There was no food or scented items inside. Paw prints and scratches on the door along with smaller paw prints below. Possibly a sow and yearling.

Bear Hotline report from unknown Camp Tawonga employee reporting a bear canister taken from a campsite at Snow Creek during a Camp Tawonga organized backpacking trip. No bear was seen but the canister went missing sometime around midnight. There was no issue with the canister lid previously, so assumed it was closed properly. Bear canister was either Bear Vault or Backpackers Catch brand. Camp Tawonga contact at 209-962-7459. $10 food damage and $60 for the missing canister.

Bear Hotline report from unknown Camp Tawonga employee reporting a bear canister taken from a campsite at Snow Creek during a Camp Tawonga organized backpacking trip. No bear was seen but the canister went missing sometime around midnight. There was no issue with the canister lid previously, so assumed it was closed properly. Bear canister was either Bear Vault or Backpackers Catch brand. Camp Tawonga contact at 209-962-7459. $10 food damage and $60 for the missing canister.

LocationDetail: Confluence of Wilson and Matterhorn Creek on PCT
IncidentDescription: Backpacker reported a bear in his camp early in the morning. Bear tried to make off with pack, then bit into water bottle. Bear then tried to break into bear canister but was unsuccessful. Visitor yelled and threw rocks at bear and it ran off.
Bear 3082 Yellow 76 and cubs obtained (seen) food from LYV campground and were then chased away from it in Lost Lake area. Toothpaste and apple hand sanitizer damaged.
Bear 3082 Yellow 76 and cubs obtained (seen) food from LYV campground and were then chased away from it in Lost Lake area. Toothpaste and apple hand sanitizer damaged.

Bear obtained s'mores (chocolate, marshmallows, graham crackers) off picnic table. Visitors had back turned and were maybe 10 feet away. Bear 0968 was present in campground at the time of incident but visitor could not determine if bear had tags/collar. Visitors were given verbal warning about being too far from food and were educated on proper food storage. Incident was reported to a campground ranger but was not relayed to wildlife. **This is case number 2013:07:13-115**

LocationDetail: Junction of John Muir Trail and Mist Trail
IncidentDescription: Dispatched called with reports of an orange tagged bear that was bluff charging people off their food near the intersection of the John Muir Trail and the Mist Trail. I hiked up there and talked to around 30 people about what happened. All said that she got an abandoned pack and ate the food out of it but that she was not aggressive. She got very close to people, within 15 feet. I saw the bear and saw that it was Yellow 48. She was doing bear stuff but starting walking towards me and 30 visitors. She was nor being aggressive but got very close, around 15 feet. I yelled at the bear and she immediately ran away. When she was 30-40 feet away I paintballed her and she ran out of site.

LocationDetail: Junction of John Muir Trail and Mist Trail
IncidentDescription: Dispatched called with reports of an orange tagged bear that was bluff charging people off their food near the intersection of the John Muir Trail and the Mist Trail. I hiked up there and talked to around 30 people about what happened. All said that she got an abandoned pack and ate the food out of it but that she was not aggressive. She got very close to people, within 15 feet. I saw the bear and saw that it was Yellow 48. She was doing bear stuff but starting walking towards me and 30 visitors. She was nor being aggressive but got very close, around 15 feet. I yelled at the bear and she immediately ran away. When she was 30-40 feet away I paintballed her and she ran out of site.
Two cars had car doors opened by bear but not damaged. Other car belonged to a resident : Mary Clapp.

LocationDetail: 30 yard up from Illilouette foot bridge
IncidentDescription: Reported to Gavin at LYV on 6/30/13 that Y48 came into OB campground by Illilouette bridge. She knocked over bear canisters and sniffed at bathroom supplies. She did not obtain any food, however, visitors followed bear to its 'den' where they observed $250 worth of food supplies, clothing, bottles, notebooks, etc. that had been obtained. Gavin walked out from LYV and cleaned up the mess. Y48 was not witnessed obtaining these items.

LocationDetail: 30 yard up from Illilouette foot bridge
IncidentDescription: Reported to Gavin at LYV on 6/30/13 that Y48 came into OB campground by Illilouette bridge. She knocked over bear canisters and sniffed at bathroom supplies. She did not obtain any food, however, visitors followed bear to its 'den' where they observed $250 worth of food supplies, clothing, bottles, notebooks, etc. that had been obtained. Gavin walked out from LYV and cleaned up the mess. Y48 was not witnessed obtaining these items.

Admin 21 reported house broken into in Ranger Camp. Bear broke through screen of unsecured back window. Both back windows were open and front door was open with food items strewn about outside and inside cabin. Bear obtained hot sauce, yogurt, multiple types of cheese, and sauces. Bear did not eat entire fridge. There were scented items left out inside the cabin such as soaps, recycling, cleaning solvents, trash, etc.. Occupants are aquatics crew volunteers that should be aware of food storage rules and what needs to be stored in bear lockers/fridges. See other report for vehicle break in. Disciplinary action will be handled internally.

Admin 21 reported house broken into in Ranger Camp. Bear broke through screen of unsecured back window. Both back windows were open and front door was open with food items strewn about outside and inside cabin. Bear obtained hot sauce, yogurt, multiple types of cheese, and sauces. Bear did not eat entire fridge. There were scented items left out inside the cabin such as soaps, recycling, cleaning solvents, trash, etc.. Occupants are aquatics crew volunteers that should be aware of food storage rules and what needs to be stored in bear lockers/fridges. See other report for vehicle break in. Disciplinary action will be handled internally.

Admin 21 reported house broken into in Ranger Camp. Bear broke through screen of unsecured back window. Both back windows were open and front door was open with food items strewn about outside and inside cabin. Bear obtained hot sauce, yogurt, multiple types of cheese, and sauces. Bear did not eat entire fridge. There were scented items left out inside the cabin such as soaps, recycling, cleaning solvents, trash, etc.. Occupants are aquatics crew volunteers that should be aware of food storage rules and what needs to be stored in bear lockers/fridges. See other report for vehicle break in. Disciplinary action will be handled internally.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Adrianne heard bear outside her tent early in the morning. She woke up and observed a large bear eating a candle. She yelled at the bear. The bear dropped the candle and ran away. Adrianne picked up the candle and stored it in the locker. 1/6 or the candle was eaten and is 'now unusable.' I checked the monitoring box and bear 3520 was present in Camp 4 at 04:30

Unknown details, second hand report from a Tuolumne interpretation ranger. Visitors saw 'yellow 27' eating food out of a cooler at Glacier Point. No other descriptions of bear were given. Unknown how much food or what was eating. Bear hotline message.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: LYV SAR Intern reported to Gavin that visitor admitted to illegal food hang and bear obtaining bathroom materials from illegal food hang at Sunrise Creek camping area. I walked back to speak with visitors and they were away form their site. I left a warning/violation slip with a handwritten note that I would like to speak with them in the morning. I walked back in the morning with Victor 53, but they had already left.

Second hand report from a visitor that a bear entered a campsite and dragged two packs away that were left out. One of the packs contained food, the other pack was empty. The pack containing food reported as beef jerky.

LocationDetail: Lyell Fork between McClure and Ireland
IncidentDescription: Food was hanging because not enough room in canisters. PCT through hikers claim that they picked up extra food left by another hiker near Agnew Meadows. They then didn't have enough room for everything so they hung a bag which a bear obtained in the night. Bag contained- honey, oatmeal, coconut oil, and pop tarts.
Bear went in the window of a RV and obtain food from fridge/cabinets.
12 oz. bag or pretzels, 2 bags of chips, 2 apricots, part of a package of Thai noodles, and toiletries were found on scene. Bear broke into topper in pick up truck and opened tailgate.
12 oz. bag or pretzels, 2 bags of chips, 2 apricots, part of a package of Thai noodles, and toiletries were found on scene. Bear broke into topper in pick up truck and opened tailgate.

Bear half ran, half walked at a woman who was making sandwiches with her family. Woman was scared and abandoned her food. Park Ranger S. Spencer observed the bear, Yellow 48, eating the food and attempted to yell at the bear. The bear did not respond and acted aggressively. A crowd of 50-100 people gathered, some within 2 yards. The victim did crowd control and reported the bear to another ranger. The bear left when the food was finished.
Bear attempted to gain access to resident's home via window in back door. Bear broke window, but did not gain access.

Visitors reported losing their food to a bear at Vernon Lake. The bear obtained food from a backpack (which was damaged) 10 yards away from where the visitors were eating. The bear came back 10 minutes later and obtained the visitors dinner which they had been eating. The bear also returned again the next morning. No further details were given.

Visitors reported losing their food to a bear at Vernon Lake. The bear obtained food from a backpack (which was damaged) 10 yards away from where the visitors were eating. The bear came back 10 minutes later and obtained the visitors dinner which they had been eating. The bear also returned again the next morning. No further details were given.

"The bear was looking for canisters and walked through the meadow at 1am. At 3am we heard the camp across the creek whistle. Food was damaged by the water when the bear dropped the canister into the creek. The bear did not obtain any food. The night before, the bear got a friends bin, but we recovered it unopened. "

Wildlife units responded to the alarm in North Pines and saw B53 sitting by a fire ring eating potatoes and food left on the grill and table as well as trash from the outside of the bear locker. He was chased out towards backpackers camp.

LocationDetail: Junction with Cloud's Rest and Sunrise Creek
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear got into toiletries that had been hung in a tree. Items damaged include toothpaste, sunscreen and some garbage as well.

LocationDetail: Campsite with big stone on fire ring
IncidentDescription: Bear took black, rented bear canister out of a spot in the bushes around 1:40am. I got out and chased the bear away. I placed the canister deeper in the bushes. We were awake for another hour-hour and a half. We didn't hear it again, but in the morning it was gone. We also had a Bear Vault canister, but the bear didn’t touch it. On our hike out we found the empty and broken canister without lid about half way down the switchbacks.

LocationDetail: Campsite with big stone on fire ring
IncidentDescription: Bear took black, rented bear canister out of a spot in the bushes around 1:40am. I got out and chased the bear away. I placed the canister deeper in the bushes. We were awake for another hour-hour and a half. We didn't hear it again, but in the morning it was gone. We also had a Bear Vault canister, but the bear didn’t touch it. On our hike out we found the empty and broken canister without lid about half way down the switchbacks.

We awoke to see our canister gone with our cook kit originally on top, remaining on two downed trees. We searched down creek and in woods, but couldn't find it. Two girls camped across creek from us reported chasing a bear twice during the night out of there site.

We awoke to see our canister gone with our cook kit originally on top, remaining on two downed trees. We searched down creek and in woods, but couldn't find it. Two girls camped across creek from us reported chasing a bear twice during the night out of there site.
Woke at 21:00 6/25/13 to running sounds followed by a plastic volley noise. Hopped out of tent and did not see or hear the bear. The bear canister was missing.
Woke at 21:00 6/25/13 to running sounds followed by a plastic volley noise. Hopped out of tent and did not see or hear the bear. The bear canister was missing.

Visitor had gone to bed and stated that he thought he had put all items away. 874 and 880 responded to alarm and saw a bear eating a candle. They chased the bear away who was positively ID'ed as Blue 53. This case # is 124.

Witnessed bear getting food from backpack. Visitors had a young child and as the bear approached, they were frightened and ran away. They left behind their backpack which the bear got a hold of, found food (sandwiches, 2, bag of chips.)

We arrived to a car alarm sounding and found bear 3520 on food. He saw us and kept eating for about two seconds until we started chasing him. The bear destroyed a small backpack and obtained mixed berries, peanut butter crackers, and maybe a bit of leftover Lucky Charms. The car alarm was initiated by campers to try and scare the bear, but it did not work as the bear kept eating throughout the car alarm.

We arrived to a car alarm sounding and found bear 3520 on food. He saw us and kept eating for about two seconds until we started chasing him. The bear destroyed a small backpack and obtained mixed berries, peanut butter crackers, and maybe a bit of leftover Lucky Charms. The car alarm was initiated by campers to try and scare the bear, but it did not work as the bear kept eating throughout the car alarm.

Visitors awoke to use the restroom and saw a bear digging through their warm campfire ring. They had had s'mores earlier. Visitor found a half eaten citronella candle on the table, dirt on the table, and a paw print on the ground next to the table.

Josh (resident) heard banging at the kitchen window from his bedroom. He went to investigate and he came to see two bear paws on the window sill. The window was already open, but the bear had ripped the screen off and was attempting to get in the kitchen. Food was present in the kitchen but no food was obtained. Josh yelled "hey" and the bear slowly walked away until it got to the steep hill, then it 'bolted'/ran. Josh described the bear as a cinnamon colored sub-adult, small, no tags or collar identified.

Some animal obtained food from an abandoned cooler next to the kiosk. Dave Wright found the food scattered and thought it was raccoons or ravens, but since food had been eaten he pulled a case number.

Visitors heard something in their campsite at 03:30. The next morning they found a candle that had been bitten into but not consumed. They saw bear prints on the ground near where the candle had been damaged.
Bear reportedly dragged away backpack with deodorant inside. Backpack was retrieved- damaged. Sunrise Creek Campground.
Bear reportedly dragged away backpack with deodorant inside. Backpack was retrieved- damaged. Sunrise Creek Campground.
Found pack at side of trail with food/trash pulled out of it. Nothing but food garbage inside. Impounded at LYV.

Unknown amount of food taken by bear out of backpack. Visitor (reporting) walked upon scene when it was happening. Unknown amount of food and type. Reporting visitor said it looked like a snack type food.

The visitors in site 8 woke up to loud banging noises, and came out and saw a bear right next to them in the neighboring site (10). The bear had knocked over some Rubbermaid tubs of cookware, etc. and bitten/broken two cases of water bottles. It is unknown if there was actually food obtained or left out, but water bottles were damaged.
Bear canisters stolen by bear. Unknown if food was obtained. Canisters dragged/pushed into canyon and not recovered.
Bear canisters stolen by bear. Unknown if food was obtained. Canisters dragged/pushed into canyon and not recovered.
Bear canisters stolen by bear. Unknown if food was obtained. Canisters dragged/pushed into canyon and not recovered.

Scared it away twice. Third time bear snagged a canister and batted it away like a basketball. Only heard it, didn't get a good look third time. Container was stolen and pushed off cliff. Approximately $20 worth of food inside. Condition of food canister is unknown.

Scared it away twice. Third time bear snagged a canister and batted it away like a basketball. Only heard it, didn't get a good look third time. Container was stolen and pushed off cliff. Approximately $20 worth of food inside. Condition of food canister is unknown.
Messing with bear can 4 times, tore hole in backpack.

LocationDetail: After switchbacks next to Snow Creek
IncidentDescription: Bear pushed 6 bear cans into Snow Creek and off cliff east of North Dome. Four were retrieved, one was spotted, and one was not seen. All of the bear cans were not broken into, but water did get inside and ruin some food. Similar incidents occurred on Saturday June 22, 2013. One can was taken and broken into and food was eaten. The contents are unknown.

LocationDetail: After switchbacks next to Snow Creek
IncidentDescription: Bear pushed 6 bear cans into Snow Creek and off cliff east of North Dome. Four were retrieved, one was spotted, and one was not seen. All of the bear cans were not broken into, but water did get inside and ruin some food. Similar incidents occurred on Saturday June 22, 2013. One can was taken and broken into and food was eaten. The contents are unknown.

The bear threw the canister off the cliff, and it was not located. The food was stored properly in the canister. It is unknown if the canister broke at the bottom of the cliff and the bear obtained food. The canister contained oatmeal, emergen-C, coffee, quinoa, and lentils. It was a bear vault canister.

LocationDetail: Near the river behind the 200 loop of Upper Pines
IncidentDescription: The bear was observed eating food out of an unattended backpack near the river. Visitors took pictures and scared the bear away. The photos clearly show it to be Yellow 50. The amount of food obtained is unclear. By one report the bear ate a couple of sandwiches, and there was also shredded bags on the ground, one of Cheetos.

LocationDetail: Near the river behind the 200 loop of Upper Pines
IncidentDescription: The bear was observed eating food out of an unattended backpack near the river. Visitors took pictures and scared the bear away. The photos clearly show it to be Yellow 50. The amount of food obtained is unclear. By one report the bear ate a couple of sandwiches, and there was also shredded bags on the ground, one of Cheetos.

The visitors hid 2 bear canisters away from their campsite and when they woke up there was only one. They were unable to locate their canister but did find a different one in the river at the bottom of a small cliff that was sealed but waterlogged.

The visitors hid 2 bear canisters away from their campsite and when they woke up there was only one. They were unable to locate their canister but did find a different one in the river at the bottom of a small cliff that was sealed but waterlogged.

LocationDetail: East of the trail near the footbridge
IncidentDescription: The visitors woke up and their bear canister was gone. They later found their canister down the cliff, near the creek, without a lid and surrounded by food wrappers, etc. They could not locate the lid of the canister, and the body of the can was undamaged.

LocationDetail: Camping area on North side of stream.
IncidentDescription: Group was going to bed and NPS wildlife employee Mbrown picked up 3825 O15 on telemetry strong and saw a bear lurking at the outskirts of camp. Waited by the canisters for a while until bear moved away and became inactive. Approx. 15 mins after Brown left there was heard by the campers banging of the canisters. The campers yelled from within the tent and went back to sleep. In the morning both canisters were in the river and one was banged up and the contents smashed. The Bear Vault canisters were not broken and no food was obtained.

LocationDetail: Camping area on North side of stream.
IncidentDescription: Group was going to bed and NPS wildlife employee Mbrown picked up 3825 O15 on telemetry strong and saw a bear lurking at the outskirts of camp. Waited by the canisters for a while until bear moved away and became inactive. Approx. 15 mins after Brown left there was heard by the campers banging of the canisters. The campers yelled from within the tent and went back to sleep. In the morning both canisters were in the river and one was banged up and the contents smashed. The Bear Vault canisters were not broken and no food was obtained.

LocationDetail: Just southwest of Snow Creek falls.
IncidentDescription: The visitors had 2 bear canisters. One was rolled down into their campsite and was still there in the morning, the other one was gone and they did not recover it.

LocationDetail: Just southwest of Snow Creek falls.
IncidentDescription: The visitors had 2 bear canisters. One was rolled down into their campsite and was still there in the morning, the other one was gone and they did not recover it.

Case number 2013-07-28-116. The bear pushed the canister into the creek and off of a small cliff. They could not locate their canister in the morning but saw trash from inside of it. Items that were eaten from the canister include salami, cheese, peanut butter, crackers, bread, pancake mix, and candy.

Case number 2013-07-28-116. The bear pushed the canister into the creek and off of a small cliff. They could not locate their canister in the morning but saw trash from inside of it. Items that were eaten from the canister include salami, cheese, peanut butter, crackers, bread, pancake mix, and candy.

LocationDetail: Junction with May Lake trail and Olmstead trail
IncidentDescription: The bear tore a pack in search of food. No other details given, unknown if food was present or obtained.
The bear bit a water bottle and attempted to get into a bear canister without success, but the water bottle was damaged. Case Number: 20130728-117

LocationDetail: Campsite between Illilouette falls and creek
IncidentDescription: Heard neighbors yelling for at least 15 minutes to scare the bear; about 15 minutes later it approached our campsite but went away almost immediately when yelled at. We later saw food wrappers scattered at the other people's campsite that looked like the bear had chewed on.

LocationDetail: Campsite with steel grill fire pit
IncidentDescription: On 6/22/13 my wife and I camped at Snow Creek at the site with a steel grill over fire pit, approximately 300 yards southeast of the footbridge. After dinner I set our bear canister 30 feet from the tent with a pot/pan on top as I had been warned by Wilderness rangers of a female bear in the area that had learned to push canisters off the cliff to break the canister and obtain food. I felt that our canister was far enough from the edge that I would hear something prior to losing food. I got up at 02:30 and the canister was present. I got up at 05:30 and the canister was gone. I was able to locate the canister in the creek approximately 200 yards down creek from where we were camping. We did not hear the canister being moved the 100 yards perpendicularly from us to the creek. I was able to get close but not retrieve the canister. A rope will be needed to access the canister. The canister looked broken and some food was floating in the water, but I can't be sure. I feel horrible for leaving trash and food in the backcountry but I could not access the location to retrieve my canister.

LocationDetail: Campsite with steel grill fire pit
IncidentDescription: On 6/22/13 my wife and I camped at Snow Creek at the site with a steel grill over fire pit, approximately 300 yards southeast of the footbridge. After dinner I set our bear canister 30 feet from the tent with a pot/pan on top as I had been warned by Wilderness rangers of a female bear in the area that had learned to push canisters off the cliff to break the canister and obtain food. I felt that our canister was far enough from the edge that I would hear something prior to losing food. I got up at 02:30 and the canister was present. I got up at 05:30 and the canister was gone. I was able to locate the canister in the creek approximately 200 yards down creek from where we were camping. We did not hear the canister being moved the 100 yards perpendicularly from us to the creek. I was able to get close but not retrieve the canister. A rope will be needed to access the canister. The canister looked broken and some food was floating in the water, but I can't be sure. I feel horrible for leaving trash and food in the backcountry but I could not access the location to retrieve my canister.
Victim heard bear getting into the canister at 01:00. She tried to scare the bear away but to no avail. She found the canister the next morning broken open by a bent lid.
Victim heard bear getting into the canister at 01:00. She tried to scare the bear away but to no avail. She found the canister the next morning broken open by a bent lid.

The bear was standing on the side of the parking lot close to the entrance eating watermelon off the ground. Also present was a beer bottle and banana peel. Unknown origin of food. Bear obtained an unknown amount of the half-eaten watermelon. The bear was untagged and ran when approached.

Pulled into the trailer court with bear 2255 (Blue 69) very strong on telemetry. Pulled up to a dilapidated structure (Jim Sommers') residence. Building in poor shape. I took a shot and hit the bear with a bean bag. In the house was an open refrigerator with some V8, other fruit juice, and food trash. Food trash and recycling were scattered about the house. I was unwilling to explore the house because it appeared unsafe with too much clutter, debris, construction, trash, etc. There is possibly more food in the house.
Ripped door off hinges, got into trash and energy bars, and cat food. Bear sat on bed and got stickers all over the only screen door. No solid door.
Ripped door off hinges, got into trash and energy bars, and cat food. Bear sat on bed and got stickers all over the only screen door. No solid door.

The resident was staying at the house and around 5am she heard a crashing noise. She ran to the kitchen and saw a bear's head in the window. She yelled at the bear and it slowly got down out of the window. She watched it slowly walk down off the porch and down the hill. The bear seemed to not be afraid of humans. The window had been left open and the bear ripped the screen out to crawl in. Recycling was left outside. Case number 2013:08:13:103

The residents heard a banging noise and then found bear paw prints on their glass door. In the morning there were prints on every ground floor window and on their vehicle, but there was no damage or food obtained. The next day they saw a bear walk by the house in the morning.
People saw Yellow 48 obtain a backpack from a visitor that had left it while going down to the river. Case number 2013:07:07:103

LocationDetail: JMT and Vogelsang Junction near Potter Point
IncidentDescription: The bear canister was screwed closed but not past the locks on the lid. The canister was opened but not broken. The bear clawed through plastic bags and obtained food. Food eaten includes pancake mix, salami, power bars, Gu gel, crackers, and nuts.

The resident was sleeping on the front porch when a bear started sniffing on the porch. The bear was startled and stepped on the woman's toe. She has a claw mark but did not need any first aid. She chased the bear off.

The bear was described as aggressive and stole food from visitors while they were cooking, getting within one to two meters of them. The visitors made noise but the bear did not leave. They backed away and let the bear eat their food before throwing rocks and hitting the bear. The bear came back two or three time in the night and knocked over bear canisters and backpacks.
The bear rolled their rented canister away and in the morning they found it with the lid opened and trash all over.

Bear broke window frame, tried to rip out back seat. DNC stables employee stated that they saw a large light colored bear with no tag around 0130 in camp. Heard horns around 0145 from bear damaged car.

Observers saw bear breaking into car. Victim was not present. The bear broke drivers side window and there was glass inside and outside of the car. Bear obtained cookies and rice. Inside of the vehicle was damaged, but the remaining food was untouched. Observers said the bear was tagged, but did not see a color or number. They said the bear was dark brown.
