Observers saw bear breaking into car. Victim was not present. The bear broke drivers side window and there was glass inside and outside of the car. Bear obtained cookies and rice. Inside of the vehicle was damaged, but the remaining food was untouched. Observers said the bear was tagged, but did not see a color or number. They said the bear was dark brown.

Lima 2 arrived at the SAR cache around 06:45 to find a trash can knocked over with food and food trash scattered all around. A moldy loaf of bread had been partially consumed. The can was so full, it was unlikely ravens or raccoons could have tipped it over. There was a fair amount of food trash in it. Lima 2 said as of 21:00 the night before, the trash wasn’t even there but by the morning it was. Lisa Hendy said the trash can is usually not even at the location.
Window left 2 inches open. Bear broke out window and found bag of nuts in sack. Escaped with sack which was later recovered. Victim overlooked nuts in the car.
Window left 2 inches open. Bear broke out window and found bag of nuts in sack. Escaped with sack which was later recovered. Victim overlooked nuts in the car.

Bear approached a group of men sitting in a circle eating their breakfast. Bear took bag of granola placed next to man (~2 feet away). Bear ran 15 feet off and ate food. Bear was hazed with paintball but returned 20 minutes later and attempted to get more food in the same manner. Approached group stealthily and within 2 feet of humans.

Date approximate. Second-hand report of a bear obtaining an energy bar from a pack that was left in a tent vestibule overnight. Bear was described as small, no other details. Visitor already left, reported by camp-mates.

Climbers stashed water in a cooler at the base of Mt. Watkins. When they came down from their climb, the cooler was punctured by teeth and claws. They turned the cooler in to Valley Wilderness office.
Bear climbed up a hill and was next to us so we left our packs. As we were on the way to Nevada Falls, the bear was following us and took 3 bagels out of our pack.
Bear climbed up a hill and was next to us so we left our packs. As we were on the way to Nevada Falls, the bear was following us and took 3 bagels out of our pack.

Bear obtained cat food and potting soil. Resident reported seeing a small bear (< 3ft at rump) while feeding his cat on his front porch every morning around 6 am. The bear has obtained the cat food multiple times while the resident was inside. When he noticed the bear he tried to chase it away and claimed it was difficult to scare. Resident is a retired trail crew employee and explained he had chased many bears. This night he explained that the bear had dragged a bag of potting soil into his driveway and tore it open.

Bear obtained cat food and potting soil. Resident reported seeing a small bear (< 3ft at rump) while feeding his cat on his front porch every morning around 6 am. The bear has obtained the cat food multiple times while the resident was inside. When he noticed the bear he tried to chase it away and claimed it was difficult to scare. Resident is a retired trail crew employee and explained he had chased many bears. This night he explained that the bear had dragged a bag of potting soil into his driveway and tore it open.
Bear opened car door and ate food. Resident had just moved from Tuolumne so food was still in her car.

Visitors called dispatch after 1 hour elapsed and described a yellow tagged bear that ate their picnic while they watched. They were able to subsequently scare it away. The number they gave was unreachable thus their was no firsthand report.
Bear approached picnic area and took food. It took salmon, tortillas, dried fruit, chips, etc. The visitor scared it away.

Called to Yellow Pines for report of a bear returning to site D 6 times during the morning. En route, saw bear 3131 (purple 2) cross Southside Drive at Yellow Pines where it almost got hit by vehicles. Camper in Yellow Pines site D had pictures of bear 3131. Found a crate with clothes and toilet paper tipped over and toilet paper torn into and ripped apart. Couldn't find any evidence of food or scented items. Unable to pick up Purple 2's frequency despite just seeing him cross the road.

Visitor found a stuff sack on the trail behind the campground, near G loop. The stuff sack had been ripped open, Quinoa remained in the bag, unclear what items the bear obtained or whose stuff sack/ food it was. The reporting visitor was not the owner of the stuff sack.

Greg Coit drove up to a car and a bear was seen leaving the vehicle with food. The victim, Lisa Khan, called in and reported half a loaf of bread, half a bag of chips, and a jar of peanut butter consumed. There was no vehicle damage and no damage to packs etc. which were also in the car.

LocationDetail: Lehamite Creek junction w/ North Dome
IncidentDescription: Would not leave with noise. Cub ran away immediately. She was observed for about 10 minutes with lots of noise from us. She finally gave up. Extensive cosmetic scratches to bear canister but no food obtained.

We heard some noise in the night, I went to investigate and saw nothing, canisters were still there. In the morning one canister was gone, sauce pans that were on top were scattered everywhere. Canister was 25 feet from the tent before it disappeared. Searched all morning but could not find it. Assume it was pushed over the cliff. Canister #1854

We heard some noise in the night, I went to investigate and saw nothing, canisters were still there. In the morning one canister was gone, sauce pans that were on top were scattered everywhere. Canister was 25 feet from the tent before it disappeared. Searched all morning but could not find it. Assume it was pushed over the cliff. Canister #1854
Rolled canister but did not get food. Broke platypus and stove container. No food obtained.
Bear took the entire container. Container had food and a small red dry bag, medium orange ditty sack, and red first aid kit.
Bear took the entire container. Container had food and a small red dry bag, medium orange ditty sack, and red first aid kit.

Sow and cub approached camp after midnight. Sow waited while cub stood against tree and worked Ursack food bag. Food was obtained by both. Next morning a different medium brown adult bear was seen digging and picking around area where food had been. A smaller, lighter adult bear approached camp and was run off by the previous bear. Sow and cub were distinguishable only by silhouette, but we are sure the morning bears were different. Sow and cub got food and toiletries. Medium brown morning bear got some trash. Light brown bear unknown. Food obtained was overflow food (ramen, tuna, cheese), trash, toiletries (toothpaste). Food obtained was stored in an Ursack, which the bear destroyed. We notified the company of the incident. A platypus hydration bladder was also broken.

Sow and cub approached camp after midnight. Sow waited while cub stood against tree and worked Ursack food bag. Food was obtained by both. Next morning a different medium brown adult bear was seen digging and picking around area where food had been. A smaller, lighter adult bear approached camp and was run off by the previous bear. Sow and cub were distinguishable only by silhouette, but we are sure the morning bears were different. Sow and cub got food and toiletries. Medium brown morning bear got some trash. Light brown bear unknown. Food obtained was overflow food (ramen, tuna, cheese), trash, toiletries (toothpaste). Food obtained was stored in an Ursack, which the bear destroyed. We notified the company of the incident. A platypus hydration bladder was also broken.

Sow and cub approached camp after midnight. Sow waited while cub stood against tree and worked Ursack food bag. Food was obtained by both. Next morning a different medium brown adult bear was seen digging and picking around area where food had been. A smaller, lighter adult bear approached camp and was run off by the previous bear. Sow and cub were distinguishable only by silhouette, but we are sure the morning bears were different. Sow and cub got food and toiletries. Medium brown morning bear got some trash. Light brown bear unknown. Food obtained was overflow food (ramen, tuna, cheese), trash, toiletries (toothpaste). Food obtained was stored in an Ursack, which the bear destroyed. We notified the company of the incident. A platypus hydration bladder was also broken.
Tried to break into Bear Vault. Batted it about 35 meters down the hill. Had bear slobber all over it in morning. Smashed backpacker pot.

LocationDetail: Two miles north of Donahue Pass
IncidentDescription: Friend left her plastic pack liner against a tree. Her clean pot was in the bag so possibly the bear smelled odors from that. It dragged the bag 15 feet but left when we scared it. There was a rip in the plastic pack liner.

Bear entered housing unit through the kitchen side screen window which was reportedly open. The bear climbed in and out of the window at least two times. It took 3 people to yell and clap successfully to scare the bear away. No tags on the bear. It was described as large, at least 300 pounds. There was damage to the refrigerator which had been flipped upside down and unhinged. The screen was damaged. Food was scattered about the floor. Neighbors secured the food after chasing the bear away.

Bear entered housing unit through the kitchen side screen window which was reportedly open. The bear climbed in and out of the window at least two times. It took 3 people to yell and clap successfully to scare the bear away. No tags on the bear. It was described as large, at least 300 pounds. There was damage to the refrigerator which had been flipped upside down and unhinged. The screen was damaged. Food was scattered about the floor. Neighbors secured the food after chasing the bear away.
Bear got into food and trash hanging from a tree. Bear obtained eggs.
Bears came to the campsite 3 times. Bear obtained 2 cans of beef. Sow with 2 cubs. Victim scared the bear off each time. The cans of food were left out because they did not fit in the container.
Bear stole two different canisters from neighbor's site and carried them into the woods but was unable to open either. Scared the bear both times and got both canisters back.
Bear entered camp and tore into one backpack. It also batted food canisters around.

Bear attempted to open canister for 15-20 minutes. Bear smashed canister onto the ground. The contents of the canister were damaged due to all of the smashing around, but the bear did not get inside. The bear returned and yelling and throwing pine cones had little to no effect.
Something dragged one backpack from camp and destroyed it and its contents, an unopened freeze-dried food package.
Something dragged one backpack from camp and destroyed it and its contents, an unopened freeze-dried food package.
Bear got into food locker. Campers insisted that locker was closed properly.
Locker not fully latched. Bear obtained a box of cookies.

Resident heard scratching and thumping outside her house and saw a sub adult-sized bear, the same bear she had seen multiple nights recently, standing on top of a swamp cooler trying to get acorns stashed in the siding of her house by woodpeckers. The bear was scared away and we were UTL about 30 minutes after the incident. The only damage was a torn swamp cooler vinyl cover.

Visitor backpacking to Snow Creek. Bear can placed 30-40 feet from tent overnight. In the morning it was missing. Visitors found a cup/mug w/ a screw lid that had been placed near the bear can but was clean and had been moved toward the cliff and the screw lid was now off. Visitors did not see the bear and were active backpackers through the sierra.

Visitor backpacking to Snow Creek. Bear can placed 30-40 feet from tent overnight. In the morning it was missing. Visitors found a cup/mug w/ a screw lid that had been placed near the bear can but was clean and had been moved toward the cliff and the screw lid was now off. Visitors did not see the bear and were active backpackers through the sierra.

Awoke at night from an impact to the side of the tent. Protas assumed it was a branch falling on the tent, but in the morning she observed claw marks and a hole in the tent. She did not observe the bear.

Vehicle parked in group site had the back driver's side window slightly rolled down. The vehicle contained tick-tacks and packets of mustard. Unknown if the bear obtained food items. Vehicle owner made damage report with Tango 21 also. Vehicle owner was only contacted for a short amount of time on his way out of the park. Rear driver window was pulled down by the bear and broken. No bear was observed but Bear # 968 was in the campground the day before.
Bear broke into the back of a pickup. Resident cleaned up the mess themselves before LE arrived.

A bear took a backpack at 2 am that had food in it that the visitor forgot inside. The bear dragged the pack up the hill. The visitor got the pack back with slight damage, the bear obtained brownies. Later the bear knocked over a couple of bear cans.

A bear took a backpack at 2 am that had food in it that the visitor forgot inside. The bear dragged the pack up the hill. The visitor got the pack back with slight damage, the bear obtained brownies. Later the bear knocked over a couple of bear cans.

Bear was eating a bee trap when an employee walked by. The employee did not notice the bear under a bush until he was 10 feet away from the bear. The bear bluff charged to about 3 feet. The person yelled and backed off. The bear bluff charged two more times and eventually left. Other visitors also nearby at the time.

Visitors were cooking at picnic table with food out on top of their locker approximately 10-15 feet away. The bear came into/ on the edge of the campsite and took a loaf of bread and ran away with it when the visitors began to yell at it. UTL on bread, but bear returned twice more to camp before being paintballed and left for awhile.

Two bears approached a group of picnickers and were chased off enough for most food to be put away. 3132 returned and grabbed a bag of nuts that had been left behind when the visitors fled. I responded after V34 (J. Olson) had chased 3132 off. #510 remained in the area, and treed when I arrived. 3132 Returned about 20 minutes later and was hazed across the road with two slugs and yelling and chasing.

Bear obtained several pounds of nuts, orange peels, a banana, a pound of dried coconuts and many other miscellaneous items and a lot of trash. 3132 approached a busy picnic area with at least 50 people present. It walked towards a large group that had finished eating and were packing up. They attempted to scare it off without success. The bear ransacked the remaining food that was left and continued to eat for about an hour with a large group of visitors surrounding it taking pictures. I responded and hazed the bear out of the area with one bean bag and two slugs. I remained in the area to educate the 40 or so visitors who remained. The bear returned two more times and was hazed with high level both times.

Bear damaged three backpacks (2 day packs, 1 backpacking pack) during the night. Visitor observed bear and scared it off. Bear dragged packs away from tent. All food and scented items were stored in locker according to visitor. Inside packs were only napkins and water bottles with water in them. Bear was a sub adult with no visible tags or collar.

Larger bear. Visitor was unable to see color of bear because it was dark. Bear took a hydration pack which contained a camera. The camera was apparently lost or destroyed by the bear. The bear ate a few granola bars which belonged to another camper.

Larger bear. Visitor was unable to see color of bear because it was dark. Bear took a hydration pack which contained a camera. The camera was apparently lost or destroyed by the bear. The bear ate a few granola bars which belonged to another camper.
Wildlife units were tracking a bear and found a pack and a trail of nuts and empty plastic bag on ground nearby. There was a small tear in front of the pack.
Wildlife units were tracking a bear and found a pack and a trail of nuts and empty plastic bag on ground nearby. There was a small tear in front of the pack.
Baby clothes, a camera, water bottle, and sunscreen were found strewn about across the road in North Pines. An apple was shredded. Pack was found damaged.
Baby clothes, a camera, water bottle, and sunscreen were found strewn about across the road in North Pines. An apple was shredded. Pack was found damaged.
Trash was ripped up, attractants were filling the site, there was food in the fire, bug spray, soap, etc. Visitor claimed trash belonged to someone else, but other attractants were present.
Found bear eating a bag of apples while spotlighting in response to an alarm. Unknown source of food. Questioned.

Locker found by campground ranger open with food pulled out, eaten, and torn up. Small footprints unidentified at site. Visitors one site away did not hear the bear. Pictures of footprints were taken. May have been bear 3132 and another animal followed after she left.
The bear ate an unknown amount out of an 8 oz. bag of chocolate pomegranate. The visitor couldn't remember how much was left. They were cited by Hotel 41 and 11. We chased the bear across the road.

LocationDetail: Behind Maple building at Yosemite Lodge
IncidentDescription: 2 people standing by table full of food. Bear approached, startling the people who backed away. Bear consumed an entire bag of chips.
We found the bear eating out of a plastic bin full of food. The bear ate an entire, very large package of rolls. The food had been accidentally left out. The whole package contained 2160 calories.

Backpack was found ripped and scattered in the morning by R. Kirtland and impounded. Unknown if/ how much food was obtained. There was supposedly a GoPro in the pack that was not recovered (as reported to LE later upon impound release).

Backpack was found ripped and scattered in the morning by R. Kirtland and impounded. Unknown if/ how much food was obtained. There was supposedly a GoPro in the pack that was not recovered (as reported to LE later upon impound release).
Visitors in site reported to Dave Hahn (V-22) about a bear getting their backpack last night. The bear ruined the pack.

The visitors were sitting at their table with hot dog buns next to their locker approximately 5 feet away. The bear 3132 had been hanging out on the border of camp. It approached their site and took the bag of buns and walked off calmly. It then stayed near the site and did not react to yelling by the people. Behavior described as bold and calm.
Ice chest left out. He said there was not enough space in locker. Occurred at 0230 hours.
Ice chest left out. He said there was not enough space in locker. Occurred at 0230 hours.
Scout group came late. They were sloppy and left pack out with possible food in it. Hazed bear with voice. Third hand report to NPS. Possibly obtained food.
A bear ate a melon that was left out. It walked off across the bridge to North Pines. 2nd hand report.

Bear heard sniffing near our tent. I saw and yelled at the bear and it ran away. Later I heard a lot of banging sounds in another part of camp. Another camper said that at 14:00 a bear broke into someone's improperly stored food and ate it all. Camper did not describe any attempt at discouraging the bear. I saw the bear, but it was dark and it was running away.

A lady told me that she talked to a woman during breakfast this morning at Curry that a bear stole a pack from their campsite this morning before breakfast. She didn’t know anything else about the incident, although she said that they reported the incident to "a ranger" but we never heard anything about it.
Found by A. Minich in the rear loop of Upper Pines. Looks like the bear obtained Capri Sun and bubble gum.
Bear took a backpack and ate a pack of Welch's Fruit snacks. We scared the bear off with noise.
Bear took a backpack and ate a pack of Welch's Fruit snacks. We scared the bear off with noise.
Bear came in camp 4 or 5 times. We screamed at him and he went away and visited other camp sites in the area. Bear obtained lasagna.

Bear 3131 approached tent and dragged two packs out from the open vestibule area of tent. The bear bit into one of the packs, ripping it. The other pack was undamaged. The damaged pack had no food in it, but did have food odors. The visitors yelled at the bear to no avail. We showed up and easily scared 3131 away.
Bear 3131 ripped a backpack containing granola bar wrappers and Ziploc bags. One may have had some cashews left in it.

Visitors reported bear obtaining food from a neighboring picnic table after the bear approached some people and scared them off their food. Visitors showed pictures of bear 3131 eating a plate of food from the table.
The visitors left granola bars and sunscreen in a pouch of a camp chair. The bear ripped the chair and ate one granola bar. We chased her across the river.
The visitors left granola bars and sunscreen in a pouch of a camp chair. The bear ripped the chair and ate one granola bar. We chased her across the river.

Eating food at picnic table, bear walked into site. Visitors attempted to scare it off by clapping, but bear ran off with pack. When bear team arrived she bluff charged. Paintballed but continued to circle campsite. Bear 3131 was extremely persistent, other team members arrived with shotgun.

Eating food at picnic table, bear walked into site. Visitors attempted to scare it off by clapping, but bear ran off with pack. When bear team arrived she bluff charged. Paintballed but continued to circle campsite. Bear 3131 was extremely persistent, other team members arrived with shotgun.
Bear 3131 observed bluff charging by guest who reported to hotel staff. Wildlife units saw 3131 in lot near additional hotel staff who reported more bluff charging.

The visitor left food out in his backpack and forgot to put it in the canister. The bear dragged off the pack while some other visitors yelled. The top brain portion of the pack was ripped. The bear ate a couple packages of pasta and bit some soap. I recovered the pack behind a boulder near the site but did not see the bear. 3131 was very close on telemetry and was seen in North Pines.

The visitor left food out in his backpack and forgot to put it in the canister. The bear dragged off the pack while some other visitors yelled. The top brain portion of the pack was ripped. The bear ate a couple packages of pasta and bit some soap. I recovered the pack behind a boulder near the site but did not see the bear. 3131 was very close on telemetry and was seen in North Pines.
Bear grabbed backpack that people were standing 100 feet from. 326 came upon the scene almost immediately and chased her into the bushes/ talus. Bear 3131 was the only GPS collared bear around.
Bear grabbed backpack that people were standing 100 feet from. 326 came upon the scene almost immediately and chased her into the bushes/ talus. Bear 3131 was the only GPS collared bear around.

While we were impounding food from swinging bridge picnic area, visitors claimed there was a bear nearby, towards the 4-Mile trailhead. I then grabbed the shotgun and Jess (879) grabbed the telemetry. As we walked towards the bathroom of swinging bridge, I heard and saw Shelby (878) chase after the bear. The bear then stood its ground and bluff charged Shelby. I then proceeded to chase the bear out of the picnic area with the shotgun and was able to connect with 1 rubber slug. The bear then ran into the meadow.
Bear bit into a baggie of soap and knocked over Tecate cans with limes. A tortilla was also present, but we had tracked the bear through camp and chased her away before she ate the food.
People were yelling and waving arms at the bear. Bear lunged 3 times while man was blowing his whistle, then lunged at a man who was clapping. Other bluff charges were probably purple 2 (bear 3131).
Bear bluff charged.

Woman informed laundry service of bear crossing the street. The bear came by the rental desk and the first cabin. One employee yelled and attempted to chase the bear but was bluff charged. Two others yelled and ran after the bear after the first guy retreated. Bear was lethargic, never fully ran, and meandered across the street into the woods.
Big bear came into camp and got a backpack that had crumbs in the bottom of it. Bear was scared off by neighboring site. Bear ran away quickly.

While packing and repacking for day hike, occupants of Lower Pines 45 had left their food locker open and unattended. A bear approached the locker and removed a box containing multiple bags of potato chips. The bear moved approximately 15 feet to the north between sites 59 and 60 and began to eat the chips. Visitors from site 60 tried to chase the bear but the bear bluff charged all three visitors. They then were assisted by other campers and scared the bear toward the river. A short time later these visitors heard yelling from the volunteers camping area.
Bear came into camp/tent cabin and took backpack with lunch in it. Visitor was standing 10 feet away.
Reported through email. Bear walked through camp and up to people before it finally approached a campsite and took a backpack and ran away. Unknown if pack was recovered.

Bear was messing with table of dishes. Visitors heard ripping sound, saw it was a bear, yelled, and the bear scampered off. Visitors followed the bear because it had a pack. The bear would pause and look back. Visitors decided bear was too bold to pursue for pack. Wildlife found sunscreen and ripped up bag of trail mix and pepperoncini. Wildlife heard screaming through camp. Victims were in tent when incident occurred. When the neighbor shined a light on the bear, it did not leave or react but did scamper eventually. Pack retrieved near north pines site 319.

Bear was messing with table of dishes. Visitors heard ripping sound, saw it was a bear, yelled, and the bear scampered off. Visitors followed the bear because it had a pack. The bear would pause and look back. Visitors decided bear was too bold to pursue for pack. Wildlife found sunscreen and ripped up bag of trail mix and pepperoncini. Wildlife heard screaming through camp. Victims were in tent when incident occurred. When the neighbor shined a light on the bear, it did not leave or react but did scamper eventually. Pack retrieved near north pines site 319.

Bear 3131 set off the alarm and was chased out of campsite. 3131 then circled back and was on a medium bag of trail mix when we spotted her again. She was chased (reluctantly) out of camp again and paintballed. 3131 took the trail mix with her. She dropped some trail mix on the way out. The visitor at the site claimed that she had put all of her food away earlier and that someone's kids had probably dropped it in their campsite.

Came out of site 189 and neighboring campsite left out food and bear was at the bear box inspecting. Neighbors 191 left food out and bear obtained hamburger, went back into tent and heard bear rummaging through camp. Stayed for a while and then walked away.

Message from Bear Hotline saying at noon she saw a bear with a tag #2 that stole a backpack from a campsite and swam across the river with it. Wildlife crew responded around 14:30 and nobody there knew anything about the incident and bear 3131 (Purple 2) was not very close to the area.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Used telemetry to locate bear 3131 (purple 2). Heard yelling and people scared the bear away from their campsite. The bear ripped their backpack and pulled out an empty beef jerky package before running away.

Bear was seen pawing at tent trying to pull clothing and gum out of vestibule. Visitor made noise, bear then proceeded to move to another site then into grove of trees behind North Pines. It grabbed a onesie while waddling into the grove, but dropped it. The bear obtained gum.

Purple 2 was found at a food locker that had one door open. She picked up a loaf of bread and ran. She was chased out of camp. Purple 2 ate most of the bread, 8 pieces. The visitors said that they closed the locker before they went to bed. It was their first time in the park and they did not have experience with bear lockers. They said that nothing else was missing and that the bread bag had 8 slices left.

At 02:00 neighbors of site 227 witnessed a bear walking through site 227 and obtain items from a left-out bag. Neighbors scared bear away. Unknown how much, if any, food was in the trash bag, but visitor believed it was mostly just food trash and recycling. GPS data confirms that bear 3520 walked through the 227 loop of Upper Pines at almost the exact time of the incident. GPS map attached to incident report. Visitors reported that the bear was collared.

Found bear 3131 using telemetry and spotlight near the river at North Pines. Chased after her with paintballs. She crossed the river but left a pack where we saw her. The pack had ripped up wrapper and a Capri sun. It looked like the bear had chewed through the wrappers and obtained food but not sure because we could not find the owners of the pack. Also, the pack was drenched. Maybe she dragged it from across the river.

Found bear 3131 using telemetry and spotlight near the river at North Pines. Chased after her with paintballs. She crossed the river but left a pack where we saw her. The pack had ripped up wrapper and a Capri sun. It looked like the bear had chewed through the wrappers and obtained food but not sure because we could not find the owners of the pack. Also, the pack was drenched. Maybe she dragged it from across the river.
Bear 3131 had the pack in the woods when we found her. She was chased away from the pack. It looked like there was a mostly eaten lunch on the ground nearby and a container of lotion.
Bear walked into campsite, grabbed pack from 10-15 feet away. Visitors chased bear and retrieved pack, carrots, snap peas, granola bars
Locker not fully latched. Bear got a bag of popcorn and some trail mix. People did not chase bear.
Reported through email of a secondary report of a bear approaching a visitor cooking and getting some of his food.

second hand report from victor 31 that 3132 obtained food from a small stuff sack with granola bars in it. Visitors heard a noise, shined their flashlights and clearly saw tag white 5 as the bear was eating their food. Bear took sack and ran across the road.
There was a bear in housekeeping camp. People chased the bear out of camp. It bluff charged them. May be bear 3131.

Visitors thought all food was put away but they had missed something. Chased 3520 out of Lower Pines. When I found him at Upper Pines, he was 25 yards behind a campsite. Visitors were looking through their camp. I saw 3520 with something on the ground. I chased him and he dropped most of the box of graham crackers but still had some. I recovered what he dropped and he ran off. Visitors said they come here every year and never had a bear get food. The box of crackers had fallen behind their bear locker and they did not see it.

LocationDetail: Woods behind orchard lot and tent cabins
IncidentDescription: Found 3520 in the woods eating a pack. Bear was easily chased away. Bear ate brownie. Unknown location of pack before pack was taken. Pack contained PCS and law enforcement was contacted.

LocationDetail: Woods behind orchard lot and tent cabins
IncidentDescription: Found 3520 in the woods eating a pack. Bear was easily chased away. Bear ate brownie. Unknown location of pack before pack was taken. Pack contained PCS and law enforcement was contacted.
Food stored properly. Bear messed with plastic cups and utensils on top of food locker and destroyed some plastic cups. No food was obtained.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear entered site and ate part of an unscented candle that had been left out. Second hand report. Another visitor saw the bear in the site and the candle was eaten.

Possible scent on sleeping bag. LYV ranger reported that a bear bit into an occupied sleeping bag. The visitor awoke and the bear ran off. Second hand visitor observation: they could see the teeth marks in the sleeping bag. Not sure what the bear was interested in. Unknown if there was food or scented items in the sleeping bag. The visitor in the bag was not in a tent, just out on a tarp.

People walked away for a short time. A visitor had left his bag with food out for a short time. He walked away to grab something when a bear snuck up and grabbed the bag. The visitor yelled and chased the bear. The bear dropped the bag, ran off, and came back to the same campsite later. No more food was obtained. Trail mix and triscuits obtained.
Bear grabbed a pack with a camelback bladder inside. Unsure of the contents of the bladder. The pack was found ripped in two, but the bladder was not recovered.
A bear consumed sunflower seeds left in a visitor's pair of pants and in his/her backpack. Unknown as to where the pants or backpack were left out. This was a second-hand visitor report.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: From LYV Ranger camp log: bear ripped open a pack for hand wipes. Unsure as to how the wipes were not obtained.

Victim rationale was disregard for food storage rules. After being warned they still walked away and did not store food in their canisters. Bear obtained 10,000 + calories in the form of clif bars, Luna bars, other food, possibly medication. Bear team responded to banging canisters to find the bear standing over several canisters. Bear ripped backpack containing food, wrappers, bottles, toiletries. Bear team found a canister at the bottom of the hill that had been open.

Victim rationale was disregard for food storage rules. After being warned they still walked away and did not store food in their canisters. Bear obtained 10,000 + calories in the form of clif bars, Luna bars, other food, possibly medication. Bear team responded to banging canisters to find the bear standing over several canisters. Bear ripped backpack containing food, wrappers, bottles, toiletries. Bear team found a canister at the bottom of the hill that had been open.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: woman reported seeing a bear rip through her kitchen-tent screen and completely devour a citronella candle.

Bluff charged by bear 3131 in Happy Isles. Standing 40 feet away in uniform, yelling. The bear came incredibly close. Followed and found her on Mist Trail surrounded by visitors. Yelled to make the bear leave but unresponsive.
Visitor did not see or hear bear, but had canister "tied" to tree with straps. Everything apparently stored properly but the canister disappeared.

Bear 3132 walked in to camp. Liz Williamson immediately tried to yell and scare the bear. It got up on its hind legs and bluff charged Liz. Liz recruited other campers, and with enough people and yelling, the bear walked and then ran away. Breakfast was cooking so odors were prevalent, but all food was within arm's reach.

Three guys from Chile got done eating/ cooking and were putting stuff in bear locker. They turned away for a second and a bear (Blue 54) came in and got a 1/2 bag of marshmallows. They spotlighted him and he took off with the bag. Visitors had good picture of Blue 54.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Found bear 3520 at campsite eating citronella candle. We chased him out of campground. It looked like he ate/ carried away most of the candle. The campers at the site said that nothing else was missing or moved. Case number is 2014-07-12-125.
Visitor reported a bear obtaining food from another camper, possibly out of a backpack. Bear also took a jacket and checked out other packs in the area.

LocationDetail: Junction of Cloud's rest and JMT
IncidentDescription: Food stored properly in canister. Bear was persistent and was around camp for awhile, going from one camp to the next. Bear walked within 10 yards of two camper's beds. Camping at junction of JMT and Cloud's Rest Trail. Bear first appeared at around 20:30 and was around until 02:00. Bear messed around with bear cans but did not get food. Did roll 1 can about 50 yards down the hill. Bear apparently damaged a backpack.
Food stored properly in a locked bear canister. Visitor heard grunting sounds and was missing a canister in the morning.

Small bear stole and tore up pack of hiker who was camping without a permit and without a bear canister, near Cloud's Rest junction of John Muir Trail. Another hiker met this man and came to the VC to report the incident. Said he also told a ranger at half dome. Bear got food from side bag. Bear obtained power bars and perhaps other stuff.

Small bear stole and tore up pack of hiker who was camping without a permit and without a bear canister, near Cloud's Rest junction of John Muir Trail. Another hiker met this man and came to the VC to report the incident. Said he also told a ranger at half dome. Bear got food from side bag. Bear obtained power bars and perhaps other stuff.

LocationDetail: .5 miles from half dome JMT junction
IncidentDescription: Bear walked through camp and took a backpack about 50 yards from camp. We found the bear there eating sunflower seeds from the pack. We scared the bear away but it returned several times.

LocationDetail: .5 miles from half dome JMT junction
IncidentDescription: Bear walked through camp and took a backpack about 50 yards from camp. We found the bear there eating sunflower seeds from the pack. We scared the bear away but it returned several times.

The visitors heard a scratching noise and jumped out of the tent. A bear was about 20-30 feet away at the fire pit, and about 10 people out there yelling managed to scare the bear away. They noticed that their tent and 65 liter backpack were ripped, and could not remember any food being left inside, but thought that maybe it was smells from the previous backpacking trip. They also spoke to a neighboring camper and found out that the bear had recently approached him and gotten food while he was cooking breakfast.

The visitors heard a scratching noise and jumped out of the tent. A bear was about 20-30 feet away at the fire pit, and about 10 people out there yelling managed to scare the bear away. They noticed that their tent and 65 liter backpack were ripped, and could not remember any food being left inside, but thought that maybe it was smells from the previous backpacking trip. They also spoke to a neighboring camper and found out that the bear had recently approached him and gotten food while he was cooking breakfast.
The visitor woke up to a ripped pack, the scout leader found it in the morning. The bear ate chocolate and bit into sunscreen.
The visitor woke up to a ripped pack, the scout leader found it in the morning. The bear ate chocolate and bit into sunscreen.

The bear obtained one granola bar that was left out inside of a pack. The visitors did not see the bear, but based on noises, were convinced it was a bear and not a raccoon. Bear 3132 was moderate on telemetry and had been in camp recently.

The visitors were about ten feet away from their picnic table and White 5 grabbed a loaf of bread off of the table and ran away. The bear came back but they scared her off and she did not obtain more food.
The bear approached picnickers and they made noise but could not scare the bear off. The bear got minimal food, some trash, and soda.

Food was found on the ground. It included chips, mountain house meals, Clif bars, beer cans, and Odwalla bars. It was the result of an illegal food hang. The bear ate all of the food and only trash was left when Wildlife Management staff got there. No victim was present.

Food was found on the ground. It included chips, mountain house meals, Clif bars, beer cans, and Odwalla bars. It was the result of an illegal food hang. The bear ate all of the food and only trash was left when Wildlife Management staff got there. No victim was present.
The bear canister was placed in a sleeve, and the bear was able to bite and move the sleeve and canister. The sleeve was damaged but no food was taken.

The visitor hung food trash from a tree because it wouldn’t fit in the canister. The bear climbed the tree and ate all the trash and food. The bear was active all night in that area, and was hesitant to back away when yelled at.

Sometime between 5/31 and 6/5 a bear ripped in to an unoccupied tent belonging to Visitor Use and Social Science. No food or attractants were inside the tent. This incident might have been reported by Victor 26 Ian Rippetoe as well.

A platypus containing water was left outside the tent and in the morning was bitten seemingly from a bear. The food was all in a canister and was un-disturbed. In the morning a bear walked through the campground.
Tuolumne SAR member staying in Yellow Pines had their rain fly ripped by a bear. There was no food, trash, or scented items in the tent. The rip was about 12 inches long.

Sometime during the night a bear ripped an approximately 6 inch hole in the tent. There were 5 gashes in approximately the same configuration as claws. There was also a water cooler knocked over. The visitors saw and heard nothing. There was no food in the tent. The visitors were asleep.

LocationDetail: next to site 20 and front of restroom
IncidentDescription: An unknown bear (no transmitter based on monitoring box data) obtained an entire locker full of food and the people in the site fled the campground in the middle of the night. Large amounts of food trash were strewn about the site. Bear obtained health natural bars, Doritos, Pringles, etc.

Visitors were eating their food when white 5 started to approach them. They then put the majority of their food in their locker, leaving some behind. They became very frightened and claimed the bear was being aggressive. They got into their cars and watched the bear eat marshmallows and trash from their picnic table. Wildlife units arrived and chased the bear away by yelling and paintballing.
The bear got into the locker at site 118 that was closed incorrectly, and some food was left out on the picnic table. Other campers said they saw 3132 eating the food when they heard yelling.

The bear entered the tent and grabbed a backpack containing no food. The visitor deployed bear spray at the bear. We chased the bear out of Housekeeping all the way to the Curry Dorms. The visitor then went to the bathroom and exposed his genitals and the ambulance got called out because he got pepper spray on his genitals.

Campsite 225 in Housekeeping camp left out two coolers and they were obtained by an unknown bear, they said it had a tag. The campers were verbally warned by Law Enforcement on multiple occasions due to noise, large fire, and a messy camp.

White 5 (3132) was followed by telemetry by wildlife in housekeeping. She managed to rip open the bottom of a backpack that contained minimal food items; a baggy with peanuts that visitors said was empty, and a small bag of almonds that was mostly gone. She was chased off the backpack by bear techs and was chased across the bridge to lower river campground. She ripped open a new Osprey pack.

White 5 (3132) was followed by telemetry by wildlife in housekeeping. She managed to rip open the bottom of a backpack that contained minimal food items; a baggy with peanuts that visitors said was empty, and a small bag of almonds that was mostly gone. She was chased off the backpack by bear techs and was chased across the bridge to lower river campground. She ripped open a new Osprey pack.

Dave Curtis was just moving in to the house. It was empty except for food and no on e was home. Some time on the night of the 24-25 a bear entered the house and ate everything in the kitchen. The doors are old and do not latch well. The door must not have been fully latched, and the bear opened it. The door was not intentionally left open. The bear ate backpacking food, power bars, oatmeal, and everything in the refrigerator. Likely 2255.

The resident was out of town and a bear got into her house through a door that had been propped open for her sick cat. The screen/door in to the kitchen was unlatched. The bear ate cheese, bacon, and a couple other items out of the refrigerator. There was no damage to the building. The next night the bear came back, but there were people staying there and they chased it off. It came back multiple times and was very persistent. Likely 2255.

The bear opened the car door and ripped open the glove box. There was a cookie that had been accidentally left in there from earlier in the day. There was minimal damage to the vehicle in the glove box.

The bear opened the car door and ripped open the glove box. There was a cookie that had been accidentally left in there from earlier in the day. There was minimal damage to the vehicle in the glove box.
The bear scared off a family while they were eating lunch. The bear got one pound of cherries and one pound of oatmeal.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek/ JMT junction. Campsite to the east.
IncidentDescription: The visitor left the bear canister unscrewed, the bear obtained full jars of peanut butter and Nutella, packets of oatmeal and powdered soup mix. Estimated around 8000 calories. The visitors claimed to have yelled, clapped, spotlighted, and thrown rocks at the bear. The bear returned again to the same canister which was now closed two times at 2:45 am and 4:15 am. Five members of bear team were camping below at a different campsite and were still awake during this time, they did not hear any yelling etc.

A PCT hiker forgot about a bag of trail mix in his pack, despite having been talked to by Wildlife staff and warned about 15 minutes prior to the incident. The bear fished the trail mix out of the bag without causing any damage and walked 15 feet away to eat it. Other visitors heard the bear eating and started yelling. The wildlife volunteer ran back and chased the bear six or seven times before it dropped the trail mix. The bear returned later and was messing with canisters.
Third hand report through K. Randolph of visitors who showed her a picture of a bear that obtained food from people picnicking by the river. The bear reportedly obtained meat.

Wildlife crew spotted a backpack that was dragged behind a tent about 20 feet. The owner was located by Wildlife staff. The bear ate 2 small Clif bars and there was no damage to the pack. The girl thought she had taken everything out of the pack, the pack was inside the outer port of the tent.

An employee who lives in site C75 heard visitors yelling. He got out of his tent to see a large bear in his campsite. He then yelled and chased the bear out of camp. He asked the visitors if the bear had gotten food and they told him that the bear ate a bag of M&M's. Another visitor said the bear was pawing at his tent before the bear was chased off.

A bear hotline report. Unknown name or address of a resident who called and reported a bear got in to his vehicle and tore up the back seat cushions and instrument panel. The bear also left a lot of scat in the vehicle . The phone number given was a wrong number when we tried to call back.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Alarm went off, wildlife responded to lower pines, found bear 3520 in campsite eating a citronella candle that he took from a picnic table. We spotlighted him and then chased him out of camp

Backpacks stored at junction against tree, bear dragged away and ripped into all 3 left on trail. Bear traveled 300 yards while being chased and yelled at. E packs, grey (4 inch tear on top, pocket on side ripped), Purple (top ripped, dry bag w/down jacked ripped, sleeping pad scratched and can see claw maps), orange (ripped large hole in center, 1 foot wide, strap broken, sleeping bag torn). No food taken, party estimates $500 of damage (200 bags, 200 sleeping bag, 100 misc.)

Tracked 3132 with telemetry, and found her in back of lower pines with food item in mouth, 871 fired 2 hazing rounds, dropped food (package of lunchmeat) and ran away as wildlife chased out of campground

Bear alarm went off in Lower Pines, we found W5 with telemetry outside of camp making noise, no visual, found shredded garbage in camp and shredded backpack with food items just outside camp, campers had food under a tarp that bear found and pulled the 2 packs from. Les responded, no citation given, French nationals didn't have a campsite and had no bear locker to store items in.

Bear alarm went off in Lower Pines, we found W5 with telemetry outside of camp making noise, no visual, found shredded garbage in camp and shredded backpack with food items just outside camp, campers had food under a tarp that bear found and pulled the 2 packs from. Les responded, no citation given, French nationals didn't have a campsite and had no bear locker to store items in.

Chased away five times, hit on tent and chewed padding on pack. Approached at close distance during five chases, not intimidated by noise or shouting. Padding on pack torn, estimated $90, no food in pack, all food items stored in bear canisters and left untouched by bear.

Bear obtained candy bars, returned 3 more times over 2 days, ripping at food bag filled with clean dishes, bear found snack bag left out, all other food in canisters. Bear returned at dinner time and after dark both nights, effectively scared off.
unknown food storage method. Bag of peanuts obtained in campsite, unknown origin

LocationDetail: 5690 Foresta Road, red house, bottom apt.
IncidentDescription: Employee from Ahwahnee had apartment broken into previously, wasn't able to re-secure house due to fire evacuation, bear re-entered on 7/30/14. bear opened door to basement that had no latch and entered the bottom of the house. Bear pushed in window to bathroom which leads directly to the kitchen. Resident claimed bear ate cliff bars and tried fruit. This is 2nd of 3 incidents at this residence in 1 week. Resident was away from home at time of the incident and upon arrival bear was UTL.

LocationDetail: 5690 Foresta Road, red house, bottom apt.
IncidentDescription: Employee from Ahwahnee had apartment broken into previously, wasn't able to re-secure house due to fire evacuation, bear re-entered on 7/30/14. bear opened door to basement that had no latch and entered the bottom of the house. Bear pushed in window to bathroom which leads directly to the kitchen. Resident claimed bear ate cliff bars and tried fruit. This is 2nd of 3 incidents at this residence in 1 week. Resident was away from home at time of the incident and upon arrival bear was UTL.

872 and 877 tracking bear 2255 in old El Portal on telemetry after previously hazing bear with bean bag ammunition, telemetry led wildlife to house with unsecured door that was pulled open by bear leading to basement of house. Bear was in kitchen eating food, bear became trapped (one exit) in structure, bear eventually left structure and chased/hazed by wildlife. Bear ran towards 872 on exiting house. Residents report this was 3rd time bear 2255 was in structure.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear was eating a citronella candle near the road when Wildlife staff came upon him. They honked and chased him off.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Wildlife responded to an alarm in Upper Pines West. Meanwhile, unit 326 (Dave) saw bear 3520 with a citronella candle in his mouth. Dave chased the bear and retrieved the candle which was only 1/4 eaten. Unknown what site the candle came from.

Visitors preparing sandwiches at dusk when they noticed a bear approaching. They were seated in their vehicle next to their food and watched the bear take a loaf of bread and run. They put their food away in the car. The bear returned, they honked their horn, the bear ran away. They watched the bear take food and did not scare it. They had pictures. The bear had a GPS collar and what looked like a white allflex tag on the right ear. 3132 active moderate on telemetry 45 minutes later. Likely white 5.
Campers awoke to eating sounds outside their tent. Black bear with collar eating watermelon from unknown source. Bear ran off when confronted after eating half of the melon.

We found 3520 Blue 54 on the edge of a campsite. He had food and was chased out of the campground unwillingly. When we returned we found a shallow hole filled with food including rice, chicken, waffles, and uneaten apples. The hole had been dug up and all of the food looked fresh. We picked up the food and threw it away. Campers at either side of the food cache said they knew nothing. Blue 54 returned to the same location multiple times during the following few days.
Bear 3520 seen eating something. Bear obtained corn from bean bags that were part of a child's game. Visitors had no idea the bean bags were full of corn. 4 bean bags and a Frisbee were destroyed.

Bear in vehicle in site 108 upper pines. Called out by dispatch. Arrived as bear had just left the area. Occupants of site saw tag #5 white and a gray collar. Bear remained in vehicle for 5-10 minutes and ate unknown quantities of food. At least a bundle of bananas. Bear was across seasonal creek to the north when I arrived. Thousands of calories with multiple bins and cooler inside vehicle. Bear entered open passenger front door. Visitors complained that the campsite was not peaceful enough and asked me to get rid of the bear. Moved all food to locker.

Resident called to say that upon moving back into residence after mandatory evacuation she noticed what looked like the bear had attempted to re-enter her house. The house had previously been broken into and the house had been re-secured by being boarded up. The bear apparently tore shingles off near the repair job but no entry was gained to the house.

We tracked 2255 through old El Portal and yelled at him as he entered the basement of an occupied residence. The bear refused to leave and was aggressively charging us as we attempted to get him out. Darted the bear at 04:00 and euthanized the next day.

Bear got into house after it was evacuated from fire. A friend went to check on it and the place was trashed. Unknown if any damage to building or how the bear got in. Ate a lot of food including whole fridge, dog food, and some dry goods from cabinets. Have since found out that the door to the house is never fully closed enough to latch.
unknown bear obtained corn from a child's bean bag game. Visitors heard bear eating something but did not, at the time, connect the dots that it was a bear in their site. Bear ate 5 bean bags.

Hotel 41 (Julian) saw a bear on top of a bear locker eating unknown item. He chased the bear out of the campground using 3 shotgun rounds. The bear obtained a half box of cheerios, and a couple bags of dried fruit. A tub was broken by the bear. Bear carried off unknown item into the woods.

Hotel 41 (Julian) saw a bear on top of a bear locker eating unknown item. He chased the bear out of the campground using 3 shotgun rounds. The bear obtained a half box of cheerios, and a couple bags of dried fruit. A tub was broken by the bear. Bear carried off unknown item into the woods.

a small bag of crackers and oatmeal left out in a bag. Bear ate the food in the bag some time around 03:30 and 04:00. Incident was reported by neighboring campsite and the people from campsite 60 had already left the campground. Neighbor said that the people in campsite 60 reported the incident to a ranger.
Blue 54 was on a fanny pack. He was chased out of the camp. The fanny pack contained crumbs, a few peanuts, and M&M's.
The bear was on a backpack and was chased out of camp. He dropped the pack and upon inspection it contained 2 granola bars. Unknown how much other food was in the pack that the bear ate.
The bear was on a backpack and was chased out of camp. He dropped the pack and upon inspection it contained 2 granola bars. Unknown how much other food was in the pack that the bear ate.

Visitors were staying in the SAR Site and left the resident's bear locker open after the SAR resident had gone to bed. The SAR resident woke up to the bear eating out of the food locker. The bear obtained a few bags of chips. The resident yelled and threw things and it ran away immediately. The bear was described as very large.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear bit into a container of "Odor B Gone." The container was about a quarter full. It is used to deodorize the vault toilets. The bear was being chased by interpretation rangers and did not obtain much of this liquid.

The visitors forgot that there was a bag of trail mix and one pouch of applesauce left out in a small backpack. The bear ripped the pack and ate the food. The visitors heard the bear and yelled but did not get out of their tent while the bear sat behind the locker and ate. GPS data shows bear 3520 in site 17 exactly at 4:00AM.

The visitors forgot that there was a bag of trail mix and one pouch of applesauce left out in a small backpack. The bear ripped the pack and ate the food. The visitors heard the bear and yelled but did not get out of their tent while the bear sat behind the locker and ate. GPS data shows bear 3520 in site 17 exactly at 4:00AM.

The visitor forgot that there was food in his pack. Other visitors saw the bear take the pack away from camp and eat the contents. They tried to chase the bear away and noticed that the bear eventually took the pack away. They searched the woods but didn’t find anything. They filed a lost and found report. The items included a Camelback, pack, hat, sunglasses, car keys, and small snack type food items.

The visitor forgot that there was food in his pack. Other visitors saw the bear take the pack away from camp and eat the contents. They tried to chase the bear away and noticed that the bear eventually took the pack away. They searched the woods but didn’t find anything. They filed a lost and found report. The items included a Camelback, pack, hat, sunglasses, car keys, and small snack type food items.

The visitor forgot that there was food in his pack. Other visitors saw the bear take the pack away from camp and eat the contents. They tried to chase the bear away and noticed that the bear eventually took the pack away. They searched the woods but didn’t find anything. They filed a lost and found report. The items included a Camelback, pack, hat, sunglasses, car keys, and small snack type food items.
The visitors left out a pack and the bear got it. It had a small bag of trail mix in it that was only about one quarter full. The pack was not damaged and nothing else was missing.

Liz Williamson found a ripped up pack near the Columbia boulder in Camp 4. Food and wrappers were present and strewn about. There was bear scat near by. The victim claimed her pack in the morning and was given a verbal warning.

Liz Williamson found a ripped up pack near the Columbia boulder in Camp 4. Food and wrappers were present and strewn about. There was bear scat near by. The victim claimed her pack in the morning and was given a verbal warning.

Trash was left in the cup holder of a reclining rocking chair. The bear dragged the chair out of camp and tore the carrying case. There was an empty trail mix bag with a little food left in the bottom, a couple of margarita cans, and sunscreen. The bear was chased off.

The bear was eating a large bag of corn flour that had been left out in a reusable shopping bag. The bear was very difficult to scare off of the food. Could not locate the owner of the food and it was unclear which unit the food came from.

Backpack was found torn apart in the boulders with food trash everywhere around it. The trash included energy bar wrappers, muscle milk bottle, various recycling items, and other plastic wrappers and bags. There were also personal items like clothing and a whistle. No identification was found and the trash appeared to be a few days old.

The bear attempted to grab a bag of food trash that had been hung. The bag ripped but nothing was obtained. The visitor yelled and threw objects but the bear wouldn't leave. Wildlife staff showed up and the bear was guarding the food and was very aggressive and huffing. The bear refused to run away even with intense yelling and chasing.

The food was in a bear can with the lid closed but possibly not all the way locked. The bear broke the lid and obtained Clif bars and a bag of trail mix. The bear was very aggressive, huffing and growling.

The bear obtained an entire bear canister that had been left open and was trying to get into a second. They attempted to yell and chase the bear off but were unsuccessful. The bear eventually left and ran over a sleeping bag, ripping a hole in it. The bear cans contained a couple of days worth of food.

The bear obtained an entire bear canister that had been left open and was trying to get into a second. They attempted to yell and chase the bear off but were unsuccessful. The bear eventually left and ran over a sleeping bag, ripping a hole in it. The bear cans contained a couple of days worth of food.

Described 2 large bears attempting to break in through poorly secured window. Same location of break in 3 days prior. Residents chased bears out and away. Cat food was left out and present. Unknown if obtained. The Covington's are the ones with 5000 cats. Bears attempted to gain access unsuccessfully multiple times later throughout the night.

LocationDetail: sunrise creek cloud's rest junction campsites
IncidentDescription: A bit of beef jerky was accidentally left in pocket of pack. Bear dragged pack 100 feet from site and tore the pack. Bear stayed in camp 30-45 minutes despite hollering and objects being thrown.

LocationDetail: sunrise creek cloud's rest junction campsites
IncidentDescription: A bit of beef jerky was accidentally left in pocket of pack. Bear dragged pack 100 feet from site and tore the pack. Bear stayed in camp 30-45 minutes despite hollering and objects being thrown.

Hiking guide Kari Brandt's client was the victim. Kari wrote the report and turned it in to wilderness: Bear didn’t come into camp when first seen, was just scoping things out. Scared away from camp and he didn’t return until dusk. Scared away again and he didn't return until 0400 when I turned on the stoves. I had to get within 5 feet before he ran away. The bear didn't come back until group was almost packed up and one person stepped away from their pack briefly and the bear ran off with a day pack with snacks and water in it. I followed the bear and waited for him to finish with the pack. After he was done I told him "bad bear" and he started growling and huffing at me. I stood my ground and he continued and I slowly backed away to come back later and get the pack. The bear ate a granola bar, ginger, and mixed nuts. In the area I had also found a Garcia canister with no lid on it, downhill from a different site. I could not find the lid anywhere and there were chewed packages of top Ramen and 3 packages of dried food. There was no damage to the bear canister, leading me to think that the lid was not locked on. I checked the upper site and there was no one there.

Bear juggled and threw bear canister until it popped open. Bear consumed all contents: oatmeal, rice, shot blocks, cliff bars.

LocationDetail: sunrise creek cloud's rest junction campsites
IncidentDescription: Bear took food out of neighboring camper's opened bear canister. Looked like bear obtained 2 mountain house packages. Food taken from bear canister left open.

Bear entered trailer through a window that had plastic over it. The bear tore through the plastic and climbed into the trailer. The bear then obtained 2/3 of a bag of cat food but did not take any other food. The bear is currently trying to enter the trailer every day usually early in the morning or late at night. It is attempting to enter through another window and has clawed at the door. The window that it first entered is now covered with a board. The resident will let his dog out to chase the bear away.

Bear entered trailer through a window that had plastic over it. The bear tore through the plastic and climbed into the trailer. The bear then obtained 2/3 of a bag of cat food but did not take any other food. The bear is currently trying to enter the trailer every day usually early in the morning or late at night. It is attempting to enter through another window and has clawed at the door. The window that it first entered is now covered with a board. The resident will let his dog out to chase the bear away.

Orange 22 and her two cubs were causing a bear jam in Stoneman's Meadow. Andi responded and was working at the jam. One cub started walking towards Andi and the road, so she yelled at it to try to scare it back. The cub did not stop and kept walking towards her so she yelled louder. Orange 22 then huffed and made aggressive steps and small bluff charges towards her. The cub walked back to Orange 22 but the family unit did not move far and continued to make attempts to cross the road.

The victim left his vehicle parked in the Orchard Lot for several days. He checked the car the morning of the incident at around 7:30am and did not observe anything abnormal. At 19:30 he found that his passenger side window had been forced down. There were bear paw prints in the dust all over the vehicle and claw marks in the window frame. Presumably, the window had been forcibly opened (pushed down) by the bear. The glass was intact but there may be damage to the window opening mechanism. According to the victim, no food was present or acquired.

A child who was part of a large kids group left a pack out with sandwich crumbs and possibly mayo/mustard packets in it. Visitors witnessed a large, dark, collared bear come into the site and rip into the pack. Visitors chased the bear out. Blue 54 (Bear 3520) matches the description and was in the area at the time according to GPS data.

A child who was part of a large kids group left a pack out with sandwich crumbs and possibly mayo/mustard packets in it. Visitors witnessed a large, dark, collared bear come into the site and rip into the pack. Visitors chased the bear out. Blue 54 (Bear 3520) matches the description and was in the area at the time according to GPS data.
Blue 54 ate some sunflower seeds and peanuts that were accidently left out at campsite. He walked out of camp as soon as he saw the wildlife truck.
Sow and cubs entered apple tree and broke a 3 inch diameter branch off which fell into the vehicles windshield and roof. The windshield was spider-webbed and there were scratches on the car's roof.

Backpack with food possibly drug from Upper Pines 1 by bear or raccoon. Animal, possibly bear, obtained multiple bars, banana, fruit snacks, and whole jerky package. Items were ripped open. No actual damage to pack, just dirty and soggy.

Bear was reported being seen in Huff Housing around 01:00. The resident reporting said the bear got into a backpack and got at least a bag of skittles and some sunflower seeds. The bear was wearing a white collar. No other details were given.

LocationDetail: In the boulders adjacent to camp
IncidentDescription: Backpack found in boulders behind campground. Ripped up.

Bear approached me as I crossed the bridge. Yelled and shouted aggressively - bear continued to approach. When bear was within 2 meters, I ran at the bear. It hesitated and turned off trail, but was not afraid. Hikers told me it had gotten food from guests in that area previously that day, and had been chased by a ranger. Bear did not seem to be accompanied by adult. Showed no fear of humans.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Camper left beef jerky wrapper under seat (driver's). Camper went to bed around 0100 hours. Bear broke into vehicle sometime between 01:00 and 04:30. Camper did not hear bear break into vehicle. Green 21 was in North Pines between 01:30 and 04:30 according to monitoring box data.

LocationDetail: On horse trail behind DNC stables
IncidentDescription: Reported through dispatch; visitors saw bear and abandoned pack with food and SLR camera with case. Bear obtained chips and soda left in the backpack. Pack camera recovered by JR of DNC stables who reported the bear eating the pack. Damage to pack and camera case. Backpack was shredded. Camera case had hole, no damage to camera.

LocationDetail: On horse trail behind DNC stables
IncidentDescription: Reported through dispatch; visitors saw bear and abandoned pack with food and SLR camera with case. Bear obtained chips and soda left in the backpack. Pack camera recovered by JR of DNC stables who reported the bear eating the pack. Damage to pack and camera case. Backpack was shredded. Camera case had hole, no damage to camera.
Bear obtained .5 bag of licorice and ripped a backpack apart. Visitors saw a large bear but did not identify tags.
Bear obtained .5 bag of licorice and ripped a backpack apart. Visitors saw a large bear but did not identify tags.

Some food and trash was left out at site. Trash bag was scattered all over when we arrived. Same site left food and trash out and was verbally warned the previous night. Blue 54 sett off alarm and was in the area at time of incident, but was not actually seen getting food from trash. Items left out: onions, food trash, BBQ sauce. Called Law Enforcement but they did not respond.

Bear ripped tote bag with ripped granola bag found in woods at edge of Upper Pines. Victim unknown, date of incident unknown (although it was before 10/27/14 because rips were dry, no bear saliva). Bear unknown. Likely Blue 54 as he has been regularly getting into Upper Pines in the last two weeks. Rips indicate a bear, not a raccoon.

Camper heard bear getting into trash, got up and yelled, bear ran away. 1 hour later bear came back. Camper was sleeping in his vehicle, bear stood up and looked in vehicle, sniffed and put his paws on the door. Camper yelled and bear again took off. I Dave Wright saw the paw prints on the truck. Bear obtained minor food trash and garbage.
French visitor unaware that walnuts needed to be stored (language barrier). Walnuts left in paniers on bicycle. Bear ripped into one of them and broke it.
French visitor unaware that walnuts needed to be stored (language barrier). Walnuts left in paniers on bicycle. Bear ripped into one of them and broke it.
Bear obtained multiple corn-filled bean bags. Visitors heard bear eating something but did nothing. 5 bean bags obtained.
Victim stated that at 0330 hours he woke up to a bear with front paws on driver's side window. Bear broke through window, put head in, then turned and walked away.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear broke into driver's side window. No food inside but a pumpkin spice scented air freshener was inside. Bear also took a backpack with unknown contents.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear broke into driver's side window. No food inside but a pumpkin spice scented air freshener was inside. Bear also took a backpack with unknown contents.

Visitor thought trailer was secure. Food stored in enclosed trailer. Bear ripped back door of trailer and obtained bagged granola. Visitors easily bent door back into place and insisted no vehicle damage needed to be claimed.
Bear obtained cups of jam and a whole loaf of bread. Visitor was sleeping next to her pack. Visitors described a large bear. Food was inside a woman's bag. Bag was torn apart.
Bear obtained cups of jam and a whole loaf of bread. Visitor was sleeping next to her pack. Visitors described a large bear. Food was inside a woman's bag. Bag was torn apart.

Found via website. Posted on 7/31/2014. A JMT hiker decided to use an Ursack for most of the JMT because, "it was much lighter and pack friendly, a pliable bag made out of military grade spectra, a 'bulletproof' material similar to Kevlar." The visitor understood that, "it was not approved for parks like Yosemite because the food could be obtained by the bears by chewing on the fabric even if they didn't tear it open." When she got to Yosemite, she, "signed up for a free bear canister loan program, but kept her Ursack in case of overflow items. Anything that didn't fit in the canister at the end of the night would be tied to a tree, not legal with the rangers, but safe from the bears". She, "hiked out of Tuolumne Meadows with 3 days of food and most of hers went into the Ursack." Her and her friend woke up in the night to scratching and saw a sow with cub, "trying to get into her food bag 80 ft. away. They shouted, shone lights, and threw rocks." By '30 minutes' into the encounter "the bears had a hole in the side of the 'bear proof' bag." Eventually those bears moved on, but before the night was out, two more bears had stopped by to eat the food and garbage still left. The visitor was left with, "a demolished Ursack and a whole lot of slobbery bear smelling mush." Additionally, a bear had bitten into the platypus hydration bag. The visitor hiked through to Mammoth Lakes and "bought a bear canister" for use on the rest of the trail. When she reported this to Ursack, they were, "surprised and apologetic about the bag failure and is sending a new, stronger version.
