LocationDetail: Top of Snow Creek Switchbacks campsites
IncidentDescription: Group missing bear can in morning. Looked everywhere, unable to find. Missing bear can, details not known.

LocationDetail: Top of Snow Creek Switchbacks campsites
IncidentDescription: Group missing bear can in morning. Looked everywhere, unable to find. Missing bear can, details not known.

We were eating dinner sitting on a log with an open canister right behind me, about 2 feet away (definitely arms reach). Another camper saw her and yelled bear. Rangers came quickly and saw her running off with the can. They had been trying to find her and tranquilize and collar her nine hours later. Shaun said to mention that he wanted to confirm that we did everything properly with the can.

We were eating dinner sitting on a log with an open canister right behind me, about 2 feet away (definitely arms reach). Another camper saw her and yelled bear. Rangers came quickly and saw her running off with the can. They had been trying to find her and tranquilize and collar her nine hours later. Shaun said to mention that he wanted to confirm that we did everything properly with the can.

Backpack was recovered by wildlife staffroom Lake Vernon near the ranger cabin on 6/25/16. Backpack had 2 small tears/punctures. There was minimal damage. After setting up camp we stored food and toiletries in bear can and went on day hike. When we returned, a backpack was missing and was never recovered. We didn't think there was any food in it, but there may have been. We had to hike out a few days early because we were a group of 2 people and were now missing one of our packs and part of our gear.
Bear got garbage from visitor's site. When they tried to scare it off, the bear bluff charged them to 15 yards. They backed off.

Bear took open bear canister. Bear ate all food from canister before visitors went to retrieve it since they were scared of the bear. Visitors retrieved canister, all their food was gone. Bravo 41 also likely took a report, so we will wait to hear more.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek/ Cloud's Rest junction. Campsites
IncidentDescription: Bear came into camp and grabbed a pack and ran a few feet with it after the trail mix had been forgotten in the top pouch. Bear was scared off after it had eaten the bag of trail mix. Bear returned to camp a few hours later. RP didn’t have a description of bear as it was dark and he was half asleep.

Visitors parked bikes near fire pit at Fen and walked away. When they returned, a bear with W10 tag was going through bike side packs and got 4 cookies. They did not shout but took pictures and the bear eventually walked away.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear pulled open a pack - stuff was scattered around. Visitor saw bear take off. (just its rear) bear scattered toothpicks…no food present. Raccoons were also in camp throughout the night.
3 mountain meal packets were found torn into at sunrise junction campground by new visitors in the campsite. Food may have been obtained the previous day.

LocationDetail: North Rim Trail ~ 0.5 mi E of Tamarack CG
IncidentDescription: Soft-sided cooler and backpack found on the side of the trail. Ripped open, some food items missing. Neither bear nor owners were seen. In pack: pancake mix, Cheese Whiz, toiletries. Notified Crane Flat LE.

LocationDetail: North Rim Trail ~ 0.5 mi E of Tamarack CG
IncidentDescription: Soft-sided cooler and backpack found on the side of the trail. Ripped open, some food items missing. Neither bear nor owners were seen. In pack: pancake mix, Cheese Whiz, toiletries. Notified Crane Flat LE.

LocationDetail: North Rim Trail ~ 0.5 mi E of Tamarack CG
IncidentDescription: Soft-sided cooler and backpack found on the side of the trail. Ripped open, some food items missing. Neither bear nor owners were seen. In pack: pancake mix, Cheese Whiz, toiletries. Notified Crane Flat LE.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: The bear was observed squashing and ripping the tent in an attempt to pull the sleeping bag out. The visitors that saw the bear did not report it immediately and LE called us with the report later. Upon arrival the visitor that observed the bear showed us pictures of the bear grubbing on logs near by camp. Later this night Wildlife Staff came in contact with the owner of the damaged tent while he was trying to pack it up. He explained there was no food or scented items in the tent, but when he picked up the sleeping bag, strawberry chapstick fell out of it. The bear was blonde and approximately 100 lbs. The visitor additionally explained that the bear jumped over and landed on another tent breaking the pole, making two broken tents.
Bear went through multiple campsites. Tore into pack (small). Not ruined, slight damage. NO food reward.
Bear put itself in front of the cub. Did 2 bluff charges, and then casually walked away on the side of the river.

Report from dispatch that a bear obtained food in Bridalveil Campground last night/this morning, called in by the camp hosts. Whiskey 43 (Tara) responded, but before she got there the visitors had cleaned everything up. The visitors explained that they were "tipsy" and must have not operated the bear locker properly. Tara explained that they never admitted to leaving food out and there was a lot of statements that seemed deceptive. The neighboring site could hear the bear rummaging around the campsite. The bear then pawed the tent and put a few small holes in the rain fly. Wildlife staff arrived immediately after the visitors left. Tara said they were given a stern talking to and she advised them on why food storage is so important. In the end, the visitors said the bear just ate garbage.

Bear opened camper shell to truck without damaging it. Bear pulled out a bag of dog food and likely ate some since the bag was ripped open. An electric food dehydrator was also damaged that was left in the bed of the truck. Report was made by a witness, not the victim. Bear chased off dog food bag. Remaining food cleaned up and brought inside a house.

Bear opened camper shell to truck without damaging it. Bear pulled out a bag of dog food and likely ate some since the bag was ripped open. An electric food dehydrator was also damaged that was left in the bed of the truck. Report was made by a witness, not the victim. Bear chased off dog food bag. Remaining food cleaned up and brought inside a house.

LocationDetail: Residence near the Wildland Fire Station
IncidentDescription: Bear broke the driver's side window of a large truck. Lots of food and trash (messy vehicle) in cab. Bear bit into a gallon box of grease, sunflower seeds, and other items. Reported by a witness, not their car. Witness also reported many other cars parked at this location also had bear paw prints on the cars.

LocationDetail: Residence near the Wildland Fire Station
IncidentDescription: Bear broke the driver's side window of a large truck. Lots of food and trash (messy vehicle) in cab. Bear bit into a gallon box of grease, sunflower seeds, and other items. Reported by a witness, not their car. Witness also reported many other cars parked at this location also had bear paw prints on the cars.
Visitors put 3 rented canisters 50 feet from the campsite and awoke to find: one canister where it was left, one a quarter mile away in Snow Creek, and the third was not to be found.
Visitors put 3 rented canisters 50 feet from the campsite and awoke to find: one canister where it was left, one a quarter mile away in Snow Creek, and the third was not to be found.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Wayne Hartlerode reported 2 parties had their sunscreen bottles bitten into.

Untagged sow and cub obtained half a cookie and bottle of Ibuprofen from backpack that was left unattended for a short time as boulderers were moving stuff to the next spot. No tags confirmed by RP and Jesse McGahey who saw the bears. No damage to the packs. Sow and cub weren’t afraid of hikers or RP making noise, but people were 50 yards away. Bears eventually sauntered away after obtaining a cookie.

Untagged sow and cub obtained half a cookie and bottle of Ibuprofen from backpack that was left unattended for a short time as boulderers were moving stuff to the next spot. No tags confirmed by RP and Jesse McGahey who saw the bears. No damage to the packs. Sow and cub weren’t afraid of hikers or RP making noise, but people were 50 yards away. Bears eventually sauntered away after obtaining a cookie.

Bear first circled camp at 20:30 and obtained a quart of dog food (500 calories) and 1 Mountain House Meal (500 calories). The visitors were away watching meteor shower. Wayne Hartlerode chased the bear away hitting it with rocks. Bear returned at 23:30 and again at 01:30 and was scared off each time by the campers. Bear described as waist height, 180-200 lbs., light brown adult, slender.
Crew doing bullfrog eradication had a gear cache at the site. While the crew was gone on a break, a crew member's sleeping pad ripped by a bear. No food or scented items were left out.

Bear ripped tent and caught sleeping bag. The bear ripped the tent in one paw swipe and caught a corner of the sleeping bag. There was no food or scented items in the tent according to the owner and officer. The tent's owner is part of the team and I believe him. It appears the bear was investigating the tent, got no food reward and left. The officer found footprints 60 feet from the tent with raindrops in it. It rained yesterday around 6 pm and the officer was at the tent at 2. The footprints were over the tire tracks, so the bear was a the tent sometime between 2 and 6.

Bear ripped tent and caught sleeping bag. The bear ripped the tent in one paw swipe and caught a corner of the sleeping bag. There was no food or scented items in the tent according to the owner and officer. The tent's owner is part of the team and I believe him. It appears the bear was investigating the tent, got no food reward and left. The officer found footprints 60 feet from the tent with raindrops in it. It rained yesterday around 6 pm and the officer was at the tent at 2. The footprints were over the tire tracks, so the bear was a the tent sometime between 2 and 6.

The bear appeared to be walking from site to site along the ridge. Completely indifferent to people and noises, but would run away when we ran toward it yelling. When the visitor tried to help another visitor, it false charged once as it tried to get back to their tent (they had camped too close to the cliff and it had no good escape route. It ended up rummaging through their tent and gnawed at their canister (no food was eaten).
Bear climbed a tree and ripped open a "food" bag from a neighboring camper. Luckily food was in the bear cans and the bear ignored it after ripping it down.

Bear didn't react to yelling. Heard people yelling at the east end of lake. Two people had left food unattended. Bear got food chased it north towards Conness. Bear was not very afraid of people . The two hikers had food out about 20 feet away. The bear wouldn't leave camp. No reaction to loud noises.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct
IncidentDescription: Visitor was separated from partner who had the bear canister. Slept out at the Sunrise/Cloud's Rest Junction and illegally hung their food for the night. Sometime in the middle of the night a bear came and grabbed the food hang. The bear got one freeze dried meal (entrée) and one days worth of snacks. V36 took the actual report, reported secondhand.
Tent smashed. Paw print visible on the tent fly.

Employees were walking through Lamon's Orchard, saw Yellow 50 a good ways away. Employees stopped and were observing her from a distance when she bluff charged. Employees were approximately 40 yards away, backed up and she slowly began walking in a different direction.
Bear came into the campsite, chewed on some paper plates, paper cups, scratched a cooler (empty) and chewed/destroyed a soft grocery cooler bag (empty).
Bear circled the campsites twice. It walked into the camp from two different spots. It tore open a girl's pack to get an apple.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Small backpack was left by the river in Lower Pines. Later found in the woods with bite marks in the bag and sunscreen bottle. Pack had mostly trash, unknown if food was taken.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Small backpack was left by the river in Lower Pines. Later found in the woods with bite marks in the bag and sunscreen bottle. Pack had mostly trash, unknown if food was taken.
Visitor missed bottle of mustard when putting food away. Bear took the mustard.
Second hand report of Orange 22 getting unattended apple, then ran off.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear took large container of liquid soap. Visitor retrieved it and then threw it away. Bear seen in various campsites all morning starting at 04:00. Only obtained soap from one site. No other incidents.

Described as about 300 lbs. Bear came in through laundry room door or open sliding glass door. Dogs treed the bear. Bear obtained: chicken, cocoa powder, molasses, and maple syrup in freezer. The bear got into the garbage inside the kitchen and freezer in garage. Second time in a row owner left the house unsecured and bear obtained food.
First bear break-in incident at residence. Bear obtained steaks, dog food, and elderberries from garage which was unsecured.
Bear seen 2 days before (Orange 15), but not during the incident. One canister disappeared. Naturebridge emailed us the report.
Bear seen 2 days before (Orange 15), but not during the incident. One canister disappeared. Naturebridge emailed us the report.
Third hand report of a group losing one canister with food. Possibly lost a second canister-no details.
Third hand report of a group losing one canister with food. Possibly lost a second canister-no details.
Bear ripped into a stuff sack that contained no food, only utensils.
Bear got food left out in the late afternoon. Approximately 5 freeze dried meals and a large bag of banana chips. Did not see the bear. Didn't think freeze dried food needed to go in the canister.

Bear canister disappeared while visitor's were sleeping. The bear canister was stored about a quarter to a half mile away from the tent site. Visitors were not close enough to hear. Unknown if visitors were camped in the closure area.

Bear canister disappeared while visitor's were sleeping. The bear canister was stored about a quarter to a half mile away from the tent site. Visitors were not close enough to hear. Unknown if visitors were camped in the closure area.

Visitor reports: "Bear came into camp five times on 6/2/17 to get the canisters. The bear could not get the canisters based on placement and pots and pans on top scared off by flashlights. It opened zippers and went through backpacks. No food, trash, or smellables. It was just curious and biting into everything. "

Visitor's Account: " We put our bear box about 100 meters from our tent in a hole next to a fallen tree. It was gone in the morning and our neighbors said their two bear boxes had also been taken in the night. Smart bear! All food and scented items were placed in the container and left 100 meters from camp away from the cliff. All neighbors experienced bear rummaging through possessions. When we woke up canister was gone with tracks and dirt turned up around it."

Visitor's Account: " We put our bear box about 100 meters from our tent in a hole next to a fallen tree. It was gone in the morning and our neighbors said their two bear boxes had also been taken in the night. Smart bear! All food and scented items were placed in the container and left 100 meters from camp away from the cliff. All neighbors experienced bear rummaging through possessions. When we woke up canister was gone with tracks and dirt turned up around it."

LocationDetail: North of the footbridge and closure
IncidentDescription: First group camped north of the footbridge and closed area. Saw one bear on their way up during the day. Saw a second bear during the night that disturbed their canisters twice: first at 2:30 am, then at 5:30 am. When they got up in the morning they were missing

LocationDetail: North of the footbridge and closure
IncidentDescription: First group camped north of the footbridge and closed area. Saw one bear on their way up during the day. Saw a second bear during the night that disturbed their canisters twice: first at 2:30 am, then at 5:30 am. When they got up in the morning they were missing

Canister was missing in the morning. No bear seen during the night. Bear sighting in the morning, unclear if this is the same bear that presumably took the canister. It was a large medium brown bear with no tags or collar. Never recovered missing canister.

Canister was missing in the morning. No bear seen during the night. Bear sighting in the morning, unclear if this is the same bear that presumably took the canister. It was a large medium brown bear with no tags or collar. Never recovered missing canister.

Incident via visitor's video and description (this visitor was not the victim): bear was within feet of a visitor along the JMT. The visitor was not moving and at times also approaching the bear. Bear swiped at the visitor's foot. No injuries.
Visitor put canisters away from their tent, but not near the cliff edge. Two canisters were missing in the morning. No bear was seen or heard.
Visitor put canisters away from their tent, but not near the cliff edge. Two canisters were missing in the morning. No bear was seen or heard.
Visitor put canisters away from their tent, but not near the cliff edge. Two canisters were missing in the morning. No bear was seen or heard.

Visitor attempted to scare a bear away from the bathrooms. Bear treed briefly, visitor kept approaching, got within 3-4 feet of the tree. Bear jumped off tree and advanced toward visitor. Visitor backed off, bear advanced further towards visitor then stopped. Wildlife staff arrived on scene and chased the bear away. Visitor reported observing the bear eating scraps of bread near the bathroom.

LocationDetail: On the east side of Snow Creek. Not near the cliff
IncidentDescription: Visitor camped inside a "closed area" and reported that the bear presumably knocked the canister down the cliff. Did not observe the bear. In closure area. Bear was not seen, but the canister was missing. Missing: bug spray, four cups of oats, protein powder, cookies, two dry meals, nutrition bars, baggies. Assumed improper food storage because the canister should never have been near any cliffs, the closure was supposed to prevent this type of incident.

LocationDetail: On the east side of Snow Creek. Not near the cliff
IncidentDescription: Visitor camped inside a "closed area" and reported that the bear presumably knocked the canister down the cliff. Did not observe the bear. In closure area. Bear was not seen, but the canister was missing. Missing: bug spray, four cups of oats, protein powder, cookies, two dry meals, nutrition bars, baggies. Assumed improper food storage because the canister should never have been near any cliffs, the closure was supposed to prevent this type of incident.

Bear was not seen. One canister full of food and toiletries went missing. Rental canister under permit holder Ryan Criss. Visitor account follows: "Bear approached our canister ring around 2am, knocked several canisters out of the ring and stole one canister after he scared it away. Couldn't see bear because his glasses weren't on. Chased blurry bear."

Bear was not seen. One canister full of food and toiletries went missing. Rental canister under permit holder Ryan Criss. Visitor account follows: "Bear approached our canister ring around 2am, knocked several canisters out of the ring and stole one canister after he scared it away. Couldn't see bear because his glasses weren't on. Chased blurry bear."
Katie Ashe and LYV intern were bluff charged by a bear twice unprovoked. It was reported that the bear ran at them. They shot paintballs at it's feet and it stopped, then chased them again.

A group of two backpackers camped in the Lake Vernon area reported seeing a mother and two cubs. The mother bear tore open one backpack and clawed at a sleeping pad and a bear canister. The hikers had dropped their packs and walked down to the beach. At the time of the incident the canister was separate from the pack, but only by a few feet. The bear did not get any food from the encounter. The visitors said that they did not hav any other attractants in their packs. Items damaged included a Deuter overnight pack and an old Therm-a-rest. Their bear canister was significantly scratched, but not damaged or compromised.

A group of two backpackers camped in the Lake Vernon area reported seeing a mother and two cubs. The mother bear tore open one backpack and clawed at a sleeping pad and a bear canister. The hikers had dropped their packs and walked down to the beach. At the time of the incident the canister was separate from the pack, but only by a few feet. The bear did not get any food from the encounter. The visitors said that they did not hav any other attractants in their packs. Items damaged included a Deuter overnight pack and an old Therm-a-rest. Their bear canister was significantly scratched, but not damaged or compromised.
Empty cooler left out in backyard. The cooler had preveiously contained rotten food. It was being aired out. Very smelly. Bear clawed it and ripped the lid off. No food present.

This is the old condemned structure on the hill, heading west on 140, just past Abbey Road. Arrived to find 15x4' area of siding ripped off structure surrounging a window. Side framing of window was teeming with bees/wasps. There was a lot of smudge and slobber marks on the siding. It appears the bear was attracted to the multiple bee/wasp nests behind the siding. The window in question can easily be raised (opened) but the building is empty and otherwise secure. No bear scat or any other attractants nearby.

Chris Deubella and Ivy Curren were hiking up the Mist Trail at the switchbacks to the Nevada Falls bathroom when they came around a switchback and bear #3223 was bluff charging another group coming down the trial. The bear immediately walked toward Ivy who went into a defensive/fetal position. The bear made contact, sniffed her head, and bit her shoulder leaving small puncture wounds and moderate abrasions. Bear appeared to start tugging on her, but released and ran downhill off the trail when she screamed in pain. Visitor refused medical attention at the Clinic. Chris clearly observed White #23 tag in the bear's left ear as well as GPS collar.

"Bear and 2 cubs came into camp at night. Stole bear canister and rolled it to the creek. Never got canister back," per visitor. People were afraid of sow with cubs and hid in their tent while it happened. We are uncertain if this happened in or out of the closure area but it was likely just outside the closure.

"Bear and 2 cubs came into camp at night. Stole bear canister and rolled it to the creek. Never got canister back," per visitor. People were afraid of sow with cubs and hid in their tent while it happened. We are uncertain if this happened in or out of the closure area but it was likely just outside the closure.
Backpacker's stacked food canisters. They came back to find cans knocked over and sleeping pads ripped apart.

An adult and cub came down the switch back trail near the south of the lake. A bear was tearing into a pack and no other people were around. Visitor's yelled (14 people) and the bears looked up and kept eating the backpack. Visitor's reporting the incident were not the owner's of the pack.
A young bear took food from outside a tent that was left out. RP yelled and threw rocks to get the bear away. The bear ran off. (Reported through the Save-a-bear hotline).
Visitors reported to a campground ranger that a bear bit through their tent and punctured an air mattress.
Visitors reported to a campground ranger that a bear bit through their tent and punctured an air mattress.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained a backpack full of food rappers and toothpaste. Owner walked away and returned to see some of her items on the ground but the pack was missing. She believed the pack was stolen by people. Pack was later retrieved by Bear Management while tracking Green 7, which was still nearby the area of the pack. Pack was ripped open with food wrappers around it. Owner stated that it was just trash, however the bear did eat a tube of toothpaste.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained a backpack full of food rappers and toothpaste. Owner walked away and returned to see some of her items on the ground but the pack was missing. She believed the pack was stolen by people. Pack was later retrieved by Bear Management while tracking Green 7, which was still nearby the area of the pack. Pack was ripped open with food wrappers around it. Owner stated that it was just trash, however the bear did eat a tube of toothpaste.

Wildlife staff came upon scene with bear in horse feed and bear box wide open. Chased the bear away. Not much food was obtained, but there was definitely a food reward. Bear (Purple 49) is no longer responding well to paintballs. He was hit 3-5 times and was unfazed. An air horn worked well.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct- large campsite
IncidentDescription: No food present other than properly secured canister. It appeared that a bear collapsed a tent, ripping the rain fly and putting bite marks in the non-food items including: sandals, cup, etc. No bears observed in the area.

Orange 22 and 2 cubs caused a bear jam at 16:00 that spanned from the Chapel apple tree to Superintendent's Bridge. No abnormal behavior at this point. All visitors were very far away. At 16:30, Orange 22 with cubs moved into thick vegetation towards Residence 1 and became not viewable. Bear jam dispersed. Shortly after, received a call via Dispatch of a "bear with cubs" in the back of a government vehicle getting into backpacks at Residence 1. Arrived on scene to Orange 22 with 2 cubs with 2 backpacks across the river from Residence 1 and the vehicle they had obtained them from. Hazed across Yosemite Creek with bluff charges. Sam- this person's pack was taken second, no monetary damage to his pack, handful of granola bars eaten. Laura- first pack also no monetary damage, food was eaten from this pack.

Victim and group were camping 0.4 miles North of the Snow Creek Footbridge. At around 04:00 on 9/13/18 the group woke up to find all their canisters scattered about the area and one missing. No bears or sign of bears were seen.

Victim and group were camping 0.4 miles North of the Snow Creek Footbridge. At around 04:00 on 9/13/18 the group woke up to find all their canisters scattered about the area and one missing. No bears or sign of bears were seen.

LocationDetail: Halfway btwn Stoneman and Ahwahnee Bridge on river
IncidentDescription: Visitors were sleeping in a hammock with a pack within arm's reach and were awakened by Orange 22 and 2 cubs dragging the pack away. They attempted to scare the bears away, but the bears were persistent and would not leave. Bear barely moved way enough for visitors to get out of the hammock. Wildlife staff arrived from Upper River and fired pyrotechnics to push the bears off of the food. The cubs would not leave, so staff crossed the river and fired more rounds and chased the bears displaying no fear of people, and were hard to run off. The bears returned a minute later with cubs leading the sow to the scene and were difficult to chase away again with several rangers yelling and chasing.

LocationDetail: Halfway btwn Stoneman and Ahwahnee Bridge on river
IncidentDescription: Visitors were sleeping in a hammock with a pack within arm's reach and were awakened by Orange 22 and 2 cubs dragging the pack away. They attempted to scare the bears away, but the bears were persistent and would not leave. Bear barely moved way enough for visitors to get out of the hammock. Wildlife staff arrived from Upper River and fired pyrotechnics to push the bears off of the food. The cubs would not leave, so staff crossed the river and fired more rounds and chased the bears displaying no fear of people, and were hard to run off. The bears returned a minute later with cubs leading the sow to the scene and were difficult to chase away again with several rangers yelling and chasing.
Visitor left cooler with drinks (beer and liquor) out overnight. A bear knocked the cooler over and 3 glass beer bottles were clawed and bit open. Got pictures from the camp host.
Bear turned over a bear locker and ripped seam in tent cabin.

Orange 22 with 2 cubs was seen on the JMT above Clark Point. Hikers continued to hike on the trail, cubs treed and Orange 22 stayed on the ground around the base of the tree. Hikers attempted to yell to scare off the bears, but they did not leave. When hikers attempted to pass, Orange 22 reportedly "slashed" at them with her paw and made audible distressed noises. When she reportedly slashed at the passers she was about 20-25 ft. back and the cubs were still treed above her. Orange 22 stayed adjacent to the trail for about 1 hour. Hikers were advised to take an alternate route, but those who continued to pass her reported aggressive behavior and an inability to scare her away. She eventually moved off.

Bear obtained trail mix from backpackers- canisters were 10 ft. away behind them: "canisters were open, no more than 10 feet way from them, they were all looking at the lake, the bear quietly came up behind them without making a sound and obtained trail mix".
Container missing in morning. Second canister found some way away from camp.
Container missing in morning. Second canister found some way away from camp.

Rear passenger door open on gray pickup truck. Rear seat damaged, 5qt container of motor oil punctured and spilled, food , trash, and attractants present in cab of vehicle. Beer and food present in bed of truck. Paw prints present on all cab windows and passenger side canopy window. Passenger window rain trim damaged on front and rear doors. Bear possibly entered vehicle (unlocked) by operating door latch or door was not fully closed.

Bears came out of the talus, approached group on rock, scared visitors off food. Obtained large chip bag and apple. Scared educator off backpack with one food item. Bluff charged NatureBridge educator and persisted with 6 groups around.

Bears came out of the talus, approached group on rock, scared visitors off food. Obtained large chip bag and apple. Scared educator off backpack with one food item. Bluff charged NatureBridge educator and persisted with 6 groups around.

Visitor was walking on trail and got too close to a sow with 2 cubs ripping into a trash bag. Sow bluff charged visitors which backed off and started yelling. Bear headed towards Stoneman Bridge. Blanket and paper towels were in the scented trash bag. Paper towels were scattered about.

Visitor awoke at midnight to a bear eating food off of a table and "opening" a bear box. Bear ate 2 bags of English muffins and several bags of noodles from the locker. Trash scattered all around the site. Bear attempted to break into a cooler, but moved onto the bear locker. Described as a "smaller" bear. Blue 58 (3855) and Green 7 (#3077) GPS collars showed them going through those campsites. Blue 15 (#3825) was also strong on telemetry. The visitors saw the bear but stayed quiet and did not scare it.

Resident awoke to BBQ overturned and pieces scattered around the yard. Grease on multiple components of the grill that the bear likely licked. Lost approximately $40 in wood chips. Will follow up if the BBQ doesn't work. Has had BBQ out for about 2 years (cleaned regularly due to knowledge of bear presence) and had no issues before.

Visitor had trail mix taken from their camp by a coyote and dragged out behind their campsite. Visitors were about 5 to 10 feet from the trail mix at the table at the campfire. A neighboring campsite saw a bear fight with 2 coyotes over the bag of trail mix. They reported that the coyotes were biting the bear in the rump and the bear was swatting at the coyotes. Wildlife arrived on scene and chased the bear out of camp- the bear took the bag of trail mix- much was spilled on the ground. Fired banger while chasing the bear.
Bear pushed around bear canisters and tore apart some bowls. Unknown if visitor was camping within closure. Description of location indicates the Snow Creek footbridge, no contact information.
Bear stole canister from visitor. She was not aggressive and fled when noticed.
Bear stole canister from visitor. She was not aggressive and fled when noticed.
2nd hand report of bear obtaining food and garbage from some hikers.
Third-hand report of a black bear getting food from a food hang at Lake Vernon.
Two canisters were taken on the night of 7/2/19- 7/3/19. One was found, one unable to locate.
Two canisters were taken on the night of 7/2/19- 7/3/19. One was found, one unable to locate.
Canister missing during the night 6/30-7/1.
Canister missing during the night 6/30-7/1.

Food stored inside tent, "food stolen from tent". A large black colored bear was indifferent to visitors as it approached their tent and proceeded to tear the corner of their tent. Then went on to investigate other campsite.

Food stored inside tent, "food stolen from tent". A large black colored bear was indifferent to visitors as it approached their tent and proceeded to tear the corner of their tent. Then went on to investigate other campsite.

Canisters were knocked around, moving them 20-30 feet from where visitor had placed them. One canister was broke into and about $30 of dried food was obtained. Canister seemed fine, found 20 meters away. Other canisters were moved but had not been cracked open. Container was full and locked, placed upright.

Canisters were knocked around, moving them 20-30 feet from where visitor had placed them. One canister was broke into and about $30 of dried food was obtained. Canister seemed fine, found 20 meters away. Other canisters were moved but had not been cracked open. Container was full and locked, placed upright.

LocationDetail: Mist Trail. 0.5 mi West of Happy Isles
IncidentDescription: The bear was on the path of the Mist trail eating something on the ground. There was a large group of about 40 people close to the bear taking pictures. The bear reportedly didn't care about nor was concerned about the people nearby. One guy got "too close" to the bear to take a picture and the bear ran at him for 1-2 meters. Otherwise the bear did not act aggressive or afraid of the other visitors. Then the bear walked away up into the forest. Reported by Marine Jouvent. Jouventm@natur.cuni.c7

16 year old was left to attend grill while his parent's went to the bathroom. When he saw a bear walking towards him, he ran. The bear hopped up onto the picnic table and proceeded to eat all the food. At least 20 other people were present, watching and filming. Only 2 people half-heartedly tried to scare it away. The bear walked away on it's own once all the food was gone. Food Storage Type: Other - 16 year old boy was left to attend food and grill.
Visitor threw lunch to bear. Language barrier. Was trying to explain that bear approached him and he threw his lunch to the bear.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct
IncidentDescription: A bear took my bear canister while I was sleeping. Attempted to find canister but couldn't find it. We were sleeping close to the streams running through Junction. Saw a bear paw print on ground, next to where I had placed canister. I am unsure if bear got food. I know he knocked it down a slope. Didn't see any trash in surrounding area. Smart bear.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct
IncidentDescription: A bear took my bear canister while I was sleeping. Attempted to find canister but couldn't find it. We were sleeping close to the streams running through Junction. Saw a bear paw print on ground, next to where I had placed canister. I am unsure if bear got food. I know he knocked it down a slope. Didn't see any trash in surrounding area. Smart bear.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained Horse pellets (condensed alfalfa and grass) as well as a greasy dish sponge. Adult bear with no tags was persistent and returned 3+ times. Bear obtained food while visitors were away from camp. Returned to see bear eating the horse pellets.
Dark brown bear with white blaze eating something near campsite at water's edge. Scared bear away and saw bear had obtained 3 of 4 beers at the shore.

Food left unattended on table. Victim thought bears don't come around during the day. Green 7 and cub entered campsite , investigated tent and table, and grabbed 1 loaf of bread, 1 bag marshmallows, 1 bag rolls. Bear did not respond to verbal yelling, banging pots and pans. Bear drug food into nearby woods.

LocationDetail: snow creek trail, right after footbridge
IncidentDescription: Visitors stacked their canisters 30 feet from campsite. Saw a bear knock them over right after sundown. One was missing in the morning. Likely visitors camped in the closure, unsure.

LocationDetail: snow creek trail, right after footbridge
IncidentDescription: Visitors stacked their canisters 30 feet from campsite. Saw a bear knock them over right after sundown. One was missing in the morning. Likely visitors camped in the closure, unsure.

Ranger Christine (Glacier Point) was shown photos of a group of visitors feeding B8 near Illilouette Creek on the Panorama trail. The reporting group said that the visitors claimed to be afraid of the bear, so they threw food on the ground to "keep it from attacking them". However, they then proceeded to throw more food to the bear and tried to approach the bear, despite the reporting group telling them to stop. Food amount is unknown. Picture did show a loaf of bread and confirmed tag # Blue 8.

A group of 5 camping Lehamite Creek Junction (Snow creek and Yosemite Falls junction) had their bear canisters tossed around and water bladder punctured. There were fresh bear tracks of 2 different sizes present in their campsite.
A 12 year old boy saw a bear rummaging through a purple backpack. The bear ran off carrying the backpack when it saw the boy. Unable to locate bear or backpack.
Blue 58 obtained an unknown amount of food from site 57.

Claw marks and rips to a tent. Party was asleep except for daughter. We have 2, 1 man tents. My daughter heard a bear run into the tent, growl, and claw the tent. The tent guy ropes were pulled from the ground. Bear footprints observed. Bear canisters rolled over, but no food obtained.

Campground staff found a bear incident in site A58. Obtained a watermelon, sour cream, and other small food items from an unlocked YETI intentionally left out by first time visitors. Bear got into cooler easily by puling the rubber handles as it was unlocked. TM LE cited them when they came on shift. Two or three adult bears in the campground throughout the day. Unknown which bear caused the incident, but the tracks were of an adult.

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct
IncidentDescription: Hikers on JMT spent 2 nights at the Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Junction. They used two Ursack bags for overflow food and toiletries. Tied one black and one white Ursack together around a tree after tying each shut as instructions said. Second night at 1am one person got up and noticed the Ursack cords tied around the tree had been completely severed and the white bag had been taken 100 ft away into the burned area. Bear chewed a 3 inch diameter hole in the bottom of the bag and ate 8 jerky sticks, a couple of bars, and some nuts. Other food and prescription meds left alone. No bear seen. Obvious bear from trash left behind and damage caused. Ursack thrown away at a trailhead on Tioga Road. Unable to be recovered

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Jct
IncidentDescription: Hikers on JMT spent 2 nights at the Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest Junction. They used two Ursack bags for overflow food and toiletries. Tied one black and one white Ursack together around a tree after tying each shut as instructions said. Second night at 1am one person got up and noticed the Ursack cords tied around the tree had been completely severed and the white bag had been taken 100 ft away into the burned area. Bear chewed a 3 inch diameter hole in the bottom of the bag and ate 8 jerky sticks, a couple of bars, and some nuts. Other food and prescription meds left alone. No bear seen. Obvious bear from trash left behind and damage caused. Ursack thrown away at a trailhead on Tioga Road. Unable to be recovered
Bear got food scraps at Swinging Bridge.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Wawona Redwoods hired Central Sierra Pest control to place 100-150 rat traps at Redwoods properties throughout Wawona. A bear broke open and consumed rodenticide (Bromadiolone and Bromethalin) from at least 35 traps, likely closer to 50 traps. Bear was discovered deceased shortly after incident. Head and organs sent for toxicology testing, carcass burned to prevent poisoning other scavengers. Chad Andrews (Wawona L.E.) investigating possible criminal case. Food obtained would have presumably been a mix of a very small amount of possible calories mixed with poison.

Emily Dayhoff saw Purple 26 on JMT and bear was on trail and she could not pass. She and friends "stood up" and the bear bluff charged them. When they attempted to go down the trail again a few minutes later, the bear was staring at them through the trees. I (Rob) responded 2 hours later and found Purple 26 near the trail and hazed her extensively every time she saw me for about an hour, then I left her alone at the horse trail/water tank.
Camped past snow creek bridge. Saw bear "playing" with bear can. Scared her off. In the morning the bear can was gone, trail was seen towards slope ending in cliff.
Camped past snow creek bridge. Saw bear "playing" with bear can. Scared her off. In the morning the bear can was gone, trail was seen towards slope ending in cliff.

Four seasons guide Jeremy Williams and a family of 3 teenagers and 2 adults were camping north of the snow creek closure when an adult bear (large black in color) approached their camp. The experienced guide gathered the group together and attempted to haze the bear. The bear did not back down but continued to approach to within 10 yards while slapping the ground and bluff charging the group. The bear would circle around to approach over and over in what Jeremy called a "dominance battle". The group grew afraid and began packing up to leave when the bear aggressively tore the guide's tent, sleeping bag, and sleeping pad apart. After the bear disappeared again the group packed up and hiked down to the Valley during the night

After the bear disappeared again the group packed up and hiked down to the Valley during the night

LocationDetail: Sunrise Creek and Cloud's Rest junction
IncidentDescription: Bear obtained 6 servings of oatmeal and multiple unknown food items from an unlatched bear canister by knocking it over. Bear was testing and rolling multiple bear canisters from multiple parties. Bear ignored attempts to scare it away. Bear returned 7/16 but was unable to obtain food from canisters after testing them for 20 minutes.

LocationDetail: Trail between Backpacker's and North Pines
IncidentDescription: A couple was walking through Backpacker's camp when they heard what they thought was a baby crying in the woods. They approached the sound and were immediately bluff charged by a bear. They left the area and saw a cub lower from a tree and believed the bear that charged them was the mother. Wildlife staff was UTL any bears on follow-up

Medium, small in size, shaggy brown coat, skinny bear. They pawed through our campsite taking down one empty tent and then got spooked by a flapping hammock and ran off. Was not scared by people. We tried to clap to scare it off to no avail. Unsure if the tent was damaged as it was not our site. Would assume it is salvageable. Wildlife staff added $20 to damage assuming the tent was at least damaged a little bit.

The family involved was along the river bank behind the curry 4-way meadow, and left their packs far away. I heard second hand that she tore into a bag and got a White Claw, among other food. I also saw her with a cardboard box in her mouth when I hazed her off and noticed she was very indifferent to hazing.

The family involved was along the river bank behind the curry 4-way meadow, and left their packs far away. I heard second hand that she tore into a bag and got a White Claw, among other food. I also saw her with a cardboard box in her mouth when I hazed her off and noticed she was very indifferent to hazing.

LocationDetail: JMT a few switchbacks above Clark's Point
IncidentDescription: Large group abandoned their pack in the presence of Orange 22. Bear ate their pack contents while they watched. People then proceeded to feed the bear jerky. This report was corroborated by multiple witnesses that I spoke with at a trail block at Happy Isles. The "victim" was ahead of witnesses and I was unable to find them.

LocationDetail: JMT a few switchbacks above Clark's Point
IncidentDescription: Large group abandoned their pack in the presence of Orange 22. Bear ate their pack contents while they watched. People then proceeded to feed the bear jerky. This report was corroborated by multiple witnesses that I spoke with at a trail block at Happy Isles. The "victim" was ahead of witnesses and I was unable to find them.

LocationDetail: Swinging bridge picnic area, Lodge side of beach
IncidentDescription: Yellow 32 approached family (16 people, 7 adults and children, 2 dogs), Family had multiple coolers but were completely surrounding the coolers completely within arms reach. Yellow 32 still approached family and broke into 2 coolers and 1 bag of trash. Family yelled, screamed, and waved their arms, but Yellow 32 was not deterred. Family feared for their children's lives and stepped back and called rangers. Dispatch notified wildlife - bear roving Interp chased him into tree. Food included dog treats, cookies, beer, chips, Cheet-o's, a bottle of wine, hot dogs.

Collette was walking on the gravel path through Hutchings Orchard on a day off (not in uniform), Yellow 32 was in an apple tree right off the trail. When Collette passed by the tree he was in, Yellow 32 climbed down and bluff charged her, stopping only 5 feet short of her on the other side of the fence.
I pulled into Yellow Pines and his head was in a tent. I hazed him away with lots of paintballs. He had ripped the tent in multiple places.

Visitor left bike with towed child carrier at Mist trailhead. Forgot they had lunch scraps (half bag of carrots, bell peppers, trash) inside carrier. Came back to find it tipped over and destroyed. Other visitors told them a bear did it and showed them video of Orange 22 ripping into carrier.

Visitor left bike with towed child carrier at Mist trailhead. Forgot they had lunch scraps (half bag of carrots, bell peppers, trash) inside carrier. Came back to find it tipped over and destroyed. Other visitors told them a bear did it and showed them video of Orange 22 ripping into carrier.

Visitor left bike with towed child carrier at Mist trailhead. Forgot they had lunch scraps (half bag of carrots, bell peppers, trash) inside carrier. Came back to find it tipped over and destroyed. Other visitors told them a bear did it and showed them video of Orange 22 ripping into carrier.

A. Crowley (Wilderness) found a chewed-on can of beans and a lot of chewed on poopy toilet paper. No bear interactions in Pate Valley. Can of beans was un-opened by humans but chewed through by a bear.
White 8 got into a bag of sandwiches on the beach at Ahwahnee Bridge. People too far from food.

Tom awoke at midnight to the sound of a bear tearing at his house siding. Bear ripped some siding off and punctured a hole in the wall under a window. There was a wasp nest in the wall at the damaged section. Bear described as jet black, "Yellow tag" left ear, collar. Could have been Green 7 (3077).

LocationDetail: Panorama trail 1 mile up from JMT junction
IncidentDescription: Party of 4 taking photos 20 meters from packs. Y32 grabbed pack and ripped pack and damaged tent. Bear bluff charged at member of the group who tried to scare bear away. Ate peach, jerky, tea, granola. Group deployed bear spray but it did nothing to deter the bear. I talked to the RP on the phone and instructed them on how to scare the bear away. It worked and they retrieved the pack and remaining food.

LocationDetail: Panorama trail 1 mile up from JMT junction
IncidentDescription: Party of 4 taking photos 20 meters from packs. Y32 grabbed pack and ripped pack and damaged tent. Bear bluff charged at member of the group who tried to scare bear away. Ate peach, jerky, tea, granola. Group deployed bear spray but it did nothing to deter the bear. I talked to the RP on the phone and instructed them on how to scare the bear away. It worked and they retrieved the pack and remaining food.
Visitors camped outside closure. Saw large brown color bear previous night. Morning of 8/16 their canister was missing. It was closed properly.
Visitors camped outside closure. Saw large brown color bear previous night. Morning of 8/16 their canister was missing. It was closed properly.

LocationDetail: west side of trail from Kuna Creek @ Donahue Pass
IncidentDescription: Party of 2 walked away from their packs. When they returned a bear was on their packs ripping them up. Bear was hard to haze, but when they did get him off he ran into a campsite where a third visitor was present making food. The bear swiped through her tent. No food reward reported in either case.

LocationDetail: west side of trail from Kuna Creek @ Donahue Pass
IncidentDescription: Party of 2 walked away from their packs. When they returned a bear was on their packs ripping them up. Bear was hard to haze, but when they did get him off he ran into a campsite where a third visitor was present making food. The bear swiped through her tent. No food reward reported in either case.

Second hand report. Yosemite Hospitality employees reported to an NPS maintenance employee that they were bluff charged by a light colored bear with a collar and a "faded red or purple tag." Purple 26's points have her in that exact area at that exact time. No other details besides the bluff charge and location given.
bear approached picnic area and snagged a bag of cookies and a package of muffins while group had stepped away.

A couple was hiking down the upper Yosemite Falls trail when they saw yellow 32 walking up the trail towards them. Scared that the bear would attack them for their food, they left their backpack on the trail and scrambled up a rock on the side to get out of the way. Y32 went straight to the pack and proceeded to rip it apart and eat the contents for 20 minutes. The couple called 911 and was transferred to wildlife staff. Raquel attempted to advise them to scare the bear but they did not. The bear eventually left after 30 minutes and the couple hiked out. This was the couple's first visit and first time seeing a bear. The male individual proceeded to call the wildlife office frequently in the following days, worried about zoonotic diseases from contacting bear saliva on the backpack.

A couple was hiking down the upper Yosemite Falls trail when they saw yellow 32 walking up the trail towards them. Scared that the bear would attack them for their food, they left their backpack on the trail and scrambled up a rock on the side to get out of the way. Y32 went straight to the pack and proceeded to rip it apart and eat the contents for 20 minutes. The couple called 911 and was transferred to wildlife staff. Raquel attempted to advise them to scare the bear but they did not. The bear eventually left after 30 minutes and the couple hiked out. This was the couple's first visit and first time seeing a bear. The male individual proceeded to call the wildlife office frequently in the following days, worried about zoonotic diseases from contacting bear saliva on the backpack.

A couple was hiking down the upper Yosemite Falls trail when they saw yellow 32 walking up the trail towards them. Scared that the bear would attack them for their food, they left their backpack on the trail and scrambled up a rock on the side to get out of the way. Y32 went straight to the pack and proceeded to rip it apart and eat the contents for 20 minutes. The couple called 911 and was transferred to wildlife staff. Raquel attempted to advise them to scare the bear but they did not. The bear eventually left after 30 minutes and the couple hiked out. This was the couple's first visit and first time seeing a bear. The male individual proceeded to call the wildlife office frequently in the following days, worried about zoonotic diseases from contacting bear saliva on the backpack.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: W36's (3536) GPS points appeared in/around a building at Badger Pass Ski area. Upon follow up H. Vince discovered a left out grease drum that a bear had got into (footprints, poop).
Untagged bear got into a left open bear locker that was being used for hotel room trash. Bear remained in area and had to be hazed away twice.
G7 (3077) ripped into a bag of left out recycling, then opened the side compartment of their RV and got into more trash. No damage to RV.
Bear got into a left out cooler with trash in it. No damage
Desk Officer found 4 trash cans turned over with trash spread everywhere.
Found garbage can knocked over and ransacked in parking lot. Garbage strewn about.

Kate Gunsolus reported that she came up on P29 on accident, yelled and threw a stick at 25ft, then P29 bluff charged at Kate to 5 feet. Kate hit her with an acorn "right between the eyes. Like, hard." P29 treed and Kate left.

LocationDetail: Bike path between Ranger Y and Hutchings
IncidentDescription: Purple 29 bluff charged visitor who was taking photos 15-20 yards from the bear. I instructed him to move away, he ignored me and continued to walk adjacent to her. When I yelled at him again he did turn away from her, and she charged him while his back was turned. The rest of the evening she and her 2 cubs grazed acorns.

Adult male and female visitor were at their picnic table eating dinner when Green 7 approached their site from the direction of Stoneman meadow. The visitors were startled and immediately retreated to their vehicle. When I arrived Green 7 had her front paws on the picnic table and appeared to be eating. I pulled into the campsite with the horn blaring and hazed her away with yelling and paintballs. Later in the evening, she got a cooler out of an opened bear box in North Pines but did not get into the cooler.

3797 walked up the river bed from the west and through a large group of people who backed away. He approached a family picnicking on the beach to within 5 feet before they were too afraid and backed away from their closed cooler. The bear opened the cooler and consumed 2 apples, 3 sandwiches, and a box of granola bars before laying down 10 feet away as a large crowd looked on. I arrived and immediately hazed the bear aggressively across the river to the north. He stopped on the bank and then ran in response to pyrotechnics. Food conditioned behavior as many people were present and were rightfully afraid. Victor 35 and M. Dennis also responded with good education provided by M. Dennis.

Bear started ripping into siding of house. Bear was going after wasp nest. Ripped screen and siding. Resident came outside and saw tail end of the bear. Sam Crenshaw (paramedic) also saw the bear running away.
Green 7 was found by wildlife staff eating out of a large bucket filled with honey outside the Aramark warehouse paint shop.

Two people were bouldering approximately 50 yards from their packs when Yellow 32 approached. The climbers noticed him there and tried yelling from their location but he did not react and proceeded to rip into both of their packs. He obtained 2 granola bars and a small bag of banana chips and destroyed both bags estimated $100 each. The climbers tried yelling from a distance with another party who arrived, but Y32 did not move. He remained on their things for approx. 20 minutes and then left on his own. Party was educated thoroughly by MD on all aspects of living in bear country.

Two people were bouldering approximately 50 yards from their packs when Yellow 32 approached. The climbers noticed him there and tried yelling from their location but he did not react and proceeded to rip into both of their packs. He obtained 2 granola bars and a small bag of banana chips and destroyed both bags estimated $100 each. The climbers tried yelling from a distance with another party who arrived, but Y32 did not move. He remained on their things for approx. 20 minutes and then left on his own. Party was educated thoroughly by MD on all aspects of living in bear country.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear slobbered and scratched tailgate and camper shell of Tacoma. Empty ice chest stored in bed of truck.
Victim was making brownies in her kitchen. Turned around to see the face of a bear pushing through newly ripped screen at open window. Husband went outside and threw rocks at the bear.

Green 7 approached man in a hammock. He tossed his sandwich to lure the bear away from himself. He then got up and walked a distance away while the bear proceeded to eat his sandwich and walk to the hammock to also obtain pistachios and almonds. R. Lester arrived on scene to green 7 still eating snacks. Fired 4x h-stars from shotgun as bear exited N. Pines, which was closed due to Covid-19

Collared bear broke window assembly off Hasting's kitchen window, then went around to front porch and entered enclosed porch via screen door. It was trapped and couldn’t go out that one-way door, so it jumped through a small screen on side of porch. Rob responded at 22:30 to help LE find bear. Yellow 32 was not audible on telemetry. Green 7 was moderate. GPS points indicated it was Green 7, bear #3077
Matt Bablitch and Lissie reported seeing a small blonde bear spending time at the train, ripping siding off the caboose for acorn caches.

Josh Helling stepped out onto his front porch and a large, dark (maybe black) bear bluff charged him to within 10 feet. He had previously seen this same bear in the tree over his house on a couple occasions. The bear had been eating acorns in the tree, and in his yard. He threw rocks to chase the bear away. Bear was described as possibly having a #11 tag, either Green or White. Based on description of very large, probably not Green 11. Thinking it might have been White 17 but unknown.

2 nights later Josh reported seeing 3 or 4 bears in the tree above his house. Based on all the evidence, we believe this was a defensive bluff charge from a startled bear, or more likely, a mother with cubs very close by.

A yearling or subadult bear consistently climbing onto roof and peeling back metal roof to access stashed acorns. Also punched a hole in wooden siding to get stashed acorns. Bear climbing onto roof since 11/15, usually in the mornings around 6am.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Resident accidentally left kitchen door unlatched/ open. Bear walked in at 03:00 and obtained food trash and tossed trash around. No property damage. Bear returned a couple times after being chased off by Dan Bush, longtime resident

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear walked through busy beach/picnic area and grabbed a bag of trash that was unattended. Ran off with it, ate a bit of the contents, visitors then scared the bear away and collected the garbage.

White 8 had been in HK roaming around for nearly 1 hour before someone called dispatch. M. Dennis arrived to site 50 around 11:00 to find white 8 casually milling around the site with trash strewn about and 3 people watching from 25 yards. She immediately scared the bear away by honking and using paintballs. She chased bear across housekeeping bridge. White 8 did not respond super well, walking after running only a short distance. Visitors reported that she had been chewing on a coffee cup for 30 minutes then spent over an hour in HK going in and out of peoples' cabins. M. Dennis did strong education about calling dispatch for wildlife in development.

LocationDetail: Just upstream of backpacker's camp bridge
IncidentDescription: Witness on backpacker's camp bridge saw bear walk onto log and grab unattended food (victim was also on bridge, 50+ feet away). Visitor scared bear off. Visitor referred to bear as purple 26. Unclear on amount of food obtained. Described as snack, or small bowl of pasta.

Visitor sat down on rock at east end of boardwalk to eat lunch. Small (reportedly untagged, uncollared) brown colored bear approached her on the boardwalk from the west. Ms. Vu froze and did not move. The bear was hesitant at first but then made several attempts to get on the rock. It sniffed her face, but didn't touch her, then scratched her right thigh seemingly testing out of curiosity which punctured her pants and left two puncture wounds and a raised welt on her thigh. Refused medical response. She told two visitors on the west side of the boardwalk that the bear "just scratched me". The couple recorded the incident and we obtained photos of the bear from them. They made noise which startled the bear. It then darted away, ran to the west boardwalk. They made noises and the bear entered the fen vegetation a short distance. The two parties met up and walked east away from the fen. The bear came back to boardwalk and finally ran off after Ms. Vu cracked her hiking poles together.

Green 2 being walked towards Swan Slab, climbers being moved, Green 2 began running, climber had to leave bag. Green 2 ran up and grabbed bag. Was chased and paintballed by 879 but ran into talus with backpack. Cubs treed next to Swan Slab. Approximately 10 minutes later, Green 2 returned and lead cubs behind Camp 4. Backpack was found 30 minutes later. 2 sandwiches and 2 small chip bags and a fruit cup had been eaten. Green 2 also bluff charged someone while we were searching for pack.

Green 2 being walked towards Swan Slab, climbers being moved, Green 2 began running, climber had to leave bag. Green 2 ran up and grabbed bag. Was chased and paintballed by 879 but ran into talus with backpack. Cubs treed next to Swan Slab. Approximately 10 minutes later, Green 2 returned and lead cubs behind Camp 4. Backpack was found 30 minutes later. 2 sandwiches and 2 small chip bags and a fruit cup had been eaten. Green 2 also bluff charged someone while we were searching for pack.

Visitor was hiking on east side of Mirror Lake Loop trail, stopped to take lunch on a log before rock-slide field. Large untagged bear came down from talus and approached on trail. Visitor backed away from pack. Bear then ripped through pack and obtained some chips, a sandwich, and a sports drink. Visitor did not try to scare bear off due to fear of the bear. Bear eventually walked off on its own.

Visitor was hiking on east side of Mirror Lake Loop trail, stopped to take lunch on a log before rock-slide field. Large untagged bear came down from talus and approached on trail. Visitor backed away from pack. Bear then ripped through pack and obtained some chips, a sandwich, and a sports drink. Visitor did not try to scare bear off due to fear of the bear. Bear eventually walked off on its own.

A family plus several other people were picnicking near the beach of Sugar Pine bridge when G2 approached them. The family grabbed most of their bags, but not all, and G2 grabbed one small backpack. The group reports yelling and waving arms but it had no effect on the bear. The bear then dragged the pack into the woods and consumed the contents, a half sandwich and a peach.

A family plus several other people were picnicking near the beach of Sugar Pine bridge when G2 approached them. The family grabbed most of their bags, but not all, and G2 grabbed one small backpack. The group reports yelling and waving arms but it had no effect on the bear. The bear then dragged the pack into the woods and consumed the contents, a half sandwich and a peach.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: G2 and offspring foraging in corridor. Green 2 entered campsite and knocked over two bins, bit tent and started shaking it. Observers did not see any items removed from tent. Site appears clean. Only bug spray and mulberry silk pillow.

LocationDetail: Between California Falls and Waterwheel Falls
IncidentDescription: Bear pawed at tent and then put enough pressure to break tent pole. They hazed bear off, it returned, hazed off again, they packed up and left. Described as frequent backpackers who were good about food storage.

Bear 3636 obtained food from a drawstring backpack with Gatorade, watermelon slices left hanging on a tree at Sugar Pine Bridge. No visitor in the area would claim it. Watermelon slices were fully eaten though visibly moldy. LE responded but no identifying items were in the bag. Visitors reported they had seen the bag hanging up there for a few days.

Bear 3636 obtained food from a drawstring backpack with Gatorade, watermelon slices left hanging on a tree at Sugar Pine Bridge. No visitor in the area would claim it. Watermelon slices were fully eaten though visibly moldy. LE responded but no identifying items were in the bag. Visitors reported they had seen the bag hanging up there for a few days.

Bear walked right up to two people with a picnic and they were scared, they ran a short distance away. Bear began sniffing, ripping, and eating. Many beach-goers watched the whole incident. Photos were taken of the bear on food. Bear was on picnic for approximately 15 minutes before I arrived and hit the bear with a HV-star round. I chased bear hard but never got a second clear hazing round opportunity. Bear obtained cheese sandwich, trail mix, and chewy granola bars.

Bear walked right up to two people with a picnic and they were scared, they ran a short distance away. Bear began sniffing, ripping, and eating. Many beach-goers watched the whole incident. Photos were taken of the bear on food. Bear was on picnic for approximately 15 minutes before I arrived and hit the bear with a HV-star round. I chased bear hard but never got a second clear hazing round opportunity. Bear obtained cheese sandwich, trail mix, and chewy granola bars.

Four concession employees were having a small picnic next to the river just south of Ahwahnee Bridge, Yellow 32 scared them away from their food. They had chips and lots of alcohol. They said they yelled at the bear and he had no reaction. Y32 tore into a backpack that didn’t have food in it, and bit through a JBL speaker.

Four concession employees were having a small picnic next to the river just south of Ahwahnee Bridge, Yellow 32 scared them away from their food. They had chips and lots of alcohol. They said they yelled at the bear and he had no reaction. Y32 tore into a backpack that didn’t have food in it, and bit through a JBL speaker.

Four concession employees were having a small picnic next to the river just south of Ahwahnee Bridge, Yellow 32 scared them away from their food. They had chips and lots of alcohol. They said they yelled at the bear and he had no reaction. Y32 tore into a backpack that didn’t have food in it, and bit through a JBL speaker.

P26 in VIP loop raspberries in campsite. Chased out by 879 20 minutes prior. P26 Re-entered campsite less than 15 feet from campers eating dinner. Attempted to haze out again by Skyler, off duty. Refused to move then bluff charged 879 by trotting up to him, clacking jaws, and stomping feet. Ran off and treed twice after being hit with small rock, then left campsite.

Large yellow tagged bear walked directly up to Aaron Smith's backpack on the beach which contained no food. Aaron tried scaring Y32 away but the bear bluff charged him twice (once to within 5 feet), forcing Aaron to retreat to the water out of fear.

Y32 mini-bluff charged people off their picnic. People watched bear eat food for 20 minutes. Unknown how much food obtained but ate a BBQ grill worth of food, including steak. Onlooker video should be coming our way soon.

Minor bluff charge. Purple 26 walked into U. Pines towards raspberries in 5th loop. Dean (camp host) and a few visitors yelled and banged pots. P26 took a few quick deliberate steps towards Dean, no jaw clacking. She then turned, ate a few berries, and left the campground into the woods.

Group of visitors eating tacos at orchard lot after dark. Bear approached visitors despite yelling. Visitors were scared and retreated. Bear got one taco before visitors started throwing rocks and were able to scare off the bear. Yellow 32 (#3797) was found
Bear took 2 cliff bars from a pack. Mother bear and 3 cubs. Visitors 20 feet away. Damaged the pack, hydration bladder and ate the cliff bars
Bear took 2 cliff bars from a pack. Mother bear and 3 cubs. Visitors 20 feet away. Damaged the pack, hydration bladder and ate the cliff bars
Bear took 2 cliff bars from a pack. Mother bear and 3 cubs. Visitors 20 feet away. Damaged the pack, hydration bladder and ate the cliff bars
Trail crew had one tent torn into. There was nothing smelly inside, no food or toiletries. No witnesses. Rainfly pole damaged.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Trail crew sitting around campfire at 17:00, later they noticed a pack that had been behind them, had been dragged up the hill and ripped apart. Toothpaste was in the pack. Bear not observed but Bill was very confident it was a bear.

LocationDetail: Swinging bridge down by the water
IncidentDescription: Y32 approached family of 12 on the beach. Family was with their food, yelled and made noise, but Y32 still advanced and grabbed a backpack and ran off. Y32 then came back after destroying the pack and bluff charged the family off their entire picnic. Family retreated to water to get away. Y32 obtained 6 chicken sandwiches, a bag of chips, plate of tri-tip, and cookies.

LocationDetail: Swinging bridge down by the water
IncidentDescription: Y32 approached family of 12 on the beach. Family was with their food, yelled and made noise, but Y32 still advanced and grabbed a backpack and ran off. Y32 then came back after destroying the pack and bluff charged the family off their entire picnic. Family retreated to water to get away. Y32 obtained 6 chicken sandwiches, a bag of chips, plate of tri-tip, and cookies.

NPS custodial staff (Jewell and Aaron) tried to scare Yellow 32 away from a picnic, but were bluff charged twice when they approached. Y32 came within 10 feet. This was just the second bluff charge component of the 2 incidents, so food was present and obtained earlier, but property damage is recorded in the previous incident.
Bear broke into septic line at Trailer in EP. Fresh bear scat present

Harry, the gardener at the Ahwahnee, walked around the back of the cabins and saw Purple 26 in the woods. He approached and hazed her with yelling and she bluff charged and came within 10 feet of him. He backed off after this and called wildlife management. When I arrived P26 was lingering in the same area as when Harry found her. I hazed her with bangers, paintballs, and yelling/chasing and she ran with something in her mouth that looked like a dead squirrel. The spot she left from had blood and juvenile deer jaw bone fragment. She returned to the back of the cottages 5 times in the next two hours.

Boulderers were swimming in river with crash pad on beach. They had left a box of Cheese-its in the crash pad. Purple 26 was being followed for darting. She came across the food and ate the cheese-its, which helped facilitate E. Degutis hitting her with a dart.
Bear tore screens off windows and clawed into windowsill of the "Comfort House", a trail crew NPS house. It did not get into the house or obtain any food. Pictures attached to the incident form.

A large and very light colored bear with a tiny yellow tag ran off with a pair of women's underwear from one party, then grabbed another woman's hat while running away. Underwear family tried to yell and scare the bear, but then backed off their stuff when it wasn’t deterred. No food was obtained (none present). Bear ran when they started throwing things.
Volunteer camp host had dog food in improperly closed locker and a bear got into it. Bear quickly revisited seeking food.

Took report from bear hotline of young light brown bear that got into a bike trailer on the paved path at Lower Falls, UTL on RP. Wildlife was not able to follow up. White 8 (bear #3666) data points in the area at the time of the incident.

White 8 got food from an unattended picnic table at Swinging bridge. Visitors were at the river and away from their food. Picknickers nearby scared the bear away. Wildlife staff and L.E. both responded and hazed White 8 into the talus.
Bear obtained bait from a turtle trap. Consumed 400 calories of mackerel.
Bear obtained bait from a turtle trap. Consumed 400 calories of mackerel.
Overnight, a bear destroyed aquatics bait station and ate 400 calories of mackerel.
Overnight, a bear destroyed aquatics bait station and ate 400 calories of mackerel.
Bear crushed turtle trap and bait cup and ate 400 calories of mackerel
Bear crushed turtle trap and bait cup and ate 400 calories of mackerel

Dark brown, maybe black sub-adult checking out trailer and sewer line every few nights. Caught on game camera. Second time this bear has damaged the resident's sewer line, but seemingly got no calorie reward despite the damage.

Head and paws through the right side of window, was able to see another bear on the stairs on the deck. 1st bear fully entered and tore open trash, did not open fridge. Bear ate pancake powder, ripped the window screen. Bear came in and out of the occupied residence multiple times. This bear was positively identified by Wawona rangers and euthanized the following night of this incident.

Head and paws through the right side of window, was able to see another bear on the stairs on the deck. 1st bear fully entered and tore open trash, did not open fridge. Bear ate pancake powder, ripped the window screen. Bear came in and out of the occupied residence multiple times. This bear was positively identified by Wawona rangers and euthanized the following night of this incident.
Owner out of town Sunday through Wednesday. Extensive property damage to siding/ building exterior. No food present near location.

Green 2 and cubs broke into Curry back dock freezer for the second consecutive night. They obtained substantial amounts of ice cream and chicken. The freezer door was not bear proof, even when locked it could be forcefully pulled open. Concessionaire management has been contacted and is addressing the locking mechanism. Earlier in the night a bear also entered the kitchen and had to be let out by employees. No food loss or damage was reported and a positive ID of the bear could not be given. Green 2's GPS points put her in the area at the time.

Green 2 and cubs got into the Curry back dock freezer and obtained substantial amount of ice cream and frozen chicken. Curry staff arrived in the morning to find food from the freezer pulled out and spread all over the back dock area. The door to the freezer was also damaged from the bears prying it open. This report initially went unreported to wildlife staff.

Green 2 and cubs got into the Curry back dock freezer and obtained substantial amount of ice cream and frozen chicken. Curry staff arrived in the morning to find food from the freezer pulled out and spread all over the back dock area. The door to the freezer was also damaged from the bears prying it open. This report initially went unreported to wildlife staff.

Bear approached and was not scared off easily and kept returning. Visitors said the bear obtained food from their backpack. Visitors tried to yell and scare it away but could not. Bear was on food for 10 plus minutes while people filmed and took photos. The whole incident was posted to social media as well. White 8 (3666)

Bear approached and was not scared off easily and kept returning. Visitors said the bear obtained food from their backpack. Visitors tried to yell and scare it away but could not. Bear was on food for 10 plus minutes while people filmed and took photos. The whole incident was posted to social media as well. White 8 (3666)

Family was cooking pasta on beach next to food. White 8 (3666) approached and they yelled but not very loud. Bear would not leave so they grabbed their children and backed off. White 8 ate a bag of Doritos, popcorn, and pasta. Father pepper sprayed the bear and emptied the whole bottle but she didn’t react at all. They yelled more and another family joined and she finally backed off, but stayed pacing on the beach. Wildlife staff showed up and chased her away 4 separate times before she gave up.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear entered our campsite while we were out by the river and tore through two packs and left footprints in the dirt. One backpack had a Clif bar wrapper, the other the bear was after the stove. The bear tore through 2 out of 3 of our packs, ripping everything in his way to get to what he smelled. One pack was completely ripped on the right side, the other with a claw mark hole. One pack's contents were completely destroyed: stuff sacks, tent covers, and bags. Packs were a Gossamer Mariposa and Osprey. The third pack was never touched. We had our canisters with us at the river, the bear did not touch them.
