Alex Wild (wilderness ranger) was climbing at Chapel and noticed a bear getting into an OB camper's food stash. He chased the bear away and said he saw a collar. Rob arrived on scene off duty, and coordinated cleanup and LE response and guarded food for an hour. Hard to tell what the bear consumed but there were a lot of various food wrappers around, including Ramen, candy bar, and jar of peanut butter. Backpack was ripped to shreds. Food and trash scattered everywhere. 99% sure it was Blue 70, bear #2037, as GPS points put her in the area, and she was the first to return that night on photos from game camera. Multiple other untagged bears also were caught investigating the scene the following night.

Alex Wild (wilderness ranger) was climbing at Chapel and noticed a bear getting into an OB camper's food stash. He chased the bear away and said he saw a collar. Rob arrived on scene off duty, and coordinated cleanup and LE response and guarded food for an hour. Hard to tell what the bear consumed but there were a lot of various food wrappers around, including Ramen, candy bar, and jar of peanut butter. Backpack was ripped to shreds. Food and trash scattered everywhere. 99% sure it was Blue 70, bear #2037, as GPS points put her in the area, and she was the first to return that night on photos from game camera. Multiple other untagged bears also were caught investigating the scene the following night.

Family was on bikes on the north side of the bridge. They saw white 8 and got scared, so they picked up their kids and moved away. The bear pulled trash out of their bike trailer and ate one hard-boiled egg. She nosed around some mango peels but didn’t eat anything else. Other people started yelling and the family joined in. White 8 paid no attention and sauntered off when she was done with the egg.

Family was on bikes on the north side of the bridge. They saw white 8 and got scared, so they picked up their kids and moved away. The bear pulled trash out of their bike trailer and ate one hard-boiled egg. She nosed around some mango peels but didn’t eat anything else. Other people started yelling and the family joined in. White 8 paid no attention and sauntered off when she was done with the egg.

Visitors were 10-15 feet away from their backpacks when White 8, bear #3666 appeared and snatched a pack. Visitors yelled loudly (I heard them and can confirm this - loudly and persistently) and threw some sticks. They even moved towards her to try to shoo her away but she did not react. To distract her from the backpack, they threw a handful of beef jerky pieces at her and she ate 2 pieces before wildlife staff arrived.
Dark brown or black, medium sized adult caught on game camera coming from Kristen Higgins trailer, subsequent to destroying her sewage line

Bear reported sniffing around trash cans at Pizza Deck. Wildlife staff responded and found several overflowing trash cans, one showing obvious signs that a bear had got into it. Wildlife staff responded to a call an hour later at the same location. Respond and saw bear (P29 #3125) trying to get into the top of the trash can.
Bag of trash left out over night. Wildlife staff arrived in the morning to see W8 (#3666) ripping up the bag of trash in site #186. Hazed out.
Bear knocked over a coffin locker at LYV ranger station. Locker then popped open and spilled out a bunch of food trash that bear then got into. Locker only had one clip latched.
Food trash found strewn about site with signs of bear damage.

Employee arrived in the morning to find bear scat and knocked over trashcans inside the kitchen. Unknown how bear entered the building. Wildlife staff was out with G2 (3077) and her 2 cubs on the Curry Deck prior to this report. Cubs were in tree, G2 appeared from roof then gathered her cubs and left.
Bag of food trash discovered strewn about maintenance yard next to bear trap.
Concession employee came across an a bunch of trash strewn around a bear locker with signs of bear damage.
Lodge staff walked up on a bear in trash by a bear locker between building 3200 and 3300. Bear ran away when it saw them. RP described bear as small with a white tag.
Bear obtained trash from a vehicle while it was being loaded. Stated bear acted like it had done it before.
Maintenance workers found 2 trash bags ripped into by a bear in the open top dumpster.

LocationDetail: Between Cascade picnic and Arch Rock
IncidentDescription: Bear came down hill toward Katie. She moved away, afraid. The bear bit the pop-socket off her phone and didn't respond to her yelling. It hit the play button with its nose and when the music came on it got spooked and moved away from the phone. She threw water at it and it eventually moved away.

B+G reported a bear had ripped the siding off a house. It happened sometime between Monday night 9/20 and Tuesday night. They know this because they worked on the house on Monday and the damage was not there. They came back on Wednesday and noticed it. The residents are on vacation so they weren't there when it happened. Bear ripped into siding to get a bee's nest.
Bear bit hammock hanging in backyard several times, damaging it. Also left paw prints on hammock
Visitor watched as a beautiful caramel colored bear went through his neighbors unattended trash. Visitor reported incident to E. Kokotan (wilderness ranger).

On July 3rd, I was hiking down from HD around 1600 and came across an open pack on the side of the trail with its contents all over the place. The pack looked like it had been dragged uphill. No one was around. A few minutes later, a visitor told me that the owner had left it at the Sunrise/HD junction and the owner said she could have one of the 5 water bottles. I was able to confirm the pack I found was the pack she was talking about, though she never saw it prior. I was a 1/2 mile from the junction and concluded a bear dragged it. Peanut M&M's were being munched on by a squirrel, but the bag looked like it had been torn open. There were 2 clean and empty cliff bar wrappers, a cleaned-out cookie wrapper and an empty honey stinger wrapper strewn about. After closer inspection, the pack was not damaged, but all zippers with food were open. There was an uninjured jacket inside too. They were able to be turned into lost and found. But since the owner will likely never get them, I consider them lost. I estimate the value of the pack to be $40 and the jacket $20. There was no bear observed in this incident.

Ed Canapari of BCU had hung his backpack on a hook on the shed behind the Vernal Footbridge bathroom and Blue 70 got it off and started ripping into it. She didn’t get anything from the pack and she was difficult to haze but Ed was successful with very aggressive shouting while he approached her. She treed nearby after the incident and continued to eat acorns.

Blue 70 (#2037) was observed on resident's Ring App pulling the AC window unit out of the window. The falling unit startled the bear but not by much. She continued to approach the open window but was scared off by a neighbor. She ran fast when the neighbor yelled and no food was obtained.

Colton Marshal heard a commotion on his porch, went outside and saw a large dark/black bear eating food out of a haul-bag on his porch. He aggressively scared the bear away, but the bear was briefly defiant. Colton successfully scared it away and gave a stern warning to the owner of the haul bag which was a guest. The individual who left the food out was Juan Jose, who also had his food taken by a bear earlier in the summer at Chapel Wall. He got a second mandatory citation this time and was asked to leave Yosemite.

EP resident Rosemary MacCallum returned to her home on 11/12 at 4pm after spending a couple hours in the Valley, to find trash sprawled everywhere, the window pushed open, and a bear just outside her home with a bottle of protein powder that it had taken from inside. She noted "it just made a mess of my recycling and took the protein powder". Damage includes protein powder and window screen. She said she left the window cracked while she was away.

EP resident Rosemary MacCallum returned to her home on 11/12 at 4pm after spending a couple hours in the Valley, to find trash sprawled everywhere, the window pushed open, and a bear just outside her home with a bottle of protein powder that it had taken from inside. She noted "it just made a mess of my recycling and took the protein powder". Damage includes protein powder and window screen. She said she left the window cracked while she was away.

Linda left house for 15 minutes with door open. Untagged bear ripped through door screen, entered kitchen, opened cabinet, ate a cake and sourdough bread. Linda returned to find the bear on front yard eating. It spooked easily and went up a tree.

Linda left house for 15 minutes with door open. Untagged bear ripped through door screen, entered kitchen, opened cabinet, ate a cake and sourdough bread. Linda returned to find the bear on front yard eating. It spooked easily and went up a tree.

Second-hand report through Joey , Valley L.E. responded to a bear getting people's food at Churchbowl around midnight. The people were 30 feet from their food. An uncollared bear obtained food and garbage. LE hazed the bear verbally and it did not go far, only 20 feet away each time they hazed.

I woke up hearing strange noises outside bedroom window. I went out and spotlighted a bear in an open-top dumpster. He ran immediately when spotlighted. Dumpster had a bunch of minor food trash: wrappers, condiments, empty food packages. The bear likely didn’t get too many calories, was just licking and rummaging through scented trash.
Mike Hastings responded to a bear getting into trash at Church Bowl picnic area around midnight. He fired 2 shotgun rounds at the bear. Large dark colored bear with right ear tag.

LocationDetail: Circle meadow, 18 trail to Dewey Point
IncidentDescription: Visitors camped at the edge of Circle meadow on the night of December 18th. On December 19th they started back towards Badger Pass when one of their party could not continue due to dehydration. They abandoned a duffel bag and some other gear. The duffel contained a bear canister with food along with some unsecured MRE's, bars, and trash. A bear obtained this food sometime overnight on the 19th-20th. Badger Pass staff retrieved the bag on the morning of the 20th and found the evidence of a bear incident.

LocationDetail: Circle meadow, 18 trail to Dewey Point
IncidentDescription: Visitors camped at the edge of Circle meadow on the night of December 18th. Badger Pass staff retrieved the bag on the morning of the 20th and found the evidence of a bear incident.

Liz Lauer was on trail when Bear 2037 (blue 70) crossed footbridge in her direction. Liz was very afraid and tossed her pack towards the bear. B70 ate string cheese. Subject reports $50 damage to pack. Visitor says she would have felt more empowered to scare the bear if she could have carried bear spray. Subject states this happened on a commercial photography tour with "Arizona Highway Photoscapes." Original report given to Kristin Anderson at YC Nature Center.

Liz Lauer was on trail when Bear 2037 (blue 70) crossed footbridge in her direction. Liz was very afraid and tossed her pack towards the bear. B70 ate string cheese. Subject reports $50 damage to pack. Visitor says she would have felt more empowered to scare the bear if she could have carried bear spray. Subject states this happened on a commercial photography tour with "Arizona Highway Photoscapes." Original report given to Kristin Anderson at YC Nature Center.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: NPS employee arrived to check status of bathroom at 08:00 and found significant damage to interior saniboxes. RP reports that multiple unused urinal cakes were eaten along with 4+ rolls of unused toilet paper, along with miscellaneous wrappers/garbage (no food reported). A visitor reported on the hotline, seeing a bear exit the Vernal Falls footbridge bathroom at 07:30, no description.

Kevin Killian was patrolling EP Trailer Court and saw a subadult black bear exiting unit E7. The bear had no tags or collar and was skittish. Bear received substantial food reward including 5+ packs of ramen, multiple cans of soup, Oreos, etc. Bear captured 5/18/22 in tree near incident location, tagged Purple 1 - #2212, released at Crane Flat.

Following P1 (Bear #2212) GPS points concentrated in Trailer Court, food trash was found in Trailer Court that appeared fresh from previous day. Trash that had clear bear bite marks included beefy stew, English muffins, peanut butter, and ginger ale. It is suspected that about 1000 calories could have been consumed, unconfirmed. On 5/24/22, bear management was able to work with B+G to secure substantial remaining food/recycling in area.

Bear #2212 seen in trailer court by unit E8. After chasing bear out of trailer court, food trash was found at location where bear was first seen. Additional canned soups w/ punctures were found surrounding exterior storage area. Residents of Unit E5 state they are finding new food trash with bear sign daily.
Third-hand report of a bear getting food from backpackers at Lake Vernon. Unknown how food was stored or obtained.

LocationDetail: Unknown which campground but campground in valley
IncidentDescription: Individual called PIO line to report seeing an Instagram post of a bear obtaining food from an open locker in Yose Valley CG. RP said that she told the poster it was a bad idea to post. Call taker advised RP to call Save-A-Bear hotline but they have not. Filled out incident report from D. Wright's information, feel confident in reliability. Wildlife staff UTL original post.

At 07:30, two bags of trash were found between dumpsters in SBPA, ~5000 calories of food trash appeared to have been consumed, including 1/2 a watermelon. Trash bags were left next to dumpster that was not full. Second trash bag contained 40+ Corona bottles

NW side of Lake Vernon, bear got trash bag that was unattended by campers who had left to get water, campers came back and tried yelling, it left the trash but circled back south towards campsite of the RP. They were making breakfast, a group of 10 campers came together to scare the bear off. Bear was not scared but was deterred from campers and walked further away towards river. Not super reactive, clearly used to people, between 7am and 8am.

Backpacker walked > 10 feet away from open canister. Saw bear ~10 feet away and visitor fled out of fear because she was between the bear and open canister. Visitor watched the bear consume >5000 calories of food. Visitor then stated the bear followed the party of 4 out. Visitor stated she had visited YOSE 4+ times and the wilderness ranger did not tell her what to do if she saw a bear. Had BV canister but used improperly (left open out of arm's reach).

Group of PCT'ers scared away from food/trash/gear by persistent, large blonde bear. Bear was difficult to haze, it obtained trash and cheese. Another group witnessed the incident. 2nd group then helped push bear out of campsite by throwing rocks at it. Bear was persistent and roamed around to different campsites in search of more food/canisters.

Purple 29 bluff charged myself and Kyler Mosher after we lightly walked her out of Lower Falls and pursued her into Hutchings. Cub had gone up a tree and was vocalizing, P29 did a leap and double step towards us, and we backed away.

Drove past wash rack at fort late in the evening. Bear was in distance walking away into woods, only saw butt so unknown if tagged. Found ripped open bag of trash with several empty cups of ramen bit into along with damaged pop cans. Unknown where the trash bag came from. No cars or trucks nearby. Appeared to be from resident. Receipt with name Elizabeth Vandentoorn.
Bear was witnessed eating trash from an overflowing can. Visitors had tough time describing location but clearly saw bear eating trash off ground
Bear got into overflowing trash and was scared away by fire personnel.

Trash was scattered around the trash bins. Wildlife clearly got into food. I went to clean it up and throw trash away and bins were very full. I was able to disperse the trash amongst all three cans and recycling cans to clean everything up
Bear observed accessing garbage by break area. Photos on Teams. Chased off by night housing.
Visitor returning to car by swinging bridge witnessed bear access trash from overflowing dumpster/small trash can by bathroom. Hit panic button on car to scare bear off.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear and cub were in the area when we ventured from our vehicles. The bear was interested in our packs. Cub was treed, we left to try and allow the cub to climb down. Bears tore through packs gourging on sweaty items and wrappers. Bear got into 1 pack with food wrappers in it. Bear also gnawed sweaty parts of 2nd daypack (back pad and vest). Bear described as light brown with ear tag and collar, with purple tag. Purple 29's GPS points put her in this area at the right time.

Jace, defensive bluff charge. Ranger came up on five visitors on trail to softball field - bear and cub were 20 feet away. Ranger asked visitors to leave and told the bear to stay away and to keep aware of location. Ranger spoke up, bear made two body strides forward and huffed after ranger tried to push away from eyesight. Cub ran off, mama bear behind.

Bear obtained trash as visitors were done cooking breakfast. Visitors fearfully backed away from their food as large dark brown bear approached. Bear was untagged and seemed habituated and food conditioned. Visitors tried unsuccessfully to yell and scare bear away . Bear returned 20 minutes later and investigated their canisters which were closed properly.
Victor 3 was walking through woods in search of suspect. Came upon sow and cub and was bluff-charged. Bear was Orange 22 (3540) and cub. Defensive as both bear and LE were caught off guard.

Canister taken by bear. "Before going to bed we put all of our food in the bear canister and put it 50 feet from our tent in some rock formations but in the morning we could not find it. We did not hear anything during the night but there was some tracks not far from the rocks where we put it. We looked for it but did not find any tracks of it neither sign of our food and we had to shorten our hike because we had (luckily) only 2 bars that we forgot in our bag. I do not think It could have fell off unless someone/something pushed as I placed it like 30/40 feet away from the east edge of Dewey point and placed some rocks above so it couldn't move to prevent the exact situation that happened. Again I am really sorry for this too I really wanted to take back the canister to the end of our adventure in the park. "

Canister taken by bear. "Before going to bed we put all of our food in the bear canister and put it 50 feet from our tent in some rock formations but in the morning we could not find it. We did not hear anything during the night but there was some tracks not far from the rocks where we put it. We looked for it but did not find any tracks of it neither sign of our food and we had to shorten our hike because we had (luckily) only 2 bars that we forgot in our bag. Again I am really sorry for this too I really wanted to take back the canister to the end of our adventure in the park. "

Bear approached backpackers, they were scared and ran away, they tried scaring it with rocks and yelling, bear finally treed. Bear ripped a backpacking pack and had a plastic food bag in its mouth when RP showed up. Second hand report.

Bear approached backpackers, they were scared and ran away, they tried scaring it with rocks and yelling, bear finally treed. Bear ripped a backpacking pack and had a plastic food bag in its mouth when RP showed up. Second hand report.

Visitor was sitting on beach with food, looked up and O22 was < 10-15 feet away. Visitor yelled aggressively and waved arms with no response from bear. Cub ran out between visitor and O22. Vis got scared and retreated from food. O22 tore into bike side bags and bit ENO hammock in its bag. The bear accessed gummy bears, sunscreen, food trash. Cultural resources attempted to scare bear throwing large rocks at it and eventually was able to scare off. EDIT: Spoke to cultural resources staff that was present, says RP was far from food in the river the whole time. Unclear who is the reliable narrator.

Visitor was sitting on beach with food, looked up and O22 was < 10-15 feet away. Visitor yelled aggressively and waved arms with no response from bear. Cub ran out between visitor and O22. Vis got scared and retreated from food. O22 tore into bike side bags and bit ENO hammock in its bag. The bear accessed gummy bears, sunscreen, food trash. Cultural resources attempted to scare bear throwing large rocks at it and eventually was able to scare off. EDIT: Spoke to cultural resources staff that was present, says RP was far from food in the river the whole time. Unclear who is the reliable narrator.

LocationDetail: Between Ireland Jct and Kuna Creek on JMT
IncidentDescription: Bear approached camp, fiddled with backpack, then visitor scared it off. Did not get any food.

Medium sized chocolate bear took unattended backpack and continued to approach people. Woman got scared and threw her sandwich to the bear. Bear eventually lost interest and walked off. At one point, the bear was surrounded by a half-dozen people within 15 feet.

Medium sized chocolate bear took unattended backpack and continued to approach people. Woman got scared and threw her sandwich to the bear. Bear eventually lost interest and walked off. At one point, the bear was surrounded by a half-dozen people within 15 feet.

RP Brian called RO, Nick Sullens took his contact info. Chelsea talked with RP on phone. At top of Nevada Falls, at dry island area in the river just off trail, a bear approached a group of visitors. Visitors all backed away toward trail. Bear obtained food and trash that had been left behind up there by a previous visitor. Bag had bags of beef jerky in it. No visitors claimed trash/food items. RP gave bear space when bear approached, snuck up within 20 yards, left area and called RO. Estimated 300lb bear.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Anonymous text received about 2 bears in lower falls bathroom. H. Vince arrived to find just Blue 70 (Bear 2037) on trash near bathroom. She used a banger and chased the bear away. We cleaned up multiple tipped over trash cans and lots of bathroom trash. Unknown if actual food was obtained. Seemed like maybe not.
An OB camper had set up a tent and mattress, and left food out, behind the Curry Boulders, specifically the Angler Boulder. Blue 70 bear #2037 found the food and obtained thousands of calories.
An OB camper had set up a tent and mattress, and left food out, behind the Curry Boulders, specifically the Angler Boulder. Blue 70 bear #2037 found the food and obtained thousands of calories.

LocationDetail: Pohono Trail 0.5 miles from Pohono/Panorama Jct
IncidentDescription: "Walking towards Taft Point on Pohono Trail just past cabins near Glacier Point. Bear charged me from left side of trail. I charged/yelled at the bear and it slowly backed off. I noticed a cub in a tree on the right side of the trail after a couple of minutes. I slowly backed away from bear while making lots of noise after it gave me some distance. Hiked Glacier Point Rd to Taft." Bear #3125 GPS data confirms presence at location at time of incident.

Bear accessed a refrigerator full of food from garage with damaged door. Garage door had been damaged months prior by motor vehicle, leaving large hole in bottom of door. Bear ate produce, butter/oil, and hummus but did not access > 100,000 calories of dry storage in immediate area. N. Vince secured door that afternoon.

Victim was guest on backpacking tour from CUA Sports Basement. Victim did not click cannister shut. Orange 1 (3233) approached canister, knocked it over, and obtained food reward of five Kind bars and a tortilla. Bear stayed on perimeter of camp until scared off by noise.
A supersack of empty bags of cement and food trash was left out of the construction site between camp 6 and the village store. Call came in that a bear was on the garbage pile eating trash

LocationDetail: Foresta Hilltop rental cabins, 1276 Dana Way
BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Incident report taken from Patty Haskins, the housekeeper who cleans the cabin and found the mess, and Noreen Trombley, who Patty initially reported the incident to. The bear (not seen by anybody) broke into the outdoor-access housekeeping closet at the cabin, via a vent on the bottom of the door. The bear obtained a tub of rodenticide, a container of bug/ant/Taro bait, laundry detergent, and damaged toilet paper, Clorox scented wipes, and another container of cleaner in addition to the door.

Visitor was sitting with chair in river facing Housekeeping Camp reading a book with back to Camp 6 meadow. Visitors on Housekeeping Camp beach saw bear behind victim and yelled to warn him. B70 obtained ~1000 calories of snacks, damaged camp chair, shredded pack, and bit into six library books. When I arrived, B70 was on food with ~50 visitors less than twenty feet from her taking pictures. Hazed hard with 3 shotgun and 1 pyrotechnic round, good response.

Visitor was sitting with chair in river facing Housekeeping Camp reading a book with back to Camp 6 meadow. Visitors on Housekeeping Camp beach saw bear behind victim and yelled to warn him. B70 obtained ~1000 calories of snacks, damaged camp chair, shredded pack, and bit into six library books. When I arrived, B70 was on food with ~50 visitors less than twenty feet from her taking pictures. Hazed hard with 3 shotgun and 1 pyrotechnic round, good response.

When I arrived, B70 was on food with ~50 visitors less than twenty feet from her taking pictures. Hazed hard with 3 shotgun and 1 pyrotechnic round, good response.

A bear got into trash overflowing from trash cans. These cans had been taped off with signs telling people to pack their garbage out. People removed the tape and put trash in them until they were overflowing.

LocationDetail: Junction of Rim Trail (El Cap Tr) and Eagle Peak T
IncidentDescription: From RP: "The bear was on top of pack, ripping it apart. Bear can was scratched laying by the side." Erin: John Gould (backpacker) was hiking up towards Eagle Peak and left his pack near the junction with the Rim Trail. Backpacker reports no food or scented items were left in pack outside of bear canister. Backpacker was unable to locate his pack when he returned and without any gear abandoned his backpacking itinerary and returned to his vehicle. A day hiker (Aaron Johnston) found the pack 0.2 miles up towards Eagle Peak from the junction on 9/9 with a bear ripping into it. The bear canister had been taken out of the pack and was scratched but intact. Although RP reported no radio collar or ear tags, on follow up phone call he was not sure. Medium brown untagged/uncollared bear.

AgroThrive liquid fertilizer was stored outside in the garden that was fenced by wire fencing. Animal broke metal wire that was being used to secure the fence to the side of the house. Animal bit into the liquid fertilizer as well as digging up carrots and onions. Animal entered the garden between 8-5pm while resident was at work. Animal later returned in the middle of the night and dragged the fertilizer into the woods.

AgroThrive liquid fertilizer was stored outside in the garden that was fenced by wire fencing. Animal broke metal wire that was being used to secure the fence to the side of the house. Animal bit into the liquid fertilizer as well as digging up carrots and onions. Animal entered the garden between 8-5pm while resident was at work. Animal later returned in the middle of the night and dragged the fertilizer into the woods.

Good Morning, Hello, my name is Jaquelin Garcia, and I am the new volunteer coordinator for the VIP program in Yosemite! Location: Women's restroom besides visitor center in Yosemite Valley. This morning at around 7:49 am, I came across the women's restroom trash bin knocked over with trash scattered. There were Ziploc bags with food that were ripped open as if they were chewed on. This was very likely a wildlife encounter during the night. I called Dispatch and let them know and facilities came over to clean the floor and put a new trash bag in the trash bin. Additionally, we are informing the YCA to pass this information along in the evening program and to everyone helping in the event! I have attached a photo of the restroom the way I found it. Please let me know if you would like additional details. Jackie
Trash can overflow, bear seems to have reached in through recycling hole and pulled trash out. Lots of food trash scattered about.
Heidi reported that Redwoods wedding guests overfilled dumpsters and a bear got trash and left quite a trail.

Victim was a member of Curry Housekeeping staff. Housekeeper left food unattended (1/2 bag of peanuts) in employee's personal backpack inside the housekeeping cart while she was flipping rooms in Boystown/Curry tent. Employee saw bear and was scared. Other employees chased bear off. No property damage.
S. Young (Wilderness) spoke to visitors who had a bear access garbage from the brains of their backpacks. Looked like a bear accessed food/trash/tampon wrappers. No bear sighted.

The bear was noticed when it started digging beneath the wooden fence surrounding the tent cabin. It may have been trying to get at a hanging bag of trash. Not getting any food this way, the bear moved over to open bear locker and got three muffins before being yelled at enough that it left.

Two 30-gallon black trash bags worth of trash was collected. Confirmed bear sign, scat, and bite marks observed by 848. The trash appeared to be pulled out of at least two of the trash bins in front of the restrooms. No bear seen during this incident, but bear #2343 had two cluster points at exact location after the gates had been swung at midnight local time.
About 1/2 gallon worth of trash was present near the trash cans opposite the cathedral beach restrooms. Visible punctures from teeth present.

Sow + 2 cubs (formerly sow + 3) found at Cathedral ripping into trash. Had to haze several times, but they kept returning. Took trash and left a long wake Eventually called LE to assist & keep lookout while I cleaned up Trash was NOT overflowing - unsure if front of trash was fully or only partially unlatched

Did the bear damage any of your equipment? Just a very minor chomp out of the corner of my old foam pad. Sleeping pad was damaged? Yes - see above. Did the bear get any food/calories at all? No - none. You said the bear worked over your pack, was it damaged? No, he just tipped it off of the log it was leaning on. I had removed the canister before going to the nearby river for water and a quick bath. It knocked the canister about 10' from my pack with no success in opening it. Did you see the bear? No, but I heard from others that a bear was active at the Glen Aulin BC camp and along the trail into the canyon while I was there. This occurred at a beautiful camp in a stand of mature cedar and Ponderosa pine about a 1/2 mile below the footbridge over Matterhorn Creek.
Bear smashed the glass on the front door of the office. Paw prints and slobber visible. Unknown what the attractant was.
1st incident of 2. Bear broke into a shed and got dog food. This first incident seems like the shed was not locked properly and only food was obtained.
2nd of 2 incidents. Bear broke into shed again at same residence and got more dog food. This time the door was latched and the bear caused some structural damage.
2nd of 2 incidents. Bear broke into shed again at same residence and got more dog food. This time the door was latched and the bear caused some structural damage.

Bear ate turkey bacon, chicken, and tomato totaling between 1501-9999 calories. A couple were picnic at El Cap Picnic Area when a bear approached them. The people backed away and got in their car where they made noise honking their horn until a shuttle driver told them to stop. The bear took a packet of turkey bacon and ran away. The people returned to the table and put some of their food away before the bear returned. The bear was eating chicken and tomato when K. Mosher got to the scene and yelled and hit it with paintballs. The bear treed for a minute then ran away as Mosher yelled and shot paintballs. It returned to the picnic area three more times, leaving again when Mosher yelled and shot it with paintballs.

Bear ate turkey bacon, chicken, and tomato totaling between 1501-9999 calories. A couple were picnic at El Cap Picnic Area when a bear approached them. The people backed away and got in their car where they made noise honking their horn until a shuttle driver told them to stop. The bear took a packet of turkey bacon and ran away. The people returned to the table and put some of their food away before the bear returned. The bear was eating chicken and tomato when K. Mosher got to the scene and yelled and hit it with paintballs. The bear treed for a minute then ran away as Mosher yelled and shot paintballs. It returned to the picnic area three more times, leaving again when Mosher yelled and shot it with paintballs.

Christian Pondella (LE) came upon a large tagged bear eating trash from the open door of a trash can. He scared it to the west. It supposedly had a white or yellow tag but he wasn't too confident in that.
Neighbor saw bear getting into trash/recycle. Yelled and scared it off. Would not say specific residence
Purple 1 seen by Gdickman getting trash from a neighbor's porch that they had forgot overnight.

A bear tore open door to under-house storage area. At almost everything in a drop-in freezer: walnuts, bread, roasting chicken, turkey soup stock. Severely damaged freezer. Resident has been seeing a tagged bear (purple 1) and an untagged in their yard regularly. Doors to storage area were old wooden doors with a fairly flimsy latch. Bear simply pried doors open and latch broke.

A bear tore open door to under-house storage area. At almost everything in a drop-in freezer: walnuts, bread, roasting chicken, turkey soup stock. Severely damaged freezer. Resident has been seeing a tagged bear (purple 1) and an untagged in their yard regularly. Doors to storage area were old wooden doors with a fairly flimsy latch. Bear simply pried doors open and latch broke.

A bear tore open door to under-house storage area. At almost everything in a drop-in freezer: walnuts, bread, roasting chicken, turkey soup stock. Severely damaged freezer. Resident has been seeing a tagged bear (purple 1) and an untagged in their yard regularly. Doors to storage area were old wooden doors with a fairly flimsy latch. Bear simply pried doors open and latch broke.
Bear obtained 300 calories of chicken from pacific fisher trap. Three traps rolled by bears in the last week on this line. Bear captured on camera trap, untagged, white blaze on chest
Bear captured on camera. Rolled trap. No food reward but damaged the Tomahawk fisher trap
Campers awoke to see their neighbors picking up garbage and food trash around their campsite and reported it looked like a bear had come through an made a mess.

Visitor left cooler unattended for 10-15 minutes, went to bathroom. One visitor sitting in vehicle finally noticed bear on their cooler and bags of trash. Visitors watched bear eat their food and drag away bags of trash for 10-15 minutes before LE arrived and found the bear still on food, and chased it away. I (R. Lester) arrived at 21:50 and found White 42 (bear #3822) on edge of campground. I hazed the bear with 1 bean bag round and several more foot chases over the next 2 hours as it tried to return multiple times. Finally the bear treed, I waited an hour, and it fell asleep in the tree so I left.

20-gallon trash can full of food and trash was knocked over by a bear. Aaron, garage employee, witnessed the bear on trash at around 03:00 and called it in to dispatch. He cleaned up the trash but did not secure the trash can. The bear returned the following night
I went to investigate an incident from the previous night and found the same trash can had been flipped by a bear this morning, and trash scattered everywhere. Unknown what time.

Found bear at site of at least 3 days old trash incident (buried under freshest layer of snow). Canine marks in recycling and other containers. Untagged adult dark brown to black colored bear seen at garbage today, unknown what bear initially took the garbage. Likely minimal food scraps obtained from trash strewn about.

Aramark Concession Employee went to the bathroom at 6:30 in the morning and found a bear with a yellow tag getting into a bag of garbage they thought was likely left out by the Housekeepers who clean their bathrooms. Employee scared the bear off and then cleaned up the garbage. Reported on Bear Hotline.

Grey Recology dumpster had the bar down. A large dark bear with a right ear tag lifted the bar and lid and climbed inside. RP yelled at the bear and the bear fled the dumpster. RP went back inside but came back out in response to the noise of the bear back inside the dumpster. Yelled again and the bear ran away and did not return. Paw prints at the trash can. Dumpster belongs to the contractors working at the Ahwahnee. The dumpster was not bear-proof without a carabiner that prevents the lock bar across the lids from opening. Carabiner since clipped on.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear entered yard over fence or through gate to access compost. No response to yelling. Stomped at Molly a couple times and kept eating. He seemed to lose interest after a few minutes and wandered off, but did hustle away when I shouted after him. Bear damaged gate in accessing the compost area.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Nic Ross left out a lunch pale w/ Tupperware w/ sandwich aroma, and a child carrier with food wrappers. Bear found on porch ripping the child carrier backpack, lunged at Nic when he tried to scare it. Nic grabbed a stick and smacked bear in face and it took off. Large, light brown, looked like no tags.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Bear was seen on back porch, resident's chased it away. They later saw that 2 of their sheds had been broken into. Bear ate 2-lbs of bees wax and out of first shed and some birdseed and fertilizer out of second shed. Resident reported specific damage to shed as latch, wood, paint. Sheds were reportedly "locked" but were not secure to begin with, so locking was a moot point.

Bear opened car door and spent an hour in the car causing extensive damage after the door closed behind the bear because the car was parked on a hill. Front driver's side sustained the majority of damage - upholstery, ceiling fabric, head rest, weather stripping, and inside panel of car door ripped out. Food present in vehicle: bear obtained chicken, peanut butter, jelly, crackers. Left in a backpack forgotten by owner. Neighbor eventually came over and opened the hatchback of the car and the bear exited and walked away.

Bear opened car door and spent an hour in the car causing extensive damage after the door closed behind the bear because the car was parked on a hill. Front driver's side sustained the majority of damage - upholstery, ceiling fabric, head rest, weather stripping, and inside panel of car door ripped out. Food present in vehicle: bear obtained chicken, peanut butter, jelly, crackers. Left in a backpack forgotten by owner. Neighbor eventually came over and opened the hatchback of the car and the bear exited and walked away.

Bear used unlocked door handle to enter vehicle, sat on parking brake and the car rolled backwards down a hill, and became high centered on a rock wall. Bear totally destroyed inside of car. Totaled. Rob and Erin responded and released bear from vehicle.

Nature Bridge employee. Bear opened unlocked door handle of vehicle and became stuck inside vehicle. Bear obtained food: ghee, quinoa, sugary fizzy drinks, maybe a few other minor items. Bear was stuck in vehicle for 20 minutes. Rob and Erin arrived on scene and opened rear hatch, hazed the bear as it ran away. Car was extremely aromatic with a saccharine, fruity smell.

Nature Bridge employee. Bear opened unlocked door handle of vehicle and became stuck inside vehicle. Bear obtained food: ghee, quinoa, sugary fizzy drinks, maybe a few other minor items. Bear was stuck in vehicle for 20 minutes. Rob and Erin arrived on scene and opened rear hatch, hazed the bear as it ran away. Car was extremely aromatic with a saccharine, fruity smell.
Bear dragged trash about 100m and obtained various food items. Reported by Valley Custodial.

The screen to the skylight over the bathroom was clawed by a bear in the early morning hours of 2/18. Patty heard movement above her and saw the bear's butt as it retreated. The bear had climbed onto the roof of the building the night before. The skylight is often left open day and night when unoccupied.

Small blonde yearling bear stole a hiker's shoe and socks. Hiker saw the bear and "bothered it" out of camp. He said he retrieved his shoe near the bear's "den cave". He also reported hearing other backpacker's attempting to scare the bear away at night.

Garrett Gomez was inside texting friend and heard scratching, then tearing at side of house. No windows were open. Roommate opened blinds to find a bear on side of building. They yelled and it ran away quickly. Did not gain entry into house. Neighbors also reported car door open in the morning and paw prints on seat. Bear not seen well, but likely #2212.
Bear smashed back passenger door of vehicle parked in same spot as previous two break-ins associated with food rewards. Does not appear bear spent much/any time in vehicle. No damage to interior.
Bear seen getting trash at 02:30am. Scared off, then returned but did not get anything
Green E52 seen by 847 and 848 in an open top dumpster. Bear had obtained food trash. They hazed with paintballs, bear treed twice and then fled uphill.

Resident left room to laundry unlatched and external door open. Resident left house at 08:00 and returned home at 19:00. Resident arrived to find dark bear with purple tag #1 in her yard, eating a large Tupperware 1/3 full of cat food. Based on footprints, RP reports bear exited through her kitchen window, which was left open. The screen was damaged. RP chased bear off property. Video confirmation of Purple 1.

Resident left room to laundry unlatched and external door open. Resident left house at 08:00 and returned home at 19:00. Resident arrived to find dark bear with purple tag #1 in her yard, eating a large Tupperware 1/3 full of cat food. Based on footprints, RP reports bear exited through her kitchen window, which was left open. The screen was damaged. RP chased bear off property. Video confirmation of Purple 1.

The bear was coming towards our bear canister and trash which was left outside of it. We tried scaring it away but it continued its advance towards the food and ate it. We backed off and came back but the bear didn't budge. Instead, it walked towards us and grabbed my bag. On the third time, it left. As we left we saw it again. The trash was left outside near a bear cannister. The bear continued its advance and was not afraid of us. Bear ate food scraps: banana peel, onion peel, a tiny bit of beef jerky, porridge scraps. The bear bit a backpack and deformed a cup/mug. I talked to RP 7/12/23 - RL

LocationDetail: Parking near SF Waterhouse housing area
IncidentDescription: Bear seen eating bag of trash left by a car. Person using car alarm to scare it unsuccessfully. RP threw sticks at it to scare it away, and got garbage back.

LocationDetail: Riverside across from Housekeeping beach by Camp 6
IncidentDescription: Hotline call from resident Nick that he found 3 large bags of trash filled with food trash at beach north of HKC beach south of Camp 6. Nick reports throwing the three bags of trash away but Purple 20 obtained miscellaneous scraps including melted ice cream, onion scraps, etc. < 1000cal. Nick called into Hotline and I was able to arrive and haze Purple 20 off food and secure remainder of scraps

841 tracked Purple 20 to Yellow Pines and discovered a dog at the Climbing Stewards site leashed to a table with dog food and cooking oil next to it. A friend visiting the hosts flagged 841 down to report chasing a bear out of the site minutes before. She was uncertain who's dog it was. She assisted 841 in cleaning up the food after which P20 was tracked to the adjacent campsite (A) standing next to a tent. The bear treed immediately when hazed. A trash can was discovered knocked over adjacent to where the bear was treed. Trash was strewn on the ground including food items. Bear scat was on the ground next to the trash. Further inspection of the site revealed other food/attractants left out including cooking oil, cocoa powder, cinnamon, a coffee urn, cooler with ~30 sodas, and several more trash cans with food items. Additionally, all other food associated with the camp kitchen was stored in a wooden trailer that had 2 side windows approximately 6"x6" left open with food visible at the screen window. The whole camp kitchen smelled of bacon grease. No one was at the site. 841 called LE for assistance in securing the camp. The bear came out of the tree once LE arrived and 841 chased it further away with paintballs and communicated the food storage issues to V33. While discussing the campsite overall and concerns about the wooden "food storage trailer" with LE, some of the campsite occupants returned from climbing. We learned this was a YC group who had received a "bear talk" 3 times from: Sandy the camp host, Steven the YC liaison, and Wildlife Management staff the night before. Campers were confused as to why food was left out because the bear message had been reiterated so many times and understood it was unacceptable. They cleaned everything up. Campers informed NPS staff that they were in fact not actually responsible for the kitchen area, but that the "camp cook" (Renae and Mark) were hired for the event and in charge of the kitchen area and trailer. After approximately 1 hour at the site from initially chasing the bear, Renae arrived. 841 communicated what happened and expressed concern about continued use of the wooden trailer for food storage after stressing that the camp was left unsecured and the bear obtained food- the first time for this yearling at a campsite so it was just a matter of time before it would return, likely repeatedly, and that bears are designed to pull wood apart, that's how they forage, and that the trailer was not a reasonable or legal way to store food. Renae said that they had been using the trailer for food storage in the park for 20 years and hand never had an issue including last year at the same campsite and even in years where the bears were constantly in camp. V33 was unsure what the compendium stated as "legal" food storage. I mentioned I would follow up with my supervisor who had more experience and had been with the program the entirety of the claimed use of the trailer and therefore could verify whether it had ever been "allowed". During this conversation, P20 had approached camp again further down so 841 left to again chase the bear. During the time 841 was away from the campsite, V33 cleared the area and 841 talked to 840 who confirmed wooden trailers are pliable material and therefore not a legal way to store food. Since V33 cleared, 841 could not follow up directly on LE's stance, but did notice the bear locker trailer was parked in Yellow Pines and could easily be moved over to unload all the food from the wooden trailer. Upon 841's return to Campsite A, Mark (the man who owned the trailer) had returned and apologized for leaving camp unsecured since it had been his responsibility and he had simply forgot. 841 again explained everything to Mark explaining the plan to unload the food from the wooden trailer into the lockers. Mark was reluctant, again explaining that the trailer had worked for 20 years. 841 reiterated it was not compliant and that giving a bear unlimited access to a wooden trailer full of food (when they went to bed that night), the bear would absolutely gain access and be rewarded again for entering their campsite whereas the lockers would not allow the bear access to the food no matter how long he tried. I also added this bear is very hard to chase. Mark and Renae then mentioned they had an air horn to keep the bear away or offered to sleep in the trailer. 841 reiterated storing food in the lockers and "guarding" food is not a legal food storage method for obvious reasons (safety and food rewards for the bear if unable to scare). While talking to Mark, the Climbing Stewards returned to camp (Ethan, Gus, Maria?) and explained the dog leashed in their site was a friend visiting a different employee and were disappointed and upset about the food left out next to the dog. They promised to follow up with the friend. They also asked if I needed help. 841 gave them a quick tutorial on radio telemetry and asked them to locate the bear on the edge of camp if possible and keep him out. 841 ended the conversation with at Mark and Renae felt strongly that the trailer had been used for years without issue and therefore would continue to be OK. They were not disrespectful, just reluctant to change. In fact, Mark helped move the bear locker trailer over to their campsite kitchen area but felt if the wooden trailer would be "allowed/legal" that he didn't want to unload all of his food unnecessarily. 841 decided for the time being to leave everything secured in their trailer (doors and windows closed) and to follow up with LE shift supervisor for clarification on the food storage regulations and what would be enforced. The climbing stewards had located the bear high in a tree approximately 50 yards outside of camp toward Southside Drive, the direction the bear had been chased. 841 cleared from the area to try to follow up with LE and touch base with Wildlife Management night shift. 843 and 850 headed back out to Yellow Pines once briefed on the situation. In the 1 hour wildlife staff was absent from Yellow Pines, the bear returned at least 3 times. 841 got clarification from V20 that the wooden trailer does not constitute proper food storage. 841 communicated this to 843 who had already followed up in campsite A and helped them move the majority of their food to the locker trailer (with the exception of 2 large coolers that wouldn't fit). 843 stated the wood siding on the trailer was so old that light was visible filtering from the outside of the trailer in. 843 also believed the trailer to not be bear resistant. While 843 was out tracking the bear, LE also followed up with the site and had the contents of the coolers emptied of food into the food storage lockers. Between the time of the incident (around 11:00) and 20:00 hours, the bear returned no less than 10 times to the boundary of camp including approaching campsites with food out repeatedly in broad daylight. The bear was hazed repeatedly with yelling by campers, yelling and chasing by staff, paintballs, and noise makers. As of late last night, he had retreated to across Southside Drive by the Four Mile Trailhead. There is no question that the food reward obtained in camp changed the behavior of this bear who had previously only been seen on the outskirts of camp foraging naturally.

Bear tore a 6" hole in tent and pulled sleeping bag part way out, ripping it as well about 6", some down filling came out. Pulled down clothes line and ripped towel. No food or trash obtained. Occurred sometime between 08:30 and 15:00. Caitlin responded to a bear near the campground at noon and chased Purple 20 (3316) from Sent. Beach at that time. They noticed a Yellow Pines campsite had been disturbed during a drive through then, but did not notice the property damage. Bear 3316 also hit the monitoring box at 10:45 A.M. so all signs point to Purple 20.

Bear tore a 6" hole in tent and pulled sleeping bag part way out, ripping it as well about 6", some down filling came out. Pulled down clothes line and ripped towel. No food or trash obtained. Occurred sometime between 08:30 and 15:00. Caitlin responded to a bear near the campground at noon and chased Purple 20 (3316) from Sent. Beach at that time. They noticed a Yellow Pines campsite had been disturbed during a drive through then, but did not notice the property damage. Bear 3316 also hit the monitoring box at 10:45 A.M. so all signs point to Purple 20.

Bear entered campsite and pulled food out of an open bear locker. Obtained cup-o-noodles, cookies, Doritos. Multiple other campers corroborated the scenario. Visitors said they forgot. Green 23 was on telemetry. Pic and video support observation of a collared bear with right ear tag.

Purple 20 (3316) obtained 5-6 sandwich rolls and 4-5 bagels (1501-9999 calories). Visitors were eating within arms' reach of locker when bear snuck up around back of tent and entered open locker, which scared the visitors away. A large crowd gathered 20 feet away and watched bear eat but also tried scaring him. P20 finally got scared and went up a nearby tree, 100 feet up.

Bear ripped hole in tent fly and mosquito netting. At 0315 bear heard by RP's husband, who called out "bear". At that time the bear "fell" on tent partially collapsing it in and ripping hole. The bear made contact with RP's face (no injury). Bear then fled to near-by restroom where it was seen by a member of the RP's party. Only eyes were seen, no description. Based on position bear is likely a yearling. No food storage violation. Guy line and steak pulled out of ground.
People at the trailhead feeding a massive bear. They had a plate of food down and standing within 10 feet of the bear. Reported by Pink Jeep tour guide
Purple 20 (3316) obtained bag of tortillas. Trash strewn across ground near parking area by RC.

P20 was walking through Housekeeping and he poked his head into unit 155 where visitors were actively cooking ramen noodles. They freaked out and fled, P20 at multiple packs of ramen noodles. The group tried yelling and screaming but the bear was unfazed. The visitors described it as a frightening experience overall.

LocationDetail: river's edge, east side of Sentinel Bridge
IncidentDescription: Bear 3316 (Purple 20) walked towards them sitting in their inner tubes. Visitors got scared and got into water about 15 yards away, bear approached the tubes and played with them for a few minutes, he bit the tube and it popped, which scared him away. Tube may have had sunscreen residue, no food or drinks present

Occurred between 11am and 19:20 when resident was at work. Bear entered through small 2' x 2.5' kitchen window left open. Bear simply pushed through the screen to get inside house. Bear ate many items including fruit, granola bars, muffins, fresh berries, graham crackers, pancake mix. Did not eat grapefruits or oranges on counter. Only damage was screen window and food. Tim said he secures his other windows but forgot/did not think this would happen to him with the kitchen window.

Occurred between 11am and 19:20 when resident was at work. Bear entered through small 2' x 2.5' kitchen window left open. Bear simply pushed through the screen to get inside house. Bear ate many items including fruit, granola bars, muffins, fresh berries, graham crackers, pancake mix. Did not eat grapefruits or oranges on counter. Only damage was screen window and food. Tim said he secures his other windows but forgot/did not think this would happen to him with the kitchen window.

Bear 3822 (white 42) was approached by visitors who came within 20 feet away. Bear looked at them and charged about 15 feet, coming to within 10 feet of them when finished charging. Bear was minding its own business in Cook's when the visitors approached while filming the bear. Interp saw the video and informed Wildlife MGMT about incident. Confirmed bear had a collar. Kyle arrived at Cook's after talking with Interp, and White 42 was only bear in the area.

Purple 1 (bear 2212) GPS points indicated she was at this location at time of incident, but bear was not observed. Bear obtained dog food stored in a 40-gallon trash can with a lock on it. Resident did not think a bear could get into this food. Bear obtained 900 kcal of dog food. LE contacted but no action taken.

Showed up at property and saw Purple 1 (#2212) hanging around backyard of house where she recently got food reward. Chased and yelled after her but unable to get paintball rounds. Roxy returned to house and found bag of Wild Bird Seed on ground. Bear had dragged bird seed out and was eating it when staff first arrived on scene. LE contacted resident.

Purple 1 (2212) GPS points indicated she was at this residence at noon on this day. A bear entered back of house sliding glass door that was not fully latched closed, and got multiple food items (cereal, cat treats) on top of fridge. Ate 1/4 of a brownie off counter. Residence not occupied as out of town. LE responded, no citation. Resident gave us permission to enter and determine extent of damage.

A bear forced open laundry room some time between 23:30 9/1 and 12:15 9/2. Door and frame were damaged. Bear did not gain access to rest of house, and did not appear to have eaten anything. Attractants in laundry room were detergent and soap. Bear entered this same residence the day before via a sliding glass door.

Kym heard a noise at her door and found a bear paw stuck through cat door. She made noise and bear ran away. She said it was a black bear with white collar. Likely Purple 1 as she was nearby. Cat door locks automatically so the bear had to break it to get its paw through. Cat food next to door but bear did not obtain it.

BlameFactorDesc: Improper storage of a bear attractant
IncidentDescription: Cheyenne awoke to a bear clawing at compost barrel in their backyard. She yelled and bear ran off. Bear did not get large food reward. Potentially licked some garbage juice. Compost barrel was damaged. This barrel was at residence before current tenant moved in.

Resident heard downstairs door banging and found Purple 1 (#2212) in breezeway. Resident banged and bear walked away. Bear damaged fence upon leaving backyard. Bear damaged cat door when she ripped outer framing of the cat door. Bear did not enter residence or get food reward. Cat door will be secured by resident going forward.

Bear seen "Trying to breach into bear box, but when we woke up our dirty water bag had been bit" [by bear]. Bear seen but unknown radio tag, collar, and color. RP: Dan Lieber dlieber@batterymetals.com

Purple 1 (bear # 2212)was on porch, attempted entry through screens (damaged them in the process) leading to the kitchen. Kids were inside, yelled at bear, she ran. Bear was gone by the time we arrived. Bear wound up in brush northwest of Rancheria. On the porch were potted strawberries and tomatoes, along with other garden plants. Plants not disturbed but may have been initial attractant.

Bear got gear cache at Gravel Pit Lake and obtained mackerel from panniers at site. Damage to 2 float tubes, minor damage to panniers, and obtained approximately 40 cans of mackerel. Aquatic crew discovered damage after it occurred. No bears observed, reported through Rob Grasso.

Bear got gear cache at Gravel Pit Lake and obtained mackerel from panniers at site. Damage to 2 float tubes, minor damage to panniers, and obtained approximately 40 cans of mackerel. Aquatic crew discovered damage after it occurred. No bears observed, reported through Rob Grasso.

Bear was observed eating a bag of groceries: chips, protein drinks. Was chased off but returned twice. Was squaring up and had to be aggressively ran off by running at the bear while racking a less-lethal shotgun. No bean bags were launched.

Animal (likely bear) bent open an overflowing trash can lid and scattered a bit of trash. Trash can lid bent out of operable condition but manager at Curry thinks her maintenance staff can fix it easily.
